PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 9 a.m., and read prayers.
Motion (by Mr Young) agreed to:
That the House, at its rising, adjourn until Tuesday, 20 May 1986, unless Madam Speaker fixes an alternative day or hour of meeting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Government Business take precedence over General Business for this sitting.

I think that all honourable members are aware that we have a busy day ahead of us. The fringe benefits tax legislation is already listed on the Notice Paper. I said that we would give sufficient time for the House to debate that legislation. Circumstances now demand that we deal with other legislation today. I am sure that the Opposition understands that both of those matters should take precedence over the General Business item. I apologise to the honourable member whose General Business item was listed for debate today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is becoming more and more apparent that this Government is falling apart. It is incredible that on a day when there are matters of major significance to the people of Australia to be considered in this place we have been told that the Government has put a ban on judges from New South Wales. We have been told that the Ministry had to come here early this morning so that it could try to determine resolutions relating to a Bill that is to be introduced without notice into this House later this day. We know that the Government's tax package legislation that is to come before the House today is a dog's breakfast, if ever we have seen one. A decent dog really would not eat it at all. Frankly, on that basis the proposal to give precedence to Government Business is just not acceptable to members of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: As all honourable members will know, the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) has a very significant private member's matter for consideration on the agenda today. It relates to the concern that we on this side of the House have about the adequacy of research and development in Australia and, in particular, about the area of research and development that is undertaken by the Commonwealth Scientific Industrial and Research Organisation. There needs to be an understanding that CSIRO is being hamstrung by Labor. The Government seems to have given up the idea that this prestigious research organisation of international renown which has been able to create so much in the areas of original research over the years is being prejudiced because of Labor's parsimonious attitude towards its survival. A large number of individuals within CSIRO-the research scientists-are despairing of their future. They know that their research projects are prejudiced because the Government cannot get its act together while it is funding some of the regional employment development projects and the idiotic schemes that our Waste Watch Committee has revealed. The Government is denying CSIRO adequate funding. That was the subject of the private member's business which would have been considered in the normal course in the House today.

The Opposition believes that a range of important matters needs to be considered. Pages upon pages of notices are listed under General Business, all of which, we know, are little likely to be raised because of the Government's approach. Indeed, at this stage, there are 108 General Business notices. If the Government is going to go about its business of denying the debating opportunity that occurs but once in a sitting fortnight, there will be little chance of our achieving a resolution of those notices unless the Parliament were to sit well beyond its present allocated time. What an incredible situation it is when in a normal three-year bracket there is no chance of all those general business items that members have sought to have listed being considered. In that climate there is no doubt that our consenting to the Government's approach, which is to deny us a chance to debate matters of importance, just would not be acceptable, and on that basis we reject the motion by the Leader of the House (Mr Young) and suggest that he look again at the matter and try to get his act in order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Madam Speaker, it was not my intention to take up the time of the House but some of the matters raised by the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Sinclair) do require answering. First of all, the reason I did not wish to take up the time of the House by presenting my arguments for doing what we are doing at the moment is that I would have thought it would be more important to get on to the debate on the matters that are listed for today, which include matters to which the Opposition says it has great opposition. I would have thought members of the Opposition would have wished to use the time to express their views. Certainly many members on this side of the House want to speak in support of those measures because they see us restructuring the tax system to do away with all the rorts that were consolidated in our tax system by virtue of 30 years of conservative government, when the Liberal and National parties watched develop all the rorts and perks of the tax system which allowed those perhaps in the upper bracket of income earners to manipulate the tax system while greater and greater burdens were placed on the shoulders of wage and salary earners. It was not the intention of the Hawke Labor Government, elected in 1983, to see this process continued. We will be going to the next election with the fairest tax system that this country has seen for decades, because there will be substantial tax cuts this year, in September, and in July of next year. So by virtue of the Opposition's behaviour, when we face the election at the end of 1987 it will have been telling the Australian people that it will reinstitute all the lurks-the free lunches, the free cars and everything else that goes to make up all the things that were rotten about the tax system-and do away with the $4 1/2 billion tax cuts that will come into operation from 1 September this year.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought it was more important to spend time debating those matters rather than have the Manager of Opposition Business lecture this Government about the way the House ought to be conducted. Let me say this: This session of the Parliament has been perhaps the most constructive session of Parliament in terms of opportunities for members of this House to speak that we have witnessed for many years. The previous Prime Minister, the right honourable Malcolm Fraser, when he was on this side of the House standing at this dispatch box, took the view that there were no such things as the conventions of the Parliament. There were no notice boards about whether Bills were being introduced, and no notices about whether he wanted to make statements to the House. Not only did he treat the present Opposition's side with complete contempt; he also treated the Opposition at that time with contempt. In fact, it got to the stage where he was treating everybody in Australia with contempt, and they gave him an answer to that in March of 1983.

I would have thought that, seeing that the Opposition has been harping all week about having an inquiry into certain matters, it would have facilitated the introduction of the legislation of which we have given notice today. It is not all that unique-it has happened before in Australia-to have legislation introduced and debated in the one sitting and passed off to the Senate because it is necessary to do so. I would have thought that Opposition members would have welcomed the move by the Government, rather than sitting around in their rooms last night, as the newspapers tell us, gurgling in their champagne. What are they celebrating? What was the big celebration that led the Opposition to spend so much money on champagne last night? What was the big celebration? It makes one wonder. The Australian people are entitled to ask: `Why all the champagne in the Opposition rooms?' Perhaps the Opposition had already set up its jury and reached a verdict in relation to the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Speaker: I know that you are working very hard to lift the standards of this chamber and I suggest that the sorts of comments that the Special Minister of State is making should be ruled out of order.
—There is no point of order, but I accept that the standard of behaviour in this place should be lifted. Could I have less noise from the Opposition benches and fewer interjections.

—I associate champagne with celebration. It is a long time since I had any, but when I did it was always on an occasion of celebration. I just want to know what the Opposition was celebrating last night. Is this the sort of conduct one would expect from people who are asking the Australian people to put them into government at the next election? There was some big celebration last night and I suspect that during the debates that take place later in the day we will hear why the Leader of the National Party brought everyone to his office to celebrate whatever occurred yesterday. It is not like him to unlock his wallet all that often. I understand that my friend, the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) was not invited-he has not been invited to the Leader's office for about 12 months, not since he got the dump. He does not mind a glass of champagne occasionally but he has a sense of decency about when he has it and for what reason he partakes in such celebrations.
—He had a birthday yesterday. You ought to congratulate him; he turned 21.

—He turned 21? I congratulate him, but that will come as a surprise to a lot of people in Toowoomba. Today is an important day in terms of the legislation that will come before the House and, I remind the Opposition, be completed before the day's sitting is finished. As I had made arrangements with the Opposition about the amount of time to be given to the fringe benefits legislation, it may be necessary later in the day to look at the time available again. It depends on the amount of time that is given to debating the special legislation that will be introduced. I will speak to the Manager of Opposition Business in order to ensure that there is adequate time to debate both matters when they come before the House. It is not the Government's intention to curtail debate on these matters which are important, not only to people in this chamber but also to people outside who want to have a proper understanding of the ramifications of both pieces of legislation. We intend to see that adequate time is given today.
—With your indulgence, Madam Speaker--
—The Leader of the House has closed the debate. Did you wish to speak to it?
—Yes.
—Well, I am afraid you cannot. The Leader of the House has closed the debate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Dr Harry Edwards

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wish to explain that I am anxious to support the remarks of the Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair).

INTERJECT.PARA: That the motion (Mr Young's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986[COGNATE BILLS:FRINGE BENEFITS TAX BILL 1986FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1986FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 May, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986 concurrently with the Fringe Benefits Tax Bill 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax (Application to the Commonwealth) Bill 1986, and the Fringe Benefits Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1986. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today at last, after waiting for about eight months, we are debating the fringe benefits tax. This package contains four Bills, 151 pages of legislation and 176 pages of explanatory memorandum. We also have a 56-page booklet, appropriately in the mourning colour of purple, that is to be issued to employers called `Fringe Benefits Tax-a guide for employers'. Make no mistake; this is a new business tax, pure and simple. It is a new tax on business. It is a payroll tax, but unlike State payroll taxes, which are a straightforward levy on payroll-and that is bad enough-this new business tax is levied on the payroll of the employer in a wide variety of excruciating and complicated ways. It is levied on motor cars, low interest loans, waiver of debts, payment of private expenses, residential accommodation, living away from home allowances, free or subsidised board, staff air fares, entertainment for tax exempt bodies and free or discounted goods and free or discounted services. So if one loves one's payroll tax, what a feast one will have on the fringe benefits tax. If one enjoys the paperwork on payroll tax, what fun one will have filling in one's fringe benefits tax return. Let me quote from the 56-page purple booklet that is going to be sent out to 700,000 or 800,000 businesses around Australia over the next two or three weeks. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: FBT payers will self-assess their liability to FBT annually. That means calculating the taxable value of each fringe benefit provided in a particular year in accordance with the valuation rules explained in following chapters, and applying the appropriate rate of tax to the total. An annual FBT return is to be lodged showing the different categories of fringe benefits provided, their taxable values, and the amount of tax payable. Return forms will be made available.

How generous! The tax will be paid every quarter and this, of course, will involve further paperwork. The tax applies to all employees in all locations. It applies to all of their different benefits-there are 11 major categories of benefits and dozens of sub-categories-all their different rates, all their formulae, all their calculations and all their options. Does the Treasurer (Mr Keating) have the slightest idea what effect this new business tax, this new monster, will have on business? It is a big tax; It will raise $625m in a full year according to the Treasurer's estimates and, if the motor industry is correct, it will raise $200m above that. So it is a $600m or $800m tax on business-a new business tax. It is a disastrous measure. It is disastrous for business, for investment, for employment, and it will be disastrous for this Government.

Every small business, every farm, every factory, every mine, every shop and office, every work-place across the length and breadth of Australia, will be hit by this plague of paperwork, of complexity, of frustration and of additional cost. This purple booklet will go out to all employers registered with the Australian Taxation Office. It will go out to every small business, every large business, every farm and every mine. Also, all currently exempt employers, religious, charitable and non-profit bodies will in future have to register and pay the tax. The following comment is made at page 8 of the purple booklet:
Organisations exempt from income tax and other employers who do not have an income tax number should notify their nearest Tax Office so that a file number can be allocated.

Big brother is waiting to hear from you. So all those priests, nuns, brothers, pastors and reverend gentlemen, all those people who run charitable organisations to look after the sick, the poor and the homeless, will now have to go to the Taxation Office and get a file number so that they can pay this tax. I will return to the problems of religious, charitable and non-profit bodies in due course. I hope they will receive better treatment than this Parliament. This enormous package of 151 pages of legislation, 176 pages of explanatory memorandum and 56 pages of guide to employers was dumped contemptuously on this table last Friday afternoon at 4 o'clock by the arrogant Treasurer. He could hardly conceal his contempt for the Parliament and the people of Australia as he put it on the table as honourable members were rushing to catch their planes back to their electorates for the weekend. We had the weekend to look at the legislation, all 300 or 400 pages of it. The shadow Cabinet had to consider it on Monday. We had to take it to the party room on Tuesday, and we have to debate it now-Thursday-under a guillotine imposed by the Government.

It has been nearly eight months since this measure was announced in the House in the package on 19 September. Why have we had to wait so long for the legislation? Why do we have so little time to examine it? What has the Treasurer got to hide? The Treasurer treats this Parliament and the people of Australia with arrogance and contempt. He will not even brief the Opposition on the clauses in the legislation. He has denied us the briefings from officers of the Taxation Office which, when we were in office we gave to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is he?

—He is not in the Parliament to debate the matter today. He did not come into the Parliament last night to sum up the negative gearing Bill. He treats the Parliament with total contempt and the electorate in turn will treat him with the contempt he deserves. It seems that Government Ministers and members are starting to realise what his game is. In this morning's Daily Telegraph, in a story headed `MPs on edge as economy fails to pick up', Peter Logue reports:

SPEECH.PARA: Senior ministers and Labor backbenchers are worried about the direction of the economy, particularly after ALP surveys and an opinion poll result released yesterday.
Those concerns were raised at a late night Cabinet meeting on Tuesday during a general discussion on the economy, informed sources said.
Leading the criticism of the Treasurer, Mr Keating, was Foreign Affairs Minister and former Whitlam Treasurer, Mr Hayden.
The major concern articulated by the ministers was the failure of the promised J-curve effect to materialise in balance of payments figures and the consequential continuing high interest rates.
One prominent backbencher said: ``The trouble with Paul Keating is that he is just too good at selling bad arguments and no one has been able to roll him because he's had the polls on side.''
It appears now that the effect of the Government's April 2 decision to scrap the housing interest rate ceiling for new borrowers has hit the electorate.
There is concern that new polls over the next month will be much worse.

Indeed, this week the polls did show that the Opposition is leading the Government. If an election were held now this Government would rightly be thrown out of office. It would be thrown out of office because of the effects of its economic policies, its high interest rates, its high spending, its high taxes, its subservience to the trade union leadership, the ministerial scandals of the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins), the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), criticisms by the left wing Ministers, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West), of their own Cabinet decisions, and the chaos and confusion over the affair surrounding Mr Justice Murphy.

Taxation is the issue which has yet to bite with great depth on this Government. Taxation is a major issue. The present polls will be a picnic compared with what will happen when people get their fringe benefits tax booklets and when they find that the miserable tax cuts they have been promised are threatened. We have been threatened by this Government that people will not get their income tax cuts if we deny passage to this horrendous measure. I make it quite clear on behalf of the Liberal and National parties that we will not be bullied on this matter. If this legislation is bad, and it is bad, we will oppose it; we will throw it out. The Government is like the drug addict who wants the bystander to help him rob the chemist shop. We are not prepared to help this Government rob anyone to help it meet the costs of its addiction to high spending of taxpayers' money. We will not be bullied. We will treat legislation on its merits. This package of Bills has no merit.

What is the history of this measure? The Government promised the reform of the taxation system. It promised relief for low and middle income earners. During the election campaign in 1983 the Government gave a firm promise that there would be no capital gains tax-a promise which has been repudiated. During the election campaign in 1984 the Government equivocated over its taxation policies. Under pressure, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised during an interview on a Perth radio station that there would be a taxation summit, hoping to repeat the public relations success of the National Economic Summit Conference. Look where that has led us! There was a big campaign by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer to sell the idea of tax reform. They said: `Let us shift tax away from direct to indirect. Let us make major reductions in the personal income tax rates for low and middle income earners. Support us at the Summit and you will pay less income tax'.

All this enthusiasm eventually died in this chamber at the National Taxation Summit after the Prime Minister had gone off to a motel room on the other side of Canberra to receive his instructions from the leaders of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. He had to sneak off from the Tax Summit to receive his instructions. He came back here and pulled the rug from underneath his own Treasurer, which meant the collapse of the so-called Option C and goodbye to the chances of lower taxes for low and middle income earners. Those hopes died here in this chamber because the Prime Minister capitulated to the trade union movement. We are left with the 19 September package. We are left with the rubbish put up by the unions and the Australian Taxation Office. All the old things they were trying to get through when we were in office were dragged up and put into this mess of a package today-all the anti-business, anti-entrepreneurial measures so beloved of the left wing and the trade union leadership. These Bills are a prime example of that. What were the stated objectives of the Government? The Prime Minister said at the National Taxation Summit:

A genuine reform of the Australian tax system to promote growth and to ensure that the benefits of that growth are fairly shared and bring lasting relief on personal income taxes to the millions of ordinary Australian taxpayers.

Those were the objectives stated by the Prime Minister. We would agree with those objectives. The promise of relief to ordinary taxpayers was sold off to the ACTU in the motel room. When the so-called reforms are in place over the next year we will finish up with 50 per cent of Australian taxpayers paying a top marginal rate of 40c or more in the dollar. Every year another 4 per cent will be added to that total.

TALK.START.PARA: —Robbery.

—As the honourable member for Fisher said, that is robbery. The people have been cheated. They will realise that they have been cheated. What other objectives were stated by the Government? The Prime Minister also said:

SPEECH.PARA: At this Summit I reaffirm our commitment to the totality of the people's mandate-
whatever that is-
That, of course, means reaffirming our commitment to the nine principles on which we undertook to base both the process and the program of tax reform.
Let me quote just three of those principles here today. The fourth one states:
. . . any reform must lead to a simpler system, which therefore all Australians can understand more easily.

Is this a simple measure? This measure alone breaches that principle with its 150-page Bill, its 176-page explanatory memorandum and its 56-page guide to employers explaining how they will have to fill in the paperwork for this new business tax and fork out the $600m to be paid. This is only one of the 22 items listed in the Treasurer's statement of 19 September last year.

The overall picture before the so-called tax reform to simplify the system was that the Income Tax Assessment Act had about 1,100 pages. Added to that, since we have had Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2), 56 pages; Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), 53 pages; Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4)-the no- torious entertainment tax Bill-55 pages; the negative gearing legislation, which we had yesterday, 47 pages; the fringe benefits tax legislation, 139 pages-a total of 350 additional pages. So, on top of the 1,100 there has been another 350-an increase of 32 per cent. There have now been 1,450 pages of taxation legislation under this Government's simplifications.

To give honourable members some idea of the rubbish we have here, I refer to the definition clause at page 107 of the Bill. The Prime Minister will enjoy this quotation because it explains to the Australian public, for the first time, what is meant by the Prime Minister's favourite phrase `in respect of'. The phrase `in respect of' means, we are told:
in relation to the employment of an employee, includes by reason of, by virtue of, or for or in relation directly or indirectly to, that employment.

I am sure members of the House will be enlightened by that. I will not go into the description, which runs for about seven or eight lines, of what an `in-house property fringe benefit' means, but employers who provide in-house property fringe benefits will need to read those seven or eight lines and if, after they have read them, they are any the wiser I shall be surprised. That is the simplicity, that is the objective that the Government had. The eighth principle was:
. . . any reform must provide the best possible climate for investment growth and employment in Australia.

What effect will one have on investment by loading an extra $625m of extra payroll tax on to the economy? I asked the Treasurer the other day in this House how much of the $625m would come from government bodies and therefore would be paid for directly through taxes or additional government charges, and he was unable to answer. I checked last night whether the Treasurer's office had an answer to this question-no. We checked again this morning, and apparently he had to go off to some extraordinary Cabinet or Party meeting for some other purpose-still no answer. The Treasurer does not know how much of this new business tax will be levied on government versus business. How could he have calculated its effects on business? Can he understand its effects on business if he has not even done the simple sum of the split between its effect on business and on government? The ninth principle of the Government was:
. . . any reform package must have widespread community support.

That is a laugh. Most of the Labor Premiers say that they will not pay this tax. Unions in affected industries, for example, the car industry, will not support it. Employers large and small oppose it. Employees, who are squeezed because of the effects of this tax on their after-tax income, are not supporting it. Indeed, on Tuesday night I was at a motor industry dinner held in Canberra that was addressed by the Premier of South Australia, Mr John Bannon. He said:

I had hoped to be able to address you tonight in the knowledge that the Federal Government had accepted the arguments put forward by the automotive industry, unions and various governments to change the proposed fringe benefits tax plans in relation to company cars. Unfortunately, however, I am addressing you in the knowledge that a decision has been taken which will prove detrimental to the car industry and one which will have severe ramifications for my State in particular.
This was said by the Labor Premier of South Australia, Mr John Bannon. He continued:

I am particularly disappointed that the Federal Government was unable to show the flexibility to change its plans as this was an issue which was not being opposed on purely sectional grounds. Governments, unions and the industry itself had all come to the same conclusion, namely that the fringe benefits tax in its proposed form would have a detrimental effect on the car industry in Australia. The Federal Government had been presented with rational arguments and demonstrable evidence that this was so. What made the Government's decision all the more disappointing was the fact that at no stage were we opposing the principle of tax reform but rather the method by which its was introduced. Indeed, at the Tax Summit in 1984 I acknowledged the desirability of the tax reform being mooted by the Federal Government, but on the strong proviso that such reform should not have an adverse effect on employment in the car industry.

So, the Premier of South Australia agrees with the Opposition in this Parliament that the Government has breached its own principles on tax reform. There is no community support for this. There is no serious attempt by the Treasurer to deal with the matter. Premier Bannon got the same cold shoulder that we get from the Treasurer. I am told by people in the Caucus that the Treasurer treats the Caucus with contempt, too. He will have to stop treating the Caucus, the Parliament and the people of Australia with contempt; otherwise, he will be leading the charge out of office of this Government.

This new business tax to raise $600m to $800m of revenue is complicated and damaging. Let us look at some of its effects. My colleagues, over the course of today, will be examining the various clauses of the Bill in more detail. They will indicate how it will be damaging within their electorates, to the constituencies that they represent. I hope that Labor members on the other side of the House, particularly those in marginal seats, will listen very carefully to what is said today, because they will realise that Treasurer Keating, the Treasurer of their Government, is digging their political grave with his taxation legislation.

Let me look at some of the matters that are raised by the measure. Firstly, there is the question of the rate. Again, there has been cheating in regard to the rate to be levied initially. The 49 per cent tax rate that is otherwise applicable to companies from 1 July 1987 has been brought forward by three months for fringe benefits tax purposes and will apply for the period from 1 April to 30 June 1987, whereas it was originally announced that the fringe benefits tax would be levied at the existing corporate rate of 46 per cent. In other words, business will have its tax rate put up by three percentage points three months early. That goes against the original statement.

Secondly, there is the question of the implementation, which, quite frankly, will be a shambles. It will be extremely difficult for employers fully to absorb the contents of this legislation in order to discharge their obligations and liabilities under the fringe benefits tax by the time the first instalment is payable on 28 October this year. Heaven knows, with the advice we have been able to get, we have had extraordinary difficulty in reading this stuff and trying to understand it. How on earth will all of the employers of Australia and their tax advisers-some of them cannot afford to employ tax advisers, if they run farms these days, in particular-be ready to pay this tax by 28 October? The 28-day period after the fringe benefits tax year ends on 31 March, in which the fringe benefits tax returns must be lodged, is unreasonable because three instalments are paid during the year. The legislation is complicated. Undue resources will be required by employers to calculate the fringe benefits tax liability and prepare the fringe benefits tax return in the 28-day timeframe. It is more likely, because of the complexity, that fringe benefits tax returns will be prepared by tax agents. It is totally unreasonable to expect tax agents to prepare and lodge all of their clients' fringe benefits returns in a 28 day period.

Let me return to the question of religious and exempt bodies. The original blanket exemption for religious institutions has been substantially narrowed and will now apply only to the provision of benefits to a minister of religion, a full time member of a religious order, or a student at a college conducted solely to train persons to become members of religious orders. We have been barraged by letters from religious and charitable bodies, fearful that the Treasurer would go back on his promise in his statement of 19 September last year to exempt those bodies from the tax. It became clear that he had no intention of exempting them. The lines are drawn so carefully that hardly anybody in these areas is exempt. So, when one raises money through fund raising campaigns for charitable bodies, collecting money from people to do good work in the community through religious, voluntary, non-profit bodies, one should set aside a percentage for Keating's business tax. The fringe benefits tax will hit religious, charitable and non-profit bodies. What a disgrace! Every time the Red Cross knocks on one's door a few cents is set aside for Keating's--

TALK.START.PARA: —You knock them back.
—The Minister supports the tax.
—The emotional rubbish you go on with is unbelievable.
—The Minister supports the tax. The honourable member supports the tax and he will suffer for supporting the tax.
—Emotional junk.

—Government members opposite use the term `emotional junk' to describe my support for the religious, charitable and non-profit bodies which believe that they should be exempt from this tax. It ought to be known that the honourable member for Burke has committed himself to introducing this tax. The honourable member will know that every time there is a Red Cross doorknock in his electorate a few cents will be set aside for the Keating tax. What will happen to farmers and miners? How are they to work out exactly how the tax applies to accommodation on farms, farm properties, meals for farm workers or the occasional use of farm vehicles? This tax will be an administrative nightmare. When the purple book arrives at every farm house, what will farmers do with it? They will be in big trouble. They will have to go to tax agents, whom they may never have employed previously. The total cost to the mining and farming communities, when it is added up, is hundreds of millions of dollars. It will not just include the cost of the tax; it will also include the additional cost of employing assistants. There will also be frustration and diversion from the farmers' and miners' ordinary work.

SPEECH.PARA: What about the car industry? On the basis of calculations by the car industry, on the basis of research done be the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research, which is a totally independent body, of research done by the Bannon Government's Department of State Development in South Australia, on research done by the Vehicle Builders Employees' Federation of Australia, on research done by the Federal Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce-and we are reliably told that is supported by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button-10,000 jobs in the car industry are threatened as a result of the fringe benefits tax. On the basis of these research findings the Opposition has calculated that there will be a loss of revenues and taxes to the State and Federal Governments of $301m. The Government says that it will collect $350m from this tax. We believe that by the time the loss of sales tax, fuel tax and duty, the loss of income tax from workers who lose their jobs, the loss of company tax, the cost of unemployment benefits, the loss of State payroll tax, stamp duty and registration fees are added up it will amount to $300m. Yet the Government expects to get only $350m out of the fringe benefits tax from the motor industry in the first place. So a net $50m gain is going to cost 10,000 jobs in the motor industry. The Labor Premier of South Australia, Mr John Bannon, agrees with me. If honourable members opposite who are interjecting wish to say that Mr Bannon comes out with emotional junk, let them say so. We have the support of the South Australian Labor Government in our claim. It is going to hurt.

What about the banks? The Treasurer said in his second reading speech that every opportunity for consultation with groups had been provided. That is untrue. The Australian Bankers Association requested meetings with the Treasurer and officers on numerous occasions but was denied the opportunity to discuss this tax. The effect on the banks will be very serious. Something of great concern to banks-there are many concerns but I will mention one specific concern-is the exclusion from the valuations of housing benefits of the restrictive nature of some housing benefits. For example, where a bank employee lives above bank premises in a country town and must act as the caretaker of the bank, such restrictions are specifically excluded from the fringe benefits valuation. In other words, no allowance is made for the fact that that employee has to be the caretaker. The bank has to pay the full fringe benefits tax. In many respects the tax on the banks is retrospective in effect because their arrangements with employees have been in existence for a long time.

There are numerous other anomalies and difficulties with this appalling new business tax. They will be taken up successively over the course of the day by members of the Opposition parties, the Liberal and National parties and they will be taken to the electorate. They will be explained as well as we can explain them, given the complexity of the matter; and, of course, all employers will receive their purple booklet telling them in 56 pages, if they can understand in, exactly how complicated it will be for them to fill in their taxation returns and meet this onerous burden. We in the Opposition have a very clear view that rorts should not be allowed in this area; that, if rorts are there, they should be cleaned up; that the principle of the taxation must be maintained; that benefits are taxable in the hands of the person getting the benefit; and that if they are not fair they should be cleaned up. We are totally opposed to this new business tax, this new payroll tax, which will destroy investment and destroy employment. We will vote against it here and we will vote against it in the Senate. We will not be bullied by this Government. We will maintain our determination to oppose it both here and all round the countryside. It is a bad tax.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition's hypocrisy on tax reform or, indeed, on any change to our tax regime knows no bounds. I was reminded during the comments of the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), that in 1980, for example, the then Liberal Government, during the course of the 1980 election campaign, embarked on a scurrilous scare campaign to the extent of seeking to frighten people into a view that their houses were going to be taxed. We all remember the scurrilous housing tax campaign of 1980, and I wonder whether the shadow Treasurer would be prepared to disassociate himself from that sort of campaign. We have heard here, from the doom merchants, predictions that 10,000 jobs will be lost in the motor industry. Let me just remind the people of Australia about some of the other predictions of this discredited Opposition. It, of course, predicted that there would be tens of thousands of jobs lost in the restaurant industry. Honourable members on the other side of the House were baying for blood on that particular issue. What has happened? Now that people have had time to reflect, they ought to go back and have a very close look indeed at what the Opposition was putting in this House. The reality, as every Australian now knows, is that that tax has been implemented and there has been no substantive job loss in the restaurant industry. Indeed, the restaurateurs with whom I have discussed the issue have indicated that in many instances, depending on which segment of the market they are in, things have actually improved. In my electorate, for example, there is a hotel, the Ascot Vale Hotel, which puts on a very good business lunch but which also puts on a type of lunch that is more family oriented. The owner of that establishment has indicated that, whilst there was an initial contraction of business for the business lunch component, it was more than compensated for by the fact that families now coming into the restaurant on weekends were able to afford a lower cost meal, the end result being that his business is booming. We can go on and on.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many scare campaigns. I can also recall the campaigns around the assets test. The Opposition had most pensioners in fear in the lead-up to the last election and it was used as a political ploy. They were all concerned that they were going to lose their pensions. The reality, as all pensioners now know, is that the assets test has had a particularly marginal impact. The numbers of people affected by it are very small. It means, in terms of tax reform in this country, that we might have to insist that millionaires in our society, on the grounds of equity, not receive the pension. I think fundamentally that is the sort of issue that governments ought to confront in times of limited resources, and this Government has done that. The Opposition's approach to tax reform has never been one to embrace a cohesive and sensible approach, not only in terms of redistribution but in terms of broader macro-economic policy objectives. While in office it simply presided over a tax regime that became increasingly subject to institutionalised tax avoidance and evasion. One need only look at the recommendations of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. Mr Costigan should be congratulated by all in this chamber on being responsible in a large part for the genesis of the tax reform package that we are talking about here today. His pioneering work in this area, whilst embarrassing to the then Fraser Government, in many respects laid the groundwork for the type of package now before the House.

Of course, one expects the Opposition to come into this chamber, to isolate particular components of any tax reform package and to seek to gain political points by misrepresenting or distorting them. But there is one fundamental on which this House and the people of Australia ought to focus. There is really no choice. If one embraces the view that average pay as you earn taxpayers in this country ought not to continue, as they did under the Fraser Government, to pay an increasingly large part of the tax revenue, to shoulder an increasingly inequitable burden in terms of their contribution to tax revenues, reform is inevitable. There will always be debates about the precise tax regime that one attempts in terms of this sort of reform. But that fundamental reality remains. The choice is a stark one indeed. Either the Opposition accepts that the PAYE taxpayers of this country ought to continue to shoulder an ever increasing burden of tax revenue or it must put before this House alternatives in terms of tax reform that will ensure that the PAYE taxpayers do not have to bear that burden. To date it has done nothing. The suggestions that it made in the lead-up to the last election, and those that have been floated since, would all have a massive impact on the revenue of the Commonwealth.

The day before yesterday in this House the Treasurer (Mr Keating) articulated in some detail the cost of the various measures that have been put by the Opposition to date. What the Opposition has to address in this debate, rather than isolating particular components of the fringe benefits package, is where the money will come from for those policies to which it has committed itself. I might add that the cost of the Opposition's measures is in the vicinity of $6 billion.

For goodness sake, tax reform is difficult. That is why in the post-war period and substantially in the pre-war period no governments were prepared to embrace any degree of reform; they were worried about the electoral consequences. It is worth reflecting on some of the material that was handed around in the document entitled `Reform of the Australian Taxation System' that was issued by the Treasurer in 1985. The fundamentals have not changed. The basic objective of reducing high marginal tax rates was the centrepiece of the tax reform package. The amounts and timing of additional revenue from the income tax base and its broadening measures were, of course, addressed at the National Taxation Summit. But fundamentally the Government was concerned with the distributional impact of any additional tax reform package.

I go back to that distributional factor. If the Opposition is prepared in this House to argue that PAYE income earners should continue to shoulder the burden that they increasingly did under the Fraser Government, let it do so. If the Opposition does not believe that to be an appropriate point to argue, what it should be doing, rather than simply whingeing and knocking proposals, is to put what it considers an appropriate alternative tax reform package. The days of fiddling around at the edges of tax reform have finished. We have embarked on a fundamental reform of the tax system. It behoves members of the Opposition to do the same lest they be categorised accurately in the community as simply whingers and knockers.

It is worth reflecting on this reality. The number of taxpayers subject to the current 46 per cent or higher marginal rates was estimated to increase by around 20 per cent to about two and a half million taxpayers in 1985-86. In the absence of any change to the tax regime, that would result in some three million or over half the full time work force in the year 1986-87 going into the highest marginal tax brackets. The proportion of taxpayers in the highest marginal tax brackets under the pre-tax reform package regime was exploding. They are the people who, in the absence of any meaningful reform, are looking to members of the Opposition for what they would suggest. It is worth reflecting that the past practice in Australia of allowing high marginal tax rates to fall on ever increasing numbers of taxpayers-that is the creeping into higher tax brackets-has not been matched by a commensurate increase in tax revenues and the actual progressivity of the income tax system was a farce. It had the appearance of progressivity. Fundamentally it was not and was increasingly becoming quite the opposite.

It is worth reflecting that in 1984-85 people earning more than 1.6 times the average weekly earnings accounted for approximately 21 per cent of the total net tax assessed. In 1954-55, by way of comparison, that figure was 54 per cent. So what members of the Opposition are arguing, in the absence of any meaningful tax reform suggestions being put by them, is: What are those who were rich enough in 1954 to legitimately shoulder the highest marginal tax bracket going to do for those people who are earning relatively low levels of income in our community and who are being thrust by the existing regime into those highest marginal tax brackets?

I think I have gone on for long enough on the background to the fringe benefits tax proposals. There is one area I would like to focus on very briefly; that is the concessions allowed to employees of the airline industry. I will not go into too much detail because I know time is short, but it is worth just making these few points. I have had many representations on this matter. There is now agreement between the Government, the unions and the industry that results in the following: Firstly, who pays the tax? The companies will pay the tax as proposed, not the employee. Secondly, how is the tax calculated? The fringe benefits tax applies to the arm's length price of an airline ticket. The Government concession accepts that staff travel is not equivalent to commercial travel. So the reality is that nothing in the fringe benefits tax regime will have any impact on employees of the airline industry. What happens is that essentially the status quo has been maintained. I notice my colleague, the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar smiling and looking to the roof. The reality is that if he does not understand the agreement, he is welcome to come around to my office and I will explain it to him at the first opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are certainly better than the Treasurer; he will not respond to anything.

—I will conclude on this point, and I will not respond to the interjections by the shadow Treasurer. His interjections are often as confused as his substantive contributions to this House. The honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) will be addressing some of these issues later during today's debate. This honourable member is particularly well informed in this area. Members of the Opposition have never put before this House either whilst in opposition or when they were in government anything that would even approach the concept of meaningful tax reform. Increasingly under their Government-this is indisputable-
—Oh!

—If my colleague disputes this, I think he is in a very bad way indeed. He ought to get back under the dashboards of cars because there is no doubt-it is unarguable-that under his Government PAYE taxpayers shouldered increasingly large and increasingly higher burdens of providing tax revenue. These reforms will address that one fundamental problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths) for the invitation extended to the Opposition to call around to his office and hear his explanation of the legislation. I assume that invitation extends to me and, if so, I will have black tea and no sugar. I warrant that we will be there for a considerable period. The honourable member for Maribyrnong seems to be really serious about advancing the explanation that an impact on a company, an impact on employers, will not also impact on employees, the people who work for that company. That is a very interesting explanation indeed. In his short time in this House the honourable member seems to have made a speciality in monitoring matters aviation. I would tell him that he need only go to any airport and any tarmac in the country and talk to the employees who work at these establishments to understand and learn first hand their very serious concern and reservations about this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: It also gives me great pleasure to follow the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), and to repeat, because they bear repeating, some of the opening remarks that he made about the way this Government has treated this legislation, about the way this Government has treated Parliament and, through the Parliament, about the way this Government is treating the people of Australia. This legislation comes eight months after the original announcement last September by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). As the shadow Treasurer said, taken together, these seven Bills which constitute the package amount to 151 pages of legislation. I have one Bill here, the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill, which alone runs to some 139 pages with something like 167 clauses. If the 151 pages of legislation is not enough to give one an understanding of the legislation, one needs only turn to the 176 pages of explanatory memorandum. If that is not enough, if one still cannot understand the legislation, the Government has helpfully produced and published, and no doubt will be circulating, a 56-page booklet that will help us understand this legislation.

This legislation forms an incredibly complex package. Eight months after the Treasurer initially announced the legislation-telephone book size, if one adds together the legislation, the memorandum and the booklet-this Parliament, as representatives of the Australian people in this chamber, have one day of guillotined debate to discuss it. The Government is treating Parliament and the Australian community with outrageous contempt. Quite frankly, I am surprised that we are not debating the legislation on a non-broadcast day. The Government must have slipped up here because that would have been consistent with the way the Government is putting this legislation through. If the legislation had been brought on on a non-broadcast day this debate also would have gone unheard by the Australian community at large. If the community-

TALK.START.PARA: —We wanted it on a broadcast day.

—The honourable member's turn will come in a minute, and he will stand exposed for his support of this legislation as well. The honourable member should not be so impatient as to interrupt my contribution. The Australian public in the months ahead will come to understand this legislation, because it will impact on almost every Australian worker. To give the House just one little insight, if a person happens to operate a vehicle which has both a commercial and private purpose, a standard item of equipment in that vehicle will not be a spare tyre but a log book in the glove box to enable the owner to keep the hour by hour and day by day records that will be necessary for him to stand under this legislation. It is an incredible and outrageous assault on the Australian taxpayer, and let me say that it is an ill wind that blows no good.

SPEECH.PARA: As the shadow Treasurer said, this legislation will herald the flight of this Government from office. The Government was nearly done at the last election over so-called tax reform. I am quite confident, even though it is risky making political predictions in a business fraught with uncertainty, that this legislation alone, let alone the plethora of other matters this Government can be attacked on, will see this Government out of office.

Because of the outrageous guillotine to which we are all subjected and because of the inordinate number of speakers on both sides of the chamber who wish to make comments on this legislation, we are necessarily restricted in time. I would like to concentrate on one specific area in my shadow ministerial responsibilities of education and youth affairs; that is, specifically how this legislation will affect non-government schools and particularly non-government boarding schools. With the ideological blinkers that those opposite wear, they believe that only the wealthy send their children to non-government or private schools; the wealthy can afford it and, so the logic goes, they can afford the taxation assault on non-government schools. I will detail that in a minute.

Let me tell those opposite that the parents who sent their children to non-government schools are not necessarily wealthy, and the parents in the rural areas, who send their children to non-government schools are certainly not wealthy. One has only to speak to the parents of isolated children, parents who live in the many square miles of outback Australia, to understand that for many of them the choice is between education on the farm or property and sending their children to a rural boarding school. One of the ways in which rural boarding schools exist and operate in Australia is by extending to the teachers and staffs of those schools subsidised and concessional accommodation.

This is not a perk, a rort or a rip-off; it is one way in which those schools in the far-flung, outback regions of Australia can attract the necessary and qualified staff to deliver fundamental education to rural Australian children. One way of attracting staff is to provide concessional or subsidised accommodation and the associated meals and support that go with it. With the cost of running non-government boarding schools, one of the ways in which suburban and city non-government boarding schools try to meet the costs of their boarding staff, the husbands and wives who look after the children who are sent to the schools and the single men and women who are housemasters and the like at the schools-one of the ways in which they attract those individuals for a very low rate of remuneration-is by giving them subsidised or concessional accommodation. Again, the concessions enjoyed by those staffs is not a perk or a rip-off.

This tax, impacting as it will on the schools, will necessarily lead to fee increases for both day pupils and boarding pupils. This is not only an outrageous assault on taxpayers across Australia but an ideologically blinkered, outrageous assault in this one specific area. Anything in today's educational climate, with today's cost pressures, which impacts adversely on the costs of running non-government and boarding schools in the cities and suburbs, but especially in the rural areas, is to be argued against and to be opposed vigorously.

I end where I began, recognising that I said I would keep my remarks specific and short. Almost every clause and paragraph of this legislation can be contested. It is a piece of legislation that will lead this Government out of office. In the meantime, it will impact outrageously on so many individuals and families across Australia. One of the specific groups I speak for this morning is that group of parents, especially in rural and outback Australia, who, not for reasons of wealth or privilege, but for reasons of economic necessity, have to send their children to rural-based boarding schools. Because their staffs and teachers enjoy the concessional or subsidised accommodation and other arrangements at the schools-benefits which the schools have to extend to attract the right sort of staff in the first place-those schools will be caught up by and subjected to this piece of legislation. As those schools try to survive-they are not profit-mak- ing organisations-and try to meet their costs year by academic year, the inevitable consequence of this legislation will be that fees will rise. As fees rise, that rise will impact on those families in the depressed rural sections of Australia who have enough trouble as it is now in sending their children to boarding school without additional costs being imposed. As I have said, they do not send their children to boarding school for reasons of privilege but for reasons of economic necessity. If for no other reason, this legislation should be opposed for that reason. If it is not going to be knocked out and thrown out, as it should be, I urge the Government to take off its ideological blinkers and to look at the adverse impact that it will have on non-government schools around Australia, especially those in rural Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the fringe benefits tax legislation. I have been looking forward to the day that it would be introduced in the House so that I could take the opportunity to dispel the fears of the people of Australia. I acknowledge that today is a broadcast day; I am glad that it is; it gives the opportunity to dispel for all Australians some of the emotive junk that comes from the honourable members on the other side of the House every time that the Government tries to do something to bring some credibility back into the tax system in Australia. Every country must have a fair tax system. If some people are able to opt out of paying their fair share, a snowball effect develops. As more people look for ways of opting out and look for loopholes, the worse the system gets. Let us not forget that that is exactly what happened in Australia during the 1970s. Under the regime of the Government of honourable members opposite, the tax system broke down.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has come to office on a platform of tax reform. It was clearly put to the electorate in the November 1984 election run-up that this Government would reform the tax system. The people of Australia supported that proposal. They want the system to be reformed, and it will be reformed, and we have their support. While honourable members opposite continue with their emotive junk, they are simply alienating themselves from the people of Australia. While talking about their emotive junk, I ask: What did honourable members opposite say about the assets test? They urged all pensioners in Australia to put their money under the bed. Honourable members opposite scared pensioners witless. Now they are out in the community talking up the rural depression, causing banks to add loadings on to farmers' loans encouraging the vultures to sit back while rural farm values become further depressed. The more they talk it up, the worse they make it for the very people they purport to represent and they are at it again today.

The Tullamarine airport is in my electorate. Thousands of airline industry employees who live in my electorate are vitally concerned about the real nature of this legislation. As did my colleague the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths) a few minutes earlier, and so that everyone can understand it, I will put the record straight simply and succinctly with regard to the application of the fringe benefits tax to airline travel. The position is simply this: A tax will be applied to concessional travel granted to employees by the airlines. As a result of negotiations with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Government, it has been agreed, firstly, that the tax will be paid by the employer-the airlines. Secondly, it has also been agreed that there will be no cutback in the availability of standby travel opportunities for airline employees. Thirdly, I refer to the other side of the deal: The airline unions have agreed that they will make no increased claims in this area in the future. In other words, they have a package. They are content with it and they are content with the position adopted by the employers. I do no care how much honourable members opposite go out in the community and peddle their junk. Those are the facts, and those are the facts that I want the people in my electorate to understand.

I turn now to the motor vehicle tax, because I have a bit of an interest in that. The Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd factory in Broadmeadows is also in my electorate. Thousands of people working in the motor vehicle industry are concerned about its future. There is no dispute among workers in the motor vehicle industry that there is a need for fringe benefits tax legislation. There is no dispute that the tax system has been rorted and they, as ordinary workers paying high PAYE tax, are looking for relief. There is no dispute at all. The question that really arises is whether there will be a downturn for the motor vehicle industry and if so what is the cause.

Let us look at company cars. The Government is not opposed to people having company cars. We are not opposed to people having salary packages. All we are saying is that if an employee has a company car as a fringe benefit or perk, tax should be paid on that. That does not apply to a car that is used for business purposes only because business mileage is not taxed. Members of the Opposition know that but I have not heard them mention that fact once this morning. There will be no tax at all on business mileage. We are concerned with private mileage that would normally be done by a person using a private vehicle. If an employee has a company car and that car substitutes for private expenditure then tax should be payable. I do not have any problems in supporting that. The tax pay- able is minimised. The more the vehicle is used for work purposes-as in the case of the travelling sales representative or the person who uses the company car for business related matters-the less tax is payable. I have no problems with that. In the fringe benefits tax booklet that we have published there is a clear scale that shows that. So anything that Opposition members say in this debate today that contradicts what I have just said will be a downright lie and honourable members opposite will be exposed for using it.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: I think the honourable member for Burke should rephrase what he just said. What he in fact said was that every remark made by any Opposition member which did not totally agree with his remarks was a downright lie. I do not think that is an acceptable formulation of words at all.
—Perhaps the honourable member for Burke might like to say `it is not true'.

—I am quite happy to rephrase it and say that it will not be true. What has just happened is yet another misrepresentation by a member of the Opposition. That happens all the time. I said that anything that was said later in the House today that disclaimed what I had just said about the table in the booklet would be a lie. That is what I said, and the honourable member for Bradfield knows very well that that is what I said. Let us return to the future of the motor vehicle industry.
—The honourable member for Burke might be more advised not to use the word `lie'. Perhaps he will rephrase what he said.

—I accept your advice, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will rephrase my words to `it would not be true to say that later in the day'. There will be a downturn in the motor vehicle sales this year when compared with last year. That will be caused by several factors. One factor which is not the cause is the fringe benefits tax. Let us look at some of the key factors. First of all, last year was a record year for the motor vehicle industry as a result of the efforts of this Government in restoring the economy, restoring confidence and encouraging sales in the industry. We reached record levels. That is not disputed by any of the manufacturers. They all know they had a big year last year and there are several reasons why that will not recur this year. The first is that the Government has removed a rort that Opposition members were responsible for-the way in which the investment allowance worked. Last year many companies put in orders before 30 June, even though the deliveries came later, in order to qualify for that investment allowance. Secondly, there have been price rises because of the introduction of unleaded petrol. Thirdly, there are price rises in the system for imported vehicles and components because of the devaluation. The Opposition's efforts in holding an overvalued dollar for as long as it did when it was in office caused imports to have an advantage in Australia. That has been one of the prime reasons why imported vehicles have replaced locally manufactured vehicles. Opposition members know that and they know that it is not true to say that devaluation has not had and will not have a significant effect on the value of motor vehicles.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to look at two or three articles which have appeared in the Press this week. In the Melbourne Sun on Tuesday there was a big item headlined `Perks tax ``cause of car firm crash'' '. The firm was a Mazda dealership in Dandenong, Victoria. This firm was dealing in imported vehicles and of course imported vehicle prices have gone through the roof because the devaluation of the dollar has put our local vehicles in a better competitive position. Of course import dealers will feel the crunch. So they should. There was also an article entitled `Cost price squeeze for the motor vehicle industry' which clearly outlined a number of reasons for the downturn. An article in the Age on Tuesday 6 May relates to the Peugeot operation-another imported car. The article says that Peugeot distributors last week cut $5,000 off the price of one of their vehicles in the market-place. Why? Because they want to maintain market share and under the new arrangements if they want to maintain their market share against Australian vehicles, that is the sort of thing they will have to do. I welcome that, I have no problems with that at all. In effect what I am saying is yes, there will be some shake-outs in the motor vehicle industry. We have known that since we came to office. The 1992 motor vehicle plan will cause shake-outs in the industry and those will be to the advantage of locally manufactured products.

I make yet another point on the effect of the fringe benefits tax on salary packages. This is something that honourable members opposite will be particularly interested in because they have so much contact with senior business executives. What was the effect on the business sector, particularly in relation to salary packages, when the Government introduced its legislation last Friday? In Friday's Australian Financial Review there were 90 advertisements for senior business positions. Of those 90 only nine specified salary only; the other 81 set out a salary package and 14 of them not only set out a package but specifically nominated a company car as part of the deal. In the attempt to recruit senior executives the business sector out there-with whom honourable members opposite claim to be in touch-has filled a newspaper with advertisements offering salary packages. Obviously that sector is not worried about this tax. Opposition members know as well as I do that every time a package is mentioned a company car is included.

My final point about the fringe benefits tax on cars is that this Government is entitled to be suspicious of the political motives of some of those who make decisions in this area. Late last year, on the day the Government announced its intention to move in this area, the Adelaide Steamship Company Limited and Elders IXL Limited moved to cancel their fleet orders. I ask honourable members to reflect on who are the leaders of those companies and how they are affiliated with the Liberal Party of Australia. They could not care less about the effect on workers or ordinary Australians. All they wanted to do was cancel their fleet orders because that would put pressure on the Government. I think that that is despicable. When we talk about knocking off tax deductions for overseas borrowings, those same companies say: `We will go offshore, we will take our business out of Australia'. Those people do not want a fair tax system because they have lived off the rorts for all those years. This Government was elected on a platform of tax reform. It was elected to take the rorts out of the system. It will do so and it will have my full support in doing so. I fully support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating an extra tax that is to be imposed on the people of Australia-the fringe benefits tax which is to apply from 1 July 1986 and which must be paid on non-cash benefits granted to employees. This may seem logical to some who live in the antiseptic world of Canberra, but nevertheless it is an extra tax. Those people who go out into the paddock, out into the real world and look at the damaging practicalities of this will have grave reservations about it. I emphasise that this is an extra tax. In 1986-87 an extra $330m will be collected; in the following year $540m; and in 1988-89 an extra $625m. The employer has to pay the tax. Fringe benefits will not be allowable as a tax deduction. If we divide those amounts by the 800,000 employers in this country we find that they will each be paying an extra $10 or $15 a week. However, as most employers employ only members of their own families, they will have to pay on average an extra $30 or $40 a week. That may not sound a large amount of money but it probably represents 20 per cent of their income.

SPEECH.PARA: This fringe benefits tax has been structured in line with the typical socialist mentality of making the employer pay so that the employee will not be offended. I think this is ridiculous. The Government has also structured the tax in this way to ensure that it can be collected. The Government knows that the employees would revolt against such a tax if it were imposed on them. However, the attitude of the electorate will become apparent at the time of the next election. The way in which the Government has gone about implementing this tax immediately makes it a bad tax. The tax is inconsistent in that the employee pays tax on the cash part of his income but he does not have to pay the tax directly on the non-cash part. Where is the logic in that? Because this tax has to be paid on the fringe benefits part of the income, it means that, in the course of time, fewer fringe benefits will be granted to workers. That is an unavoidable fact of life. It will mean in effect that the quality of life will drop. We just cannot pluck $500m out of the economy from nowhere and say that this will have no effect on anybody. That $500m will not be there any more.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not unless you are naive.

—That is right. The tax will mean fewer jobs, fewer fringe benefits and higher prices for the consumer. The Government would do better to ask itself why fringe benefits were granted in the first place. There are a number of reasons for this. They are granted because the marginal rates of tax are too high. This Government says that it is bringing down marginal rates from 60c to 49c in the dollar. While that move can be applauded, the fact is that because of inflation, indexation, fiscal drag, bracket creep and all of these other fancy terms, everyone in this country will soon be paying tax of 40c to 49c in the dollar anyhow. So the amount of tax collected will actually go up. Let us wipe the idea that the increase in tax will be offset by tax cuts later in the year.

SPEECH.PARA: Fringe benefits are used to attract employees to certain jobs-for example, jobs in remote areas-or because the employer cannot afford to pay enough in cash wages. However, all this will now go by the board. Therefore, the fringe benefits tax will be a tax on jobs; it will be a tax on decentralisation; and it will be a tax on the hard workers of this country. Who will be hit by the tax? I know that the Government aims to soak the so-called rich because it does not like success. It wants to drag everyone down to the same level. It is ironic to look at members of the front bench, when they are in this chamber, because it is stacked with millionaires. This tax will not affect them. It is going to hit the middle class. It is going to hit the poor-the ordinary bloke in the street. The small businessman of this country is busting himself working 80 hours a week. He is taking home probably only a couple of hundred dollars a week whereas his employees are probably taking home more. The small businessman is going to be hit with the fringe benefits tax. It is utterly ridiculous! The one little luxury that an employer might have in small business is going to be taken away from him.

The rich of this country will get around this tax. The tax will not affect the Packers, the Abeles, the Keatings, et cetera. They will not lose any sleep at night. The average man in the street is the person who will be hit. There will be fewer fringe benefits, and fewer jobs, and the employer will have less money in his pocket. Prices will have to go up to pay for this. The practical effects of implementing this Bill are really horrific. One would think that a terrorist organisation had produced the purple booklet entitled `Fringe Benefits Tax-a guide for employers'. There is a minefield on every page. There are 56 pages of bombshells of detail, complications-

TALK.START.PARA: —Whose signature is on it-Gaddafi or Keating?

—Goodness knows; it is more socialist diatribe. As we have heard, the tax will be detrimental to the car industry. The people in my electorate will probably be riding bicycles if this tax is introduced.

SPEECH.PARA: I particularly want to restrict my comments to the effect of the tax on small businessmen and farmers. The Labor Government is trying to smash down anyone in this country who shows any signs of independence, who is not in a trade union and who is not a member of the industrial relations club. It hates initiative, thrift, work, effort, and independence. It wants to bring everyone down so that they comply and show conformity. The Government loves bureaucracy, and egalitarianism. It wants everyone to be dragged down to the one level. It wants everyone to be in a trade union. One has to look only at the Leader of the Australian Labor Party-he is an ex trade union leader, for goodness sake!

The fringe benefits tax will apply from 1 July and will have to be paid quarterly. It is quite frightening to see the calculations that are contained in the book, the paper work that is going to be involved and the bureaucracies that will have to spring up. This country will be awash with what I call the three Ps-paper, public servants and poverty-if the fringe benefits tax is introduced. We will have to woodchip every tree in Australia to produce enough paper to supply the forms that will be needed if employers are to comply with what is contained in the booklet. The public servants will love the tax because new bureaucracies will have to spring up, and empires will be created. The tax will result in poverty because it will have to be paid for. Let us not forget that an extra $500m will be involved. This will mean fewer jobs and a lower standard of living.

I would like to conclude by directing my comments particularly to the family farmer and the small businessman, a lot of whom have set up proprietary companies. The family car will obviously become a perk. Tax will have to be paid on it. Take the case of a farmer or a small businessman who hires his sons or daughters to work for him. From my reading of the booklet, it appears that the parent of the household will have to pay an accommodation fringe benefits tax on the use of his own house. Have we ever heard anything more ridiculous? When will it stop? This Government would extract lids off coffins and take gold out of teeth if it thought there were a quid in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It tried to with the assets test.

—Yes. If one gives an employee a meal, one has to pay a tax of $2 on that meal. This is what will happen even if that meal is given in one's own kitchen. Just think what this tax will do to the shearing industry. The $2 a meal will be an extra cost on farmers. An ex-shearer is on the front bench. Imagine what would have happened if this tax applied when he was working as a shearer. His employers might have thought that he was not worth feeding. He might have starved.
—He would be a lot slimmer.

—Yes, it might have had some beneficial effects. But now he is not taking the wool off the sheep but fleecing the taxpayers of Australia. I have never heard anything more ridiculous than taxing farmers $2 a meal.

SPEECH.PARA: For goodness sake, why do we need subsidised accommodation in this country? The farmers in the remote areas of my electorate cannot afford to pay more than the award wage of approximately $240 a week. The farmers have to give people some sorts of benefits to attract them to work. They do this by, perhaps, subsidising electricity costs, throwing in a bit of petrol or subsidising accommodation. This attracts employment to those areas. It is a decentralisation incentive. The same sort of thing applies in the mining industry.
