The farmers will now have to pay tax on the accommodation that they give to their employees. The collection of this tax will be subject to an incredibly complicated formula. One would have to be Einstein, use computers or have access to accountants to be able to work it out. I presume that accountants' fees will not be tax deductible. We are told that everything is not going to be tax deductible.

All this in non-productive activity. It is the last thing that this country wants. I have to say that the imposition of this tax is a Public Service dream. The farmer often gives his employee food in the form of, say, a sheep or a lamb. How is this sort of thing going to be policed? How will the Government police whether an employee is being given petrol or a car to run around in. Even if an employee runs a cow, for heaven's sake, on the farm--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about growing vegetables?

—I am indebted to the honourable member; I had not even thought of that. The owner of the cow will have to pay fringe benefits tax on milk that is given to his employees. The application of this tax will be a nightmare. Both employers and employees will be swamped with a mountain of paperwork that will be associated with the fringe benefits tax. They will have to substantiate claims in regard to payments, the number of kilometres travelled and so on. For heaven's sake, all the records will have to be kept for six years. Even if a farmer lets a retired worker stay on in a cottage on the property, which is not an unusual thing, he will continue to be liable to have to pay tax on the value of that accommodation for his retired worker.
—Disgusting!

—It is disgusting. Since this fringe benefits tax was first announced on 19 September last year, it has taken 7 1/2 months for the Government finally to get this legislation into the Parliament. Let there be no doubt that the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party of Australia are totally opposed to it, the same as we are opposed to the capital gains tax, the assets test and the 3 per cent superannuation deal. All that we have heard from this Government since it has been in power is tax, tax, tax. This country cannot afford it. What we should be doing is not creating extra taxes but cutting government expenditure. That is what the people want. That is what the country wants. We want less government expenditure, not more tax. This Government will pay for this tax at the next election as the coalition Government will be returned to power and we will get some sanity back into economic policies in this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite frankly, I am amazed at the emotive speech by the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) on the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill and cognate Bills. I disagree with almost everything he said. I think he has been carried away quite unnecessarily on this issue. I am very pleased to be following the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths) and the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) in this debate.
—What about me?

—And to precede the honourable member for Macarthur. This legislation is aimed at creating more fairness and equity in the Australian taxation system. It represents a major part of the Australian Government's tax reform package. In recent years there has been a marked acceleration in the shift towards the payment by employers of remuneration in the form of fringe benefits. Every honourable member is aware of that shift. Every member of the Australian population is aware of that shift. High marginal tax rates arguably have contributed to this trend, at least in part. Contrary to the comments of the honourable member for Parkes, the question of high marginal tax rates has already been adequately tackled by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: In many ways the arrangements involved in the provision of fringe benefits can be equated with tax evasion because the benefits gained are not taxable in the hands of the employee, whereas a money amount in lieu would be taxable. Increasing public awareness of these so-called perks pointed up the unfairness of the tax system and contributed to an undermining of taxpayer morale generally. Therefore, our Government was determined to address this vexed question of fringe benefits. I am very pleased to endorse the contents of these Bills.

The types of benefits covered by this legislation include employer-provided motor vehicles, free or low interest loans, residential accommodation, goods and services sold at below cost or provided free by an employer, and expenses paid on behalf of an employee. In each case the tax will be payable on the assessed value of the benefits provided to employees and will be levied on the employer. While some fringe benefits are undoubtedly necessary to a person's job and pursuit of income, and while many have been fought for as part of industrial awards, many more have been granted as non-cash benefits purely for the purpose of avoiding taxation. These are the benefits which this Bill tackles.

This tax is accepted in the wider community. It is correctly seen as necessary to clean up the tax system and to assist in improving its equity. Few groups of people are able to get access to fringe benefits as it is a measure utilised mainly by employers to assist higher income earners to avoid paying tax at a higher marginal rate. Therefore, it is evident that this legislation will help to reduce the tax burden which has been placed unevenly and unfairly on ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers for many years past. Previous governments were unwilling to take on this issue, to the long term detriment of thousands of low and middle income earners who have never been party to lurks and perks of the kind covered in this legislation.

The fringe benefits tax will apply from 1 July 1986. It will be payable by employers in quarterly instalments. The employers will assess their own fringe benefit tax liability. An annual return will be filled in by them and sent back to the Australian Taxation Office. What could be fairer than that? I take the comments of the honourable member for Parkes into account when I say that I truly feel that most employers would much prefer to assess their own tax liability in this regard than to have the Taxation Office do it for them. The technical aspects of evaluation and assessment have been covered by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and an information booklet has been compiled to assist employers with this task. That was also mentioned by the honour- able member for Burke.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some booklet!
—It is an excellent booklet. I ask the honourable member whether he has read it?
—Have you read it?
—I have read it, yes.
—Can you understand it?

—Yes, I can understand it. Fringe benefits tax will not apply to benefits associated with contributions to superannuation funds and employee share acquisition plans, which are covered already by income tax laws. Staff canteens also are generally excluded. Child care facilities and recreation facilities on an employer's premises will not be taxable under this legislation. The honourable member for Burke already has adequately covered the arguments in respect of employer-provided motor vehicles. I endorse his remarks entirely.

SPEECH.PARA: A taxable fringe benefit on housing generally arises where an employee is provided with accommodation at his or her normal place of residence. However, if such housing is located in a designated remote area, concessional valuation rules apply in most cases. Like some other members of this House, I have lived in a remote area and been provided with employer accommodation or company accommodation as it is often called. The provision of such accommodation is welcomed by workers and employees and is necessary because no privately owned accommodation is available in such areas. These cases have to be treated sensitively. I believe the Government has taken all the relevant factors into account in drawing up this legislation by consulting with employer, union and other interested groups.

This is not a tax on jobs, as suggested by honourable members opposite. It is an honest attempt to tidy up the tax system and to equalise the tax burden in Australia. This legislation is necessary and fair, as I have just said. It has the support of the majority of Australians. It is long overdue. The tax reform proposals of this Government have been overwhelmingly accepted. This fringe benefits tax is an essential component of that reform. Without this sort of tax the addressing of higher marginal tax rates may not have been possible. I totally support the concept of this tax. I compliment the Treasurer on his commitment to it and commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) in his very strong speech to the House on the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill and cognate Bills in which he indicated the difficulties facing the Parliament and the Australian public in regard to this legislation. The fringe benefit tax legislation has finally emerged after the National Taxation Summit Conference of 1985 and the statement of 19 September 1985. Now, on 8 May, the legislation is finally before us for debate. Up till this time we have been acting in a de facto manner. It is interesting to observe that the quarantining of farm losses has been removed from those proposals. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) was bold enough to suggest that the Government had forgone $65m when in fact the legislation was not even in place. I remind the Australian public and members of this House that at the Tax Summit the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) enumerated nine principles of taxation. I would like to record the three principles on which he was particularly keen. He said;

SPEECH.PARA: . . . any reform must lead to a simpler system, which therefore all Australians can understand more easily.
I wonder how they can understand this legislation. In the Prime Minister's next point he stated:
. . . any reform must provide the best possible climate for investment, growth and employment in Australia.
In his third point he stated:
. . . any reform package must have widespread community support-

He certainly has not got that. Let us look at the Medicare arrangements about which he made similar remarks. He said that the system must be fairer, cheaper and easy to understand. We have seen the results of the effect of that legislation on the Medicare system. There has been a $100m blowout in the Budget. There are 28,000 Victorians waiting to get into hospitals. We can see the particular difficulties which have resulted from the Medicare system. The fringe benefits tax will affect employment opportunities. We have seen the cost in employment opportunities already with 580,000 Australians unemployed. The cost of wages, together with the on-cost of consumer price index increases, the 17 1/2 per cent loading, long service leave, termination pay and workers compensation all add about 50c on-cost to every dollar paid in wages.

We have now two further threats. We have a 3 per cent superannuation claim in the productivity case which, we can see, the Confederation of Australian Industry is adamantly against and which threatens jobs. And, secondly, we now have before the House the fringe benefits tax. In the final analysis, this will impose a further cost on labour. The Government will get some revenue, but certainly there will be fewer job opportunities. The Prime Minister suggested that there ought to be a simple system which Australians can understand. How can they understand this legislation, which comprises a 175 page explanatory memorandum, a Bill which contains 139 pages and a tax guide which contains 56 pages? Some members opposite have not even read that guide, because, even if they did read it, they would not be able to understand it. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has indicated that there will be a revenue gain of an extra $330m in 1986-87, $540m in 1987-88 and $625m in 1988-89. I refer to those figures in the context of the total 1984-85 Budget receipts of $56.9 billion. Yet the Treasurer is seeking a revenue gain of $330m in the forthcoming year.

Let us look at the small contribution made by this tax. The key provisions are quarterly payments by the employers, a rate of 46c in the dollar and an administrative nightmare. With regard to the quarterly payments, accountants will have to sort out the arrangements. They will have to work out who will make the payments, what are the procedures required and how the arrangements will be organised in the future, once they have worked it out in the first year of operation. I am quite amazed by the record keeping requirements, the booklet entitled `Fringe Benefits Tax-a guide for employers' states that the records must be written in English. What a surprise it is that they must be written in English-in Australia! The guide states:
2.11 record-keeping requirements

The records must be written in the English language or, if not in written form (e.g. on computer), be in a form which is readily accessible and can be converted into English. The records must be kept for 7 years.

That is quite a surprise for those of us who live in Australia and who consider English to be our language. I spoke to one respected accountant who suggested that one needs to take along one's accountant in the back of the car in order to keep the records straight. The general objection that I am finding is that the administrative hassle will be too much for the farmers, the miners and the small businessmen of Australia.

Let us look at the principle involved. Generally speaking, tax is levied on those who receive the benefit or income. The Government has now applied this tax on employers because there would be too much political cost to the Government if it were imposed on employees. Also, it wants ease of collection. This will impose yet another burden on employers.

Let us look at cars. There are two approaches. One is a statutory formula which is very hard to understand and the other is an actual costing arrangement. Between them, the employer and employee can go to great lengths to log the claims and costs so that they can work out the final tax arrangements. The problems outlined on page 7 of the explanatory memorandum regarding this proposal will have a major effect on the car industry. I quote from that document:
After a car has been owned or leased for four years, the amount against which the relevant percentage is applied will be reduced to two-thirds of the original cost price, or market value if leased.
Obviously, people will use their cars longer and use cars that have less horse power. How can we log the data between private and business use?

The impact on the car industry in the Geelong area will be quite dramatic. I have here a copy of a letter sent by Mr Bill Dix, Managing Director of Ford Australia, to the employees of the car plant in Geelong. In relation to the company car tax, he stated:
It is a matter that should concern all employees because if the new tax provisions as currently proposed are implemented, they will have a most serious impact on our industry.
Expressed simply we expect the tax will:
When combined with other economic effects reduce the 1986 vehicle market by 90 thousand units;

Through the impact on the fleet market-a major portion of our business-cause an initial loss of almost 35 thousand 6 cylinder sales in 1986 with a continuing loss of 25 thousand units in subsequent years.
Cause major disruption to the Government's passenger vehicle manufacturing plant-around which our investment and planning is based.
Reduce employment in the vehicle manufacturing sector by 3 thousand with an overall loss of some 10 thousand jobs.
Reduce productivity and stall Australia's efforts to become internationally competitive.

I turn briefly to some of the other provisions in the legislation. In regard to housing fringe benefits, how will we identify the rental value in rural areas? Who will pay-the farmers or the miners? Who will assess what the rent is? How will we attract people to more remote parts? Clause 31 concerns the living away from home allowance. The bureaucrats suggest that it costs $42 a week to feed an adult at home. How do they make that judgment? They also suggest that it will cost $80 to feed oneself when one is living away from home. How do they come up with that remarkable observation?

In regard to property fringe benefits, goods consumed on the premises are okay. I draw honourable members' attention to the paragraph in the fringe benefits tax booklet. It states that no tax will be applied on a daily ration of beer consumed by brewery employees at work. The tax guide booklet suggests that that is okay.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about milk?

—I am not sure what will happen in regard to milk. Obviously, the Government is happy to get its excise. But not may other Australian workers have the option of consuming beer at their place of work. I suggest that the fringe benefits tax, as applied to the States, local government and the Commonwealth, has not been thought through. Because of the administrative effort involved and the fact that they are being asked to provide more services at the local level and receive less revenue, local government authorities and the States are very concerned that they must pay this tax.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is complicated and lengthy. It has yet to be interpreted. It is confused and it will generate little revenue. The car industry is in trouble. Australians remain overtaxed. Expenditure has not been restrained. The tax reform myth has been exploded today

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986 and cognate Bills, of course, are further evidence of this Government's commitment to the reform of the tax system. Quite clearly, members on this side of the House recognise that that is long overdue. It is quite clear that in the past honourable members opposite did nothing to see that the tax evasion and avoidance industry that has grown in this country was stifled. The need to improve the fairness of the system for the majority of Australians has clearly been demonstrated. Public confidence in the integrity of the tax system has been eroded. This has caused something of a disproportionate shouldering of the revenue burden by honest citizens in this country. That is a situation that this Government can no longer tolerate. The end result of these measures, of course, is to produce a much fairer system.

SPEECH.PARA: If we turn specifically to the Bills that are before us today-that is, the fringe benefits tax proposals-we can see that over a period there has been a very strong movement towards the renumeration of employees, especialy those on high incomes, by way of a fringe benefits package. Not so long ago, when one looked at the Saturday edition of the Sydney Morning Herald, the Daily Telegraph or whatever, one would see advertisements for senior management executives and for people on substantial incomes. If one looked fairly carefully at the advertisements, one would see that the job involved a package composed of a salary which, having regard to the qualifications required for the position that was being advertised, in actual monetary terms, was not particularly high. One would think: `That is not too good. I wonder why it will attract people'. One then read the advertisement further and saw that, along with the salary, there was a car, educational expenses for children, and a trip overseas every year. Virtually a block of flats and half of Tasmania was being offered as part of the proposal. Of course, that has meant that the tax burden that has once again fallen on the average Australian pay as you earn taxpayer was being reinforced. The lower income being offered meant that the return to the Government of a fair share of taxation benefits totally disappeared, hence, one of the major reasons for the imposition of a fringe benefits tax.

It is interesting that a number of comments have been made about various parts of the fringe benefits tax. In particular, a great deal of attention has centred on the motor vehicle industry. During the debate this morning, comparisons have been made between motor vehicle dealers operations, the fact that many people will lose jobs and that vehicle sales will go down. In recent times various estimates have been put forward to the effect that sales are down by 27 per cent at present, or that the figures are down by 22 percent on the 1985 figures. The inference to be drawn is that that has been a direct result of the fringe benefits tax. That is patently nonsense because the tax has not yet started. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has clearly indicated-it has been verified by those in the industry-that there has been a variety of changes, such as the effect of the depreciation of the dollar on the price of imported vehicles and the fact that non-leaded fuel has been introduced in this country, which has meant that all cars are being tuned so that that form of fuel can be used by them. This has meant that many people purchased vehicles at a rapid rate prior to the last couple of months.

Of course, very substantially high figures in the motor vehicle industry have now tended to trend downwards, as a natural result. I implore honourable members opposite who are taking a different view here to get out and talk amongst their own people and see what effect there has been in the industry itself; it might be somewhat enlightening. I have done that and, indeed, can speak with some authority on this because my father for quite a number of years was in fact a motor vehicle principal dealer in Wollongong. It is the sort of industry that fluctuates and goes through periods, as does the housing industry. At various times it goes through a high period and at various other times through a low period. Sales on a monthly basis are the ones that count. What we have seen in recent times is that those monthly figures have trended downwards from extremely high points-

TALK.START.PARA: —Record heights.

—Record heights, as the honourable member for Dobell states. It is quite important to get that particular position straight. The honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) and the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) were talking about the problems in saying that they were totally opposed to the fringe benefits tax. I am afraid that the honourable member for Parkes should just refer to the statement by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) on this because I do not think he is so gung-ho about it as he would have us believe. I refer particularly to an article in the Australian Financial Review of 21 April reporting on the Leader of the Opposition's attempt to take over Queensland again and bring it back to the Liberal Party. Under the heading ``Fringe tax is wrong in principle: Howard'', it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Federal Opposition, Mr Howard, yesterday refused to commit a coalition government to repealing the fringe benefit tax.

Yet, the honourable member for Parkes has stood up in this House this morning and said that the National Party-Liberal Party coalition is totally opposed to it. He should speak to the Leader of the Opposition about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does the honourable member for Mackellar say on this?
—As the honourable member for Dobell asks, what does the honourable member for Mackellar say about this? Again, I would like to compare some of those comments.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the heading `Mass job losses predicted over car fringe benefits tax bungle' in the Adelaide Advertiser of 9 April, it is stated that job losses have been estimated at something like 10,000 because of the fringe benefits tax. It stated that the shadow Treasurer, Mr Carlton, said that an industry study he had obtained exposed a massive bungle on the tax, yet one finds that the view put by Senator Messner and other people does not quite fit in. Their estimates range between 25,000 and 35,000 job losses, with a loss of production and so on; the figures are all over the place, as they are on the other side. Quite clearly, it demonstrates that honourable members opposite still have no policy on what they are to do about this. In fact, the Leader of the Opposition's comments on his grand tour through Queensland were reported thus:

Speaking over the weekend in north Queensland, Mr Howard said the Opposition was looking at a number of different approaches to taxes to encourage incentive. What we come up with might make it unnecessary to repeal the tax.

Not only is Mr Howard saying that those opposite are not against it; he is saying that they may not repeal it if they ever get into government. He is saying, of course, as usual: `We will wait and see when we formulate our policy'. This might be down the track somewhere, like all the rest of the policies of this Opposition of no policies. Those opposite say that they will look at it at some stage in the future. They might again take the goodies, but they will not have the nasties. To try to get over that problem again they will add to the Budget deficit, and on and on it goes.

I wonder whether honourable members opposite really do speak for those they purport to represent. Again on 7 April there is an article under the heading `Business will accept cost of Government's tax on fringe benefits' in the Australian Financial Review. I wonder whether honourable members opposite have spoken to the people they purport to represent to see whether that is in fact the view they are reflecting in this chamber. They are out of touch. The article goes on to state:

A survey of Australia's top companies shows business is prepared to accept the cost of the Federal Government's fringe benefits tax. The survey of Australia's top 500 most profitable companies . . . found that more than half the companies estimated that the tax would add less than 9 per cent to their overall employment costs.

They are prepared to accept it. Honourable members should go and talk to these people and see what it is about. I come back again to the whole question of the fringe benefits or car tax about which people are talking. Some mention was made by the honourable member for Corangamite about Mr Dix and Ford and the problems down there. I refer him to a very in-depth and interesting editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald on 1 May this year under the heading: `Keating must be tough on car tax'. A very good exposition was given as to why the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd and General Motors-Holden Ltd are so gung-ho about this tax. They are concerned about loss of sales of big cars, suggesting that people will go into smaller cars and therefore their market will be eroded. The editorial states:

Mr Keating has rocks in his head if he lets Ford and General Motors wriggle even half way out of the fringe benefits tax. According to the two car makers, Mr Keating's efforts to tax businessmen on their company cars threatens to undermine Senator Button's efforts to rationalise the Australian car industry.
It goes on to say in the editorial, which I fully endorse, that the industry has exaggerated the impact of the tax. It goes on to state:

Ford and GMH claim that Mr Keating's tax will induce companies and their executives to switch to smaller, cheaper cars. That would be a disaster for Ford and GMH which depend on the Falcon and Commodore to meet their local-content obligations under the car plan. They want to replace Mr Keating's fringe benefits tax, which does not discriminate between models, with a three-step tax that would make small cars less attractive to company car buyers.

It goes on to say that there would be no effect and that the effect on the car industry plan is, in fact, negligible. I and, I am sure many honourable members-including the honourable member for Mackellar-have received letters from various Ford dealerships such as Tynan Motors Pty Ltd, Petrie Ford and the Clifton Toyota-Fury group, which is into Ford, Mitsubishi, bob cats, engineering and all sorts of things. They have been writing to all members imploring the Government not to proceed with this tax and saying what effect it has had, that it has caused unemployment, that it has been a disaster, and that they have had to put off people. It is interesting that they are saying that it is the fringe benefits tax that has caused them to do that when it has not even started. Do not talk nonsense! Let us get it straight: What we are talking about here is an industry which, I intimated previously, actually goes through a cyclical phase of highs and lows. When one gets a letter such as the letter from Tynan Motors, signed by Mr Tynan, the principal-

TALK.START.PARA: —A Liberal councillor on the Sutherland Shire Council.
—A Liberal councillor on the Sutherland Shire Council, I have been informed by the honourable member for Dobell. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: I would personally expect little sympathy as your policies show scant regard for the Australian small business community.

It goes on and on. These companies write to honourable members looking for sympathy and include that sort of nonsense. Quite clearly, it has been demonstrated that the fringe benefits tax will make the system far more equitable and far more efficient. I commend the Treasurer for introducing it. I say to honourable members opposite that the fact that it has taken some months to get into the House is nothing like the time it has taken for honourable members on this side to wait with bated breath to see whatever policies honourable members opposite will bring here so that we can debate them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —People listening today could be forgiven for thinking that they had tuned into an episode of Blue Hills because Labor's tax reform proposal has been one of the longest and most drawn-out sagas of recent years. This fringe benefits tax was first suggested nearly 12 months ago. It has been in the pipeline for so long that one might well ask why it is that, after nearly 12 months, the Government rushes it into the House this day and gives us barely four or five hours to discuss it. The Bill was introduced only last Friday. There are about 150 pages in the Bill. The explanatory document contains 176 pages and the guidelines 56 pages.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government talks about simplicity of taxation reforms. The joke is that the guidelines for employers includes in its first page a list of amendments to the very guidelines brought out by the Government. Frankly, I am sick and tired of the process whereby the Government spends months putting the legislation together, rules by decree in the meantime and then expects members of parliament to master this incredibly complex and bureaucratic system in just a couple of days before it slams the Bills through the House in a few hours. The Government did the same thing to veterans in May 1985 and then it made such a mess of it that we had to be hauled back to Canberra for a special one-day sitting. Then it repeated the performance with the Bill of Rights. We had one day for debate on the Bill of Rights in the House of Representatives. The Government was in a screaming hurry to rush it through and yet months later it is letting the Bill of Rights drag on in the Senate. This is no way to introduce legislation. The Government should not treat the Parliament with such contempt. I register my strong protest at the gagging of debate.

Before dealing with the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill, I want to make it quite clear that the Liberal-National coalition parties are opposed to these new taxes and will be voting against them. We want less taxes, not more taxes. Labor's so-called tax reform originated in the December 1984 election when it went to the electorate without a tax policy. Honourable members will remember that when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was asked on a Perth radio station by an interviewer about a summit he grabbed it with both hands and that became his policy. In stark contrast, we had a good policy for income splitting, child care rebates and, importantly, a cut-back in government expenditure.

So the Government went off and prepared its draft White Paper and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) went round the country flogging his consumption tax. He said that he was no shrinking violet and he would give politics away if we did not all agree with him. He would not back off at the first whiff of grapeshot. We all know what happened to the Treasurer. The Prime Minister stepped in at the last moment just like his good old Australian Council of Trade Unions days when he would drop in at the end of a strike. He put out the fires when he did a sordid deal with the trade unions in a motel room at the end of the Tax Summit. He came out with his riding instructions from Messrs Crean and Kelty to scrap the consumption tax, but to proceed with the anti-business taxes, including the capital gains tax. Do honourable members remember that one? The Government said: `There will be no capital gains tax'. Of course, we have now got that. He came out with a proposal to scrap the entertainment expenses which would throw thousands of people in the restaurant industry on to the scrap heap. We now have the fringe benefits tax proposal before us today.

The Summit was a farce. What I think annoyed the people most was that instead of talking about new taxes they should have been talking about cutting back government spending and cutting back taxes. Labor governments always like to forget one simple economic rule-if more is spent, tax has to be increased. If tax is increased, with all other things remaining constant, private savings must be decreased. The consequence of decreasing private savings is inevitably an increase in borrowings either at home or abroad, or an increase in foreign capital. In economics that is as simple as two plus two equals four.

There are also some pretty simple principles that have been broken in this proposal. The first one, which has already been mentioned, is the principle which the Government put forward as an important principle; that the proposals be simple and that people can understand them. That has gone out the window. Our system is based on the principle that income tax is paid by the recipient of the income. In this proposal it is all the wrong way around because the employer is being slugged. I suppose the reasons are obvious. The Government knows that voters do not like extra taxes, so this is an attempt to avoid the political consequences of a new tax. The other reason is that Labor is anti-business and just refuses, as the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) did just a moment ago in this House, to see the damage it is doing to business with this tax. I am sorry that the honourable member for Macarthur has disappeared after making his contribution.

The fringe benefits tax is like payroll tax-it is a penalty on employers and a discouragement to job creation. That really ought to concern the Government. It claims to be a good economic manager. The Treasurer got a prize for being the world's best Treasurer. What the Government does not tell us that the bloke who won the award the year before was the Treasurer of Mexico. What a bloke to follow. We all know where Mexico is going. Many of the jobs created under Labor-this is another thing the Government does not tell us-have been created by the Government's make-work schemes. Quite frankly, it is all a mirage. Anybody can employ people to be clowns or to dig holes in the sand, but it is no joke when the Government borrows money to pay the salaries and the long suffering taxpayer has to repay the loan with high interest rates. As an aside, let us not forget that the high borrowings are a major cause of high interest rates which are killing off businesses throughout this country and the proposals not only discourage new employment, but are also losing jobs.

The massive 26 1/2 per cent drop in total passenger vehicle sales for the first four months of 1986 is being felt in my electorate and in neighbouring areas. The results of a telephone survey tell the sad story that in the end the working man will pay for the fringe benefits tax and he will be paying the highest price of all; he will pay with his job. Of course, the Labor blokes are the politics of envy. They say: `Oh, this is just going to get the tall poppies, the managing directors who might have a Mercedes Benz'. You might get those blokes as well, but the reality is that the baby is going to go out with the bath water.
I want to draw to the attention of honourable members some of the comments coming from my electorate and neighbouring areas. The comment from Cranbourne is:
If this fringe benefits tax comes in there will be 30 per cent less dealers in Melbourne. We are down 50 per cent on sales and will be reducing our staff in order to survive.
The comment from Frankston is:
We have already reduced staff by five, which is a reduction of 15 per cent.
The comment from Mornington is:
We are operating with two staff less than normal and I am not going to replace them.
The comment from Hastings was much the same:
I will have no choice but to lay off two staff.

If that is not enough for honourable members on the other side, perhaps they should have read the newspaper last week. The Sun ran an article which told us that the third largest Mazda dealership in Victoria in Dandenong went into receivership two weeks ago. I rang the managing director and had a chat to him about it. I asked him what were the factors contributing to the company going into receivership. He gave me three factors: Firstly, Labor's deliberate policy of high interest rates. Secondly, Labor's economic mismanagement which has led to a big drop in the value of the Australian dollar and a consequent increase in the price of imported motor vehicles. Thirdly, and most relevant for today, a general downturn in the motor vehicle industry caused by the anticipated devastating effects of Labor's fringe benefits tax proposal. I spoke to the managing director of Stewart Webster Pty Ltd, an excellent firm, I might add, in Frankston and a big Ford dealer. His comments are very interesting. He said to me:

I have little doubt that my company which employs around 80 people will reduce that number by some 25-30. Already this year with the threat of the proposed legislation our business volume is down some 30 per cent. This naturally takes business from the black ink to the red and the only alternative is a continued reduction of costs.

So much for the honourable member for Macarthur saying: `This proposal has not come in yet, therefore, how can it have any effect'? The effect is out that and it is being felt by ordinary Australians as they lose their jobs as a result of this proposal. The comments of Stewart Webster and others are being reflected throughout the neighbouring electorate of Dunkley in south-east Melbourne and my electorate of Flinders. There are 24 new franchise car dealers in the electorate of Dunkley. I am sorry that the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) is not in the House today showing some interest in the prospects of people losing their jobs in his electorate. They are all experiencing a downturn of around 25 per cent in sales volume. The average number of employees per dealership, I am told, ranges from 35 to 45 employees and each dealership will have to lay off between five and eight persons. In Dunkley alone and only in new car dealers this will mean a loss of approximately 120 and 192 jobs. This does not include all the second hand car dealers or the businesses which supply parts to the motor vehicle industry. There is no doubt that hundreds will lose their jobs in the electorate of Dunkley.

In my electorate of Flinders there are 15 smaller franchise dealers and the job losses there will be no less than between two and four jobs per dealership. There are approximately 30 to 60 jobs. The total job losses in Flinders will also reach into the hundreds. This is in an area which I share with the honourable member for Dunkley which has got the third highest unemployment level in Australia. So much for Labor's concern for the ordinary working Australia. So much for its concern about employment in this country. Frankly, this proposal is a disaster for businesses, both big and small throughout Australia. It is a bureaucratic nightmare and continues Labor's attack on business. It is about time that Labor changed economic direction, put some incentive back into private enterprise and got off people's backs. I will be proud to vote against this proposal with my coalition colleagues. This proposal will throw many hard-working Australians on to the dole queues. It is about time that the Australian Labor Party woke up to itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill. I was fascinated to hear the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) refer to the plight of a Mazda dealer in his electorate, and the litany of complaints that that particular dealer made in relation to this Government. For my part, I want to make it very clear to the House and to the people of this country that I support the car industry in this country which builds motor vehicles here. I think that one of the best things that has happened in my view since this Government came to power is the fact that devaluation of the Australian dollar has meant that Australian manufacturers can once again compete on the world market. Many people have not caught up with the fact that, although the devaluation has been 20 to 30 per cent in relation to the United States dollar, the Australian dollar is in fact about 50 to 60 per cent in relation to the Japanese yen. The effect of this is that Australia's motor vehicle industry, our home grown industry, our industry that makes motor vehicles in this country, is now very much more competitive with the imported product than it was prior to this Government coming to power. As I say, I am very pleased about that.

SPEECH.PARA: I realise that that will cause some readjustments on the way through. One of those readjustments will be that less imported cars will be bought and less imported cars will be sold; nonetheless, the effect will be an overwhelming advantage for the people of this country who are employed in this country in the motor vehicle manufacturing plants of the nation. I think that that will more than offset any effects from the fringe benefits tax. A lot of the debate that has gone on so far has been a good deal of speculation about what might or might not happen. The doomsayers on the other side of the House-and I suppose it is inevitable for members of the Opposition to be doomsayers-have been predicting doom and gloom and a horrendous future for this country. I do not see it like that at all. I think that this legislation is worthwhile and long overdue.

When the Government announced its intention to reform the taxation system, a task for which those opposite did not offer any constructive support, we promised that we would produce a system which would be more equitable, fairer and more just than the one which preceded it. I believe that that is just what we are achieving through this legislation. That objective has been largely achieved now. I do not claim that every aspect of the package is ideal, but the system which we will have when the whole of the legislative package passes the Parliament represents a very great improvement than the one which is currently in place.

One of the things that we were faced with was the incredible amount of tax avoidance and evasion which had been allowed to flourish virtually unchecked by the Fraser Government. Of course, we know that those benefiting most from these practices were the friends of those opposite. We have seen the Opposition continue to attack and oppose any meaningful assault on the tax avoidance and evasion industries and, likewise, on any meaningful attempts at taxation reform. It has been unable to offer real reforms which would improve the equity and fairness of the system to catch the avoiders and evaders who rob ordinary Australians, real reforms that in any way amount to more than tinkering with an inadequate and increasingly discredited system.

The measures introduced in this part of the package, dealt with in this series of Bills will significantly improve the equity of the taxation system. Let me say at the outset that I strongly support the principles on which this legislation is based. There is no doubt that there can be no equity without bringing fringe benefits into the taxation system. There is no rational way of describing fringe benefits as other than income. Their proliferation over the past few years is a good testimony to this. As the tax system has become less and less fair, as ordinary taxpayers have been made to bear the brunt of the taxation burden while the rich avoid and evade their proper contributions to the running costs of the country, the use of fringe benefits to minimise taxable income has become far more common. However, the system still favours the well-to-do. It still promotes inequity and unfairness, and continues to allow those who can afford to pay their way and who should pay their way, to get away without paying their fair share of the taxation bill.

Anyone who has a vision of a fairer and a better Australia must support the principles on which this Bill is based. Why should workers who go to the pub for a few drinks after work to relax with their friends pay 50c in the dollar taxation on every drink of beer they have while business executives can go out for lunch, have their wine in pleasant surroundings, and get a 50c in the dollar tax rebate for doing so? Why should the ordinary worker, travelling to and from work, whether by public transport or by private car, be unable to claim the cost of that transport, while those fortunate enough to be in possession of a company owned or leased vehicle receive a tax free benefit. Why should the average Australian not be able to claim a taxation deduction on the educational expenses of his or her child while there are those for whom expensive school fees are provided as a fringe benefit, enabling them to receive extra tax free income, and their children to attend schools which give them advantages other kids do not have?

Mr Deputy Speaker, you and the House will know that I, along with my South Australian parliamentary colleagues, and the South Australian Government, sought to have the provisions regarding the fringe benefits tax on cars altered. However we did not seek to change the content of the provisions. As I have already said, I strongly support the principles on which this legislation is based. I strongly support the provisions which it introduces. What we were seeking to do was to delay and not to scrap the immediate operation of the measures as they applied to cars. I believe that, in the light of information which has been given to us by both the South Australian Government and by the car manufacturers, a phasing in period would not have been unreasonable. It was a phasing in of the provisions of this legislation as they affected the car industry that we were seeking, not their abolition. We did this because of estimates that there would be a loss of sales resulting from an immediate application of the measures. These ranged from a Treasury estimate of between 10,000 and 15,000 units through to estimated losses by the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Limited and General Motors-Holden's Limited of 40,000 units per annum. This, I might say, is out of total sales of approximately 600,000 units. I must say that I have always thought that the highest estimate was too high and was an attempt to pressure the Government into abandoning the measure entirely. However, the more realistic estimates did suggest that a phasing-in period would be useful to overcome any consumer resistance which might initially arise until the practice of the measures had been clarified. I understand, and it is interesting to note, that Mitsubishi Australia Ltd for example, estimated that the losses of sales would be approximatley only 15,000 to 20,000 units per year-far less than that claimed by the major manufacturers.

There is also a major factor which will ameliorate any possible difficulties which might face Australian car manufacturers initially: While the Australian dollar, as I mentioned, underwent a devaluation of about 30 per cent against the United States dollar, the devaluation against the Japanese yen, which has remained very strong-too strong in the opinion of most currency analysts-has been almost 60 per cent. This will inevitably lead to much weaker demand for imported Japanese cars-and of course Japanese cars form the lion's share of imported cars in this country-resulting in a transfer of demand to locally produced units. In my view, The Government must be congratulated for biting the bullet with regard to taxation reform. Honourable members opposite have been nothing short of dishonest in their approach to any reforms and particularly to any measures such as those proposed in this legislation which will make the taxation system far more equitable and much fairer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This complicated, confusing, selective and retrogressive legislation has been brought into this Parliament under false pretences. The Government, proclaiming its trite and nonsensical cry that it is a measure to catch tax avoiders, is in fact not gleaning avoided tax at all. In truth, it is imposing a savage and pernicious new tax of considerable proportions which will have most undesirable consequences and repercussions. This Government, having promised that it would bring in magnanimous tax cuts, which it now hints will be in fact less than promised, has, since the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), set about imposing a whole range of new taxes which in total are now reaching horrendous proportions. To the long list of excise increases, the abrogation of promises to pass on fuel price parity reductions, the assets test, the capital gains tax, removal of negative gearing and other measures, we now have a fringe benefits tax.

SPEECH.PARA: If and when the alleged tax cuts are legislated for, with the distinct possibility that they will be much depreciated and with the effect of the escalation in inflation, the Australian taxpayer will discover that they are or shortly will be completely negated. Although the income tax reductions will have largely dissipated, these new and vicious taxes will not only remain but also escalate. To this Government tax reform does not mean that the Australian taxpayer will have any reduction in the taxes reaped by this Government. Far from it, he will be paying considerably more. Tax reform in practice, when all the sums are done, becomes an increase in taxation and an increased harvest for this Government, already the highest taxing government in Australia's history.

I suppose that both in qualification and experience I am able to claim some authority to express a worthwhile opinion in the area of accounting and taxation practice. In examining this legislation, reading it and re-reading it, I am bound to say that it is amongst the most incomprehensible and confusing legislation that I have ever encountered. It will prove an administrative nightmare. Further, the documentation, verification and preparation of the returns required-the quarterly statements-will add a tremendous burden and cost to employers and create a nightmare for accountants.

In the area of taxation, our Income Tax Assessment Act has become so convoluted and complicated that it is long overdue for revision and rewriting. We now add to it legislation like this. This legislation, like the Income Tax Assessment Act, has become a mass of traps. We hear endlessly about alleged tax avoiders but more and more, because of the convolution and complication of our legislation in the area of taxation, ordinary taxpayers are making understandable, genuine and unintentional mistakes in the preparation of their returns. With the severity of the penalties imposed, this is a matter of concern. I have no sympathy with avoiders who get caught and are heavily penalised, but more and more I find that it is the God-fearing, honest taxpayer who, by making a simple error, is falling foul of these penalties.

This legislation now makes the situation worse and creates a new set of hazards for taxpayers and tax agents. Let us take, for instance, the section of the legislation which appertains to motor vehicles. It provides for two options. The first option-the statutory formula option-involves a mathematical formula of some complexity which, whilst being a delightfully simple calculation for the tax assessor, may in fact be the most costly in terms of tax payable for the employer. This method will apply unless the taxpayer specifically chooses the alternative option.

However, the second option, which in my view, except for the complications that I will outline, would be the most favourable in the case of heavy business use, is rendered most difficult in practice. It involves the most detailed keeping of log books, receipts, papers and documents which, surely everyone knows, are almost impossible to obtain and maintain in the busy everyday world. It involves the employer in obtaining these records by a specific date and entering into a mountain of forms and returns when the employer is already struggling under a heavy burden of costs, the Government imposes a new bundle and if he is late with his lodgment or makes some error, he is liable to incur the full range of fearsome penalties under the Income Tax Assessment Act. He has little option; his options are Hobson's choice or Buckley's choice.

Much the same confusion and problem arises with virtually every ingredient of this tax legislation. The Government, in an endeavour to prevent scrutiny of legislation which it knows is shoddy and indefensible, has guillotined the debate. We are precluded from doing what this Parliament should have the capacity to do-discuss the Bill clause by clause. If this course were taken I could readily show that not only in relation to motor vehicles, but also in relation to accommodation, living away from home, entertainment and the rest, we have inequity and confusion. The Government may curtail an opportunity to speak in this House, but it cannot and will not prevent us from exposing the legislation outside this Parliament so that it is fully understood by business and industry. The Government has not yet begun to feel the wrath and the weight of public condemnation that this legislation will bring down upon its head.

Having been denied the time to analyse in detail the deficiencies of the Bill, I turn to its disastrous consequences. The car building industry has already vocally made the Government aware of the heavy cost in sales and unemployment that will result from this legislation. The Government which made so much milage of its subsidy support and encouragement of the Australian vehicle building industry now stands exposed as the enemy and demolisher of that industry. On this aspect of the Bill alone its passage through the Senate, apparently, is far from certain.

When we look at the tax on subsidised accommodation, we see how little the Government understands or cares about development and industry in Australia. The only way in which we can mine and export our minerals in remote and difficult geographical areas is by providing expensive infrastructure and providing attractive and subsidised accommodation so that workers and their families will be prepared to go there and work. Indeed, not only in mining but also in the pastoral and agricultural industry and in services provided in remote areas, subsidised accommodation is vital. In this legislation, in one great sweep, the Government has dealt a discriminatory, vicious and disastrous blow to employers in remote areas who are battling to provide the great bulk of Australia's export income.

Instead of giving support and encouragement when our balance of trade deficits are so shocking, the Government chooses deliberately to bring about legislation which is a further penalty and a further disincentive. In its mad scramble to wring out more and more tax dollars from the reeling taxpayer, the Government has lost all touch with reality. Australia's airlines will be faced with an additional tax bill in excess of $11m-Qantas Airways Ltd, $6m; Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans Australia Airlines, each $2m; and East West Airlines Ltd, about $600,000. The airlines have expressed the hope that fares will not have to increase to meet the tax and that it can be met out of profits. But, if not immediately, certainly in the near future it will be a substantial factor in increased fares.

Indeed, this will not apply only to air fares. As business generally has to accommodate the extra imposts of fringe benefit taxation, it is certain that prices will have to increase over a whole range of products. Certainly the rural sector, reeling under the harsh treatment of this anti-rural Government and falling prices, will not be able in many instances to cope with this new tax. The Government should know the situation in the country where employee or share farmer accommodation just has to be provided and, in addition, certain other provisions, such as electricity and food, must form part of the package if the farmer is to find farm hands. Now, of course, the primary producer is being hit again and he has no capacity to increase his prices. Nor is the situation met or adequately covered under the remote area provisions.

Let us see what a typical businessman faces at the hands of this Government. He has to prepare his accounts and complete his normal income tax returns. He has to prepare on time and lodge each month his sales tax returns. He has to be the local branch of the Australian Taxation Office as the calculator, collector and remitter of pay as you earn instalments for each employee. He has to compile and forward workers compensation returns. In all probability he has to provide, at great inconvenience, returns of various kinds for the Australian Statistician. Now he has the formidable task of collecting documents and lodging quarterly fringe benefit returns. When we add to this his company returns and other paperwork he might have to lodge, we wonder when he can attend to his business and produce anything. Business is being suffocated under taxation, regulation and paperwork for this Government. The cost of all these bureaucratic demands is massive. Where is the incentive to produce, to expand and to provide employment? Is it any wonder that Australian business and industry are in a state of desperation and despair?

TALK.START.PARA: —Strangled by red tape.

—Yes, strangled by red tape. On top of that, to hear Government speaker after Government speaker proclaiming inanely that this is all designed to catch tax cheats is an added insult. They know, we know and the Government knows that that is not the case. A brand new milking cow has been added to the herd to produce more revenue for the Government-nothing more, nothing less.

SPEECH.PARA: I oppose this legislation. It destroys incentive. It is completely regressive and, like payroll tax, the fringe benefits tax is an iniquitous tax which bears no relation to profitability. It is a heavy tax on business, whether it be profitable or not. Even a business in a loss situation will not escape this tax. How the Government can justify that escapes all comprehension. How the Government can fail to understand that this will cost jobs boggles the mind. How the Government can have the effrontery to call this tax reform must certainly confound us all. Together with the assets test, which is nothing more than persecution of pensioners and the elderly, and the capital gains tax, this tax will be absolutely opposed and shortly, when the people of Australia dismiss this Government, these inequitable taxation propositions must be reversed and abolished. I will not cease while ever I am in this Parliament to pursue that objective.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann) I think we got a fair summary of the Opposition's case in opposing the fringe benefits tax legislation. I do not know whether it is deliberate or sheer ignorance or perhaps selective myopia on tax matters on the part of the Opposition that it has misunderstood the whole role and purpose of this tax. It will certainly mean a lower tax for some people. Those people who have been paying too great a burden because of tax avoidance will now have a lesser load, because those who were avoiding it will have to meet their fair share of tax. This legislation will increase tax on others-the tax cheats and the tax avoiders.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us not hear the same old tired story that total tax is to increase. This tax is not a milch cow, as mentioned by the honourable member for Fairfax. It is a measure to restore equity into the tax system. The honourable member for Fairfax said that the income tax laws are convoluted and complicated. All I can say is: Whose fault is that? For the majority of the time since the Second World War the parties of honourable members opposite have been in government. Their people made the law more convoluted and more complicated and they still have not come to grips with and dealt with the basic defects of the income tax law.

This legislation does not amend the income tax laws; it proposes a separate tax. I will say more about that later. The line from the honourable member for Fairfax that really got to me was this one: `I have no sympathy for tax avoiders who get caught'. That is what he said. The natural corollary to that statement must be that he has admiration for those who, over the years, have got away with it. This Government will bring about an end to the rorts. There will be no admiration for the tax cheats, the tax dodgers and the tax avoiders. We will bring down legislation that will make them pay their fair burden of tax as do the honest people, for whom this Government certainly has admiration.

The Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill and cognate Bills are part of a package designed to reform the Australian taxation system which, under the previous Government, became totally distorted and inequitable-far better words than `convoluted and complicated' used by the previous speaker. This legislation is part of a package which will root out tax avoidance and evasion practices. It is part of a package which will attack a tax system in which the public confidence has been seriously eroded and which caused a heavier tax load to be borne by honest and lower paid taxpayers. It will restore revenue, the loss of which also deprived the community of essential and important public programs in the government sector.

The attack on tax avoidance has allowed the Government actually to ease the marginal rates of tax on taxpayers, which in turn will discourage tax evasion as taxpayers regain confidence in the tax system and do not resort to lurks to avoid what they consider are excess marginal rates of tax. This Government is doing something about that. More importantly, the principles upon which the fringe benefits tax is based are the principles of equity in the tax system. The two basic and cardinal principles of taxation are those of horizontal equity and vertical equity. The principle of horizontal equity requires that taxpayers with the same net taxable income bear the same tax burden. With all the packages that have been offered with agreement and collusion between the employers and the employees, people with the same effective income have not been bearing the same tax burden. In other words, horizontal equity went out the window under the Opposition.

Vertical equity requires that a taxpayer who receives more taxable income than another taxpayer pay more tax than that other person. We find that the higher income earners-those who are more likely to receive the remuneration packages involving a small percentage of taxable income and a large percentage of, until now, tax-free fringe benefits; those people at the higher level of the corporate structure who are going up the ladder of success-are the people who have been paying the least tax and that those on lower incomes have had to bear the burden of paying the highest rates of income tax. In other words, under the Opposition when it was in government the basic principle of vertical equity went out the window as well. These Bills deal head on with a major ruse used by some taxpayers to avoid paying their fair share of tax. As I have said, there was often deliberate collusion to cheat the community out of revenue which should have been extracted from those people. It was collusion against the citizens of this nation so that essential programs relating to child care, education, transport and so on could not be put into place.

When I was, in an earlier period, a member of a previous government we attempted to take head on the matter of taxing fringe benefits. I want to quote very briefly an extract from the 1974-75 Budget Speech of the then Treasurer, Frank Crean. Speaking about fringe benefits, he said:

In practice, it has proved difficult to enforce general provisions of the income tax law on the value of some benefits given to employees in addition to their remuneration. Accordingly, amendments to ensure that certain fringe benefits are properly subject to income tax are proposed to apply as from the 1974-75 income year.
Deductions will cease to be allowable for expenditures on club dues, yachts and other boats, etc.
That is the sort of thing we are debating here today. Mr Crean went on:
The minimum assessable value to a taxpayer of the use of a motor vehicle provided by his employer will be determined under a formula to be prescribed in the law.

I supported then in this House those attempts to introduce a fringe benefits tax as part of the income tax law. I stand willingly behind this Government in strong support of the new approach to the taxation of fringe benefits. When the Opposition was in government it knew about these lurks. As the honourable member for Fairfax said, he had no sympathy for those who were caught, but obviously the collusion to cheat the nation of the properly assessable income tax base went beyond the employer and the employee and extended to the previous Government. That Government had no courage to tackle the problem. It threw it in the too hard basket.

What has been happening is that the employer, instead of paying a salary sufficient to pay for all these benefits, appeared to be the good guy. The employer, at the expense of honest taxpayers, was appearing to be a beneficiary to his employees, to be paying special regard to his employees, by supplying entertainment allowances, motor cars, free travel, subsidised interest rates and housing. Not once was it ever admitted by the good guys, in collusion with the Opposition when in government, and not once did it ever cause them any guilt, that those benefits were provided not because of the generosity of the employer but largely at the expense of the honest taxpayers-the lower income earners in this country.

Now the rort is over. I expect that that will bring some relief to some employees. It has been said to me on more than one occasion that some of them feel locked into their jobs and feel that, if they were to stand up to the boss and express an opinion or even if they wished to change jobs, rather than being able to claim a total portable income they would lose their fringe benefits because they might not be available from another employer. They might lose their cars or have to renegotiate their home loans. With all these benefits they felt shackled to their jobs. In the end they would deny their progress up the corporate ladder or the ladder of success and they would not change their jobs. I expect there will be some relief amongst employees as a result of this new approach where the employer is taxed and the fringe benefits are changed in their mix. I think we will find that this will be readily accepted, not only as a matter of tax equity, but also as a matter of practicality and choice for the employer.

This Government has decided that the fringe benefits tax will be imposed on the employer on the taxable value of the fringe benefit. The honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann) said that this would be an accountant's nightmare. That is not so. It will be a very simple operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you read this book?

—I have read the book as the honourable member for Bradfield knows full well. I have studied it carefully and I suggest the motive behind his question is that he wants me to explain what is in it. I will do so because he certainly seems not to have read it. After calculating the effective value of the fringe benefit to the employees, the employer will add these up throughout the company structure, multiply the total by 46c in the dollar in the first instance and 49c later and pay it on a quarterly basis. The point is that it was administratively impossible under section 26c of the Income Tax Assessment Act to calculate the value of a fringe benefit to the employee. That is where previous efforts by Labor governments foundered and that is where any efforts to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act would have foundered. In this case we are able to make it administratively simple. Perhaps it is a second best approach, but it is a sensible alternative which will restore equity to the tax base and overcome the problem of amending the Income Tax Assessment Act.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude with one comment about the motor car industry. Unfortunately in 1975 the Labor Government had to repeal the fringe benefits provision on motor cars. It was said at the time that this was done to assist the motor car industry. The Hon. Frank Stewart, who was Minister at the time, made that point in his speech when he presented the measure to the House. However, looking back we find that this did nothing to mitigate the major factors that impact on the motor car industry. In this sense we are talking about macroeconomic activity, the competition from imports and so on. That position is unchanged today. Let us not have bleating from the Opposition that this fringe benefits tax has caused the decline from the ultra high peak figures of car sales. Opposition members must look beyond that and realise what the true effects are. Let us not have that sort of bleating. The fringe benefits tax will restore equity to the income tax base. I stood behind it in 1974-75, I have much pleasure in standing behind those principles today and the Government's efforts with this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has anyone ever heard of a Labor Government reducing tax? If a Labor government gives with one hand it always takes away with the other. The Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill, which we are debating today, is one of the most complex pieces of taxation law ever introduced into this Parliament. It is 150 pages of convoluted information which may be understood by some tax experts and accountants, but which will be an absolute disaster for the thousands of employers, big and small, across Australia who, under this law, will be held accountable for ensuring that all the fringe benefits, so-called, given to their employees will be taxable under this legislation. The Bill has missed nothing. It covers the provision of motor cars, interest free or low interest loans, the waiver of debts, the payment of private expenses, free or subsidised residential accommodation, excessive living away from home allowances, free or subsidised board, concessional airline fares, entertainment for tax exempt bodies, free or discounted goods or other property, free or discounted services and other specified benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: All this will come into effect on 1 July 1986. From that day onwards employers will be expected on a quarterly basis to provide substantial information to the Australian Taxation Office within a period of 28 days. Should they fail they will be liable to the consequences under the Act. We have been told by numerous speakers on the Government side that in this debate the Opposition merely talks `emotive junk'. We have been told that Australia must have a fair taxation system and that there must be equity in that system. We were told by the last speaker, the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb), that the `rort is over'. Is it a rort that the average farmer in Australia, on an income-according to the Bureau of Agricultural Economics-of around $6,700 a year, gives to his employees free meat and vegetables, or the use of the farm car on occasions? Those same employees of that farmer will in many cases probably earn more than their employer, but often they live in difficult conditions far away from towns and cities where most Australians live. Those people are now being told that because they have those relatively simple benefits of service and a small indication of the regard that the employer may have for them, they are `rorting' the system-the word that Government speakers have used. I hope that they will be able to account for that because there are thousands of Australian workers-in fact I would go as far as to say the vast majority of the employed population of this land-who, one way or another, are rorting the system, according to this Government. If one works for a factory it has always been traditional that one should have access to the product of one's work at a discount. Under the proposal contained in this legislation that discount will be taken into account for tax purposes. It will not be levied on the employee but it will be levied on the employer. The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), who is at the table, should know this, because he ran a butcher's shop. I have not the slightest doubt that in his business of selling meat he probably offered his employees the facility of being able to buy cheaper meat.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a very generous person. They will still get it and I will pay the tax.

—I am delighted to know the Minister is generous and I hope he will be willing to pay his additional tax as a result. The fact is that there are many employers, especially in the rural sector today, who do not have excess money. They are fighting to keep their families on the land. But this Government says to them: `That does not matter; if you are giving free meat to your employees or any other facility whatsoever, of course that is taxable and you will pay for it'. It is extraordinary that this Hawke Labor Government in its convoluted political logic-that looks after the interests of us all, so we are told, that runs policies on the basis of compassion, concern and that glorious word consensus-ignores the fact that the vast majority of the work force will be affected by this Bill. It tells us that some people are involved in rorts-the people who drive around in Mercedes cars, the people who have facilities supplied to them by their employers often to help them to do their jobs better. They are all rorting the system.

SPEECH.PARA: As my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) has demonstrated, the losses to the car industry alone, because of the effects of this new tax, are estimated to be at least 7,000 jobs. Clearly the statistics available to members and others already show a steady reduction in company car sales. Let there be no doubt about it, we are not talking about a simple rearrangement of the tax laws, we are talking about a brand new tax. It is a tax which will affect directly or indirectly virtually every member of the entire working population of Australia.

The Treasurer has told us that revenue gains from the new tax will be $330m in 1986-87, $540m in 1987-88 and $625m in 1988-89. As the honourable member for Mackellar has pointed out, in the area of the car industry alone, whereas the Government believed it would obtain a tax advantage of some $350m, it has been anticipated by the industry, the Premier of South Australia, various other research organisations and the Department of Industry and Commerce itself that in fact the net revenue gain will be lucky to reach $49m. We know, and the Government should know, that the car industry is one of the cornerstones of Australia's manufacturing industry. Any change in the balance of tax must, therefore, cause serious impacts on production and sales as well as employment. It is not just employment in the manufacture of vehicles-it is employment in the provision of spare parts; it is employment in sales; and it is employment in the support industries which are so dependent on the car industry. We already know that in many cases there has been a reduction of sales of up to 25 per cent. Yet, apparently this Government prefers to ignore that fact.

When the honourable member for Streeton was making his observations, I noted that every employer in Australia very soon will be receiving a purple booklet called `Fringe Benefits Tax-a guide for employers'. It is 56 pages of highly complex matter. The extraordinary thing is that we are told by the previous speaker, and by some of his other colleagues, that the Commissioner of Taxation was not able to apply the law as it stood. The honourable member knows, and all honourable members of this House ought to know, that the law as it stood provided that all benefits, direct or indirect, could be considered as part of taxable income. But the onus rested on the Commissioner of Taxation to determine if and when he would apply that tax. If the Commissioner now says to the Government, as he apparently has, `it is all too complicated, I cannot do it, you have to change the law', it makes us question very seriously the administrative basis upon which this Government has been prepared to make decisions of this nature.

We have been told by this Government of its intention to reduce regulation. It even established a regulation review unit. That unit came out with a report early this year which showed that last January at least 16,430 public servants were engaged in regulating business. Of course, that also includes the regulation of taxation. The Confederation of Australian Industry has estimated that government regulation is employing approximately 54,500 people in the private sector. Quite obviously the Government does support this growth industry. It appears to be the only growth industry that we have in the entire country. If those figures are to be accepted-and I do accept them; they are from legitimate and appropriate sources-it is quite clear that the Government is prepared, yet again, to increase the administrative load on the private sector, the very people whose income generating capacity is at the basis of this Government's capacity to run a range of programs in the social welfare and other areas which it regards as necessary to its commitment to the Australian electorate.

The fact of the matter is that time is running out. There is a limit to how long any government can continually take from those whose role it is to produce, in a desperate effort to give to those who, for whatever reason, are not necessarily able to do so and maybe in need.
