There is not the slightest doubt that complex legislation such as this will make it so much more difficult for the private sector to be able to put its resources into useful productive activity rather than having to spend more time in that constant daily paper war which has now been forced upon it by governments, both State and Federal, through policies such as this. Why do employers have to do the job of government in collecting pay as you earn tax, sales tax, pay roll tax, et cetera? Has this Government ever suggested that it is going to give a discount on taxation to employers because of the massive subsidy they are in fact giving to the public sector at both the Federal and State levels? Of course not. There is the constant belief that one can wring from the private sector more tax irrespective of profitability and productivity and institute more administrative costs of this nature.

Fringe benefits have been brought in over the years because the marginal rates of tax are too high. There has been no incentive to work. As I said, the majority of employees will be ultimately paying higher marginal rates of tax as a result of the government's tax package and what we are seeing going through the House today. The Government does not have the slightest reason to be satisfied with its achievement. It is merely saddling the private sector yet again with a range of administrative requirements which will be so much more difficult to carry. As I said, has anyone ever heard of a Labor government reducing tax? Labor governments may play with the system but ultimately the level of tax on us all goes up and never down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly I would like to take up a number of points raised by my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). The honourable member criticised the Government for introducing this tax package on the grounds that the private sector would have to reduce its useful productive activity. I submit to members of the House that until the introduction of this tax reform package, of which the fringe benefits tax is a part, the private sector was spending an enormous amount of its time and resources trying to work out ways of avoiding paying tax. It was absolutely disgraceful that the resources of this country should have gone into looking at ways in which tax could be avoided. We would have seen a much more booming Australian economy today if all of that activity had been directed towards creative and effective work.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Bradfield failed to point out that the reason the Government has introduced this fringe benefits tax is not just for equity reasons, which I will talk about later, but to reform the marginal tax rates. It was absolutely ridiculous and unfair that certain members of the community were able to get the benefit of fringe benefits while others were not. The honourable member said that people were using fringe benefits simply because the marginal tax rates were too high. How can we bring marginal tax rates down unless we look at the eroded tax basis? We cannot get the money out of thin air. That is where the Opposition is failing totally in this debate. It is important that government supporters listen to the relevant points raised by the Opposition. But how can we accept those points when the Opposition's whole basis is one of rejecting the fringe benefits tax, changing the marginal tax rates and spending more money on its airy-fairy proposals. The Opposition is being absolutely irresponsible. The electorate is going to ask all honourable members opposite: Where is the money going to come from? One just cannot stand up in this House, and on the one hand, say `oppose the fringe benefits tax, oppose this tax, oppose that tax', and then, on the other hand, say `we still believe that you have to change marginal tax rates, we still believe you have to have tax deductibility for child care and we still believe that you can spend more and more money'. The Opposition has to learn that, basically, this money is not going to come out of thin air. The Government had to go through the exercise of learning that. It was a sad experience at times for us when we were in government before. But we have learned that. We are economically responsible, and that is the basis for this legislation.

The Opposition would lead us to believe that the Government is unique in introducing a tax such as the one now before the House, that we were the first people in the world who had ever thought about it. It is illuminating to consider the tax reform exercise in the international setting. The perspective addressed in a recent paper by a noted British tax economist, John Kay, sets it in this international perspective. He compared the recommendations of tax reform inquiries in the United States of America, Canada, the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Ireland and Australia. Kay finds the reports to be strikingly similar in the broad thrust of their recommendations. He illustrates this by focusing on several main areas, including choice of tax base, treatment of fringe benefits and rate structures. I will not go into all of those at the moment, except to refer to the fringe benefits, which is the basis of this legislation. In relation to fringe benefits Kay observed:
. . . there is no subject on which there is such clear agreement-

There have been lots of inquiries into taxation. Even we have had our fair share of such inquiries over the years. All of the inquiries which have been undertaken show that there is no subject on which there is such clear agreement as the subject of fringe benefits taxation. All of these inquiries have argued strongly for the more effective taxation of this form of income. That is not to say that the recommendations of these inquiries have been adopted by all the respective governments. Taxation of fringe benefits, both overseas and in Australia, has proved to be administratively difficult and politically sensitive. I am not arguing that that is not the case. It is difficult for a government to bring in such a tax. As all of us will admit, it is administratively difficult. However, it is important that we recognise that everyone who is serious about tax reforms believes that this is the only way to go.

Australia is not the only country to have made major moves in this direction. Recently New Zealand has taken decisive action. Its employer tax on non-cash benefits, which has applied since 1984, has served in large measure as the model for what Australia has decided to do. There we have it. There is world-wide agreement from tax experts that this tax is important for any government seriously looking at tax reform. That is what we as a government have been addressing since we were re-elected. That is the mandate we had when we were re-elected by the people of this country. I think it is appalling that with the mandate we have from the people of this country there is still talk of blocking this legislation in the Senate. I think that is an absolute disgrace to the democracy we have in this country. Fringe benefits are exploding. They are having a very damaging effect on revenue, marginal tax rates and horizontal and vertical equity and efficiency. That is why we have had to proceed with a tax on fringe benefits. As I said, no government wants to bring in legislation such as this which is administratively difficult unless it has to do it. We have not got a choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, there is.

—We have not got a choice. If we want to return to the people in this country a truly reformed system of taxation and if we want to reform their marginal tax rates, we do not have a choice. Where else will we get the money from? That is the question the Opposition is not prepared to address. Until the Opposition is prepared to address that, we really cannot take the comments and contributions of honourable members opposite seriously.

SPEECH.PARA: The extent and the range of fringe benefits have grown significantly in Australia in recent years. The available data indicates also that individuals higher up the income scale have received a wide range of fringe benefits and enjoy them at more generous levels. The honourable member for Bradfield in his speech said that all Australian wage and salary earners-the entire working population-will suffer because of this fringe benefits tax. If I went out the front door of Parliament House and did a survey amongst people outside or surveyed people in the public gallery and asked them whether they thought they were going to suffer because of the fringe benefits tax, I bet that we would not find 100 per cent of those people returning a yes to that question. I think that we would find that in fact the great majority have not been benefiting from fringe benefits. What has happened as a result is that such people have been paying more marginal tax. They have not been able to indulge in fringe benefits. For example, 68 per cent of my constituents who are in the work force are public servants. They have not been able to indulge in fringe benefits. What have they been doing instead? They have had to pay high marginal tax rates. That is why this reform is necessary. It is necessary if we are going to restore any sense of equity to the tax system.

Once we establish that as our argument it is a question not of whether one taxes such people, but how one goes about it. The situation has got completely out of hand. Cash salaries have become a smaller and smaller component of the remuneration package. No honourable member in this House, even from the Opposition, could deny that fact. In the private sector virtually no wage or salary package over $30,000 was being negotiated without a motor vehicle being thrown in. Usually, lots of other things went with it. The effects of these fringe benefits have become serious to the point of being intolerable for our tax system. The personal income tax base has been totally eroded at an accelerated rate. That is the other problem. The situation was not just bad; it is getting worse. It has been getting worse every month, every year. Who pays for it? The poor old wage and salary earner has to dish it out once again. That situation cannot continue.

That component was forcing marginal tax rates up. All that was left was for people to pay more and more tax-a 60 per cent marginal tax rate on 1.5 times average weekly earnings. We could not let that sort of situation continue. It was inefficient. It led to an over-consumption of tax free perks, such as the provision of cars, entertainment expenses, low interest rates and paid holidays. Most of all, that situation was grossly unfair. Tax free perks were not equally available to all-as I said, especially to my constituents. More generally, the blatant non-taxation of perks and their unequal availability had the insidious effect of reducing respect for our tax system and bringing our tax laws into disrepute.

The honourable member for Bradfield argued that we had the legislation anyway so why could we not just insist on the current legislation being enforced. However, the Australian history of this has been absolutely miserable. The Whitlam Government had a humiliating backdown on the subject of motor vehicles in 1974. The current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) had an even more humiliating backdown in regard to miners' housing in 1981. More generally around the world the history of attempting to tax fringe benefits in employees' hands has been a very miserable one. Therefore, the tax is being levied on the employer.

Some people have argued that it is inequitable to tax the employer since the benefit is received by the employee. While there is something in that argument, it must be recognised that the rapid growth in fringe benefits as part of remuneration packages has involved benefits to employers as well as to employees, at the expense of other taxpayers. Obviously, it is not possible to determine exactly how this benefit has been divided between the employers and the employees. However, to the extent that employers have benefited from lower gross labour costs, there is a case for them to bear a proportion of this tax. I believe that the legislation before the House will do a great deal to impair the eroded tax base-the inequitable situation that has existed in this country till today and that has been getting worse every day. This has to be seen as part of a tax reform package to bring about a fairer, more equitable tax system which will result from changing the marginal tax base. I recommend this legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the National Taxation Summit Conference the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced the nine principles to be followed in any tax reform measures. The fourth of these principles stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . any reform must lead to a simpler system, which therefore all Australians can understand more easily-
The eighth principle announced by the Prime Minister stated:
. . . any reform must provide the best possible climate for investment, growth and employment in Australia.

In relation to these two principles, as well as any other sensible taxation principles, the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill and cognate Bills are a failure. Firstly, in regard to the principle that taxation legislation should be simpler and more easily understood, let us look at the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill. The Bill itself consists of 139 pages. When we look at the explanatory memorandum put out by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to accompany the Bill we see that it is 176 pages long. We see that the little tax- ation guide for employers is 56 pages long-56 pages which are extremely complex and very difficult to understand without careful study. Certainly, by any measure, this is not a simple tax. Certainly, it is not easily understood.

I would like to emphasise the point to which the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) alluded, which is that the fringe benefits tax is a tax on employers. It represents a very significant precedent. It is a very interesting principle. This Government believes that one person should be responsible for another person's tax. I wonder how long it will be before the bosses of this Government in the Australian Council of Trade Unions suggest to the Government: `If you are going to start handing over some of our taxes for the employers to pay, why don't you give them the lot and in future, when we look for a pay rise, it will be purely on the basis of what the amount is after tax? Any taxes that you want to levy will be the problem of the employers'. I suggest that, having regard to that principle, the fringe benefits tax is a failure.

When we talk about what should be simple and what is not, let us look at what it will cost employers to comply with the tax. In regard to record keeping, anyone who looks at the complex formula and suggestion of how someone will keep log books for cars will see that it is not simple; it is complicated. It is difficult to understand and I am sure it will be very difficult to comply with. We then look at the problems that will be caused by the cost to businesses of complying with it. I spoke to a fairly senior accountant about this. He suggested to me that an average business could be looking at at least an extra 10 per cent in accountancy fees in order to comply with this legislation. Worse still, businesses are faced with this very complex bit of legislation coming into effect in about seven weeks' time. On any measure of simplicity, this new tax has failed.

The other principle that I mentioned and that the Prime Minister was so keen to talk about was the creation of the best climate for investment, growth and employment. Again, I suggest that the fringe benefits tax has failed. An additional tax will be levied on employers. Employers will sink into a mire of paperwork in trying to comply with a very complex bit of legislation. If that will not discourage employment, I would like to know what will. So, on that measure talked about by the Prime Minister the tax has also failed. I also remind honourable members that all of this extra effort in complying with this tax is unproductive effort. It will contribute nothing to the betterment of this nation. I suggest to honourable members that, in regard to those two criteria that the Prime Minister put forward before the Tax Summit, this tax legislation is a failure.

I also ask honourable members to consider why we really need this tax. Why is the Government so keen to bring in this tax? The reason is that it feels that people are getting around the tax system by way of fringe benefits. I draw the attention of honourable members to section 26 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which states:
The assessable income of a taxpayer shall include-

(e) the value to the taxpayer of all allowances, gratuities, compensations, benefits, bonuses and premiums allowed, given or granted to him in respect of, or for or in relation directly or indirectly to, any employment of or services rendered by him, whether so allowed, given or granted in money, goods, land, meals, sustenance, the use of premises or quarters or otherwise . . .

That spells out very clearly that already in the Act it is quite clear that, where those benefits are considered to be part of the remuneration of an employee, they are taxable. It is in the Act. What has happened? It is quite clear that over some years, starting, I suggest, at about the time of the Whitlam Government, fringe benefits became an accepted form of remuneration on which tax would not be paid. This question arises: Why has this been allowed to happen? Obviously, it has been allowed to happen because successive governments have not insisted on the law being properly applied. It is quite clear that, had this law been properly applied, this tax legislation that is being debated today would not be necessary.

I ask the Government: If it already has in place a law to tax fringe benefits, why is it not being applied? The answer is quite simple. If the Government were serious about this, it would be applying the law as it exists today. But the Government has seen an easy way out by putting the onus back on employers, by putting the responsibility back on employers, by making employers additional tax collectors. It is an easy way out. Obviously, the Government believes that by doing this, rather than doing the job that it was elected to do and enforcing the law as it exists today, it will hurt the employer.

It is interesting to look at the question of enforcing the law. During an inquiry held earlier this year by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, the Director of Public Prosecutions was questioned to see what was his response on the question of enforcing the laws. This question was put to him by one of the members of the Committee:
Some people have said that the only reason you can now operate and users of the bottom of the harbour schemes can be prosecuted is that the law was changed.
Mr Temby's answer is very illuminating. He said:
That is simply wrong. The charges which have been laid-
this is referring to the bottom of the harbour schemes-
are charges which were always available. If there were any charges under the new legislation-
what is called the uncollected company tax legislation-
they are few.

In other words, the Director of Public Prosecutions is saying: `Of course, under the law, tax evasion is a crime and under the Crimes Act we can enforce the law anyway, without having new legislation'. This legislation, comprising 139 pages, is extremely complicated. It puts on one person the responsibility to pay another person's tax. I suggest to honourable members that this is a bad tax. It is something that is unnecessary. If the Government were doing its job in the first place it would not even need to introduce it.

Some aspects of the fringe benefits tax, in regard to its effect on the Public Service, are remarkable. The Government has suggested that this tax will have to be imposed on all employers. Obviously, the Public Service is seen as an employer. But, when one looks at it, the Public Service effectively will be exempt. What the Government will do is to create two classes of employers. Business will have to find the money for this tax, but in regard to the Public Service there will be a bit of paper shuffling. While employers will be faced with the unpalatable choice of either reducing employment or reducing investment, or coming to some arrangement with their employees as to how they will change their tax package, in the case of the Public Service, of course, this will not be necessary. We will have two classes of employers.

All that the Public Service will have to do is take money out of one pocket and put it in another. No doubt, each department will go to the Treasury and say: `We will have to pay you the fringe benefits tax, so will you give us more money?' It is a great show, is it not? The department will get another allocation from the Treasurer in order to pay it back to the Treasury. I guess this will create a few unproductive jobs. It will require a lot of paperwork. Apart from that, it will not cost the Public Service anything.

I wonder what will be the effect on the State governments and, of course, local government. Will this Government increase the allocation of funds to State governments to cover the cost of the fringe benefits tax? Will it increase the allocation to local government to cover the cost of complying with this tax? These are the sorts of questions that the Government should be looking at. In regard to Commonwealth public servants-I am not sure about others-there will be a privileged group of employees to whom fringe benefits will remain available. Obviously, they will not be available to others.

As time is limited, I say in conclusion that the fringe benefits tax is a bad tax. It is an unnecessary tax. There is already provision in section 26 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. This legislation creates a very dangerous principle because it imposes a tax on employers for a benefit that is enjoyed by employees. One person will be paying another person's tax. It will be incredibly complicated and extremely difficult to comply with and employers will find the bookkeeping very complex. Obviously, it will lead to a diversion of productive resources into a very unproductive area. I am pleased to say without any hesitation that I will oppose this tax and oppose it on every occasion. I think that the views of the Opposition are quite clear. We are totally opposed to this tax and we will vote against it here and in the other place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This set of measures is part of the Government's overall tax reform package, the central element of which is to seek to repair and to broaden the personal income tax base. The fact is that there is not the slightest doubt that as a consequence of, amongst other things, the abuse of fringe benefits the personal income tax base has been substantially eroded in recent years. I will not go over the various statistics set out comprehensively in the White Paper; they need no repetition. Early in the piece I would like to refer to the previous speaker's contribution that the existing section 26 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act is sufficient legislative basis for the taxing of fringe benefits. There is a certain inconsistency in that argument. On the one hand, he is bemoaning the enormous costs and compliance problems involved in the tax laws that are proposed, and, on the other hand, he is saying that the existing laws ought to be rigorously enforced. This particular option was canvassed in the White Paper and the fact is that it is simply not a practical option for a variety of reasons. Perhaps I could quote from the White Paper, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The income tax law provides for the taxing of other fringe benefits under a general comprehensive provision (section 26 (e)) that requires the value to the taxpayer of all allowances, gratuities, benefits or bonuses (whether received in cash or in kind) related to employment to be included in assessable income. Despite the comprehensive coverage of section 26 (e), the taxation of benefits which do not take the form of outright cash payments (and of some which do) poses practical difficulties. For non-cash benefits, there is a difficult question in each case, for taxpayer and tax administrator alike, of determining the value to the taxpayer of the benefit provided. These difficulties have led to almost universal non-inclusion by employees of fringe benefits received in kind; effective policing of non-compliance in this area would require a heavy investment of resources. In practice, therefore, many of the benefits that ought properly to be subjected to tax escape taxation in part or in whole. Because section 26 (e) is concerned with benefits granted to employees, there are also difficulties in bringing to tax the value of fringe benefits which are formally conferred on family members of the employee (eg an airline ticket provided to the spouse of an employee).
It is fairly obvious that there are major difficulties in enforcing the existing law. The recommendation section of the White Paper, dealing with this matter, concludes:
To quote Canada's Carter Commission, it would need `an army of assessors and a battery of courts' to apply the existing law effectively. An alternative approach is therefore called for.

The argument of the previous speaker that the existing law is adequate is both internally inconsistent and simply wrong and fails to take account of well-documented deficiencies in the existing law. That has, of course, all been part of the general debate which he has apparently seen fit to ignore.

The measures we are talking about here are those whose fiscal impact is very substantial. It is amongst the largest fiscal impacts of any of the measures to be introduced in the Government's tax reform package. I will cite the relevant figures of the revenue expected to be gained from the introduction of these Bills: $330m for 1986-7; $540m for 1987-8; and $625m for 1988-89. That gives us an indication of the haemorrhaging of revenue that has taken place as a result of the abuse of fringe benefits. That gives an indication of the extra revenue we expect to gain by closing off those abused mechanisms.

The measures are justified on a variety of grounds relating to both equity and efficiency considerations. It is a well-known fact that in recent times there has been an increasing tendency for remuneration packages to executives, particularly highly paid ones, to include a very substantial component of non-cash fringe benefits and cash fringe benefits in the case of allowances. The fact is that a number of surveys have indicated that predominantly the benefits of that arrangement or situation go to the higher income people to a disproportionate degree. That fact is documented in appendix 8A of the White Paper which sets out a series of tables showing clearly that the higher one goes up the income scale the greater the value of the fringe benefits received and the greater the proportion of the total remuneration package that consists of non-cash fringe benefits. That general point is confirmed in the most recent Chandler and MacLeod salary package survey reported in the Australian Financial Review of 18 November 1985. That survey was based on a seven-part categorisation of executive salary packages ranging from grade 1, which covers people in the age range from 21 to 25 years in the first five years of business management, right up to the top level, grade 7, which refers to chief executives of large corpor-ations. Apart from confirming the general point that the higher one goes the bigger the relative and absolute benefit from fringe benefits, it shows how the value of the same type of fringe benefit varies markedly as one moves up the salary scale. In other words, not only does one gain access to additional types of fringe benefits as one moves up, but the value of these fringe benefits becomes enlarged. In the case of cars, which is a very widespread benefit, the Chandler and MacLeod survey says:

In terms of effect on the real incomes of Australian executives and the cost of fringe benefits for Australian companies, the proposed changes in taxation arrangements applying to company cars are the most significant portion of the entire set of measures.

The whole area of company cars is a tremendously significant part of the fringe benefit problem and clearly one that had to be addressed. It is worth making that point in the context of current pressures to dilute the Government's proposals. I believe that the impact on the car industry is overstated. Part of the argument is distorted by a focus on aggregate sales figures or aggregate registration figures which, of course, take account of both locally manufactured cars and imports. We can expect to see, as the devaluation starts to bite, that any adverse tendency will be significantly offset by the benefits flowing from the devaluation.

To get back to what I was saying earlier, the average cost of a car benefit ranges from $6,272 a year for grade 3-which is the middle level executive-through to $16,293 for grade 6 and $16,926 for grade 7, which roughly corresponds to the chief executive of a major company. I cite those figures to illustrate the point that the same type of fringe benefit, a car, is a significantly greater addition to effective income for somebody at the top end than for somebody down at the bottom. That underlines the regressive impact of the non-taxation of fringe benefits and underlines the beneficial effects, at least from where I stand politically, on income distribution of including those things within the tax base.

In theory it would be better to tax fringe benefits in the hands of individual employees at their respective marginal rate. The extent to which we do not do that means some deviation from an ideal incidence of the tax in terms of its distribution. Of course, as we know, there are tremendous practical difficulties in going down that track. The requirement for each employee to comply with the law is a very major difficulty. It is a considerably greater difficulty than if the tax is levied at the company level rather than at the individual level. Consequently, what we have got here is a second best solution to the problem of fringe benefits in one sense, but one that, because of overwhelming administrative and compliance problems, is really the only possible way to go.

To turn to efficiency considerations, it is a well-known economic argument that we try to avoid a tax system that distorts people's consumption choices. At the moment we have a tax system that effectively exempts consumption of some goods and services from tax. Consequently, we have a distortion of people's priorities. That that is a bad thing and has a bad effect on overall welfare is a well-known economic argument. Clearly, to the extent that this legislation fixes that up, it is justified on efficiency grounds. That is the sort of point that any genuine free marketeer would readily accept. We have a collection of people in the Opposition who are quite capable of asserting the most utterly preposterous and inconsistent set of policies under the guise of an economic policy. Members of the Opposition want to get rid of this fringe benefits tax and continue to have the large marginal rate of cuts, and avoid a whole range of expenditure cuts that the Government is forced into. The internal inconsistency and absurdity of that needs no elaboration.

I want to go on to one further point in the area of efficiency. It is an interesting aspect that emerges from the Chandler and MacLeod survey that I referred to above. According to the report of this survey, large companies frequently fail to take proper account of the total cost of their remuneration packages under the existing arrangement. I will quote from the survey:
What you find in smaller organisations is that there is a greater awareness of the need to look at total remuneration-
That is a quote from one consultant involved in the Chandler and MacLeod salary package survey. He went on to say:
In the large organisations it's my observation that there's a policy on salary, a policy on cars, a policy on superannuation, not a drawing together of the total cost.
To the extent that these measures that have been introduced force a more accurate accounting of the cost of employing managerial staff, I think we can expect to see some efficiency gain.

The time we have agreed to has elapsed. I will conclude by saying that these measures need to be seen in the context of the total package. Obviously it is imposing a larger tax burden in one sense but at the same time we are seeing very large cuts in marginal tax rates and the introduction of the imputation system of company tax which effectively gives a major benefit to companies. There is some degree of ambiguity about just where the incidence of this tax will lie. I was going to quote from the White Paper, but there is no time to do so. We really do not know to what extent companies have been successful in shifting the burden of the tax forward on to employees. So we really do not know in a fundamental sense where the ultimate burden of this tax will lie. I believe that on balance it will certainly have an equitable and desirable effect on the tax system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill before the House actually rewrites the meanings and terms of every dictionary available in the English language and certainly overturns every canon of common British and taxation law that we have come to expect in Australia since Federation. When I say it rewrites the meaning of certain words in the Oxford and other dictionaries, this is because the National Taxation Summit and the tax reformation set out as their clear objective to make our taxation system fairer, more equitable, more certain, clearer and to have some integrity. I suggest that anybody who picks up this Bill, which is 140 pages, and picks up the booklet entitled `Fringe Benefits Tax-guide for employers' will see that they define more clearly frustration, complication, inequity, the unfairness of the system, the muddled way in which it is being done and the fact that it has no integrity whatsoever.
—Do you understand it?

—I would like to have the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on the floor of the chamber during the Committee stage to debate this Bill page by page and clause by clause to find out whether the Treasurer, who is the author and organiser of this Bill, understands the complications of it.
—He wanted to simplify the tax.

—He wanted to simplify it. Any honourable member who reads this Bill and the clause on car fringe benefits will come to the formula of A, B, C over D. There are also statutory fractions. How can anybody indicate to this House and to the people of Australia that we have had tax reform? What we have had is a tax swindle in its worst case. What we have here is a brand new and additional tax. Reforming the tax system was not meant to be part of the great cry at the last election that we should make it less complicated, fair and more equitable. What we have here is a direct opposite. At this stage, much as we know about the fringe benefits tax, we know less about the capital gains tax, which is the other object of the exercise yet to come to this House. In its own way I believe that it will be very similar to the capital gains tax. It will not be subject to interpretation. I believe it will be a gold mine for accountants, tax agents and advisers around the country. It will become a matter of complaint once we get to the self-assessment stage, where these things are going to drag on for years and years before being resolved. Worse than that, I believe that it is a bottomless pit of unnecessary legislation and misery that will create greater uncertainty in the business place. I am just not sure whether small business can overcome this burden, which will fall mainly upon it and upon the rural industry of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, the tax is a new one. Secondly, it takes the unprecedented step of taxing an employer on an employee's benefit. As anybody would realise, payroll tax, which is a labour cost or tax, is passed down the line and eventually comes out at the other end as an additional charge to the consumer. So this tax, in its own way, in some cases will be another charge upon the consumer. I can imagine that, if the Government, local government and statutory authorities are to pay the proposed tax, it will mean that there will be an additional government charge at the end of the line. For instance, as a very simple analogy, the proposed tax on airline staff travel benefits is calculated to amount to millions of dollars annually. I can imagine this being the first ground advanced to the Independent Air Fares Committee as a reason for increasing air fares across Australia, so again it will be the consumer who will pay the tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be passed back to the consumer.
—It will go back to the consumer in so many cases. There are two alternatives. The first is that of passing it back to consumers.
—They are paying it now.

—Yes, they are paying it now. It is interesting to note that they have not yet had the benefit of the effect of import parity pricing changes insofar as fares are concerned. It will be said that it has been done now. Of course it is going to do that. This is an uncalculated and great cost that will be imposed right across Australia. It sets a precedent in that an employer is to be charged and that charge will fall back eventually on to the consumer.

SPEECH.PARA: The other alternative is that small business and rural industries will shed labour or go out of business, give up the fight, give way to big business, and we will have Australia in the grip again of the big companies, not the normal, traditional constituency of the small business enterprise, the family farm, or the family business-getting in there and trying to earn something. What is proposed will bring with it related costs; there is no doubt about that. As I say, its complications will be borne by accountants within firms, or special pay clerks who are trying to calculate on a monthly or a quarterly basis what the cost to the business will be. That itself will impose another cost. So, all round, I can see nothing to recommend this type of taxation to the people of Australia. Certainly, when we look back at its origins we can quite distinctly recall the Treasurer saying that he was thinking of a fringe benefit that would be taxable to the employee. Within 24 hours, Mr Dolan of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, having realised that this could mean more tax for him and his colleagues in the ACTU and the union movement and said that it was not on. On the third day, the Treasurer came back and said that the tax would be paid by the employers; that the Government would follow New Zealand in this. One could have hoped that the Government would look at the New Zealand experience to find out exactly where that country stands at the moment, as far as the implications of such a tax is concerned. I believe that that experience would be such as to suggest that no government would want to pursue a parallel course.

The general effect, of course, is a further complication, the production of 139 extra pages of legislation outside the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill itself, because it could not be fitted inside it. As previous Opposition speakers have said, the proposals are convoluted and simply produce a further tangled web. Its effect on business will be to impose an added cost for record keeping. Its effect will be labour shedding in certain instances. There will be two standards of employment-those which applied before the fringe benefits tax was imposed and those which will apply after it has been imposed, as employers try to cash up a whole package of employment remuneration instead of the fringe benefits of the past. I am not saying that the fringe benefit situation should not have been looked at but, as has been said repeatedly in this House, at the moment the law covers the situation adequately. In fact, I quite well remember an endeavour being made to apply that law with respect to the housing of miners in the Bowen Basin. That was of particular relevance to me. It affected subsidised housing provided not only in the Bowen Basin, but in all those other industries that supply it. So, when it is said that the new law is going to set aside the difficulties of the old, I would remind the Government of the current situation under the proposal to end tax deductibility for business entertainment. As I recall, about 16 pages of the legislation were devoted to denying such a deduction and, as was indicated in the Australian of this morning, thousands of jobs have been lost as a result in the small business restaurant area. Fortunately these have been taken up by larger enterprises, such as hotels, resort developments and casinos. So the effect is already there. What we suggested when it was proposed that business entertainment should not be tax deductible, was that all legitimate expenses should be allowable but that those that were not should be denied. Our proposal could have been encompassed in half a page of legislation and could have been implemented without any problems, without any of the excesses that will be created by the implementation of these proposed taxes.

I would like to deal specifically with the two areas of airline benefits. First, I believe that the tax will be passed on down the line and become another consumer tax. So far as housing fringe benefits are concerned, we have been through this exercise but special arrangements are being made at this stage again to devalue the actual effect. What this means is that there will be another tax on the employment sector of Australia. A lot of these people are traders. I cannot imagine any industry that supplies, as part of its employee package, housing benefits that is not an export industry. The message that is clearly being given in this House today is that the economic recovery of Australia will depend eventually on how we trade, yet this Government in so many ways, week after week, imposes yet another cost, another burden on our exporting industries-to the extent that they cannot be competitive. I wonder whether the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins), the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and all of the other Ministers concerned have taken that into consideration in agreeing at the Cabinet table to the proposed legislation. Also, I believe, it should be realised that this Bill was presented to the House only last Friday. There has not been time for proper public scrutiny and interpretation. It is being rushed through this House under threat of imposition of the guillotine. Instead, as I have indicated, it would have been an interesting exercise to put the Bill clause by clause to the Treasurer and ask him to explain how it was not complicated, how it was equitable, how it was fair, how it would be understood, how it would not indeed have the great implications that we fear for it. For that reason one cannot entertain having a detailed debate. All one can do is to condemn the method of and reason for its implementation, and to suggest that there is every reason that not only the Opposition, but also Government members, ought to recognise the problems that lie ahead and vote with us against this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation before the House is part of an overall package of Bills that has come before the House. Some were brought down yesterday, some today and there will be more in a few weeks time, to present the overall package of taxation Bills that this Government is putting before the people of Australia. We have heard in the last few days, and again just now from the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), the arguments about equity. I cannot understand how he comes to present his case about who is paying for what, and his statement that the cost is going to be passed down the line. Surely that will occur to some extent, but I remind the honourable member that in its first full year, 1987-88, the fringe benefits tax, when it is up and running, is expected to yield in excess of $500m. I ask him: Who is paying for that now? Who is subsidising it now? Someone is subsidising that figure. I put it to the House that it is the people of Australia and, generally, those who can afford it least who are subsidising that $500m now. That is what this whole fringe benefits area is all about. Massive amounts of money will be recouped. Severall billion dollars worth of fringe benefits and other elements are affected by this revolutionary package of taxation Bills, the most radical that this country has seen, notwithstanding the fact that the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-and I must admit that I supported him-initially proposed another tax that did not quite make it to this House. Notwithstanding that, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Bills before us are quite significant and extend across a range of fringe benefits that needed to be looked at. The Parliament is now addressing them and I put it to the House and to the people of Australia: Why should one of two people in different industries, people whose work value would be equated as being roughly equal, under the old system be substantially better off than is the other who must accept a set wage, without other benefits? The latter, who receives, say, $40,000, must pay tax on that sum, as he should. However, the other person receives $30,000, on which he pays tax, but also has his children's education paid, his housing expenses and all sorts of other costs met and consequently is better off. He is being subsidised by the people who can least afford it, people who earn in the bottom half of the taxation scale. But in the equity arguments that the honourable member for Dawson put forward yesterday and today-coincidentally I have followed him in both debates-he favours the old system, stating that the proposed system is `a bit too hard.' Of course the honourable member wants the old system. It is his mates that are ripping the system off to the extent of billions of dollars a year.

SPEECH.PARA: I admit that some of the employees, and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, did not like some of what has been proposed, but so be it. No one, whether an employer, the ACTU or anyone else, can hide behind the fringe benefits veil. In fact, some unions have realised that they have gone down the wrong track over the past 20 years in having all sorts of deals that are now being unravelled. Discussions are occurring because of fringe benefit perks and lurks that have been going on, rather than pay the up-front wage that I knew and grew up with. It was what you were worth and what you were paid, and what you paid tax on. In fact, we would prob- ably not have to go through half of this taxation revolution if everyone in this country paid a fair share of tax on what he or she earned.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics in August 1984 brought out some interesting figures. One concerned the percentage of employees who receive fringe benefit; by income ranges. It is interesting to note that, in respect of housing benefits, the payment of holiday and medical expenses and the provision of low-interest finance, from 7.1 per cent to 9.5 per cent of people earning around $26,000-the figure would be in excess of $30,000 now-receive such benefits. Interestingly enough, down at the other end of the scale, of people earning around $200 a week, 0.2 per cent enjoy low-interest finance, 2 per cent receive medical benefits, 1.3 per cent have assistance with holiday expenses and 3.4 per cent receive housing benefits. We have all come across people, whether they be employers, employees, industrialists or farmers-such as I encountered recently-who have skited about what a dreadful thing it was that last year they had to pay tax for the first time in 10 years or so. That is why we are here. We are trying to get a fair system under which everyone will pay a fair share of tax. I see in this House members of parliament, clerks at the table and the Hansard reporter and am prompted to ask: What avenues do they have for receiving fringe benefits? They must pay tax on what they earn. I must investigate it further but I do not think that the clerk at the table enjoys the payment of holiday expenses, low-interest loans and all those sorts of things. Of course he does not.

TALK.START.PARA: —He derives intellectual stimulation!

—But a price cannot be put on intellectual stimulation, can it? The Bills before the House are far reaching. There will be some teething problems and sorting out of them. That has already been done in some cases, for instance, in regard to the airline industry, in respect of which we have seen a statement put out by the ACTU, the airline industry unions, Ansett Airlines of Australia, Trans Australia Airlines and Qantas, to the effect that:

SPEECH.PARA: For employees, existing entitlements to staff travel concessions will remain unchanged.

That statement was made after they were presented with the final draft of the proposed legislation. So we are able to sit down, talk it through and come to sensible solutions right across the board. I agree with the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin) when he says he believes that the car industry reaction was a little over the hill. There is going to be some diminution in the car industry trade. That is expected. Certain figures have been put on that. Interestingly enough, one or two of the car manufacturers agree, or very nearly agree, as to what the extent of that decline will be. They agree with the Government. Others put the figure at a substantially higher level. It will be interesting to see. I heard the honourable member for Sydney talking about the depreciation. Ford and General Motors-Holden's Ltd, for example, will I believe pick up a more significant part of the car industry trade as the depreciation bites and the imported cars continue to rise in price. Their price is now quite prohibitive, because of the economic circumstances prevailing. Those companies will lift their share of the market. The tax will to an extent have an effect; there must be a readjustment, but I believe that that adjustment will not be as significant as some people are trying to make out.

It is a pity that there has not been more rational debate across the chamber by way of seeking fairness and equity, rather than from day one going back to what happened 12 or 18 months ago. All we have seen are crocodile tears from people screaming about one thing or another-if not the fringe benefits the proposed retail tax, if not that then something else. People are, even now, concerned about the lowering of the tax scale levels-though that is an adjustment to make up for a lot of the fringe benefits legislation that is before the House. As I mentioned at the start, you cannot just look at one piece of this legislation and say: `Look, that is totally unfair'. You must look at the whole of the legislation that the Government has put, is putting and will be putting to the Parliament as a package. It all interweaves. One balances the other. For all those reasons, Mr Deputy Speaker, I fully support the Treasurer's and Government's moves in introducing this legislation, and fully commend it to all honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the basic principle underlying this tax, that employers should pay the taxation on fringe benefits provided to employees, is very wrong. I do not support payment in kind, that is, of goods and services or non-cash benefits, in lieu of salary. However, employees ought to be paying the tax, not employers. If the Government encouraged the payment of wages on a strictly cash basis, thus reducing the incidence of perks that has built up over many, many years, I would be inclined to encourage and support that move. But there is nothing in this legislation or that has been said by this Treasurer (Mr Keating) over the past 12 months to suggest that this is going to happen. I venture to suggest to the House that high-powered executives will continue to be paid perks at company expense while some middle or low-income ranking employees will probably face retrenchment. And I say to the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles), who preceded me in this debate, that we will see employees retrenched in this country because employers will not be able to foot the bill for all of their employees. Really, in effect, what we have here represents massive payouts by employers for existing staff structures.

SPEECH.PARA: We saw what happened back in the late seventies when the now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the former Treasurer, realising that there was a problem in that fringe benefits were being paid and not being taxed, went to the central Queensland coal mines area to pursue that matter. He was physically abused. Of course, it was the union thugs, the union chiefs acting on behalf of their members, who caused that ruckus. Now we find that, in order to get the same result while maintaining industrial peace, the Treasurer has decided that he will tax the employers rather than the employees. It is a case of the cunning Keating taxing employers when really the taxation should be imposed on employees. On that particular occasion it was a case of the employees having their cake and eating it too. We have now got a situation where they will still have their cake and eat it too, but the employers will pay the tax for them. It is rather curious, Mr Deputy Speaker, that when unions go to bat for their unionist members and gain fringe benefits for them, those benefits are not taxable because they have been received under awards determined by industrial tribunals. But if an employer decides that he is going to give a fringe benefit to an employee, that benefit is taxable. So the employer pays for the fringe benefit and also for the tax on top of that. If the industrial tribunal determines a fringe benefit, it is not taxable, but the employer of course has still to pay the fringe benefit. What we have here is really one rule for some, and another rule for others. So much for the Treasurer's attempts at achieving consistency and equality. He is achieving neither.

Let us, Mr Deputy Speaker, look at some of the problems that have been created over the past three years by this Hawke socialist Government. We have now a fringe benefits tax-one which, as the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) has said, is enshrined in about 140 pages of legislation and a 56-page booklet instructing employers as to what to do to institute a fringe benefit tax. We have union superannuation on the horizon. Deals are being entered into at the moment by unionists who are exercising industrial muscle over employers. That is to be paid for, I remind this nation, by the employers again, with no employee contribution being made. Again the union thugs have got their own way. That is the scene that this Government has set-massive union power in league with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, a government that really does not care about the average Australian but indeed is encouraging more union power.

We have a current account deficit of $70 billion-$70 billion dollars in total debts owing, and a deficit on the part of this nation that is running at about $1m a month. We have a Medicare blowout with a levy that is accounting for about 25 per cent of the total payout. We have unemployment, about which we hear so much rhetoric from this Government, running at 8 per cent or 600,000, and we have 20 per cent youth unemployment. We have social welfare fraud running rampant and a weak Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) who institutes an amnesty. Petrol prices are higher than they ought to be-another broken promise by this Hawke Government, which said that import parity pricing would be adhered to, yet has produced only a partial reduction in the price of petrol. So Australian motorists are paying to the back teeth for that. We have just had the abolition of negative gearing. The capital gains tax represents another broken promise of the Hawke Government. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had stated himself in unequivocal terms that there would be no capital gains tax. We have an increase in home lending rates and interest rates generally. Rents are being pushed higher for the disadvantaged, the needy, veterans, pensioners-people that the Government does not really care about-as a result of the introduction of a capital gains tax and the ending of negative gearing. So it is a government that really does not care for average Australians, a government that has been encouraging union power. I think it is time that the average Australian woke up to what was really happening between the Government and the unions.

Let me turn to the Treasurer's second reading speech, because he talks in that about removing a serious gap in the income tax law and ensuring that all forms of remuneration paid to employees bear a fair measure of tax. He says that for this purpose the fringe benefits tax is pitched at all employers, both taxable and exempt. He then goes on to outline what this fringe benefits tax covers. He talks about its including employer-provided motor vehicles, free of low-interest loans, residential accommodation, board and excessive living away from home allowances-do not ask me who is to define the word `excessive'-and expenses paid on behalf of employees. But then he goes on to talk about exclusions. When he first introduced this measure back in September there were really going to be no exclusions at all. But, of course, a certain number of people have got to him in the last eight months-I remind the House that it has taken that time for the Government to get this legislation before us and it is now sought to pass it in less than 24 hours.

Let us now look at some of the exclusions. Generally excluded, says the Treasurer, are staff canteens and free or discounted use of commuter transport systems by employees. He says that there will be no tax on the use of child care and recreational facilities on an employer's premises. What he is saying in effect is this: Some have to pay and some get off scot-free. Where is the fairness in that? Some have to buy goods and services from their after-tax income, yet others get the goods free. This is quite contradictory and I would suggest to the Treasurer that he ought to have gone the whole hog, instead of being quite selective, as he has been. Then he goes on in the second reading speech further to say that there have been further exemptions not announced earlier. He lists them. One relates to low interest loans granted to veterans under the Defence Service Homes Act, another to live-in accommodation of employees who care for disabled people or disadvantaged children, et cetera. So I would suggest to the House, Mr Deputy Speaker, that despite the fact that in the early stages there were to be no exemptions, the Treasurer has now weakened to provide for certain exemptions and lists them. Thus, his original statement has been shot to pieces. The Treasurer of this nation just cannot tell the truth; he just cannot be trusted.

I move on to the motor car industry because up to 30,000 or 35,000 jobs will be lost in that industry. It is my view that governments-of whatever political persuasion-ought not to make drastic changes to policy. In so doing, they cause great disruption to business and industry. It takes many decades to have certain situations established and that is the case with the car manufacturing industry. Machinery and equipment are installed; buildings are put up; workers are employed. In other words, assets and people are involved and it is morally wrong for any government to change the game rules overnight. That is what has happened in this particular instance. Even the honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan) in South Australia wanted a phased in fringe benefits tax approach, but of course that was rejected by the Government. Fleet sales are relied upon very heavily by the motor manufacturing industry. It has been estimated that up to one-half or even two-thirds of total car sales are in this category. Fleet sales dropped 20 per cent in the first three months of this year, due to cutbacks by companies because of the proposed fringe benefits tax. This Government, with one stroke of the pen, changes established practices, practices that have taken decades to develop. It is causing chaos in industry and throwing many, many workers out of jobs.

I just want to conclude by addressing some comments to the fringe benefits tax as it applies to churches, charities and other non-profitable organisations. I believe that this aspect of the fringe benefits tax is the most dastardly of all. It is a cold and calculated tax on churches, charitable and non-profit organisations in this country. This Hawke socialist Government is the first in Australia's history to tax non-profitable, charitable organisations. It is the first Government in the history of this nation to tax churches for their welfare work, as distinct from their clergy or pastoral work. I repeat that this is the first Government in Australia's history to do that. One fairly substantial charity in Queensland alone has estimated that the fringe benefits tax will cost it $60,000 annually. Religion and charitable bodies are set up to assist governments at all levels, local, State and Federal. They deliver services to the aged, to the needy, to the disadvantaged, yet the Government has seen fit to tax them. I wonder how members of the Government feel when they go out and face people from the Smith Family, the Salvation Army and the St Vincent de Paul Society, to name a few. I wonder what they are thinking when they face those people, who work in a dedicated fashion to provide services that assist governments at all levels. They ought to hang their heads in shame-taxing religious and charitable organisations as they do under this fringe benefits tax.

Finally, Mr Deputy Speaker, we have now two tax years. This Hawke socialist Government, the biggest taxing government in Australia's history, has created two tax years. We have only ever had one tax year. That is the normal tax year from 1 July to 30 June. But now we are to have a fringe benefits tax year that will extend from 1 April to 31 March-a self-assessment system, with responsibility again on employers to lodge an annual return. The amount is to be calculated by the employer and paid in three instalments. This is a massive extra imposition on employers and I would suggest that it is going to cost this Government and this nation greatly because the unemployment that will be created will only be manifested in the months and years to come. I am sure that the Government will rue the day that it ever introduced a fringe benefits tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to speak on this legislation and must say that I am very disappointed at the continued hypocrisy, double-talk and deceit of the Opposition. We ought to remind the people of Australia, when the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges) suggests that this Government is not concerned about the average Australian, that we inherited a situation after 30 years of government by present members of the Opposition in which tax evasion and tax avoidance was reaping $7,000m annually. That deficit was being paid by the ordinary Australian-the most in- equitable system that one could imagine.
—It was all finished by the time Labor got back. You have done nothing; it was all over.

—Of course we have. We have pulled in $4,500m under the measures that we have taken so far and the Opposition has squirmed and squealed and screamed all the way. It has never supported us. We ought to go back to the White Paper and just see what was happening to the taxation system when Opposition members were in government. Over a period of 30 years they were able to produce changes whereby the marginal rate of tax for those on average earnings increased from 19 per cent to 46 per cent, while the average rate rose from 10 to 25 per cent. Some 2.1 million taxpayers, equivalent to around 39 per cent of all full time employed persons, now face a marginal tax rate of 46 per cent or more, compared with approximately one per cent 30 years ago. The top marginal rate, 60 per cent, now cuts in at only 1.6 times average yearly earnings, whereas in 1954-55 the top rate, 66.7 per cent, cut in at income levels approximately 18 times average yearly earnings. The present-day equivalent of the 1954-55 income level at which the top marginal rate applied would be about $400,000 compared with the $35,000 figure at which it now commences. Whereas income tax assessed on individuals earning more than 1.6 times average yearly earnings, now $35,000, accounted for over half of the total tax attributable to individuals in 1954-55, the comparable upper income range now accounts for only 20 per cent. The real problem for taxpayers has been the way in which the present Opposition, when in government, allowed the system to break down, to be rorted and evaded to the extent that people opted out of it. It has taken the courage of this Government to have something done about it. The Opposition has shown itself to be a champion of privilege, a champion of inequity and a champion of inequality.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to fringe benefits. According to the White Paper, the tax loss because of fringe benefits, the ending of which the Opposition would like us to forgo, is estimated at some $700m. The loss in relation to car fringe benefits has been estimated to be $280m. The revenue to be gained under this Bill is estimated to be $330m in 1986-87, $540m in 1987-88 and $625m in 1988-89. The Opposition is quite happy to support proposals to reduce the marginal rate of taxation but is not prepared to support one measure that will increase revenue. If Opposition members were in government they would be quite happy to blow out the Budget deficit by some $10 billion dollars, a huge amount, which would no doubt destroy all the gains that had been so painfully won by this Government. A lot has been made of the fact that the employers will be picking up the tax on fringe benefits. How did fringe benefits come to dominate so much of the salary packages that currently exist? Was it a concerted movement by those bogymen, the thugs that the honourable member for Petrie talked about, in the ranks of the Opposition? I do not know of any union affiliated with the Australian Council of Trade Unions that is responsible for managing directors, general managers, sales managers and a whole raft of people who have been granted, by the companies I believe, these fringe benefits. I find no difficulty in accepting the fact that we ought to be all fairly assessed. If the Opposition can demonstrate a case under which every working Australian could get a fair share of fringe benefits, perhaps we ought to leave them in place. But clearly fringe benefits have been the province of a limited few.

TALK.START.PARA: —The employees should pay it.

—What I am trying to say to the honourable member for Petrie, and perhaps he has not understood me, is that I believe that the incentive to give people fringe benefits did not come from the employees; they came from the employers.
—You are joking.
—The honourable member should go look at the advertisements. Who puts the advertisements in the paper offering these fringe benefits? Is it the trade unions?
—What about the industrial tribunals?

—It is absolutely ludicrous to suggest that the ACTU or the unions affiliated with it have negotiated an extensive range of salary packages for managing directors, general managers, sales managers and a whole raft of people who currently enjoy fringe benefits but are not covered by affiliated unions. I think that is absolute hypocrisy. Since we are talking about hypocrisy, and I have heard the honourable member for Petrie before talking about the ramps and rorts that he alleges exist in regard to social security, I ask: Is the Opposition prepared to support an ID card, which will be another level of attack on evasion, another level of attack on the loss of revenue to the Government?
—You cannot agree on that.
—I certainly agree. I want to make it quite clear to the honourable member for Petrie that I fully support having an ID card.
—What about Senator Bolkus?

—I remind the honourable member that the Opposition has opposed it, has participated in the majority report in relation to the ID card. I want to say that we have heard a lot of trite nonsense from honourable members opposite on taxation measures, but have they, in a bipartisan way, joined the Government in raising the level of debate and understanding about the current problems of the taxation system? Did they willingly go along to the Taxation Summit and say: `We are the Opposition; we believe that we ought to have a constructive debate about taxation. We may disagree with the Government on minor points of view.'? Did they go there and try, in a bipartisan way, to add to the taxation debate? Of course they did not.
—Then why are you now gagging debate?

—The problem of honourable members opposite is that they seek to protect the entrenched privileges of tax avoiders and evaders. The Australian people are beginning to understand just how hypocritical honourable members opposite are in relation to taxation matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has had to go through the pain of introducing measures such as the fringe benefits tax at, of course, the price of significantly reducing marginal rates. If honourable members opposite want to talk about incentives or about motivation, the clearest evidence that can be found is that the high marginal rates that we currently suffer-entrenched by them in the system-do act as a disincentive; that there will be a profound change in the taxation system as from 1 September 1986, when the tax-free threshold will be increased, the top marginal rates will come down from 60 per cent to 55 per cent and other changes will flow through. That will make a profound difference to the community. I want to finish with this point because I think it is a very important one.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to ignore the clowns opposite. I want to end on what I think it a very important point. Should industries, whether they be car, entertainment or whatever, be propped up by what is clearly, on all the evidence, a situation of people avoiding and evading taxation? I want to see a dynamic small business sector. I want to see a stronger industrial sector for Australia. I would hope that honourable members opposite would share my outlook on that matter, but I do not want to see business continued when a clear equity case can be made out that it is happening as a result of tax avoidance and evasion. Therefore, I commend these Bills. I tell the Australian people and this House that this is but a part of the overall taxation package that this Government has had the courage to introduce. Clearly we will be introducing more measures and, in particular, in September of this year, the taxpayer will see the first benefits of the reduction in marginal rates. This Party is committed to bringing those rates down even further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), who has just resumed his seat, protests, as my colleagues have pointed out, the desirability of constructive discussion, yet his Government gags this debate. I think that point needs to be made. I will come back presently to the charges of hypocrisy and the like that he levelled at us. But in rising to speak in this debate, I will rehearse a number of preliminary points that have already been made but cannot, I believe, be stressed too often. The first of these is that it is past time that this legislation was brought into this Parliament and debated and finalised. It is nearly eight months now since the so-called reform package was brought into the House by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). In the case of the important issue of negative gearing that we debated yesterday, it is 10 months since the relevant announcement was made. In the meantime, confusion and uncertainty have reigned and in the business context this has had very adverse implications for new investment decisions. It is one factor, indeed, in bringing about what the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, no less, has called the abysmal state of private investment.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point, Mr Deputy Speaker, is that for all that this package is presented as the greatest tax reform program of the century, it certainly does not meet what was set down by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as being one of the key requirements of tax reform. I refer to the fourth of the nine principles enunciated by the Prime Minister, namely: `Any reform must lead to a simpler system which therefore all Australians can understand more fully . . .'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The KISS principle: `Keep it simple, stupid'.

—The KISS principle, as my colleague says. In fact, the complexity of the legislation that we have had so far in implementing this package defies description. It has long been recognised that the tax Act, which comprised 1,100 pages prior to the present exercise, was extraordinarily complex and tortuous. This Bill relating to fringe benefits has some 139 pages. There were 47 pages in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill of yesterday. There have been other pieces of legislation, and the total since the exercise began-being of the order of 350 pages-brings the text of that legislation up to 1,450 pages. Some simplicity!

SPEECH.PARA: A third point which it is necessary to stress is that while the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Government constantly emphasise, that what has been presented is a package and must be accepted as a whole, there is in fact no merit in that contention. It is not a package in the meaningful sense of a group of related and interdependent measures, having a coherent sense of purpose and direction. In particular, it is not a package in the sense that one of the end objectives of the exercise-tax cuts stemming from meaningful change in the structure of the marginal rates of tax-is crucially dependent on the acceptance of each and every measure. That is not so and the Opposition reserves the right to consider each of the components on its merits. Indeed the Opposition, Mr Deputy Speaker, has been threatened that if the present fringe benefits tax measure is modified to reduce the yield, or is rejected by the Parliament, the Government will not proceed with the tax cuts. Now that it is phoney, a deceptive threat. The whole array of the tax reform revenue measures is to provide a net $705m only of the $2,000m cost of the proposed tax cuts of 1 September next.

This fringe benefits tax itself is projected to yield $320m in 1986-87, or only 16 per cent of the total cost of the tax cuts. So, I say that it is phoney to suggest that that will or should prevent the cuts. Of course, the Government would dearly like any excuse to back off from these tax cuts. Quite apart from the simple fact that hanging on to existing revenue is easier than cutting expenditure, in order to get the deficit down, there is the perhaps more complex way of arguing that in the prevailing economic situation, where the nation is already living beyond its means with a yawning balance of payments deficit amounting to $30m being spent overseas `on tick' every day, tax cuts are the precise opposite of what economic logic requires.

At all events I turn, Mr Deputy Speaker, to the fringe benefits tax itself, the subject of these present Bills. I assert that the Opposition-as has been clear from the many speeches by my colleagues here today-is clearly opposed to the tax in the form here proposed. I emphasise the words `in the form here proposed'. I would like to set out, as simply as I can, the essence of the Opposition's position. We have here a tax on the fringe benefits of employees-but it is being levied on the employer. As such, it adds up to a significant additional tax imposed on business-a de facto payroll tax which would reduce profitability, impair competitiveness, and lessen the incentive to invest and generate employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the crunch point.

—As my colleague says, that is the crunch point. I say to honour- able members opposite that this tax will cost jobs. There are other aspects of the tax that are deleterious but that is the primary basis on which we oppose this tax. That is not even to mention the fallout effects on activity and jobs in other industries, such as occurs in relation to the car industry. It may then be said: `But is there not merit in the argument that the widespread and increasing resort to non-wage salary fringe benefits in order to avoid higher marginal rates of tax is eroding the tax base, a trend which cannot be permitted to continue?' The answer is, first, that the tax should be levied on the income earner, as in the United Kingdom and Canada, not on the employer. Why we should emulate the cop-out in this regard of New Zealand, which has put the tax on the employer? The answer, of course is: `Because the ACTU dictates it; that is why'. But this is a tax on fringe benefits received in lieu of income, and should be paid by the employee. Incidentally, I would mention that the Government's draft White Paper, when it turns to this issue, states quite categorically:

SPEECH.PARA: The best approach in principle would be to impose the tax on the employee.

I make a second point in response to the query as to the merit of the argument of doing something about fringe benefits, that the root cause of the escalation in fringe benefits are the too high, exploitative, almost immoral marginal tax rates that currently prevail. I refer to the 46 plus one, 47 per cent really with the Medicare levy, and 48 plus one, or 49 per cent rates that apply to incomes greater than $19,500, which means that about 40 per cent of Australians are in the position where nearly half of any additional income they earn, or any increase in their incomes, goes in tax. I refer even more, of course, to the 60-rather the 61 rate-that comes into play at an income level of $35,000, or just 1.6 times average earnings. Genuine tax reform must be directed to that basic cause of fringe benefits, not to the imposition of a savage anti-business, anti-employment tax on fringe benefits such as we have before us.

The honourable member for Chifley referred to the facts of the situation and I do not dispute them. They are the cumulative effect of the actions, or inaction, of successive governments. As the White Paper brought out, taxpayers on quite moderate income levels are exposed to these high marginal rates that we are talking about.
