It was pointed out that in 1954-55 only one per cent of taxpayers faced a marginal rate equal to or greater than 46 per cent. Currently 40 per cent of taxpayers face it. In 1954-55, the top marginal rate, then 66 per cent, began at an average income that was approximately 18 times average weekly earnings, which would be equivalent to an income of about $400,000 today whereas, as I just said, the top marginal rate currently comes in at $35,000, which is only 1.6 times average earnings. It is these marginal rates which adversely affect incentives and hence efficiency and growth and, of course, enormously encourage people to take steps to avoid or evade paying tax. That is conceded. Therefore, we need to make a major effort in respect of marginal tax rates.

It is correct that this package of measures is directed to that end. The difficulty is that when the Treasurer wanted to do something really substantial at the Tax Summit last year he failed in his efforts. Consequently, we end up with this and associated measures as a rag bag of legislation-doctrinaire-socialist, `soak-the-rich' in thrust-although, as my colleague the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) pointed out last night, the ultimate effect in most cases is to hit the poor. The measures are anti-growth, anti-enterprise and anti-business in effect, and when all is done we get a proposed new structure of marginal rates, not due to be finally implemented until 1987, which still leaves very much to be desired. In fact, I draw the attention of Government supporters to the point that those taxpayers earning less than $19,500, less than $400 a week, are to receive a reduction of only one percentage point in the rates applicable-the 25 per cent rate is to be reduced to 24 and the 30 per cent rate to 29, and I suggest that they should reflect on that. Certainly more significant reductions for higher income groups are proposed, but the whole structure is still a long way short of good enough-if they are ever to be implemented. I conclude on the note if they are ever implemented. That becomes increasingly doubtful every day, with the continuing yawning gap in the balance of payments to which I referred earlier, and the roadblocks for this Government on the way to sound policy in the fiscal and wages areas as alternatives to the policy of crippling, sustained high interest rates such as have afflicted us and continue to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have great pleasure in supporting the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill, which has been introduced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the world's greatest Treasurer. I believe that as a result of this Bill, along with others such as that concerned with capital gains, and the alterations made to the Income Tax Assessment Act, the Government can be very proud of the reforms in taxation which it will have on the books by July 1987. Its full tax reform package will then have been legislated and be up and running. This tax reform package is not about increasing tax, as has been suggested by the Opposition. The Opposition parties, perhaps because during their years in government we saw nothing but higher and higher taxes, believe that any change to the tax system must result in average wage and salary earners paying more tax. Under this Government, the average PAYE taxpayer will be getting a better deal. The fringe benefits tax certainly will result in employers paying additional moneys by way of tax. But this whole tax package is revenue neutral, a buzz word which has been used quite a lot recently. Quite simply, it means that every dollar which this Government will be raising through the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, or any other measure which is part of our tax reform package, will be handed back to PAYE taxpayers in the form of income tax cuts. I will go into further detail on those tax cuts later in my speech.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) mentioned in his excellent contribution earlier today-it is good to see him in the chamber at the moment-the Australian taxation system was haemorrhaging at all levels of the income tax base, but particularly in the higher income levels. The average tax rate paid by individuals, increased from 10 per cent in 1954 to 22 per cent at the moment. That is the average rate, not the marginal rate. In fact, if we examine the contribution of income tax paid by individuals we find-it will be no surprise to honourable members-that the individuals in the highest brackets are making a smaller and smaller contribution to the total income tax payments made by individuals. In 1954, 53 per cent of all income tax paid by individuals was paid by people earning more than 1.6 times average weekly earnings. According to the last figures that I have, those for 1985, only 22 per cent of total individual income tax contributions is paid by people who earn more than 1.6 times average weekly earnings. So, whereas we would expect that people would be pushed into higher and higher brackets, that those in the top bracket would be making higher contributions, the figures show that those in high income brackets are making a smaller contribution to income tax as the years go by. That is why I think that this Government is to be congratulated upon bringing down measures such as this fringe benefits tax.

The fringe benefits tax is expected to raise $330m in this coming financial year and in 1987-88 will raise $540m. As has been explained previously, that means that all of those hundreds of millions of dollars will be available to be ploughed in to tax cuts to the ordinary PAYE taxpayer. When the supporters of the Liberal and National parties say that they oppose a capital gains tax and a fringe benefits tax, the simple question I put to them time and time again, and they refused to answer it is: How do they intend to pay for the income tax cuts, or the increases in pensions, which we are delivering to income taxpayers and pensioners? Without a fringe benefits tax and the levying of a capital gains tax one cannot hope to deliver those income tax cuts and increases in pensions that we will certainly deliver later this year and on 1 July 1987.

The fringe benefits tax is to be imposed on employers, so that an employer who provides a tax-free fringe benefit to an employee will be responsible for paying to the Commonwealth a tax on that fringe benefit. I was amazed to hear the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges) interject, when the honourable member for Chifley was speaking, that the employee, not the employer, should pay the fringe benefits tax. I would be interested if the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) would indicate by interjection whether he supports the honourable member for Petrie when he says that employees should pay the fringe benefits tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a political cop-out.

—The honourable member for Flinders is condemned by his silence. He was very loud in this chamber earlier today, but he obviously does not support the interjection made by the honourable member for Petrie that employees should pay the fringe benefits tax. This Government has come to the conclusion that the employer should be responsible for paying the tax on fringe benefits because the employer has the power to decide how large a portion of an employee's income package shall be provided in the form of tax-free fringe benefits. The principle of the Bill is that all forms of remuneration paid to employees should bear a fair and reasonable measure of tax. I would have hoped that everyone in this chamber would support that principle.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to draw to the attention of the House some research which was done, I believe, in connection with the preparation of the draft White Paper issued in June 1985 by the Treasurer entitled `Reform of the Australian Taxation System'. That very interesting research concerned the level of fringe benefits currently being paid. I seek leave to have these four tables incorporated in Hansard, Mr Deputy Speaker. They have been shown to the shadow Minister at the table.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted subject to the normal ruling of the Speaker in this connection.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The first three tables were prepared by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The first indicates the number of employees who receive fringe benefits and divides those benefits into different categories. Some 5.1 per cent of the survey group received entertainment allowances; 3.9 per cent received holiday expenses-tax-free income in the form of payments from the employer to help them with the cost of their holidays; and 1.8 per cent of employees received a tax-free fringe benefit in the form of club dues. If 1.8 per cent of employees are receiving a tax-free fringe benefit in the form of free membership of a club, on my figures that means that 98.2 per cent of Australian employees out there do not have their club memberships paid by their employers. What those of us on this side of the House are saying is that it is unfair for a small minority of the upper income groups to be able to receive these benefits, tax free, when the great majority of ordinary PAYE taxpayers do not. In fact table 2 indicates that there has been an alarming increase in a proportion of salaries paid in the form of fringe benefits. There was an 18 per cent increase in tax-free benefits paid as entertainment allowances and an almost 15 per cent increase in the level of fringe benefits paid in the form of club dues. The third table indicates the level of fringe benefits received by four different income groups within the community. As would be expected, low earners receive very little in the form of fringe benefits while the upper income groups receive the biggest benefits. The fourth table was compiled from data supplied by Price Waterhouse and Associates. It shows the level of income benefit received by people such as chief executive officers, marketing executives and sales executives in the form of tax-free fringe benefits. I am very interested in the attitude of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) to the fringe benefits tax which is currently before the House. We have had members of the Liberal and National parties bleating, complaining and moaning and groaning about the fringe benefits tax, but what is the attitude of their leader?
—Here come some selected quotes.

—As the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) explained to the House earlier today, when the Leader of the Opposition was on a tour of north Queensland several weeks ago he was put on the spot and was asked to give a guarantee that he would repeal the fringe benefits tax legislation. He refused to give a commitment to do so. So no matter what the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) believes, no matter what the honourable member for Flinders interjects, we have it on record that the Leader of the Opposition has refused to give a commitment that he will repeal the fringe benefits tax. If the current Leader of the Opposition is deposed by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), who is at the table at the moment, or, dare we think it, the honourable member for Flinders, can we expect that some future Leader of the Opposition would agree to repeal the fringe benefits tax? If so, we go back to the original question: Our fringe benefits tax will raise $540m in 1987-88. That will fund income tax cuts. If Opposition supporters would repeal the fringe benefits tax, does that mean that they would increase income taxes? They would not be able to fund the income tax cuts that we will deliver on 1 September of this year and 1 July of next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make it very clear from the beginning that the Opposition is not opposed to the principle of imposing a fringe benefits tax but believes that only legitimate aspects should be the subject of such taxation. I want to make that very clear because it would appear that Government supporters are claiming that we do not want a fringe benefits tax under any conditions. It was explained earlier today in the debate that industrial awards are not to be affected by this fringe benefits legislation. The people who will be affected are those who have employees who virtually do not come within the orbit of the unions and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. I believe it is very important to remember that. Might I also correct the claim expressed here earlier that the Liberal and National parties when in government did nothing to attend to tax avoidance. I would invite honourable members to have a look at Hansard and the legislation that has been passed. They will find that considerable and very constructive legislation was introduced in the 1982 to early 1983 period, legislation that did a great deal to combat tax avoidance.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to address many of the details of the legislation before the Parliament. All I want to say is that the introduction of these tax reform measures by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has caused further confusion to many, including the average Australian. Particularly concerned are the businessman and the farmer, and industry generally. Greatly concerned must be those accountants and tax and legal people who must advise their clients on the future planning of their assets and businesses generally. If the Government were to act responsibly it would undertake a complete review of our tax system-not the type of review that was carried out by the Treasurer at a tax summit that was influenced by the ACTU. The ACTU and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) finally had their say as to the future direction of taxation in this country of ours. The level of taxation is rising. The honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) has given certain figures. He is not altogether correct as to those, because the brackets involved have changed. Although there is to be a general reduction in personal taxation, the average Australian should examine the effect when people move into higher wage brackets. They will find that a great number, I understand in the vicinity of some 700,000 will be paying extra income tax. So the Government can afford to relieve, in theory, certain sections of the taxpayers of Australia. If we want to relieve taxation in this country of ours we should consider what the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) said only the other day-that taxation on petrol has increased by $2.3 billion. I was in the United States of America the other day and saw petrol being sold to the motorist for 82c a gallon, or less than 18c per litre. Also motor vehicles there are approximately half the price that they are here. Based on this fact, when we consider industry's cost of production in America as compared with that of Australia, we see the problem that we have today in this country.

I draw attention to a couple of matters that will be seriously affected by the legislation before the Parliament. We have said many a time that this nation is dependent upon the farmer. I want to reiterate that. He has not had a very good go in recent times from the point of view of markets, from the point of view of seasons or from the point of view of the policy of the government of the day. It is of no use saying that many of the issues that are involved in the legislation before the House will not affect the farmer or the businessman. I draw attention to the farmer who is employing a share-farmer. The farmer may lease the property to him. He may be a general employee who is working on the property. We have all made such agreements with employees in the past and if we have been responsible people they have been happy and satisfied with them for the everyday, every week, every year working of a property or a business. It will mean under the legislation that the employer will have to pay tax on the house that he is giving as part of his deal to that person working on his property. Furthermore, the farmer will have to pay tax on those concessions that he is being given by way of milk, beef, power, gas or other type of concession. Every Australian should know that. No member of the Government can deny the inequities that are being handed out under this legislation to those responsible people who are engaged on farms and in small business today.

During the debate some honourable members have spoken of the car industry. A manufacturer living within my electorate, Brylite of Taree, wrote to me this morning. He employs 200 people and manufactures a component for General Motors. He will be affected because more than 25,000 fewer vehicles have been sold in the last three months for the fleets that are used by businessmen. The effect will be passed down within the community from the manufacturer to the businessman. Everybody is going to be affected. Why does this Government always do things that affects the working man adversely? The whole of Australia ought to know that it has the highest taxing government that the country has ever experienced. Furthermore, the Government is condemning to unemployment those who it purports to represent. I do not want it to represent the people within my electorate because I believe that they are being sold out. We talk about the decentralisation of industry. We talk about competitiveness with other countries around the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 101. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The honourable member for Lyne will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

—I address my question to the Prime Minister. In order that Parliament can exercise its judgment on whether or not there has been proved misbehaviour sufficient to justify the removal of a High Court judge under the Constitution and finally to put to rest increasing public disquiet on the issue, will the Prime Minister assure the House that the terms of reference of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Bill will facilitate scrutiny by the Commission of all matters covered by the two volumes of the Stewart Royal Commission report, the Age tapes themselves, the opinion by senior counsel, Ian Callinan, QC, and his junior as counsel to the Director of Public Prosecutions relating to further possible charges against Mr Justice Murphy, allegations against the judge made in the National Times and such matters that may have arisen in the trial of Mr Justice Murphy as may be deemed by the Commission to be relevant, apart from the specific charge on which the jury found him innocent? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the National Party for his question. The Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Bill will be before the House later this afternoon. It will be quite clear from the legislation and the exposition on it by my colleague the Attorney-General as to the precise coverage that will be allowed. Let me make this point which I think is most relevant to the quite proper question by the Leader of the National Party: I think all members of the House will appreciate that in the preparation of this legislation the Government by definition has had to cover totally new ground. As distinct from the appetite in some quarters on the other side of the House for a political witch hunt, what the Government has properly had in its mind are these things-and may I say, it is a consideration which I am sure is shared by the overwhelming majority of this country: We have had consideration for the interests and rights of this Parliament; we have had a concern for the institution of the High Court; we have also had a concern, which I would hope others on the other side of the House would not forget, for the proper interests and rights of Mr Justice Murphy and of others who could be involved in the inquiry. To take proper account of all those legitimate interests we have, in the time available, had drafted legislation which we believe will meet those interests.

ANSWER.PARA: I do make this point, which I am sure will be made in greater detail by my colleague, the Attorney-General: We have had properly to have account, and I think the right honourable gentleman who asked the question would understand this, at one and the same time of ensuring that the Commission has every opportunity to consider those matters which are appropriate to a section 72 consideration and at the same time ensure the well-established principle, which I know the right honourable gentleman would share, autrefois acquit-once dealt with on a particular matter and acquitted there should not be a retrial on that issue. We have had to take account of both those considerations-that is, that the function and purpose of operating in regard to a section 72 requirement should be taken into account and that we should not have a retrial on a particular issue on which a decision has been taken. I think in good faith we have taken account of all the interests to which I alluded, and we have taken account of those two considerations. Therefore, I am sure that having taken those things assiduously and conscientiously into account, the right honourable gentleman will see, when the Bill is presented and the exposition of the Attorney-General is before the House, that we have succeeded.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Do the latest labour force statistics confirm that the Government's commitment to generating jobs is being sustained?
—No, they do not. What nonsense!

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The understanding of the House is assisted by the intervention of the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, who said: `What nonsense'. We will deal with him in a moment. I thank the honourable member for his question. I would hope that, irrespective of party affiliations, the statistics that have been released today in regard to the labour force would be welcome and a matter of joy to all Australians whatever one's political persuasion. The statistics for April indicate continued strong employment growth. Total employment in seasonally adjusted terms increased by 60,700 in April. So all honourable members will appreciate that since the low point of April 1983, the point reached after the battering this economy was given by honourable members opposite when in government, the total rise in employment is 669,400 in the three years April 1983 to April 1986.

ANSWER.PARA: We hear at times from this beleaguered Opposition the observation that the Government has not delivered. The Opposition does not like hearing about delivery on our promise of half a million jobs, because we have delivered 670,000 jobs. The strength of that employment growth is emphasised by an increase of 132,300 jobs since December 1985, which I know the House will appreciate comprises 73,600 full time employees and 58,700 part time employees. Since the end of the financial year 1984-85 employment has grown by 4.5 per cent. In the 12 months April 1985 to April 1986 employment increased by 358,000 in original terms. I think honourable members will be pleased to know that that is the largest April to April increase since the commencement of monthly surveys in 1978. It is also interesting to note that the participation rate has risen to a record level of 62.4 per cent compared with 61.9 per cent in March.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like youth unemployment-600,000 unemployed.
—Order!

—Do not worry about him, Madam Speaker-no one else does. Because the participation rates increased to a new record level, the actual unemployment level was not changed but stayed steady at 7.9 per cent. I think, as I say, that those figures will give comfort to everyone in the community, except the myopic and miserable-minded interjector on the other side. Honourable members may recall that yesterday, on a related issue, I was asked about the statement of Mr Fitzgibbon in the area of wage fixing, which I suppose in a sense is related to this employment matter. I recalled from the recesses of my memory that Mr Fitzgibbon had had something to say on this issue in terms of whether there was any comfort for the Opposition. I know that all honourable members will be throbbing with interest just to have the details of what Mr Fitzgibbon had to say. He referred to Mr Howard's quoted observation that there was comfort for Mr Howard and the Opposition in what Mr Fitzgibbon had to say. I quote from the Age of 27 March, in these terms:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Fitzgibbon denied Mr Howard's claim yesterday. ``It is absolute nonsense to say that,'' he said. ``I have nothing but contempt for the Opposition's policy because it is designed to produce conflict in this country, which we need like a hole in the head.''
That is a hole in the head which the Opposition will never be able to deliver because the people of Australia will not trust it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. First, is it correct that he has given an undertaking to Senator Chipp that no New South Wales judges will be appointed to the commission of inquiry into the alleged conduct of Mr Justice Murphy? Secondly, will he assure the House that there will be genuine consultation with the Opposition about the judges to be selected?

—No, it is not true to say that I have given Senator Chipp an undertaking that none will be selected. I did have discussions, in consultation with others, with Senator Chipp and there was a discussion about the possible range of selection. The observation was made that, for reasons which I think the honourable gentleman would understand and without any adverse implications for anyone there, there were difficulties in regard to New South Wales which would not exist elsewhere.
—Why?
—Why? There are only difficulties with the Labor Party in New South Wales.

—I am pleased to see that the honourable gentleman is attempting to listen to the answer. I give the House the assurance that there was nothing said to the effect that there would be a ban upon judges from New South Wales. I have made that observation, but there was no ban. As to the second part of the honourable gentleman's question, I believe that the final selection of these judges is predominantly the responsibility of the Government-I do not think he would dispute that-but I do not see any reason why the Attorney-General at an appropriate time may not have some discussion in those terms, accepting that we have the final responsibility in the matter.
—And before the determination as to who they are to be?

—The honourable gentleman can be spoken to before the final determination, yes. If what he has had to say on this matter generally is any indication of the sort of help we can expect, I do not expect him to be of much help in this respect.

—Is the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware of proposals to scrap the prices and incomes accord and substitute a policy of supposed labour market flexibility? Will he advise the House what would be the likely effects of such policies on the level of wages, industrial disputation and economic growth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that the Opposition, all the time this Government has been in office, has been criticising the accord, despite the results that it has been achieving, and calling for it to be scrapped. This is part of the policy to be revealed in a few days time. Let me remind the House that the accord had its rationale in the need for this country to have a wages policy which was compatible with substantial and prolonged economic and employment growth, something which had patently not been achieved by the previous Government. It was on that basis that the accord was developed by the present Government and the trade union movement to try to have an agreed wages policy which would be fair to wage and salary earners but which would achieve that highly desirable economic outcome.

ANSWER.PARA: The accord has been eminently successful. The Prime Minister revealed just today the latest employment figures, which show a staggering growth in employment over the last year. Honourable members will be interested to note that growth in employment in the three years that we have been in office has been just on double the increase in employment achieved by the Fraser Government in less than half the time that that Government was in office. We have achieved resounding success in respect of employment. Real unit labour costs are back to the level of the late 1960s and early 1970s, the profitability of industry has been restored, inflation went down to 5 per cent until the devaluation intervened, industrial disputes are at their lowest level for 17 years in terms of time lost, and international competitiveness is at the highest level for many years.

We can see that we have had many economic successes stemming from the accord. The accord has also been demonstrated to be flexible or adaptable in the sense that it has been able to adjust to the need for some change in wages policy, particularly in relation to the devaluation. I remind the House that if we had not had the accord and there had been a devaluation of the order that have had, the alternative policy for squeezing the inflation impost from the devaluation out of the economy would have been to recess the economy severely and to increase unemployment so that the increased inflation was not reflected in wage increases. That is the alternative policy without the accord. Without the accord, we would certainly not be looking at the employment outcomes that we are looking at at present.

In this situation, we have an Opposition which is about to produce an industrial relations policy that, we are told, will say that the accord is a nonsense and which will seek to have instead a policy of wage flexibility-something that honourable members opposite keep rabbiting on about. The key question that must be asked is how the Opposition, in the absence of the prices and incomes accord, would be able to control wages if it were by some fluke to get back into government. What policies would it have to ensure that the total wage outcome was compatible with prolonged and sustained economic and employment growth?

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on; wind up-three minutes.
—Order!
—The answer is that the Opposition would have no such policy.
—It is 3 1/2 minutes now.
—It has no policy in any way to control wage growth in this country and it is not likely to develop such a policy. It is not likely to develop such a policy because--
—Come on; make a statement if you want to.
—Madam Speaker, will you please ask the right honourable gentleman opposite to stop shouting?
—The Minister can continue his answer.
—As I was saying, despite the constant barrage of interjections, which obviously shows that honourable members opposite do not like what I am saying--
—You are now up to four minutes.

—Order! The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting. I remind the House that there is no time limit for Ministers' answers. I have pointed this out once before. Ministers are expected to keep their answers to a reasonable time. If the House would like to limit the time in which Ministers have to speak, the way is open to it through the Procedures Committee.

—Madam Speaker, I take a point of order. Our Standing Orders provide an opportunity for ministerial statements to be made and, as the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services constantly reminded the previous Government, the procedure for answering questions on notice is not designed to replace that alternative. I suggest to the Minister, who has been speaking for 4 1/2 minutes, that it would be appropriate for him to answer the question and not to use Question Time as an opportunity to make a ministerial statement.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—As I was saying before I was rudely interrupted, the policy of simply saying that one would lean on the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to prevent it from awarding wages increases is no substance for an overall wages policy. What is to stop unions going outside the Commission, as they did in 1981, and seeking wage increases directly from employers? It was that policy in 1981 which led to a spectacular wages blow-out, which in turn led to an increase in inflation and thereby to a substantial increase in unemployment.
—Wind up.
—Order!
—And it led to the end of the Fraser Government. The wages policy is absolutely crucial--
—Come on; wind up.
—I warn the Leader of the National Party.
—I am still timing him.
—I warn the Leader of the National Party.

—A credible wages policy is absolutely crucial to a credible economic policy. A party which has no credible wages policy is not, of course, a credible alternative government. A policy that simply says that the Opposition would have flexibility built into the system is no substitute for having some control over the macro-wages outcome. Indeed, circumstances of having no such controls but having flexibility-that is, enabling small business for a start and bigger business later to opt out and achieve wage increases by voluntary agreements-is simply another way in which unions would be able to break out of whatever centralised system is operating and achieve even higher levels of wage increases.

ANSWER.PARA: The crucial question that has to be asked when the Opposition reveals its long awaited industrial relations policy on Sunday is: What would be the Opposition's wages policy if it were to get into government? How would it control wages? How would it ensure that there was not a wages blow-out? How would it ensure that it would not take this country back to the stagflation in which it left this country in 1983, when we had double digit inflation and double digit unemployment?

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industry. In view of the clear findings by and recommendations of Professor Lazenby, when will the Government implement plant variety rights in Australia and provide our agricultural industries and plant breeders with the potential to improve their productivity and competitive edge?

—This matter is under consideration and the announcement will be made. There is no way that we could introduce legislation in this session of Parliament, should we chose to or decide to, but we will make a decision as soon as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LEADER OF THE OPPOSITION: SPEECH TO THE NATIONAL PRESS CLUB

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Treasurer seen the pretentiously titled `Foundations for Government' speech given by the Leader of the Opposition at the National Press Club today? What effects would these changes in policy have on Australia's economic performance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the speech, and it is a little lalapalooza. Wait until honourable members focus on this little lot to see where the foundation stones for the future will be laid. It is the most hollow, vacuous speech one could ever imagine from a leader of a major party. It was a much-heralded speech which was supposed to tell us where the Liberal Party of Australia was going, set down the principles, lay out the agenda and set the way forward. We find that it is the most empty, rhetoric-filled address one could ever imagine in one's life. For instance, I start with this basic assumption in the speech:

ANSWER.PARA: With our great natural resources and the ability and diversity of our population, Australia's relative living standards should be increasing-not decreasing.
No recognition has been given to the fact that we now have the worst terms of the trade in the world that we have ever had.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the honourable member for Barker.

—There is no recognition of the fact that the world will not pay for these great natural resources; it does not want them. We are back to the old resources boom rhetoric of the late 1970s-`Dig up another mound of rocks and the world will be our oyster'. Do honourable members remember the days when members of the previous Government were clocking up the number of projects and telling us about our resources? The fact is that now wool prices are down, wheat prices are down, iron ore prices are down, coking coal prices are down and oil prices are down. But the Leader of the Opposition says: `No, we will have an increase in living standards because we have all those resources'. That is the reality of his speech. He goes on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: The slowdown in economic activity which will intensify as the months go by is a direct result of the needlessly high interest rate policy . . . pursued by the Treasurer.

In other words, the current account does not matter. The Opposition is saying: `We will overstress the economy with 5 per cent or 6 per cent economic growth. We will let imports just burst out. We will hock ourselves to the rest of the world to the tune of $1 billion to $1 1/2 billion a month'. Liberal Party policy will not facilitate the fact that we have a major current account problem which was left by the coalition, and a disastrous decline in the pattern of world trade. Basically, the Leader of the Opposition is trapped in the late 1970s, with a project here and a project there and more economic growth and higher living standards-the great nirvana of the resources boom.

The Leader of the Opposition then got back onto wages. If ever there was an economic Bourbon who has learned nothing and forgotten nothing on the question of wages, it is the Leader of the Opposition. He even had the indecency to refer to his last Press Club speech where he said that the great challenge and the great fight of the decade would be on the wages front. What do we find that he proposes? He would take us back to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, but there would be voluntary agreements concerning work conditions and arrangements, provided there is a minimum hourly rate. In other words, we would have centralised wages with flexibility upwards. We would go back to the wages explosion of the late 1970s. We would be right back where we were in 1983, with massive unemployment and massive inflation. One cannot believe that a modern party facing the realities of this world could produce this drivel. The Leader of the Opposition went on to say that he will not have a shopping list. He said:
I do not intend to set out a long shopping list of political goodies . . . those days are gone.

The Leader of the Opposition went on to say on page 4 of his speech that he would introduce income splitting. He said that the Opposition would go back to giving tax rebates for child care and tax incentives for employee share acquisition schemes. Then he nominated a savings figure of $4.3 billion, which he said would facilitate all these tax cuts. He went back to the Fraser formula to nominate $4.3 billion, but when questioned at the Press Club on the specifics of the $4.3 billion expenditure cuts, he said: `Don't ask me specific questions, you will get that when the policies dribble out'.

What is this so-called foundation stone, the direction forward, the way forward-call it what you like? The Opposition says: `The world will save us again. We will find another mound of rocks to sell to somebody but we do not need to run a decent wages policy. We will go back to the Arbitration Commission with a minimum wage and flexibility upwards by voluntary agreements. We do not need to worry about fiscal policy. We can have a greater freedom of choice for families with regard to tax'. In other words, the Opposition proposes going back to the Howard principle of voluntary taxation of `Pay tax if you feel like it'.

The Leader of the Opposition is trapped in a time warp. He is trapped in 1978. With his views on wages, tax, external policy, wherever one looks, this is a man who has learned nothing in the years since 1978 when he was caught in the tax debate when the world had left us behind and when the mineral resources boom blew out. The speech he made today was one he could quite easily have made as Treasurer in 1978. In waiting for something to turn up from the Liberal Party which had some semblance of facing the facts and some semblance of facing reality, we have the greatest load of drivel that I have ever seen from a modern Leader of the Opposition trying to address the fundamentals of the Australian economy. All I can say is that if the Press lets him get away with that, he should wait for the rebound when they read his speech closely and carefully and analyse the facts. What the Leader of the Opposition proposed today is really not a solution to anything, but a whole lot of rhetoric and humbug which is a disgrace to the Parliament and to his own Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment. Madam Speaker, with your indulgence, I preface my question very briefly by holding up this small fossil which is 15 million years old. I would be happy to show it to individual members-for a small fee, of course. Madam Speaker, I most certainly will take this fossil around to your office. Will the Minister advise the House of the significance of the Riversleigh fossil site? Will the Minister and the Government consider additional assistance for this world shattering, historic project?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I am sure we are all aware of his long interest in fossils. Honourable members may be aware that recent Press articles have featured the unique fossil find at the Riversleigh site which is claimed to be under threat from foreign fossil collectors and from lack of Government funding. The site is of major international significance and has been described as one of the most important in the world, if not the most important. What makes the site so different is that the fossils occur in different rocks of different ages. We have recognised this valuable find as an important part of our heritage and we have assisted research accordingly. I have approved funding for $60,000 in National Estate grants and my colleague, the Minister for Science, has approved funding through the Australian research grant scheme which has provided $61,000 this year and will continue provision until 1991. My colleague, the Minister for Defence, has provided helicopters for the transport of fossil material from the field and I have recently written to him seeking more assistance in that area.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the removal of fossils from the site by overseas collectors, I should point out that regardless of how the specimens are obtained, taking them out of Australia is prohibited under the Customs Act and also under the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill which was passed by this House a week or so ago. I do not think that the nation has yet realised the importance of this site in the electorate of the honourable member for Kennedy. I believe it has been described as the Rosetta Stone of palaeontology and I can assure the House that the Government will continue its interest and give every support that it can to this very important site.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industry. Is he aware of recent reports in the media that Mr Warburton, Opposition Leader in Queensland, is critical of both the Queensland and Commonwealth governments for the lack of progress in arriving at a final package of assistance for the Queensland sugar industry? Is the Minister also aware of recent media reports that the Queensland Premier has finally agreed to the latest proposals, but has said that the Commonwealth is holding a gun at his head? What is the state of play between the two governments on price support, farm debt reconstruction and mill adjustment assistance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Yes, I am aware of the reports in the newspapers of the comments that Mr Warburton has made. Like everyone else, he has had an absolute gutful of the mental meanderings, procrastinations and abuse of the Premier of Queensland on this topic. I must say that Neville Warburton and the Queensland Labor Party have been most assiduous in putting forward to the Commonwealth Government various plans to try to help this industry and to try to break the road block. I do not have a clue what is in the Queensland Premier's mind at any one particular time or what he will say from one day to the next. A lot of figures are being bandied around and this always confuses people, but the Queensland Premier is not very numerate. Recently he was interviewed and he said that he had eight tractors at home on his different properties and three of them used $1,000 worth of fuel every week. He then went on to say `One thousand dollars for three tractors-that is $6,000 a week'. He is very good.
—He is the Treasurer, too.

—Yes, he is the Treasurer also-well, National Party Treasurer. The trouble is that he uses statistics in a most incredible way. Apparently at one stage he said that the Commonwealth Government was taking $700m in taxes out of an industry worth $800m. Somebody chipped him about that so he upped the ante again and said that we were taking $800m in taxes from that industry. His assistance for the sugar industry has gone up from $10m to $15m to $61m to $81m to $170m. Every time he is interviewed he jumps up the figure. He said that $5,000 goes to Lindeman Island but the figure is only $4,000. He uses statistics as if they were Halley's Comet. The comet is 130 million kilometres away, it is 20 million kilometres across, it is five billion years old and it is pretty hard to see anything tangible. This is a serious matter.
—Are you trying to help Joh?

—God yes, I am trying to help the sugar industry. I defy anyone to help when a bloke like Joh is in charge of the Government up there-unfortunately. The Cabinet took a decision in September 1985 to put $150m up front. That was on the table and it went and that involved the Queensland and New South Wales governments putting in additional money. This much vaunted $240 a tonne would have been possible. The counter offer from Queensland was that, up front, we should put up $174m, it should put up $26m, but then the Queensland Government raced off and claimed it was worth $170m. When one is dealing with figures and the concepts involved in this assistance package one must realise that the problem has been that the Queensland Premier keeps cutting off his Minister at the knees, as I have said before. We then took another Cabinet decision on the basis of a further discussion with the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries which involved $27m being put in by the Queensland Government-an improvement in real money. As long as that was regarded as some form of price support, we were willing to come in with $54m on price support and $46m for adjustment for debt reconstruction and for mills.

—Opposition members say `Shame' but they should listen to the figures-$150m for 6,000 producers. If one multiplies that by every farmer in Australia it amounts to $4.35 billion. Honourable members opposite cannot tell me that that is ungenerous. That and the rest of the assistance package involved a 75 per cent interest subsidy. Honourable members opposite are crazy. Further discussions I had with the Under Secretary of the Treasury, Mr Hielscher, and the Deputy Secretary of my Department last Thursday centred on the last discussions I had with Mr Turner, the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries, and involved altogether in terms of loans and moneys, a total of $306m, that is, with the Commonwealth putting $100m up front. We do not know the exact figure but the trouble is that Queensland demands that we simply hand the money over. This is not the bushranger government. We have proper Cabinet processes, a Public Accounts Committee and an Expenditure Committee. We have proper accountability. We will not hand over money to Joh to give to his mates so that they can put money into the Bjelke-Petersen fund. That is just nonsense.

ANSWER.PARA: I have tried to give the House the logic of price support, but we will not be held out to dry by the Queensland Government. The Premier sets the rules and we are prepared to play by them. His logic is that he is not prepared to put money into price support because it will set a precedent. Yet he thinks it is all right for us to set a precedent by putting in so much money for price support, as long as he can then have the privilege forever and a day of kicking us to death because we are not putting in enough. Let us look at the $240 per tonne.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on. Wind up.

—No, I am not going to wind up; it is a good question. Let us look at the $240 per tonne. We are prepared to go in at $230 per tonne, which is $10 a tonne above what the two governments, the millers and the growers agreed to in the Savage Committee report. The 1984 poll gave the industry $234.65 per tonne and we will underpin that industry so that the growers will get only 41c a tonne less for their cane. One cannot say that that is not generous. That is underpinning the industry. Honourable members opposite may remember that when they were in government there were various underwriting schemes and the whole idea of these is to put a base under an industry when there is a collapse on the international markets in order to keep private sector finance and confidence in the industry.

ANSWER.PARA: There are also mill negotiations going on. Again, we are prepared to be involved in those as long as there is proper consultation. Again, we are not prepared just to hand money across. The honourable member for Leichhardt and the honourable member for Herbert have been most assiduous in getting to me their views on the question of mill amalgamations in the far north. However, I have not heard from the honourable member for Kennedy at all. The problem with mill amalgamations is that even though the plan looks reasonably feasible to me, the Queensland Government has not bothered to have any consultation at all with the growers. That is why that plan is foundering. That is why we need a proper consultative committee if we intend to do anything about mill amalgamation or mill rationalisation. If the Queensland Premier, out of his crazy old spleen, decides to sabotage this plan, all I can say is the Commonwealth will continue to act responsibly and will proceed to do as much as possible for the sugar industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: Has there been any communication between his Government or his office and the New South Wales Premier or any part of the New South Wales Government or any adviser to that Government regarding the terms of reference for the judicial inquiry relating to Mr Justice Murphy?
—As I understand the question to relate to communication between my Government and the Premier of New South Wales or his office about the terms of reference, the answer is no.
—No. Or the Government of New South Wales or any adviser to the Government of New South Wales.
—Not to my knowledge.

—My question, which I address to the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services, relates to the article in yesterday's Canberra Times about the Cameron offices. I ask the Minister: Is the report that there are 177 water leakages in the offices correct? Are these leakages jeopardising the personal safety of occupants, as one expert commented? What plans has the Minister's Department made for stopping the leaks and for preventing further structural damage to the offices? How much will this repair work cost? Who is responsible for this costly failure and does the Government have any redress for the damage that has resulted from apparently poor design?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of Housing and Construction has advised that there are 177 water leaks in the Cameron building. Regrettably, the building leaks like a sieve and I have no doubt that the publishers John Fairfax and Sons Ltd will take note of that comment. As regards to the blame, a number of governments have been involved. Certainly, planning and construction was commenced under the Gorton Government and then under the McMahon Government. The building was under construction during the time of the Whitlam Government and was completed under the Fraser Government. So the building has a long history. There has been evidence that the water has come into contact with electrical equipment in the building. The Department of Housing and Construction has investigated the matter and action has been taken to remove any elements of risk.

ANSWER.PARA: My Department was concerned about the situation and, as a result, it commissioned the Department of Housing and Construction to report on the remedial action that should be implemented to overcome the present water leakage problem. As a result, the National Capital Development Commission, in consultation with the Department of Housing and Construction, has sponsored a three-year program of remedial works that will include rectifying the structural damage. Funds have been made available and work will commence early in the next financial year. The present estimated cost of the works is $8.92m. I cannot identify at present the origin of the water leaks and the structural problem in the Cameron offices. However, my Department has been seeking the advice of both the Department of Housing and Construction and the National Capital Development Commission to overcome these problems.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CHERNOBYL NUCLEAR ACCIDENT: CONTAMINATION OF FOODSTUFFS

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister inform the House as to what steps his Government is taking to make absolutely certain that no foodstuffs, particularly dairy products, can be imported into Australia which could be contaminated by radioactive fallout from the Chernobyl nuclear power plant disaster?

—All I can say, in answer to the honourable member's question, is that I have not had brought to my attention that there is a problem or a potential problem in this matter. I recognise the seriousness of the question. I will refer it to the relevant Minister and department. If there is anything I can convey to the honourable member, I will.

—Arising out of the previous question, I would like to put a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy. Is the Minister in a position to provide further information about the Chernobyl nuclear reactor accident, apart from the material available in the media? When might we expect a comprehensive release of detailed information about radiation and fallout? Is the fallout spreading throughout Europe likely to have any impact in the Southern Hemisphere?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The quality of information so far is extremely poor. We are essentially dependent on information from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and very little has been provided officially. Much of the media reporting is incapable of being checked and it may be some years before the precise situation is clarified. The Soviet Deputy Prime Minister has now admitted that the local experts did not make a correct assessment of the accident and that its scope was underestimated at first. While the evacuation itself was reported to have taken only three hours, it was 36 hours before evacuation of the 40,000 people in the 30-kilometre zone around the plant commenced. Admitted deaths remain at two, not due to radiation but 204 people are reported to have been hospitalised suffering from radiation exposure. Specialised treatment is said to have been given to 100 in Moscow, 18 having received heavy radiation doses. The Russian authorities are continuing to say that the accident originated with a chemical explosion and fire in an engine room. In a recent Press release, the accident was said to have occurred during a planned shutdown while the reactor was operating at less than 10 per cent of capacity. It may be many years before we know the full situation.

ANSWER.PARA: I draw the House's attention to the last major nuclear accident in the USSR of which we are fully aware, and that was the accident in the city of Kyshtym in the Central Urals, about 1,400 kilometres due east of Moscow. It is impossible to be certain what precisely caused the nuclear catastrophe but it was probably cause by the faulty handling of radioactive waste. That was at the end of 1957 or the beginning of 1958. After nearly 30 years we still do not know the full impact of it except for the fact that a number of villages in the area were evacuated, the top soil was bulldozed over and the area was fenced off and declared out of bounds. We note from scientific studies that there was a significant impact on the ecology of the area-that soil, plants, animals and birds were all affected. There appears to have been massive loss of life: The figure has been quoted at around 10,000 and possibly more. But it is impossible to confirm, except by making a demographic comparison of censuses before and after the accident which suggests very heavy loss of life.

The honourable member asked whether the accident was likely to have any impact on the Southern Hemisphere. At this stage there is no evidence to suggest that the plume of radioactivity from the accident has reached the upper atmosphere. The spread of radioactivity appears to be confined to surface wind systems and it would be 12 to 18 months before any significant movement of contamination from the accident crossed the equatorial belt. Honourable members will be aware that the wind systems in the Northern Hemisphere and the Southern Hemisphere are largely separate: Not much weather passes through the equatorial belt. In the meantime, the radioactive contamination will be reduced by natural decay and washout and it is not expected that readily detectable levels will reach Australia. I should perhaps conclude by mentioning that the Director-General of the International Atomic Energy Agency, Dr Hans Blix, is now in Moscow having direct consul- tation with Soviet authorities on the Chernobyl accident. The Australian Government has asked him to provide information on a number of detailed matters. I hope that in the course of the next sitting period we will be able to provide more specific information.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CHERNOBYL NUCLEAR ACCIDENT: CONTAMINATION OF FOODSTUFFS

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, given the importance of the question asked by the honourable member for Wannon, I briefly seek your indulgence to provide information which has just been given to me by my colleague the Minister for Health. This information indicates that last week, as a precautionary measure, the Department of Health asked the Australian Customs Service to hold all food consignments which left the potentially affected countries on or after 25 April. The Food Importers Association has been advised of this action. Following assurances received from one country, Denmark, the Department has telexed Customs to remove Denmark from the list of potentially affected countries. Further clarification of the nature and extent of the potential effect of food imports is being sought from the Federal Department of Trade and the governments of the countries concerned, through Australian missions overseas. Should it prove necessary, the Department will establish a mechanism for monitoring these particular food imports with the Customs Service, the Australian Government Analyst and the Australian Radiation Laboratory. As the Department gets further information, those controls will be adjusted if necessary.

—On Monday, 5 May I attended the Embassy of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republic in Canberra with two Senate colleagues, Senator Macklin and Senator Hill. We attempted at that meeting to present to the Soviet Ambassador a petition signed by more than half the members of the House of Representatives and a very large number of senators protesting about the treatment of Soviet Jewry. I will articulate briefly the wording of the petition. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: We, the undersigned Parliamentary representatives of the Australian people, call on the Government of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics to permit the Jewish Community within the U.S.S.R. freedom to practice their religion free of persecution and discrimination, and freedom to be reunited with their families and People in Israel.

I know I have the leave of the House, so I will keep my comments very short and will not attempt in any substantive way to go into the issues. However, I want to make the following points: Currently, there are some 1.8 million Jews in Russia. That figure was provided by the Soviet Census Bureau. The response we had from the Embassy was that that constituted `lies'. When the officer of the Embassy was asked to indicate how many people were seeking to go to Israel from Russia, he indicated that he did not know those figures. There are no Jewish schools in the Soviet Union, nor are Jewish organisations permitted. There are no books in the Hebrew language and there are virtually no books published on Jewish history, culture and so on. I conclude on that point. I thank the House for making leave available. It is my view that anybody ought to be able to leave the Soviet Union to go to any country which is prepared to accept them.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with section 10 of the Inter-State Commission Act, I present the Commission's report into Cost Recovery Arrangements for Interstate Land Transport. I seek leave to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This comprehensive and well prepared report represents a further major step by this Government in the implementation of the first truly cohesive national approach to Australian transport. For far too long transport policies and practices have been fragmented. Australia can no longer afford that fragmentation and we have shown we are prepared to develop and implement the steps necessary to improve the efficiency of Australian transport. Shortly after coming to government we acted to re-establish the Inter-State Commission, a body created by the Australian Constitution but dormant for virtually all of Australia's history. It was appropriate that the first national reference I gave to the Inter-State Commission was to address cost recovery in land transport.

SPEECH.PARA: In undertaking this inquiry the Commission was asked to build on a number of initiatives taken by the Government including:
The national road freight industry inquiry, which produced the May report, and the interstate road transport legislation that flowed from the recommendations of that report;
the introduction of the Australian land transport program which meant that all Federal road programs were funded through a set share of fuel excise.

The Inter-State Commission was asked to attempt a task that would tax the wisdom of Solomon-to establish the relative cost recovery levels of interstate road and rail passenger and freight operations. Using that assessment, the Commission was then asked to recommend appropriate charges to apply under the interstate road transport legislation. In examining these issues, the Commission had to address in great detail the whole area of costs and charges applicable to both road and rail operations, their economics and legal constraints and obligations. This is consistent with the Government's even-handed approach to rail and road. We recognise the need to place both forms of transport on an equal, competitive footing.

The Inter-State Commission found that long distance interstate road hauliers perform 30 per cent of total road tonne kilometres, that 13 per cent of road employment is in interstate operations and 10,000 vehicles are exclusively engaged in interstate operations. The ISC also found that Government rail systems carried some seven million tonnes, performing over 11,000 million tonne-kilometres and carried 700,000 passengers in their interstate operations. I might add that for the information of the House the relative shares of interstate freight, as shown by the Australian Bureau of Statistics for 1983-84, are that road transport carried 16.2 per cent of total interstate freight and rail carried 15.8 per cent.

Further, the ISC found that interstate rail and road freight and passenger operations fail to cover all costs. Revenue from interstate road freight operations ranges from about 70 per cent to 94 per cent of costs but interstate rail freight recovers only 66 per cent of its fully distributed costs. The cost recovery level for rail passenger operations is even lower at 37 per cent. Whichever method the Inter-State Commission used, it found the cost recovery figures for our inter-state railways were well below the result for road, although the figures for Westrail and Australian National on their interstate operations are encouraging, the former in fact covering its fully distributed costs.

I am pleased to note on the positive side, that the Inter-State Commission did acknowledge that the railways have recently made considerable progress in developing a far more commercial approach. In this regard, the Federal Government's revitalisation of Australian National to make it more commercial and the formation of the National Freight Group to market rail freight services on a national basis were seen by the Commission as positive measures.

The Commission experienced considerable difficulty in arriving at a single reliable figure for road cost recovery, and has recommended further research in this area. However, taking these factors into account, the Commission has nevertheless recommended an interstate road transport charging framework which should be administratively simple, but which also maintains that the equity between rail and road which I mentioned earlier is a fundamental principle of our approach to cost recovery. (Quorum formed) It is interesting to note that this morning the Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair) was complaining of inadequate time to debate issues and here we have the Opposition Whip wasting time on quorums.

The House will recall that the Interstate Road Transport Acts, passed by the Parliament last year, for the first time provide a new system of registration charges for interstate trucks which to date have been able to avoid such charges by the States due to section 92 of the Constitution. The charges anticipated by the May report were on a sliding scale for trucks to a maximum of $1,400 per year for the largest 38-tonne rig. The charges assessed by the Commission are substantially lower than those seen as being appropriate by the May report. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table of the recommended charges.
Leave granted.
