TALK.START.PARA: —Under these charges the typical 38-tonne interstate rig would pay an annual charge of $675-less than half the figure envisaged by May. As noted by the Commission's report, its recommendations are a first step and further investigations will be required. The Inter-State Commission has extensively assessed the Federal registration scheme and its legislative base against section 92 of the Constitution. It is of the view that `the level of charges recommended in this report do not infringe section 92'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission's recommendations also have implications for the Government's fast track package. It is appropriate that I reiterate the contents of that package. For the Federal Government it involved the introduction of the Federal registration scheme, the proceeds of which would be returned to the States for interstate highway maintenance, and the establishment of the Australian Road Transport Advisory Committee. For the States it involved: Removal of out-of-State fees; improved consumer protection arrangements for the road transport industry; progress towards removal of speed limit differentials between heavy and other vehicles; the introduction of graduated driver licensing; and achieving improved cost recovery by railways in their interstate operation.

It was agreed by the Australian Transport Advisory Council that these measures would be implemented as a package and a target date of 1 July was identified for implementation. It was also agreed that progress would be monitored in the period leading up to 1 July and I made it clear to my State colleagues that if they had not achieved substantial progress I would not be proceeding to bring into operation the Federal registration scheme. The Federal Government has ready for implementation its registration scheme and has established ARTAC. On the other hand, except for New South Wales, there is no expectation that the States will have achieved substantial progress in respect to the measures within their control by 1 July.

Accordingly, I have advised my State colleagues that it is not appropriate for the Federal registration scheme to come into effect on 1 July. As a number of the States must make legislative changes to achieve progress on the steps within their responsibility, I have proposed that we agree on a revised implementation date of 1 January 1987. I have also advised the States of what I will accept as substantial progress by that date.

With respect to speed limits, a number of States have expressed some concern at moving immediately to 100 kilometres per hour for trucks and buses. Consequently, I have proposed a staged approach involving a speed limit of at least 90 kph being introduced by 1 January 1987 with the impact of this higher speed limit to be monitored by the Federal Office of Road Safety for 12 months. Extension to 100 kph would be considered in the light of those results.

All States are to have graduated driver licences in place by 1 January 1987. Under this scheme progression through the range of heavy vehicles will only be permitted having regard to age, training and experience. The relative cost recovery performance of road and rail transport is one of the fundamental issues considered by the ISC in this inquiry. I note that the Commission advised it `was able to obtain an insight into management and accounting methods which it believes went beyond any previous co-ordinated study'.

As this inquiry is the first ever of its kind the ISC's assessment of railway's financial performance now establishes a clearly independent benchmark against which future progress can be measured. In this regard the Commission noted `the railway systems stress that their level of cost recovery and commercial competitiveness in relation to interstate freight operations is improving markedly, and further progress is expected'. I will be pursuing with relevant States the need to maintain this progress and expect that the Inter-State Commission will conduct similar inquiries in the future to provide an independent assessment of how successful that progress has been. The level of registration charges for trucks would be adjusted in accordance with that assessment.

With respect to consumer protection the recommendations of the May report have been substantially implemented by the amendments to the Federal Trade Practices Act which should be in operation before 1 January 1987. Only New South Wales and Victoria apply out of State fees and both States are committed to removing these fees by 1 January 1987. In arriving at this package I have taken careful account of the views of the Australian Road Transport Advisory Committee and I would note that the package I have described above is in accordance with the recommendations made to me by ARTAC.

The implementation of the fast track package has been difficult and I am sure the road transport industry shares my disappointment in the delay that has occurred in regard to the implementation of this package of May report recommendations. In accordance with the commitments I have always maintained to the road transport industry I could not in these circumstances consider implementing the Federal registration scheme on the original target date of 1 July 1986. (Quorum formed)

There is important legislation before this House. There are two members of the Liberal Party of Australia to participate in the debate. Quite clearly the members of the Opposition have no response to the legislation before the House. They do not want to debate it. They continue to waste the time of this House by calling quorums. It does the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) little credit to participate in this time wasting exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I do not consider that I acted in any way improperly by calling a quorum.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—This delay does however mean that this landmark report by the Inter-State Commission can be taken fully into account in determining the details of the arrangements, notably the level of Federal registration charges. Now that the report has been tabled I will be discussing it with my State colleagues at the next meeting of the Australian Transport Advisory Council to be held in Alice Springs on 27 June. Consistent with the Government's established practice of full consultation with all interested parties before decisions are made I will also be discussing the ISC report with industry. I would also be pleased to receive comments from individuals on the report and its implications for the road transport industry. To fit in with the timetable, such comments should be provided by 31 July this year. Regulations for the implementation of the fast track package will not be introduced until this consultative process can be completed.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, the Inter-State Commission report on rail and road cost recovery is a professional and thorough document. It complements the work of the May inquiry into inter-state road transport and provides essential findings for the implementation of the `fast track' package. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I begin by commending the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) for his presentation of this report to Parliament and for doing so in an expeditious manner and his courtesy in providing me with a copy of his speech and the report. I must confess I have not read the full report. I also commend the members of this Inter-State Commission for presenting the report within the original time scale. It is a massive report, hence my comment that I have not read it in the two hours I have had access to it. It obviously provides a very valuable data and resource base for rail and road freight. However, I am puzzled and continue to be puzzled why the Bureau of Transport Economics is not a suitable organisation to conduct this sort of inquiry without the need for the Inter-State Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The report vindicates the position taken by the Opposition when the interstate road transport legislation was debated in Parliament in the spring session last year. At that time, speaking on behalf of the Opposition, I was critical of government haste to pass the legislation. This was for two particular reasons: First, that the Inter-State Commission did have the responsibility to inquire and report by the end of April. There was a feeling that such an investigation would produce something significant which would require alteration to original concepts. That indeed has occurred. Secondly, I had contacted the States and they were in no great hurry to pass the necessary complementary legislation. After all, the legislation is supposed to be for their benefit more than at the Commonwealth level. That is also indicated in the Minister's comments. Of all the States in Australia New South Wales is the only State to even introduce the legislation, and it did so in the dying hours of the session in the New South Wales Parliament last week. The States were very much aware that they should introduce complementary legislation before 1 July this year. During the debate in this House we proposed to withdraw and redraft the legislation, for the Government to consult with the industry more and reintroduce the legislation after the report of the Inter-State Commission. The Senate would refer it to a committee to allow better exposure to industry argument and also, of course, allow more time. The failure of the Australian Democrats to support this position caused the Bill to be passed at that time.

This report very much confirms the logic of our argument at that time. We also called on the Government to look again at the inclusion of the second part of the legislation; that is, those aspects beyond what the Minister calls the fast track package or section which covers the more regulatory and mandatory positions of safety operator, licensing and monitoring devices. The road transport organisations and operators will be relieved and pleased to hear that the Inter-State Commission because of its finding of only 66 per cent cost recovery for rail freight has recommended the reduction in the cost of the 38 tonne maximum weight rig for registration purposes to under half the original of $1,400 down to $675. The 66 per cent recovery reveals the terrible state of some of our State railways. It also vindicates the view of some road transport organisation officials who were confident that the inquiry would recommend a reduction rather than an increase in the registration fee. The Government now has a renewed opportunity to sell the proposal to the road freight transport organisations and people of Australia because the industry has turned against the proposal since that legislation passed through this House. The industry has done so because of a fear of the cost; that is, that there will be no quid pro quo in freight charges from the railways in relation to the $1,400 additional cost that many operators would have to face.

The Minister now has the opportunity to say that is not so, in the short term at least, and can go out and argue on that basis. There was also the fear that it really was the sly start of reintroducing road tax again to this nation based on the distance registration alternative. There was also fear and concern over new bureaucracies checking every movement of truck operators through licensing arrangements and monitoring devices; in other words, setting up a big brother establishment. Because the States are the main beneficiaries of this type of legislation, they have a responsibility to indicate to the road freight organisations and operators what their agendas are on these aspects of monitoring devices and licensing, et cetera; they will really implement these provisions. If they believe in these aspects they have the responsibility to go out and sell them to those organisations and operators.

I was interested to hear the progress on some of the other aspects of the Minister's fast track package. I acknowledge the progress he has made in moving to a 90 kilometre per hour uniform speed limit for trucks around Australia. I will watch with interest, along with the Minister and others, just how that works out and also note some other progress that he has made in obtaining greater uniformity. January 1 is now the new date set by the Minister. Time will tell whether that can be met, but it certainly is a more realistic date than 1 July. I note that the Minister has again stated that he will not implement his registration arrangements until there is substantial State compliance and more industry consultation. Both I and the industry will be watching that procedure. I commend the action of the Minister in recognising his parliamentary and public accountability responsibility in regard to this report.

PETITION.TITLE: Changes to Veterans' Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that persistent rumour suggest that the Hawke Government intends to reduce Government expenditure by contracting or eliminating programs for war veterans and war widows.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment and that of previous Governments to ex-servicemen and women by:
Ensure no additional cut-backs will be made to the portfolio of Veterans' Affairs.
Review the previous cut-backs in such areas as the travel allowances, dental scheme and repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme.
Proceed with abolishing more stringent conditions applying to the granting of the TPI pension.

PETITION.TITLE: Changes to Veterans' Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
Persistent rumour suggest that the Hawke Government intends to reduce Government expenditure by contracting or eliminating programs for war veterans and war widows.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Honour its commitment and that of previous Governments to ex-servicemen and women by:

Proceed with abolishing more stringent conditions applying to the granting of the TPI pension.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce divisions in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House of Representatives their concern at any change to the Australian Flag without first holding a Referendum to assess the opinion of the citizens of Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray that no changes be made to the Australian Flag without reference to the citizens of Australia in the form of a Referendum.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Additional Nuclear Reactor at Lucas Heights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That they oppose the construction of any additional nuclear reactor at the Australian Atomic Energy establishment at Lucas Heights in N.S.W., or any site within Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government of Australia will not construct an additional nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights or within Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Ms McHugh and Mr Tickner.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Bill of Rights is not supported by the people of Australia, and calls on the Government to:
Delay proclamation of the Bill until all matters of contention are settled by national referenda, and that:
(1) Matters of States rights, property rights, rights of the newborn, the right not to belong to unions, among other issues, have not been submitted to the people of Australia to decide, and that;
(2) No Australian Bill of Rights should depend on any foreign convention for its basis in Australian law.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights and Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission Bills
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned showeth that there is widespread public concern about the provisions of the Bill of Rights, and especially the dangerous powers to be vested in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission, and the failure to protect vital rights such as the right to own private property.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
(i) that the Hawke Labor Government not proceed with the Bills enacting the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission; and
(ii) that we the people be given the opportunity to express our opinion on the Bill of Rights in a referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows:

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Medicare Office, Wyong, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the fact that the lack of a Medicare Office in Wyong is seriously inconveniencing the residents of Wyong Shire.
Your petitioners therefore request that a Medicare office is established in Wyong as soon as possible.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain electors of Australia respectfully sheweth:

That the Bill of Rights Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, if passed by the Parliament, will undermine human and civil rights in Australia; will attack the institution of the family in our country, and will destroy States Rights and the federal nature of our Commonwealth.

Your petitioners humbly pray that: The Parliament rejects these Bills; abolishes the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and moves to withdraw ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the government to honour its election promises to pensioners.
In particular those promises relate to the following commitments:
1. That within three years of its election to office, a Hawke Labor Government would raise the level of the standard pension to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings;
2. That the lag time between the announcement of the Consumer Price Index figures and the subsequent adjustment of pensions would be reduced to one month, and
3. That the disproportionate tax burden borne by low income earners would be lifted.
None of these promises has been honoured to date.

Your petitioners are extremely angry at the failure of the Government to live up to its commitments and as in duty bound will ever pray that these serious omissions will be given the attention they deserve.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Namibia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That the humble petitioners respectfully believe that the representatives in Australia of the African National Congress of South Africa (ANC) and of the South West African People's Organisation of Namibia (SWAPO) should not have to suffer unending financial problems related to the cost of rent, food and clothing, and the maintenance of two small offices run on the most austere basis.
Your petitioners therefore pray and urge the Australian Government provision of:
1. Official recognition of the ANC and SWAPO as the legitimate representatives of the people of South Africa and Namibia;
2. Financial support to the offices and representatives of the ANC and SWAPO to promote the anti-Apartheid cause in Australia;
3. Additional financial support for the official representatives of the ANC and SWAPO to assist the humanitarian needs of Namibian and South African refugees who are victims of Apartheid;
4. Scholarships for South African and Namibian refugees. These to be provided through the ANC and SWAPO education departments.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Horticultural Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned that Australia's important horticultural industry is being severely disadvantaged by unnecessarily rising production costs.

Many Federal and State Government regulations, excessive taxes and charges are damaging the ability of horticultural growers to maintain supplies of food and plant products to Australian families at a realistic cost. Widespread unemployment will result if horticultural producers are further depressed.

The undersigned humbly petition the Parliaments of Australia, its States and Territories, to take all measures within their powers to reduce the burden of imposed costs and regulation, allowing Australian horticultural growers to develop production potential so the nation, as a whole, can share the benefits of the resulting growth and prosperity.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's proposal to bring about a reduction in the amount payable under the present Family Allowance Scheme, that the House of Representatives assembled oppose such a move, on the evidence of its impact upon the family unit.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek to restore payments to the former level.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Weapons Tests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
And, to the Australian Government.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that a comprehensive ban on all nuclear weapons tests in all environments for all time would be a vital first step towards:
inhibiting the addition of more and more sophisticated and destabilising nuclear weapons to the world's arsenals;
arresting the extension of the arms race to outer space;
upholding the provisions of existing treaties and agreements.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:

1. The Australian Government (a) take new initiatives to encourage all member States of the United Nations-especially the governments of nuclear weapon states-to conclude at an early stage a treaty banning all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time, (b) call on all nuclear weapon States to declare an immediate moratorium on all nuclear weapons tests pending conclusion of a CTB.
2. All Federal Members of Parliament and Senators make strong representations to the Australian Government to act towards these goals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Price Control
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.

Our alarm with the continued spiralling cost of commodities, brought about we believe, by the monopolisation of retail outlets by multi and transnational consortiums. We would ask the Government legislate effective price control and anti-monopoly measures to prevent further erosion of the living standards of the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, seek your most urgent action to rectify this deep concern to the community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Western Sydney State University
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully requests that:
The world's resources be redirected to the relief of human suffering, starvation, poverty and disease.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Stop spending taxpayers money on self promotion through high cost high profile but superficial policy on nuclear disarmament and make a genuine bipartisan commitment to positive and practical policies designed to achieve progressive world-wide nuclear disarmament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Lincoln Court Shopping Centre Post Office, South Australia
PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia showeth that we hereby object to the impending closure of ``Lincoln Court Shopping Centre'' Post Office, known as ``Pooraka East''.

If this proposal were implemented, it would greatly inconvenience the people who have used this facility since it first opened. There is very close to the Post Office, a small village consisting of approximately 80 elderly citizens who will be deprived of this facility. Currently the South Australia Housing Trust and private developers are building new housing estates within the catchment area of the Post Office and these new residents will also be greatly inconvenienced.

We feel that there has not been enough consideration given to the fact that ``This is a neighbourhood shopping centre'' and as such a Post Office is an integral part of same. Combined with the above loss, we are faced with the loss of the Commonwealth Bank if the Post Office were to go, as one is an integral part of the other.
This petition is to seek re-consideration of the closure.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will humbly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Mallee electorate respectfully showeth:
that all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
That the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural sector, which will severely affect its long term viability.
That the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament is causing confusion and hindering farmers in the organisation of their affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Services, Lakesland Area, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Macarthur respectfully showeth that:
1. There are not enough lines in or out of the exchange to handle the amount of subscribers.
2. The exchange was brought to this area from somewhere else as a temporary measure quite some years ago, with a promise of a new one when needed.

3. The state of the cable work along the roadsides is a disgrace, where in a number of places wires are sitting up out of the ground with plastic wrapped around the joints, or in some cases wires are run along the tops of fences through paddocks.
4. The phones can be out of order for at least four or five days before they are repaired.
5. There are too many wrong number connections which are not the fault of the person dialling and calls dropping out in the middle of conversations.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled urge the Government to establish a larger and more modern exchange in this area and not to keep saying it will be done in the future.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains

The proposed capital gains tax penalises small business, discourages long-term investment, hinders capital formation and will freeze existing investment patterns and limits the investors' ability to adjust to changed market conditions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Immediately abandon its ill-considered capital gains tax proposal.

PETITION.TITLE: Compulsory Unionism
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Queensland respectfully showeth:

that the actions of trade unions have gone beyond their traditional goals of protecting workers conditions and rates of pay and have reached the point where they are seriously affecting the economic health of the nation and the people.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray:
1. That all Governments throughout Australia acknowledge and protect the Right of Work on behalf of all Australians.
2. That the total sovereignty of individual governments be recognised as a fundamental requirement of a workable, balanced Federal system of government.
3. That all necessary steps be taken to protect the citizens of Australia from any inducement, compulsion, threat or intimidation to join any trade union.
4. That there should be no preference in employment for people who are members of trade unions.
5. That the supremacy of elected governments over the sectional interests of trade unions be recognised, and
6. That the provision of essential services be maintained, free from industrial disruption.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

that the current policy pursued by the Hawke Government is causing an intolerable increase in home loan interest rates beyond the capacity of families to pay.
that consequently this policy is causing grave hardship throughout Australia and is contributing to social problems and the breakup of the family unit.
that unless the Government act urgently the Australian dream of home ownership is fast becoming shattered for many of our citizens.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That the Government make home loan interest rates tax deductible therefore alleviating the present crippling burden of current high interest rates on home owners and home buyers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Fisher respectfully showeth:

That we deplore the discriminatory tax proposals as outlined in the Government's ``White Paper'' and the Government's preferred option on proposed new and widened tax proposals as so outlined, namely:
Capital Gains tax
Hidden Death tax described as ``Capital Gains tax after death''
Gift Tax
Increased Company tax
Employer taxes on employees' employment benefits.
All such taxes will discriminate against and inhibit progress, growth and employment throughout the nation.

They will attack hardworking people who have built up their assets; they will discourage thrift; they will inhibit development; they will treat unfairly all who plan for the future; they will cause trouble and expense in arriving at the value of their assets; they will discourage industry and punish achievement.

PETITION.TITLE: Ayers Rock
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Fisher respectfully showeth that:

Whereas the present Government of the Commonwealth of Australia has purported to present the Title Deeds to Ayers Rock in Central Australia, in reality the joint property of the people of the Commonwealth to an Aboriginal Land Council on 26 October 1985,

Whereas opinion polls and statements of representative groups, Members of Parliament and respected individuals show clearly that the Commonwealth Government had no mandate from the citizens of the Commonwealth to act in such a disgraceful manner,

Whereas the present Government claims to be totally opposed to apartheid (separate development) in South Africa but purported to hand over Ayers Rock to an Aboriginal Council in support of a policy of apartheid (separate development) which has been shown to be detrimental to the Aboriginal people of Australia,

Whereas it is pursuing this policy, making it a crime for most white and many Aboriginals to enter, without permit, large areas of the Commonwealth designated apartheid (i.e., set aside for separate development), contrary to our democratic traditions and experience of freedom of movement for citizens of all racial origins within Australia,
Whereas Australian citizens have no present means available to them to prevent this violation of their natural rights to unfettered common ownership of, and access to, a treasured natural asset.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Seek means available for the protection of the people's interests to reverse this outrage and preserve the democratic traditions of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The confusion, lack of clear direction and delays associated with the Government's policies on regional commercial television.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's policy on regional television is a shambles, and the total absence from the chamber at the moment of members of the Labor Party is evidence of that. In a speech in Sydney on 2 February 1984, the Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy, who has now entered the chamber, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is almost 11 months since Labor came to power and I was appointed Communications Minister. In looking back on those 11 months it is my strong belief that in keeping with the Government's objectives in communications we have made several noteworthy and progressive decisions . . . Firstly, of course, we have implemented the supplementary licence scheme and have already received numerous inquiries from broadcasters and others.

That was said by the Minister for Communications on 2 February 1984. It is over two years since the Minister uttered those words. One is led to ask just how many supplementary television licences have been issued since then? The answer is none.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many?

—None-not one. Yet the Minister for Communications listed the supplementary licence scheme as the most important of his Government's communications decisions. The supplementary licence scheme was designed by the Fraser Government to provide more choice in commercial programming for people in regional Australia in respect of both radio and television. The scheme was aimed at allowing existing operators an additional broadcasting or television licence if it could be shown that a new independent television or radio service was not economically viable. If a new service was viable, the Minister could call for new applicants to provide the additional service. Under the Hawke Government this sensible policy of the Fraser Government has been given lip service, but it has been implemented so as to negate the policy itself and to beg alternatives. This from a government that has written into its own platform and endorsed at the 1984 national conference of the Labor Party the following words in respect of communications policy:

SPEECH.PARA: Consequently, a Labor Government will . . . streamline and simplify the broadcasting planning process to remove delays in providing television and radio services.

What hollow words they are to the millions of Australians living outside the capital cities who have been promised additional commercial television and radio services but who have received nothing at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been betrayed.

—Totally betrayed. The whole process of providing decent broadcasting services has been bogged down, and many entrepreneurs have lost hundreds of thousands of dollars waiting fruitlessly for Government action. In fact, since the formal beginning of the supplementary licence scheme the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has been involved with only one regional television supplementary licensing application, that is, the hearing currently being conducted in Canberra. How can that record be equated, to quote the ALP's National Conference, to the streamlining and simplifying of the broadcasting planning process. On 16 April 1984, the Minister for Communications said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a need for licencees to get their applications in early, otherwise a log jam in handling them will develop and frustration will set in. So the Government is looking for early applications and is keen to ensure that these are processed and new services are established quickly.

This Minister and his Government are condemned by their failure to meet their own stated objectives. The whole sorry saga of the ill-fated supplementary licence scheme is typical of the approach of this Government to vital communications matters. It is haphazard and ill-conceived, despite the number of inquiries and investigations that have been held. There is no overall framework or philosophy but, rather, a series of inquiries and committees looking into a variety of areas with the net result being paralysis by analysis. As Myles Wright so correctly points out with respect to all the inquiries initiated by the Labor Government:
They have all had one thing in common: They were designed to overcome a policy vacuum, but were confined to narrow areas without discussing policy as a whole.

With the rapid development of technology in the communications field, one would have thought that the Government would have a well-defined policy on how the technology can be adopted to suit the thoroughly researched policies that one would expect from a competent government. Again, this is not the case with this Government. The people of regional Australia were not consulted with respect to the equalisation of commercial services which the Minister sees as one way of improving the inadequate number of broadcasting services in this country. When the satellite went up and it was realised that it would have surplus capacity, a hasty new policy was conceived-equalisation without consultation.
In an article in the Age of 26 November last year, the Australian Consumers Association was reported to have claimed:
. . . that Federal Government's policy of introducing three commercial television channels throughout Australia showed it was out of touch with country people.
The Association based its claim on three surveys conducted over the past three years. The article said that these surveys:
. . . showed that country people preferred programs with local content. The Association said that the three channel plan would probably lead to fewer local and rural programs.

This fear that localism will suffer under the Government's equalisation plan is not confined to groups such as the Australian Consumers Association. Indeed, the Government's main supporter and ally, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, has also expressed grave concern at the Hawke Government's equalisation plans, saying that neither the aggregation nor the multi-channelled services alternatives can meet the objectives embraced by the Australian Labor Party and the ACTU with respect to the media.

The ACTU, in a submission to the Forward Development Unit of the Department of Communications last year, stated that it was worried about the impact of equalisation on localism, concentration of media ownership and Australian production and employment. The ACTU argued in the submission that the extra costs which are associated with equalisation will not be met by additional revenue from larger markets and, as a consequence, regional channels will have to reduce programming costs. This reduction in costs is most likely to be achieved by more networking and cutbacks in high cost productions such as Australian drama. Moreover, regional stations will be forced to chop their high cost local programs, thus effectively destroying localism-one of the stated objectives of the Government. The ACTU was also highly critical of how the development of policy on regional television had occurred under the Labor Government. The submission from the ACTU to the Department of Communications quotes the Minister as having said in October 1985:
Diversity would not be achieved for regional viewers merely by introducing more services if it resulted in a loss of localism.
In other words, there would be more quiz programs, more soap operas, more police drama, but less localism.

TALK.START.PARA: —More of A Country Practice.

—On every channel-Dallas on every channel, Sale of the Century on every channel. In April 1985, the Minister said that the equalisation policy was a long term policy; but only three weeks later, on 25 May, he changed his mind to say that equalisation had the `highest priority' and that it should be completed within three years. The ACTU and regional viewers will have been amazed to see these abrupt changes in policy and direction, particularly when the Minister proudly stated in February 1984:

SPEECH.PARA: Ad hockery is not part of this Government's approach to communication development in all its forms.

Ad hockery is the characteristic of this Government. That is not all that was said by the Hawke Government's closest ally, the ACTU. The unions also complained of a lack of consultation, calling the Forward Development Unit inquiry into equalisation a one-way process. If the ACTU is not consulted by this Government, what hope do other public interest groups-organisations of regional viewers, for example-have?

TALK.START.PARA: —Country people.

—What hope do country people-the people for whom we are divining the services that so far have not been delivered-have of being consulted? This condemnation by the ACTU is a very serious indictment of a government which prides itself on consultation.

SPEECH.PARA: Just what is the Government doing in terms of regional television policy? Even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Communications cannot agree on the way of implementing equalisation, and the last group to be consulted comprises those who are the most affected-the viewers of regional Australia. We know that the Cabinet had to meet on a Sunday just before Christmas when the Minister and the Prime Minister battled out their respective viewpoints and that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was brought into the act, as a result of which nothing has happened to resolve the conflict between them.

Let us look briefly at the five major objectives of broadcasting policy outlined by the Minister for Communications in September last year, and let us see what the Government's performance is. These objectives are: First, to maximise diversity of choice in radio and television services; secondly, to maintain the viability of the broadcasting system; thirdly, to encourage an Australian look for television and radio by the maintenance of an appropriate Australian content level and the fostering of an Australian production industry; fourthly, to provide broadcasting services relevant and responsive to local needs; and, fifthly, to discourage concentration of media ownership and control of stations.

The implementation of the Government's proposed policies for regional television will, in all likelihood, result in the worst possible outcome-the Minister will fail to meet all of his proclaimed objectives for broadcasting policy. In terms of discouraging the concentration of media ownership, the Government's proposed equalisation scheme for regional television stations will have the opposite effect, whether equalisation is pursued by the multi-channelled services option or aggregation, or a combination of the two.

Under the multi-channelled services option, regionals face additional costs for buildings, transmission facilities, studios and extra administrative costs. Many will also need to install satellite receiving equipment. As a consequence of these extra costs, the small regionals may go to the wall. Similarly, with aggregation, the regional operators face increased costs. Because they would be operating over a much larger market area they would need more sales outlets as well as more news teams in more than one centre. New and costly transmitters and translators would also need to be installed. Equalisation will lead to a much greater supply of advertising time, but it is unlikely that the demand for advertising will increase at anywhere near the same rate in many of these aggregated markets. As a result of that, profits will fall and the smaller regionals will go out of business. If that happens, the Government's policy of equalisation will lead to fewer regional operators-perhaps as few as eight or 10-which means that the concentration of media ownership in Australia will be worsened and not reduced.

Another Government objective in terms of broadcasting policy is the provision of services which are responsive to local needs. The simple fact is that, if the markets are aggregated, they will need to be very large indeed to be economically viable. The larger the markets are, the more disruption to existing regional operators will occur, and it is likely that localism will receive scant attention. With the additional costs associated with the multi-channelled services option, regional licensees may be tempted to opt for cheaper networking programs from Melbourne and Sydney and, again, localism will receive scant attention. On current trends, concentration of ownership may lead to more Australian programs having their origin not in Sydney and Melbourne but in Los Angeles. One can only contemplate with horror the economic, cultural and strategic costs of that. So, a third government objective will be defeated.

Equalisation will, if pursued according to the stated plans of the Minister, lead to a reduction in the number of regional operators, because it will not be viable for them to continue operating via either the MCS option or the aggregation option. Viability will be good for the big boys, but not for the small ones. There may be more choice under equalisation, but the danger may well be that there will be more television channels simply offering the same fare. If equalisation leads to severe profit reduction for the regional operators and they consequently buy a high proportion of network programs by satellite, choice may not be maximised in terms of television services. There may be more channels to choose from, but that does not necessarily mean a better real choice of programs. There will certainly be more repeated programs in regional Australia than is now the case.

The final objective relates to Australian content and the fostering of an Australian production industry. At present it is the large networks that have the dominant position in the television industry as a result of the control they have over the buying, production and sale of programs which the regionals rely on for their operation. The small amount of local production that the regionals currently undertake may well disappear if they face a cost squeeze as a result of these policies. There may be a fostering of Australian content, but it will almost certainly originate in Sydney and in Melbourne. So, the score card now is nought out of five for the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In dealing with the matters raised by the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) I start by going back to have a look at where we were in 1983 when the Hawke Labor Government came to power. I well recall that in those days people in the television and the broadcasting industry generally came to my office and the first thing they did was basically make a plea to me to do something. The honourable member for Goldstein talked about a `paralysis by analysis' and called upon Myles Wright as the luminary responsible for that quote. When one analyses what happened particularly during the last two or three years of the Fraser Government, there was a total paralysis in the broadcasting area.

SPEECH.PARA: When we came to government there was total uncertainty as to the future structure of Aussat-basically a television distribution satellite-its legislative framework, if any, and its relationship, particularly with Telecom Australia, and the other essential telecommunications authorities. There was uncertainty as to the power, if any, of the Government to influence decisions particularly on transponder allocation. I remind the honourable member for Goldstein of that, because he indicated in his speech that there was some concern about the power of the so-called networks. By that I mean channels 7, 9 and 10, which are loosely called the networks. We made a decision that the Government would not be allocating transponder space on the satellite. It is a pity that the honourable member's party did not do that when it was in office, but it was not done. Aussat made that recommendation on the basis of its commercial judgment, and the decision was taken very quickly by the Hawke Government. All of these issues that I have outlined in relation to the uncertainty of Aussat have been settled. Legislation has been passed and Aussat is up and away. With all of the difficulties that could have arisen in relation to the technical aspects of Aussat, it was a delight to all including, I think, even honourable members opposite that the operation was as successful as it was.

When we talk about regional Australia, let us not forget the remote areas and the remote commercial television services. It is interesting that when the Hawke Labor Government came to power, as I have indicated, there was total uncertainty regarding Aussat. In particular, no concept had been developed by the previous Government on the delivery of commercial services to remote areas of Australia-nothing at all. Time and time again in this House we have heard interjections from the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), and also from the Leader of the National Party of Australia, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), to the effect that the previous Government was going to develop a homestead and community broadcasting satellite service mark 2 concept for remote areas of Australia. That is absolute nonsense.

When we came to office there was no evidence that members of the previous Government had any idea of where they were going in relation to providing television to remote areas of Australia. There was a vague concept which, as I said, they referred to as HACBSS 2, but they had no idea what it was about. One of the reasons was that they did not have the guts to say to the networks that that program would be developed on a regional basis and not through channels 7, 9 and 10 on a national beam throughout this country.

Honourable members opposite should not talk to me about their courage. When it came to the media in this country, honourable members opposite were the greatest collection of wimps of any government probably in the history of this nation. They were petrified of making a decision which would have provided services through existing retail networks for fear of the pressures from the major capital networks, and they should not forget that. The Liberal-National Party Government stands condemned for that attitude as far as I am concerned, and there is plenty of evidence on that. We acted on all those matters such as the ownership of Aussat; we set up the proper legislative framework; and we took action to go ahead for the advanced technology-B-MAC-for the delivery of both television and radio.

As I indicated it was necessary to examine the two solutions-that offered by the networks and by the regional stations. The former which comprised Sydney and Melbourne commercial television stations wanted to use 30-watt transponders in a national beam. This was not the favoured solution of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, for various reasons, not the least being that it would extend the influence of the Sydney and Melbourne stations. That is a point which the honourable member for Goldstein made today. I take that as a sincere indication on his part that it is not something about which he is overkeen. I would like to see him carry his party on that issue. There is no evidence that that party has any courage on that issue whatsoever. The ABT supported the regional solution put forward by Regional Television Australia Pty Ltd. I shall move on to Regional Television Australia in a moment. The proposal that it put was for a single channel for programming licences to each satellite, footprint or region. In effect, it was a commercial HACBSS, prepared as a service to remote areas, and this was the option which this Government decided to adopt. That decision was announced on 10 October 1984.

The Australian Broadcasting Corporation HACBSS reached its final stages on 26 January 1986, which, appropriately, of course, was Australia Day, and some remote commercial television services, known as RCTS-that is as opposed to the ABC service-will be on air during 1986. By the end of 1987 even the most isolated Australian will have access to basic radio and television for the first time in the history of this country.

When we came into office honourable members opposite had no idea where they were going in that area-none whatsoever. The one thing that they did know was that they would have the most craven capitulation to the networks on this issue and they would have had national beam programs throughout this country. Yet, the honourable member for Goldstein had the gall to come in here and talk about localism. What absolute rubbish!

I move to commercial television. Sure the points the honourable member made in relation to supplementary licences are to some degree correct. When we came to power the position was that the supplementary licence scheme, which had been mooted by the Fraser Government, was in place and we confirmed that on 30 November 1983. As a matter of fact, as outlined previously by the honourable member for Goldstein, I announced the commitment of the Government to implement the supplementary licence scheme. The major purpose of the scheme was to provide a greater degree of commercial programming choice to people living outside the mainland State capital cities which would not support an independent commercial radio or television station. Under the scheme an organisation eligible for a commercial licence could apply for a supplementary licence. However, a supplementary licence would not be granted if, after thorough investigation by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, a determination were made that an extra independent commercial service, the first and preferred option, was commercially viable and in the public interest.

Is the honourable member for Goldstein pretending that a change has not taken place in the attitudes of the Government, the Opposition and the industry towards the supplementary licence scheme? The enthusiasm for the supplementary licence scheme dissipated very quickly. The honourable member is well aware of it and so should any other honourable member on the Opposition side who has taken any interest in this matter. In fact, there were well known problems in relation to the hearing procedures. There were going to be tremendous delays in the hearings on the supplementary licence scheme. We did what we could.

When we came to government, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal was not even fully manned. It had significant shortcomings in its powers and procedures. What did we do? We brought the Tribunal up to strength, with good additional appointments and appointed people who would do their job well. That is something the previous Government probably would never have got around to. We addressed the Administrative Review Council reports on the Tribunal's procedures. We accepted the largest part of its recommendations and introduced legislation to put the recommendations into effect. The so-called uniform inquiry procedures will go a long way to streamlining the Tribunal's procedures for more efficiency. We moved quickly to close loopholes that appeared in the substantive powers of the Tribunal opened up by the Saatchi and Saatchi and the Herald and Weekly Times Ltd challenge. How do those actions contrast with those of the previous Government which, in all its actions, cut back the Tribunal's powers? It cut back the Tribunal's powers, and I refer particularly to the infamous 1981 amendments. So much for that aspect of the matter. Nevertheless, there were problems down the track of the supplementary licence scheme. The industry accepted that. It was not as if that was something we just decided ourselves. There was a doubt about whether it would work, so we had to start again.

The honourable member for Goldstein should understand the complexity of regional television. The regional television industry in this country is fragmented into 36 service areas, each with one commercial service, serving populations ranging from 600,000 in Newcastle to 23,000 in Mount Isa. This is an industry which has huge employment but covers tremendously disparate groups. As I pointed out, Newcastle has 604,000 people which is about 4.1 per cent of the audience population of this country. Wollongong has 338,000 people, which is 2.3 per cent of the audience, and Canberra, CTC7, has 300,000 or 2.1 per cent. Then we have Ballarat, BTV6, with 296,000 people or 2 per cent and Lismore, RTN8, with 293,000. It is worth noting that there is only one regional station with more than 3 per cent of the audience, and that is Newcastle. Only four stations have a 2 per cent audience share or more. The population served by the regional television stations-about 35 per cent of Australians-includes areas with a share of less than 2 per cent and ranges from 245,000 down to 23,900 or 0.2 per cent. Therefore, one is looking at an industry in which one station serves 4 per cent of the population at one end of the scale, and five stations serve 0.2 per cent at the other-Geraldton, Albany, Riverland, Broken Hill and Mount Isa. The regional stations serve the 35 per cent of Australians who do not enjoy the same variety of programs as city people. In Melbourne, Sydney, Adelaide and Brisbane there are three commercial services plus the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service. Perth has two commercial stations plus the ABC and the SBS. The vast majority of the regional stations have only one commercial station plus the ABC. There are some exceptions such as Canberra, Newcastle, Wollongong and Cooma, where SBS is available.

On 23 May 1985, I announced that equalisation was the major priority of this Government. I want to make the point quite clearly-it was quite clearly made then because it was expressed as a major hope of this Government-that it is not possible to achieve equalisation, aggregation and competition in regional areas immediately and simultaneously. Obviously equalisation will not occur immediately all over Australia but it was announced and it remains the Government's major priority, and by 1990 it will be achieved. That is what I said would happen and that is what will happen.

The honourable member for Goldstein talked a lot about consultation and about the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The ACTU was consulted about the future direction for commercial television, and it put in a submission. Honourable members opposite tell us all the time that we react to everything the ACTU says. Well, I was not all that impressed with what the ACTU said on this issue, and so be it. The fact that the ACTU put in a submission did not send me into a flat spin and make me throw everything else overboard. If I did that one can imagine the screaming and yelling from the Opposition benches-quite justifiably. The ACTU's submission was closely examined and to say the least it was disappointing. Therefore it was rejected. When one looks at the facts and what people say about inquiries, one must accept that at no time in Australia was this issue properly addressed until `Future Directions for Commercial Television' was released by the Department of Communications in June 1985. That was an excellent study. The then Secretary to the Department, Mr R. B. Lansdown, in a letter addressed to me, said:
The report marks a milestone in the Department's administration of Australian broadcasting in that it seeks to approach broadcasting issues from a long term point of view.

One can say that again. Until this report was issued the options had never been laid out by any government in this nation since television was introduced in 1956. The other day the honourable member for Goldstein asked me where we were going in this matter, and I told him that I hoped to make an announcement about the future of regional television in a month. Today I can say confidently that I will be able to do a little better in meeting that commitment. In fact the announcement will be made inside a month.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The Minister's time has expired.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Dr Blewett, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend several Acts-the Health Insurance Act 1973, the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, the National Health Act 1953, the States Grants (Nurse Education Transfer Assistance) Act 1985 and the Tuberculosis Act 1948. The major amendments proposed by this Bill are contained in Part II relating to the provision of pathology services. These amendments are designed to improve arrangements for the payment of Medicare benefits for pathology services. As a result of findings by the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts in its report No. 236 on Medical Fraud and Overservicing-Pathology, there has been serious public concern about improper practices in the pathology industry. The amendments in Part II of this Bill are designed to introduce significant new controls over the provision of pathology services and thus greatly reduce the capacity for fraud or overservicing in the pathology industry.
The Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee raised a number of particular areas of concern about the provision of pathology services. The Committee said, in part, that:
The Medicare Benefit Schedule was too complex and it encouraged pathologists to perform more tests than were necessary;
payment was too high for many tests made simple by the introduction of modern laboratory equipment;
the prospect of large profits had attracted entrepreneurial pathology;
pathology groups were providing `inducements' to doctors to order more services than were necessary;

pathology groups were encouraging doctors to order unnecessary tests by other means-such as providing request form pads which set out combinations of tests which the laboratories were able to perform automatically;
many laboratories were routinely adding to their incomes by performing additional tests not ordered by referring doctors;
doctors were found to have financial interests in laboratories which performed their tests.

The amendments in Part II of the Bill before the House today are designed to meet these concerns and represent the results of an extensive review by my Department and the Health Insurance Commission of the existing arrangements covering the provision of pathology services. Statistics available to my Department show that the number and cost of pathology services have risen sharply in recent years. An estimated 15 per cent of total Commonwealth spending on Medicare benefits is on pathology. In 1984-85 claims processed for Medicare benefits payments totalled $346m out of a total outlay of $2,280m. Between 1979 and 1985 there was a 69 per cent increase in pathology services as services rose from $13m to $22m over this period.

The Government has therefore decided to introduce a package of measures which will affect the provision of pathology services under the current Medicare benefit arrangements. There are at least two fees for most services in the pathology section of the Medicare benefits schedule. The circumstances in which the service is performed by an approved pathology practitioner outside a public hospital determines whether the higher or lower fee applies:

The higher fee SP or specialist pathology applies when the service is performed by a specialist pathologist; and the lower fee OP or other pathology-that is, 75 per cent of the specialist fee-otherwise applies. It also applies where a specialist pathologist decides that additional tests are necessary without consulting the referring doctor, and in a number of other circumstances.

A lower fee HP or hospital pathology-generally about 50 per cent of the specialist fee-applies to a small number, 18, of very common tests performed in public laboratories for private patients in public hospitals. Therefore, for those 18 tests there are three levels of fees.

However, there has been a substantial shift to patient billing at the specialist rate of benefit in recent years. The Public Accounts Committee noted that the top 25 pathology groups bill virtually all their pathology at the specialist rate, the percentage varying for those groups between 94.6 per cent and 99.9 per cent. In addition, during the period 1982-83 to 1984-85 the number of services billed at the specialist rate increased by 41.9 per cent while during the same period the number of services billed at the OP or other pathology and HP or hospital pathology rates fell by 18.2 per cent and 29.1 per cent respectively.

But the fact is the increasing volume of services being billed at the highest rate is not being matched by an increasing professional input by specialist pathologists. In fact, the Public Accounts Committee pointed out:

The great majority of tests being paid at the highest (specialist) level of benefit are not-and do not have to be-done by a specialist pathologist but are being carried out by medical scientists/technologists. This can amount to payment of an unwarranted premium in some cases and further encourage overservicing. Virtually all the pathology performed by the top 25 groups is done at the highest (specialist) rate, which is 33 per cent higher than the rate chargeable where a medical practitioner other than a specialist pathologist is employed.

The Committee added that there was data showing that at the time they were contacted by a PAC member, few of the top 25 pathology groups in Australia had many full time specialist pathologists on staff. Part time specialist pathologists were associated with 60 per cent of them. Thus, the specialist fees for those 18 pathology items appear too high, because the professional premium is far more than can be justified by the specialist's professional input. There is also evidence that the fees for the 18 tests, for which there is currently an HP rate, are too high. The costs for some laboratories involved in undertaking these tests is covered by the HP fee, which is currently only 50 per cent of the specialist rate. This means that there is an excessive profit component where they are billed at the specialist rate.

In addition, by international comparison, the current specialist rates for these 18 tests are unreasonably high. When one examines the New Zealand fees for pathology tests, they are considerably less than the Australian fees-sometimes less than 50 per cent of their Australian equivalent. After allowing for the difference in currency valuation, the New Zealand fees fall to an even smaller percentage of the Australian fees.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about our standard of living? What a farce! This is just ridiculous.

—The honourable member should just listen. The Government has therefore decided it will reduce the SP rate to the current OP rate for those 18 items-that is, to the 75 per cent rate. In addition, the new OP rate will be 75 per cent of the new SP rate. The HP rate will disappear and services previously charged at this level will now be charged at the new OP rate. The 18 tests involved are generally:

SPEECH.PARA: High volume and mainly automated;
highly profitable because fees have not been adjusted downwards because of more productive technology;
generally involve minimum specialist input; and

the proposal would maintain the specialist premium but at a lower level and save an estimated $47m per annum while involving a 12 per cent in HP fees-approximately $1m-for public hospital pathology services.
The proposal outlined will have the effect of:
Reducing fees for a small number of commonly performed automated tests;
having the greatest impact on laboratories that concentrate on tests with high profits;
removing a significant financial incentive to excessive servicing and other abuses; and
simplifying the schedule by reducing the number of rates for the 18 tests from three to two.

It is also proposed to remove Part 7-pathology-from the existing Medicare benefits schedule and establish a separate new schedule for pathology items. The items to be covered in this new schedule are those contained in Schedule 1 to this Bill. It is intended that the schedule will come into operation on 1 August 1986.

The Bill also provides for the establishment of a Pathology Services Advisory Committee to oversight movements within the new schedule. The proposed Committee will consist of seven members: The Chairperson, a Deputy President of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, three members appointed by the Minister for Health after consultation with the medical profession and three other members. The functions of the Committee are to review pathology items and fee levels, to consider related matters and make recommendations to the Minister for Health on such matters. The Minister may determine principles to be applied in the performance of the Committee's functions.

This decision by the Government means that from 1 August 1986 pathology items will no longer be subject to medical fee inquiries, which has been the case for a number of years. In making this decision, the Government considers that the method of updating pathology fees through fee inquiries is inappropriate and fails to take into account productivity changes in the delivery of pathology services. In addition, the Medicare benefits schedule as currently structured is inflexible, both in responding to new technology and the deletion of obsolete tests with regard to pathology services. The functions of the proposed Committee will allow a more rapid and flexible approach to a wide range of fee-related matters, including relativity of schedule items, the value of items and additions to and deletions from the pathology schedule, than is the case under the current arrangements.

In conjunction with the reduction in certain pathology fees as already outlined, clause 10 of the Bill provides that the number of self-determined tests that pathologists will be allowed to perform is to be limited. These tests will be determined by the Minister for Health in consultation with the Royal College of Pathologists of Australasia. The Royal College of Pathologists supports this measure as the College believes that currently self-determined tests could be a source of abuse by some laboratories. The self-determined tests agreed to between the Minister and the College will continue to attract Medicare benefits at the OP or other pathology benefit rate.

In addition, the Public Accounts Committee commented that certain minor procedures, such as the collection of blood for pathology testing, should not attract separate Medicare benefits when they are performed in association with a consultation. It was considered that a separate item provided inappropriate financial incentives which led to the ordering of unnecessary or excessive pathology tests. For these reasons the Government has decided to remove item 955, which deals with venepuncture and the collection of blood for forwarding to a pathologist from the Medicare benefits schedule. The recent increase in fees for general practitioner attendance items also supports this approach.

Current legislation provides that request forms held by pathologists are to be produced within 14 days of a request. The Bill provides that, in future, request forms held by pathologists will be required to be produced to officers of the Health Insurance Commission by the end of the day following the making of such a request. A further proposal contained in the Bill is that request forms issued by the pathology laboratories for use by referring doctors are to be approved by the Health Insurance Commission. It is not intended to impose an `approved form' on laboratories but continued approval of forms by the Commission will ensure that any encouragement to medical practitioners to order inappropriate tests should be removed. This proposal should not place undue administrative burdens on the pathologist, given that laboratories will continue to be required to keep such requests for 18 months.

Advice has been received by my Department that difficulties in the interpretation of section 129aa of the Health Insurance Act have contributed to the lack of success in bringing prosecutions against persons believed to have induced practitioners to order inappropriate tests. The amendments made by clause 47 of the Bill are designed to clarify the provision and also to render it a more effective deterrent to the practice of splitting the amounts of Medicare benefit payable in respect of pathology services between the pathology practitioner rendering the services and the practitioner requesting them.
