In recognising that medical practitioners are often encouraged to request more tests than may be required by the tactics of large laboratories and that practitioners are not always aware of costs of tests or the complex details of laboratory practice, the Government has decided to provide $100,000 per annum for each of the next three financial years to promote an education program directed primarily at medical interns and practitioners. The main aim of the program is to encourage the more appropriate use of pathology services by practitioners. The program would include, for example, assistance to the Royal College of Pathologists and the Royal College of General Practitioners in the development and distribution of educational material to medical practitioners in the community and teaching-seminar programs for medical interns.

Under the existing arrangements for the payment of Medicare benefits for pathology services, benefits are paid only where the services are performed by an approved pathology practitioner who is approved for such purposes by my Department. In response to criticism of the administration of this scheme by the Public Accounts Committee, the Government has decided to revamp completely the existing scheme to greatly improve its effectiveness.

The main criticisms of the existing scheme by the Public Accounts Committee were that any person or organisation could apply and be approved as an approved pathology practitioner and there is no requirement that tests be performed in an accredited laboratory. In addition, there is often a nexus between the requesting doctor and laboratories which raises the possibility of overservicing. The Committee was also concerned that provisions of the scheme, particularly the current undertaking signed by the practitioner, were not being enforced and was generally of the view that the scheme is open ended and lacks an effective review mechanism.

The Bill proposes to change the existing scheme so that only medical practitioners, and the currently approved small number of medical laboratory scientists, will be eligible for approved pathology practitioner status. Approvals will be subject to annual review. Only natural persons can be approved pathology practitioners, a new scheme is introduced for approval of pathology companies, and there is to be greater emphasis upon closer personal supervision by the approved pathology practitioner of the pathology services rendered. Both approved pathology practitioners and approved pathology authorities will be required to sign undertakings. Breaches of these undertakings can be referred by the Minister to the Medicare participation review committees for investigation and determination. These committees will also be able to investigate cases of excessive pathology servicing either by the practitioner or authority or the initiating practitioner. Approved pathology practitioners will be permitted to enter contractual arrangements with service laboratories where they do not wish to own, operate or manage their own laboratory. The conditions which apply to approved pathology authorities will also apply to these arrangements.

The Bill also introduces a system of accreditation of pathology laboratories. Services rendered by or on behalf of approved pathology practitioners are to be rendered in an accredited pathology laboratory, being services of a kind for which the laboratory is accredited, and under his direct supervision. Under the existing approved pathology practitioner scheme, tests are often performed in laboratories not operated by such a practitioner, and approved pathology practitioners often lend their name to bills for services which are not adequately supervised. These practices will cease under the new arrangements.

The Minister for Health will have power to refuse applications for approved pathology practitioner or approved pathology authority status and there will be a right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal where an application is refused. The proposed new arrangements outlined should, when implemented, meet the difficulties identified by the Public Accounts Committee and provide better control over the operations of pathology laboratories, companies and pathologists.

The Government has given careful consideration to the implementation of arrangements for the accreditation of pathology laboratories throughout Australia. While all States, through meetings of health Ministers, support the concept of national accreditation, to date only two States, New South Wales and Victoria, have legislation to implement such a program. By accrediting laboratories the quality of health services should be assured and as the States have traditionally accepted responsibility for quality assurance the Commonwealth believes that accreditation of pathology laboratories is a State responsibility. However, in order to complete the package of changes I have outlined above, the Government has decided that it will operate laboratory accreditation arrangements for those States which do not have legislation currently in place. For those States with legislation-New South Wales and Victoria-the Commonwealth will accept laboratories accredited under the legislation for the payment of medicare benefits for services performed.

Automatic acceptance by the Commonwealth of accreditation under State legislation will depend on States adopting the National Pathology Accreditation Advisory Council's guidelines and the minimum standards. However, it is expected that these States will comply with these guidelines.
Under the proposal:
Only those pathology services performed in laboratories which are accredited under State legislation or accredited by the Minister for Health will attract Medicare benefits;
the inspecting authority is expected to be the National Association of Testing Authorities in conjunction with the Royal College of Pathologists of Australasia;

provisional accreditation will be provided for all laboratories from the date the legislation is proclaimed. Full accreditation must be applied for through the National Association of Testing Authorities prior to seeking approved pathology practitioner or approved pathology authority status and be obtained within the following two year period; and

while the Commonwealth will collect a fee for an application in those States where pathology accreditation does not exist, the charges associated with inspection of premises in States with legislation will be paid by the laboratory direct to the inspecting agency.
The chief effects of these accreditation proposals should be to:
Remove backyard laboratories which currently provide poor quality services;
ensure uniform minimum acceptable standards throughout Australia; and
be welcomed by the profession.

Substantially, these proposals will provide greater control and supervision over quality and standards for pathology services. There are also a number of minor amendments made by the Bill including amendments to bring health legislation into line with the provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984. I mention, in particular, the amendment of the definition of dependant in the National Health Act to extend it to de facto spouses. Amongst other amendments, Part III of the Bill amends the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 to permit moneys held by the Commission, and not immediately required for its Medibank Private functions, to be invested by the Commission or a person or body representing the Commission; and Part V of the Bill amends the States Grants (Nurse Education Transfer Assistance) Act 1985 by raising aggregate amount limits to provide for cost supplementation arrangements determined by the Commonwealth Government and to provide for development grants as part of the transfer assistance offered to the States.
Financial Impact Statement

When implemented, the new approved pathology practitioner scheme and related measures will provide savings to the Government of approximately $60m in a full year. Forty-seven million dollars will arise directly from reduced fees for some pathology items in the Medicare Benefits Schedule; up to $10m from the more restrictive arrangements for self-determined tests; and $2,700,000 from the removal of item 955 from the Schedule.

Figures supplied by the Department of Social Security indicate that the amendment to the definition of dependant in the National Health Act would result in increased expenditure of approximately $700,000 in the 1986-87 financial year. The amendments to the aggregate amount limits in the States Grants (Nurse Education Transfer Assistance) Act will result in increased expenditure of up to $2,761,000 in 1986-87. Finally, I should mention that because printing deadlines prevented their incorporation in the Bill before the House today I foreshadow that I will be moving a small number of amendments of a minor or technical drafting nature. I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Porter) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill proposes new arrangements for the introduction and implementation of bounty assistance whenever such assistance is proposed following the Government's consideration of appropriate Industries Assistance Commission reports. At present, bounty assistance to industry can only be introduced by way of an Act of this Parliament. The Government believes that an inordinate amount of time is spent by the Parliament in considering legislation to implement this form of industries assistance which is essentially non-contentious. We consider that the introduction of bounty assistance would be more efficiently made through a ministerial notification process, which on the one hand would preserve and ensure parliamentary scrutiny by a general disallowance right, and, on the other, would not infringe on Parliament's sitting time and to the same degree as the current procedure requiring numerous Bills and amending Bills.

To this end Part 2 of the Bill proposes that bounty schemes be implemented by bounty notices, declared in writing by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. Such schemes would of course only be introduced following the receipt of an appropriate Industries Assistance Commission report on the particular industry or industries concerned. This is for the reason that the Minister is required to comply with section 23 of the Industries Assistance Commission Act 1973 which prohibits ministerial action related to the provision of industries assistance without a current report on the industry from the Commission.

The new procedure proposed by this Bill should not be interpreted as a diminution of the importance of this type of assistance-in fact quite to the contrary. The Government has attached and will continue to attach considerable importance to bounties as one of the key elements in its industries assistance policy of providing direct support to industry against import competition.

A most important feature of the new arrangements is the ability of the Parliament to disallow ministerial bounty notices. That procedure, which is set out in clause 10, is the same as the disallowance procedure applicable to regulations. I mentioned earlier that the introduction of ministerial notices, in conjunction with the disallowance procedure, is designed to save valuable parliamentary time without derogating from parliament's opportunity to scrutinise each notice and, if considered necessary, to reject a particular measure.

It is appropriate at this point for me to provide some historical facts in relation to bounties. The first bounty legislation was introduced in 1907 by Act No. 12 of 1907 and provided for bounty assistance on the production in Australia of a variety of agricultural products and fish. Since that time a considerable number of schemes have been introduced, covering a wide range of Australian industry, generally, I am pleased to say, with the bipartisan support of the Parliament.

There are 18 bounty schemes currently in operation, the most recent being that for metal working machines and robots effective from 1 July 1985. Almost invariably each parliamentary sitting deals with about three or four pieces of bounty legislation, with the majority operating retrospectively. It is this retrospective operation which has concerned the Government for some time because the bounty assistance cannot be given to industry until the legislation has the royal assent.

The new arrangements, proposed by this Bill, are designed to eliminate the need for retrospective operation of bounties. Indeed, the arrangements will probably overcome the anomalous situation which exists at present whereby a manufacturer or importer can enjoy the benefit of a change in tariff rates almost instantly, while an intended bounty recipient might be denied the benefit of bounty assistance for some months. This is because tariff changes, which are linked to the bounty, can be effected by Gazette notification whereas bounties can only be effected by an Act of the Parliament. A similar Gazette notification procedure for bounties will enable their immediate introduction following the Government's consideration of the relevant Industries Assistance Commission report. I am sure that industry will welcome this Bill for that reason alone.

Let me illustrate the current time lag, and the benefit to industry which should result as a result of the proposed notice procedure on this Bill, referring again to the Government's assistance measures for metal working machines and robots. The legislation to implement that matter was introduced into the Parliament on 11 September 1985 and received the royal assent on 22 November 1985. Because it operated from 1 July 1985 there was a delay of nearly six months before the bounty could be paid and the Australian producers accorded the benefit from the assistance intended for them. In the absence of this Bill such delays will no doubt continue because of the complexity of some bounty legislation and the bi-annual nature of parliamentary sessions. Under the arrangements proposed by this Bill a bounty notice for metal working machines and robots could have been gazetted in late June 1985 immediately following the Government's decision, with bounty payments starting at least five months sooner than would have been possible under existing arrangements.

I now turn to the other important elements in the Bill. Parts 3, 4 and 5 will standardise the administrative provisions for all bounty schemes-a vast improvement on the current plethora of provisions which have evolved in the different schemes over the past 15 years. This standardisation is expected to result in better administration of bounties-an important consideration in today's Public Service environment, where the Government is intent on achieving the best possible use of expensive resources.

Further, clause 8 of the Bill will provide the necessary flexibility to amend schemes introduced under this Bill so as to deal with changing technological or economic circumstances. These provisions, which do not apply to schemes now on foot, will allow a scheme to be modified by regulation in very limited circumstances so as to enable, for example, an extension of the scheme for up to six months, a variation in the rates of bounty payable, the range of goods eligible for bounty. The Government is of the view that such a facility is essential if bounty schemes are to remain relevant in the face of changing economic or technological developments which could not have been reasonably foreseen at the time of introduction of the original scheme. The difficulty in applying the books bounty legislation, dating from 1969, to today's printing industry, which has undergone vast technological change, is a good case in point. The proposed amendment procedure for bounty schemes, by regulation, will of course preserve the Parliament's ability to scrutinise any proposed changes through the disallowance mechanism applying to regulations. Amendments to schemes on foot at this moment will need to be made by appropriate amending legislation in the usual way.

Because of the significance of bounties as an element of the Government's industries assistance policies, a joint management review of bounty administration was undertaken in 1984 by an experienced team led by a senior partner in the consultancy firm of Arthur Young Ser- vices. Many of the provisions of parts 3 and 4 of the Bill respond to the recommendations made by that consultancy firm and will enable the Australian Customs Service to build on the improvements in bounty administration already achieved. The Government believes the measures contained in this Bill, which will standardise the administrative procedures for bounty schemes and make their implementation and variation much more relevant to today's circumstances, will benefit not only industry, but also the administrators of bounty schemes and the Parliament itself.
Financial Impact Statement

The Bill does not in itself involve any outlays by the Commonwealth. However, bounty schemes established under the Bill will involve outlays, the extent of which will vary from scheme to scheme. For established schemes, estimates of expenditure will be given in the Budget Papers in the usual way. For new schemes, financial details will be provided at the time of announcement by the Government of the establishment of the scheme. I present the explanatory memorandum on this Bill and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Shack) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986[COGNATE BILLS:FRINGE BENEFITS TAX BILL 1986FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1986FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and orders of the day Nos 2 to 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to have a chance to contribute to the debate, which is essentially a debate on fringe benefits tax. This legislation is of great moment because it will, for the first time, help to present an honest, fair system of taxation in our nation. The legislation will apply to all employers and will require that benefits that are given to an employee in lieu of direct financial contributions will be taxable.

SPEECH.PARA: When I was in the United Kingdom many years ago people to whom I talked-accountants and lawyers-were surprised that in Australia people could avoid paying taxes by having access to a company car, perhaps by having their club membership fees paid-by having all sorts of fringe benefits which avoided tax. People in London, particularly, were astonished. The only means of avoiding tax in the United Kingdom at that time was by means of the luncheon vouchers. These were available to staff and employees and were seen as a recognised form of tax avoidance-a small perk for people who were employees.

In this nation very large amounts of tax have been avoided by the use of fringe benefits. These facts were made known to the nation at large at the National Taxation Summit which was held as promised by this Government following the last election. The Tax Summit had before it plans to present a broadly based consumption tax to the Australian people. As we all know, this was rejected by the Summit and by the Australian people and particularly by the pensioners who did not believe that they would be adequately compensated for a broadly based tax. The Government's response to the rejection of the broadly based tax was to introduce a tax on all the means available in the community for avoiding income tax and for getting around the system. This whole package of legislation debated in this House today and yesterday-it will be debated in the future-is a revenue-neutral scheme which will plug up all the avenues, all the holes, that people can get through and use to get around the tax legislation. This collection of revenue will allow very substantial tax cuts to be made for not only individual taxpayers but also companies. It will really be a watershed in the collection of tax in our nation. Today when the House is debating a tax on fringe benefits and yesterday when it was debating negative gearing mark an historic occasion.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his second reading speech detailed some of the areas that the tax will not apply to. It will not apply to superannuation funds or to employee share acquisition plans. The Treasurer pointed out that the income tax law already deals with these. It will generally exclude meals available in staff canteens and free or discounted use of computer transport systems by employees. There will be no tax on the use of child care facilities or recreational facilities at an employer's premises. As a practical matter there will usually not be any tax on goods consumed at work nor on the first $200 in value in a year of free or discounted goods or services provided to an employee, including discounted air fares to airline and travel agent employees. There will be no tax on low interest loans granted to veterans under the Defence Service Homes Act and, consistent with our international obligations, on benefits provided to employees by organisations that are immune from income tax by virtue of the International Organisations (Privileges and Immunities) Act, the Consular Privileges and Immunities Act or the Diplomatic Privileges and Immunities Act or under international agreements. Exemptions also relate to live-in accommodation for employees who care for disabled people or disadvantaged children or other persons in a home, a unit or a hostel operated by a government body, a religious body or other non-profit organisations. Exemptions from the fringe benefits tax have also been given to religious institutions. These benefits apply to the clergy and members of religious orders.

The tax on fringe benefits relates particularly to motor vehicles. Everyone in Australia knows that for years and years many people about to be offered a rise were approached by their employer who said: `Do you want a rise or would you rather have a company car?' This is a way of avoiding paying direct tax. This provision of a vehicle partly for business and partly for private use has been seen as a way of getting around the tax law in Australia. The provision of a motor vehicle to an employee may continue, but the employee must account for the private use of the vehicle, otherwise a schedule will apply which will deem a certain amount of private use. If a vehicle is genuinely being used by an employee for business, the employer will not have to pay tax, but there will be the necessity to keep a log book to record movements of the vehicle. This legislation will be of great significance not only to the rest of the community but even to members of parliament because we are given a substantial electorate allowance to run a motor vehicle. We will have to opt either to keep a log book of all the mileage of the vehicle or for the second alternative, which is to take a standard, set mileage allowance arbitrated by the Commissioner of Taxation. What honourable members will do, I do not know, but I would think that most members of parliament, particularly those whose electorates are not in the centre of a big city, will use their motor vehicles substantially to attend functions-not to go to and from their offices, which is not a deductible expense-and to go around their electorates visiting schools and hospitals and perhaps attending functions in various towns. This is a fair piece of legislation because it applies to everyone. It is to apply to members of this Parliament for the first time since federation. Members have always had electorate allowances, judges have expense allowances and many officers of state have allowances paid to them. They will all be taxed. It is a very fair and thorough system. The whole nation will have to face the fact that in any scheme which attempts to avoid tax or which attempts to get around the tax system by giving a direct benefit to an employee the employer will have to pay tax. It applies to State and Federal governments and to local governments. The Government, I feel, has been extremely courageous in bringing in this legislation.

As I said in another debate, the Whitlam Government proposed a similar reform but there was not in our nation at that time the climate to recognise that tax reform was long overdue, that there was something unfair in the tax on the community and that there was a need to root out tax avoidance. We must congratulate the Victorian Government on its McCabe-Lafranchi inquiry which showed the first clear evidence of the incidence of bottom of the harbour tax evasion whereby people, as the Treasurer colourfully says, made tax paying an option. The Australian electorate, particularly those on the pay as you earn tax system, came to appreciate that many in the community were not paying tax as they should and were getting into schemes of avoidance of all shapes and sizes.

In the House now we have this very important and really momentous legislation which for the first time will tax the fringe benefits that have been available to employees, benefits of all shapes and sizes and magnitude, but particularly company cars made available for private use. I feel that out of this whole exercise the ordinary citizen will see that it pays to be honest, that public confidence will no longer be eroded in relation to the collection of tax and that people will believe that at long last there is integrity in the tax system. I commend the Treasurer for bringing this legislation forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Dr D.J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the bevy of Bills referred to as the fringe benefits tax Bills and I join the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) and other colleagues on this side of the House in strongly opposing them. I should begin by referring to a statement on page 2 of the second reading speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) where he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the whole thrust of the tax reform package-was about improving equity and not about increasing Government revenue.

On the contrary, the whole thrust of this Government since it has been elected has been to increase revenues and taxation. One has to refer only to the Budget Papers to notice that in the three years that this Treasurer has brought down Budgets he has brought down record tax receipts in absolute terms and, in the last two years, record tax receipts as a percentage of gross domestic product. Not since the war years have we seen this kind of tax grab by the central government. It is not only in the Budget Papers; it is also in other papers, such as one produced by the Australian Family Association. In a document late last year it said:

In broad terms, by 1987-88 families will be losing approximately $1,077m a year. They will be losing this because of the non-indexation of the dependant rebates, non-indexation of family allowances and the abolition of concessional expenditure rebate.
The tax burden on the family will thus increase by 37 per cent between 1984-85 and 1987-88 and they will be paying an extra $34.47 per week in tax by 1987-88.

Professors Porter and Parish, in a recent Centre for Independent Studies forum paper, commented on the fiscal drag problem that has been facing Australian taxpayers. In the years between 1981 and 1984 the highest marginal tax rate has been cutting in at a lower amount. Instead of being at three times average weekly earnings, it is now down to about two times average weekly earnings. Similarly, Professor Porter and a group of colleagues from the Centre for Policy Studies at Monash University, in a recent paper, stated:

In 1987-88, when the new 24-29-40-49 rate scale is fully in operation, around half of all taxpayers will face marginal rates of 40 per cent or more. Unless further action is taken, this percentage will increase thereafter by around 4 per cent of taxpayers annually. Further reform of the income tax rate scale will be needed by the late 1980s.

Far from being a reform package which will benefit Australians, this reform package will end up increasing government revenues and taxes. If there is any benefit at all from the reduction in the marginal rates that I just referred to, it will be a benefit which is already being paid for by fiscal drag. In other words, Australians moving into higher tax brackets will be financing the tax reforms.

Be that as it may, I would like to turn now to the question of exactly what the economic effect of this fringe benefits tax will be. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) and a number of Government members, starting off with the lead speaker this morning, the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths), who was followed by the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), have suggested that the economic effect of this tax will be on employers. In fact, on page 4 of the second reading speech, the Treasurer says:
Fringe benefits tax will be imposed on employers on the taxable value of fringe benefits that they provide to their employees.

The implication of the Treasurer, Simon Crean and the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the thing that this Government would like the general Australian population to believe are that the employer will be paying the tax and employees do not necessarily need to worry. The average Australian does need to worry. Just because the employers will pay the tax to the Government it does not necessarily mean that they are the ones on which the tax falls. We are all familiar with the pay as you earn system. There is no doubt that the employer withholds the tax from the employee and transmits it to the Government. But the incidence of taxation clearly falls on the employee. He is the one that is really paying the tax.

I venture to say-I will examine a number of situations-that the incidence of this tax, the actual effect of this tax, will not fall on the employer but, in fact, will be transferred to the average Australian, to consumers and to employees. Let me take two examples. I will deal with them seriatum. First, let me take the position of a monopoly in the Australian economy. What is a monopoly? There are a lot of them. They start off with Federal government, State government and local government departments and instrumentalities. The airline industry in Australia acts as a virtual monopoly. There are the statutory authorities, such as Telecom Australia, in the Federal area, the electricity boards and water boards in the State area, and garbage collection agencies in the local government area. In departments there are such things as the transfer of mortgages whereby a person pays transfer fees and perhaps the payment of fines to police departments. Each of these areas has virtually a monopoly position in the Australian economy. Each can virtually set its own prices for its goods and each sets these prices based on the cost of delivering the services.

Can honourable members imagine these government departments and authorities that are in a monopoly position absorbing the fringe benefits tax they have to pay? No way. Who will absorb it? What they will do is raise their prices. Who will end up paying the tax? It will not be the departments, the monopolies or the statutory authorities; it will be the consumers of their goods and services. Every housewife who buys electricity to do the washing and cooking, every farmer and small businessman who relies on Telecom Australia, Australia Post, electricity boards and water boards will be paying these extra costs. As these costs go into prices they will affect the consumer price index, which will in turn affect the wage rates and international competitiveness of Australia. Although the Government is trying to suggest that the employer will pay up, in actual fact it is quite clear that in these situations the people who will end up paying the tax are the average Australians.

Let us take a second situation. Rather than a monopoly, let us go to a situation in which there are lots of small businesses, one we might term a competitive situation, particularly these enterprises which are competing not only against other firms in Australia but also against firms and organisations overseas. Let us look at what may happen to those organisations. The Government would like us to believe that these fringe benefit taxes will be paid by the employer. How will they be paid? They will be paid by reduced profits. They will be paid by the shareholders of firms or the owners of firms. Anyone who believes that the profits of firms can be reduced and still get the same investment from the shareholders in the future is completely wrong. The first thing that will happen if employers do have to absorb that in their costs is that the shareholders and the owners of those firms will have to meet the cost and they will be discouraged from investing in the future. What will happen if we get lower investment? We will have lower production in Australia and if we have less production we will have less employment. One of the results, even though it may be only a small result, will be that firms in competitive areas which have to absorb lower profits will invest less in the future and reduce their employment over time. The people who will pay for it are the youth of this country. They are already paying a high price with record youth unemployment. This will raise the costs of doing business in Australia, which will lead in the longer run to some marginal increases in the youth unemployment of this nation. So in a competitive firm one result will be an increase in youth unemployment.

Let us say, for example, that a firm can pass on the cost of the fringe benefits tax to the employees. Some small businesses in my electorate have already said they cannot afford to absorb this tax and the employees will have to absorb it. Very simply, this means a reduction in their standard of living. When we talk about the car manufacturing industry and bigger cars being swapped for smaller cars, what that means for the Australian population is a reduction in their standard of living. There is no way of hiding that.

We are simply not given time to examine all the details that should be examined in legislation that is as important as this. Because the Government has decided to guillotine discussion on these Bills and push them through this House, we are not given time to examine all the defects of the Bills and the real imposts that they will impose on the Australian population. But let me say quite categorically that the Treasurer and his colleagues have been deliberately misleading the population. They are trying to lead the population into assuming that employers will end up paying the costs of this legislation, and not the average person. I assure the population-trade unionists, small businessmen and housewives and so on-that they will be paying for it. They will be paying for these taxes in higher prices, higher unemployment and lower living standards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that we should get the setting of this legislation in place. We are talking about four items. My good friend and colleague the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) will also be contributing to the debate, and I look forward to hearing his comments. We are dealing in a cognate basis with the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill, the Fringe Benefits Tax Bill, the Fringe Benefits Tax (Application to the Commonwealth) Bill, and the Fringe Benefits Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill. We should put those Bills into a setting. That setting is that this Government has been committed to a series of reforms since it come into office in March 1983. The first major reform was the establishment of an economic path, in which the centrepiece was the prices and incomes accord. Along with that, went the commitment by us, as a government, to do something on the wages side, by setting a proper wages system, and to do something on the tax side, to which I shall return shortly. So we had this economic accord, developed through the summit, and it has been central to our whole strategy in terms of achieving economic recovery.

SPEECH.PARA: In this debate we could spend a lot of time talking about the merits of that, but the debate is not intended for that; it is substantially about tax on fringe benefits. Nevertheless, one ought to say that the crucial thing about this Government is that it got a series of steps in terms of economic management. The first one was the summit in 1983. That set about giving direction to the economy, and we have seen substantial economic growth and a remarkable recovery in a number of sectors, particularly housing. We have also seen great growth in employment. We had the figures before the House today. We are looking at 670,000 new jobs. That is the economic setting. I turn now to the question of the financial system. We set about deregulating the financial system to do something to modernise the financial operations of this economy. That was important because we believed that it could be made a competitive and effective economy. Financial deregulation has been pursued.

The third candle in this candelabra of reform has been the question of tax reform. This major debate took much of the energies and efforts of 1985. It was not without its controversy. It culminated in the economic summit. The elements of that reform are being worked through in this place. Today we are talking about one of the major elements-the fringe benefits tax area. But it is important that people who are listening to this debate understand that the other part that is co-extensive with a fringe benefits tax is a major reduction in marginal tax rates for pay as you earn income earners. When we talk about a fringe benefits tax, we are also talking about reductions in marginal tax rates. So, with respect to the overall setting of this discussion about imposing taxes on non-cash fringe benefits, we are also talking about the capacity, in economic terms, to generate funds to enable us to give tax cuts in the other areas.

There has been substantial canvassing of those matters concerning tax cuts. The first phase of those cuts is to occur in September of this year, and we are looking at a series of tax cuts-the 60c rate to be brought back to 55c, the 48c rate to 46c, the 46c rate to 43c, the 30c rate to 29c, and the 25c rate to 24c. That is the first stage of it. It is important that we identify that this is the first part of this major overall review. Seen in international terms, this taxation reform is a substantial reform. So I now address the question: Why should we be directing attention in this Parliament to the question of fringe benefits? What is our preoccupation with fringe benefits? (Quorum formed) As the Opposition called that quorum in the middle of this debate on taxation, it is interesting to note that it is represented by only two members in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is disgraceful. They are not interested in it. Where are they?

—It is extraordinary. It shows Opposition members' inability to grapple with the real issue of tax reform in Australia. They were unable to grapple with it when in government. We saw then the development of a major growth industry-tax evasion and avoidance. Opposition members were incapable of dealing with tax reform when in government and have shown themselves equally incapable of dealing with the issue now that it is before the country. They are not willing to participate in the national tax debate. They prefer to take a stand away from the debate and simply snipe at people who try to make constructive reform, which this Government is doing. It is pathetic of the Opposition to come limping into this place as though it has something to offer when, in fact, when the crunch comes, Opposition members are not even in the chamber. I thank my colleagues on the Government benches because they are demonstrating their commitment to tax reform, to proper economic management, and to the conduct of a proper economy-which is something that is very far removed from the experience of those opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: I was saying: Why are we proposing a fringe benefits tax? The substantial reason is that, due to the neglect and mismanagement of the Liberal and National parties when in government, they succeeded in allowing the tax system to become abused and skewed enormously. People were taking their benefits in non-cash forms and were not facing up to the reality that proper packages for people should be paid in the form of cash. So we got that enormous distortion in the tax system. To the discredit of the former Government, it never sought to repair that distortion, so there were people on what ought to have been healthy managers' salaries being given a series of other lures to get them into their positions in employment. That is not the way to conduct an economy; it is a false way.

As I said at the outset, the important thing to recognise is that we set about introducing economic reform, and we set about reform of the tax system as well as reform of the financial system, and the Liberal Party is noted for its years of neglect and abuse, and protection of the tax dodgers. The community still understands that. It is interesting that all we are getting from the people opposite, both in this debate and in terms of their conduct in the other place, is obstructionism. They are not prepared to participate in the national tax debate. Their concern is somehow to protect their friends in the tax dodging industry. It is typical of their performance when they were in office.

Why is it that, although in 1978 the Taxation Commissioner drew to the attention of the then Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), the fact that tax avoidance and evasion was rife and the system was being abused, the then Treasurer never acted upon it? It is interesting that, when the present honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) delivered a speech in Perth in 1978 on the then Treasurer's behalf, he referred to these artificial contrivances. The people who were in government at that time knew very well that these schemes were rife. What did they do about them? They did nothing. As my friend the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall) said in a speech yesterday, there was an open-house situation. The then Government was in complete ignorance of how to go about reforming the tax system and ensuring that it brought equity into the system. What happened? The people bearing the burden of tax in this country have been the ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was optional for the rich.

—That is right. As my friend says, it was optional for the rich, but the pay as you earn taxpayer was caught. The Liberal and National parties, when they were in government, did nothing about it. If honourable members opposite think people have lost their anger about that, they are mistaken. People in the community still believe that the Liberal and National parties are most interested in protecting tax dodgers such as Brian Maher. They are not interested in doing anything substantial about tax reform, and they can make no contribution to a major debate in this place. They cannot make a contribution in terms of wages policy or economic policy and when it comes to tax policy all we hear are the bleatings and obstructionism-the bleatings because they do not have a policy and the obstructionism because they are out to protect the same old crew of tax dodgers. Honourable members opposite ought to understand that that is well understood in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague the honourable member for Capricornia, who will follow me in this debate, will draw the attention of the community to the fact that the same old debate is being worked through. The Opposition is protecting the same people. People are saying to us, because we are a respectable, decent government: `Let us get ahead with tax reform; let us get some sensible equity back into the system; let us reduce these marginal tax rates; let us get the tax system working in terms of a modern economy'. Interestingly, the scope of the tax reform is very far-reaching. In introducing this fringe benefits tax measure we are saying: `If people are worth having on staff, pay them the salaries you believe they deserve'. We are also saying: `We will go about reducing the marginal tax rates on those salaries so that people can more equitably meet their commitments'. That has been our view since the National Taxation Summit.

I say in summary that anyone on the other side of the House who pretends that he is putting forward a cohesive tax policy is mistaken and is misleading the community. Honourable members opposite tried to mislead the community when they were in government and they were found out. The Australian community is still angry and still wary of them, because they are seen as members of the party that protects tax dodgers. This Government is about implementing meaningful tax reform. These Bills are part of that process. they go a long way towards providing a revenue base to give substantial tax cuts to pay as you earn taxpayers. I am sure that not only Government members but also the community will support these Bills wholeheartedly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —One could well say to the electors of the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), who preceded me, that when they see him driving off in a big, white Commonwealth car they are entitled to stand on the footpaths and yell out `Tax cheat', `Dodger' and such things, because that is what he is saying about people who have a legitimate use of company cars. There are company representatives who are issued with a car simply so that they can go to work. They finish their working days probably miles away from their offices and well after the hour to which many people work. The car is provided to allow them to get around their territories, to do their work, and to drive home at night.
—And they can claim it.

—I am glad the honourable member is listening. I will give him a couple of lessons. I would like to believe that honourable members opposite do not understand what they are doing, because there can be no other excuse. I am President of the Queensland Training and Placement Activity Therapy Centre for the Blind in South Brisbane. Our organisation will be up for $1,500 each year because we issue a car to one of our staff members. I ask the honourable member for Stirling not to go away, because if he stays he might learn something. If we were to leave that car in the streets of South Brisbane at night-we do not have a garage-that car would be knocked off within a week. Only a few months ago a nurse came to visit us in the middle of the day. She was in our institution talking for two hours, and when she came out her new Commodore had gone. Many organisations and companies have absolutely nowhere to place their vehicles at night and have no alternative to asking somebody to take the vehicle home.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members opposite say that such people are tax cheats and dodgers and that the Government has had to rearrange everything because these people have all these special benefits. The special benefit of our car to which I have referred is that during the day it picks up blind people and brings them to our therapy centre. It is used to take people to visit the blind and to pick up timber to be used in our woodwork section and other materials. Because the supervisor takes that car home, it is portrayed as a massive financial benefit; so our organisation has to fork up $1,500.

The organisation mans four street stalls a year in the suburb of Annerley in Brisbane, which brings us a total of $1,600. The Government is hooking into the proceeds of our four street stalls for which women have baked cakes and sewn and done all that sort of thing. Honourable members opposite think it is quite legitimate to get into that area. I will give the House another example. At the end of last year I wrote to the charities in my electorate asking: `How do these measures affect you?' The Endeavour Foundation, a charity which looks after the sub-normal-honourable members opposite ought to put their chests out on this one!-has advised me that this measure will cost it exactly $65,000 in a year. That does not relate just to the motor cars. The staff of the Foundation have cars because they may be telephoned in the middle of the night with a request to attend one of the people they service, due to some problem. Many of the staff have telephones so that those calls can be made in the middle of the night. This Government is so decrepit and so bankrupt in its thinking that it is even going to apply a tax on the value of those telephones.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shameful!

—It is shameful. The Government proposes to apply a tax even to the value of the telephone. The Endeavour Foundation is assisted greatly by the Government in other ways-with funding-as are many charities. But honourable members opposite are Indian givers. They are giving with one hand and taking back with the other. If this country has reached such a sad state that honourable members opposite have to rip into people who hold street stalls, the sub-normal and the others to whom I could refer, it is about time they gave the game away. It is little wonder that the polls are showing that they have slipped behind the Opposition in popularity. They are not rearranging the economy of this country; they are slamming in on any group that can be portrayed as a special group which has privileges that the rest of us, the community, does not have.

SPEECH.PARA: This is just one incident, one of a series of things that the Government has done in the last three years. I am glad that there is now some quiet on the other side. I do not believe that Government members could have understood what they agreed to in their own party room when they agreed to these measures. I will give them another little pearl. Let us say that the Queensland Cancer Fund holds a function-a luncheon, for instance. If it had the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) as guest speaker, probably not enough people would arrive to warrant its bringing in its staff to act as ushers. If it were to invite someone such as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and a big crowd turns up and a member of the Funds says to the staff `Okay, we have such a big crowd that we are asking you all to come along to help seat the guests but you can have a meal while you are there' what would the lousy mob opposite do in that case? Under this legislation, if the hotel or the place where the function being held charged $20 for a meal, the Government would say to the charity: `Twenty times 46c amounts to about another $9 and that amount will have to be paid by you as a tax'. Therefore, because the charity has asked people to come along and act as ushers, it will cost the charity an extra $9. The charity would have to pay the hotel or the place where the luncheon was held $20 and because of this legislation supported by honourable members opposite-the greedy grubs-another $9 in taxation. That is what they expect us to support in this House. I honestly do not believe that the heartless members on the other side of the House really understand that they have got to the bottom of the barrel on this subject.

I hope that there will be a revolt in the Senate, because the Government does not have the numbers over there. I have referred to the taxing of charities because earlier in the debate one speaker, a Labor member, said that any Opposition member who said that there was anything wrong with this legislation was a liar. I can assure honourable members that what I have just said is the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that parliamentary?

—No. The honourable member concerned was asked to withdraw the remark. The Deputy Speaker in the chair at the time then said: `The honourable member can say it is not true'. That is just another way of saying someone is a liar, but it is a more gentlemanly way of saying it. The story I have just told about the Training and Placement Centre for the Blind in Brisbane was run last Tuesday in the Brisbane Courier-Mail. Senator Black from Queensland, who is supposed to be a lover of Queensland, asked the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) to explain what I was talking about in that article. The Minister said: `I do not understand it. It is not right. Cameron is off the track. It would not be like this'. Just because we say to him that our charity needs to take its car home and does not want to leave it on the streets of South Brisbane, the Government is now asking for $1,500. I say the best of luck to the Government because the next Budget may be the last it is asked to balance for a long, long time.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been talking on the subject of taxes. There is an old saying that there are two things in life that we cannot avoid: One is taxes and the other is death. Mr Deputy Speaker, I hope that you may be a little generous to me whilst I have a couple of minutes left to speak on this debate and allow me to raise the subject of death.

TALK.START.PARA: —Crematoriums!

—The subject of crematoriums, as the honourable member for Perth rightly interjects. Honourable members are well aware of my views on the ways in which Brisbane Crematoriums Ltd has been behaving in recent times. It has undertaken that in the year 2007 it will throw out the ashes of people buried in the year 1957 whose descendants did not come along in the forty-ninth year to pay another amount of money so that the ashes can stay in their niche. There are only two crematoriums in Brisbane. One is at Albany Creek and the other is at Mount Thompson. I have discovered in recent times that Mr Brierley is a real mover in the Brisbane crematorium game. The other day in the grievance debate I named the six directors of Brisbane Crematorium. Mr Brierley's Industrial Equity Ltd owns 50 per cent of BCL. What is causing me great concern is the announcement that he has just bought into another funeral group called Simplicity Funerals Pty Ltd. The news yesterday in the Queensland edition of the Australian was that he has bought 10 per cent of the stock in that particular business. Keith Russell, the managing director, who, like Brierley, is a Kiwi, is reported as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: We're opening up the possibility of the average man in the street buying a funeral franchise instead of a McDonald's franchise.

That has very little to do with what I am saying, except that I want honourable members to have some idea of the mentality of some of those people. We have enough troubles in Brisbane at the moment because of the monopoly which exists, with the heartless money-grabbing company up there that is prepared--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is free enterprise, isn't it?

—I say to the honourable member that I do not believe that free enterprise should be allowed in this field. That statement comes from a Liberal. I am free enterprise to the boots, but I do not trust people in this field. Brierley may be just a mover and a dealer, but he has bought in 10 per cent of the stock in Simplicity Funerals. In the last couple of years, the Brisbane City Council has built another crematorium in Brisbane. It was to be run by the Brisbane City Council, but the recommendations of the former Council and the current Council-one was Labor and the other Liberal-was to sell it off as it was getting a little costly. It was put out for tender. Guess who has tendered $551,000 for the Parkinson Crematorium in Brisbane?
—Mr Brierley?

—No. It was Simplicity Funerals. The plot thickens. This will become the third string of the eventual monopoly. That really creates a stranglehold in Brisbane. I have been condemning Brisbane Crematorium Ltd for saying that it would kick people's ashes out after 50 years. Apparently a policy is in place in Melbourne that it will be 25 years, and out the ashes go. Who is to know that people's ashes will be booted out within another 10 years, or five years, or five weeks? Ashes will go in and out. A crematorium need have only one niche. It could save a lot of land. It could sell off much of its land and just have one niche. A person's ashes would have a week in that niche, then out they would go.

SPEECH.PARA: I am just drawing the attention of the House to what is going on in this undertaking, cremation, burial business. It is high time that State governments stepped in and put an end to this. I made inquiries in Sydney today. When I told people at one of the crematoriums about what was being proposed in Brisbane, they were shocked. They had heard about it, but they were shocked that people could even contemplate such recycling in two-thirds of one's normal lifetime.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think that the honourable member for Moreton has more than strayed from the Bill.

—You are probably right, Mr Deputy Speaker. I did outline my argument in the context of death and taxes. I really did look after the tax side of the argument in the first five minutes of my speech. I touched on the other matter in the last part. I note that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding), who represents the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in this chamber, is at the table. I know that the Government is determined to ensure that these crematoriums will not heave out the remains of former servicemen, and I commend the Government on that. I notice that the shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), is sitting opposite the Minister and agrees.
—Order! The honourable member for Moreton has been warned that the subject he is discussing has nothing to do with the Bill.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I just took advantage of the opportunity given to me. I will not repeat what I said on the subject of tax except to say that I hope that the Government will withdraw those proposals when the heat comes on it in the other place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) was as off beam in the subject he raised as he was with some of the comments he made on the original tax debate. We all agree that charities are given a special position, and that should be the case in our society. At the same time, charities, regardless of who and what they are, should pay their way when it comes to their employees. I simply cannot accept what the honourable member for Moreton has said to the effect that there should be special arrangements so that the laws that apply to others within our community shall not apply to those who work for charities. I would like to see some laws with regard to charitable institutions and even grammar schools changed in Queensland. Let us take the grammar schools for a moment. Those who work within most grammar schools are paid far less than anyone else in the community. People who work in a school laundry could end up with a little over $100 a week for the hours that they put in. If they work in the residential areas they get paid less. I do not think that is good enough.

SPEECH.PARA: I concur with one aspect of the speech of the honourable member for Moreton: If these measures are going to create problems, we need to look at that issue as a total community. But we have to say that there will be some sort of consistency in our tax laws. We do not want people setting up phoney charities, as did a fellow in Rockhampton some years ago involving the collecting of rags. I wonder whether the honourable member for Moreton would like us to give him special privileges and fringe benefits on his car and on his house simply because he is involved in a so-called charity. What that fellow in Rockhampton was doing was racing around collecting rags and giving a small percentage to charity while making a considerable amount of money on the side. Just because a group constitutes a charity it does not mean that it needs special preference and privileges.

On the broad side of this argument, I think that members of the Opposition have an enormous hide to come into this chamber and even mention the word `tax'. After all, this is the Liberal Party of Australia which has a record on taxation which almost constitutes a national scandal. For five years we saw the most blatant tax scandals in Australia's history. In that period we saw a rundown in tax administration in this nation. We saw the coalition Government-the Liberal-National Party Government-do nothing to address the basic failings of the tax system. Every time one hears a complaint about the amount of tax we pay in Australia one should realise that prior to the Hawke Government the Liberals and Nationals were in power for more than 30 years. For a very short time we had the Whitlam Government in power trying to redress the situation, but for the bulk of the time the Tories have been there. What did they do? They did nothing-except support the tax avoiders and the tax evaders. During that period the Liberal Government under Fraser, Howard and a lot of the honourable members who are still sitting on the Opposition front bench, repeatedly broke their tax promises to the people-promises to index the scales. We saw all sorts of wild promises every time there was an election, but nothing was ever done.

We can contrast that record with what this Government has done. It has instituted a vigorous policy of closing the tax loopholes and gaps. I doubt whether there are many Australians, except the rorters, the evaders and the avoiders, who do not support us today. We have seen these gaps closed-gaps in the superannuation areas, income splitting, the use of unit trusts, the leverage leasing system, the prescribed payments system, the sales tax schemes and many others. The rorts went on and on. When this Government acted to try to get back some of the money from the bottom of the harbour schemes we found the Liberal and National parties opposing the legislation that would have allowed this Government and the people of Australia to get back that revenue. That is what we are talking about when we talk about tax-the revenue available to the people of Australia. When this Government tried to do something to recoup those hundreds of millions of dollars, who voted against the measure? Who stopped the Government from succeeding in its attempt? Members of the Liberal and National parties. They stand condemned. Their record is so bad that they should hang their heads in shame.

The Hawke Government has re-invigorated tax administration in this country with major additions to its resources, as well as a massive overhaul of the penalty and compliance provisions. We have field officers out there now checking the system. Ten times more tax returns are being checked now than in the last year of the Fraser Government. The banks are co-operating properly and declaring the interest earned on bank accounts. Those bank accounts are owned by many people who were not declaring their interest regardless of the fact that it was income. Some were doing so because of ignorance but many were doing so purposely. Now we have a government that is prepared to act to overhaul the tax system with the most comprehensive tax reforms since income tax was established in this nation.

These reforms involve, first, the closure of the loopholes in capital gains, fringe benefits and tax sheltering areas. They also involve the largest tax cuts in Australia's history-some $41.2 billion with a rate of 49 per cent. This is so important because many of us who move around the nation have spoken to small business people and others who are prepared to have a go, but who say: `What is the use of working more when you are paying 60 per cent in tax?' This Government has acted properly because it is bringing fairness back into the tax system. No-one likes to pay tax but we must pay our way. If we want defence forces, roads, schools, hospitals, proper care arrangements and facilities and a proper social infrastructure in our nation then we must pay our way. But the Liberal Party says no. It says let the poor, the workers and the aged pay the way, but not those who are part of that special silver tailed, blue ribbon group in the Liberal Party. Liberal members want them to have all the fringe benefits in the world. I say no and I believe that the people of Australia will say no. This Government is acting to close all the loopholes and the rorts that the Liberals and their mates have been using for three decades.

This Government has also introduced an imputation system for dividends. That is the most substantial change in corporate tax in our history. Honourable members opposite should talk to those who have paid tax on dividends made to them, even though the company has also paid tax. They were fed up with that double dipping. This Government has acted to stop that, yet we hear Opposition members say that we are anti-business. We are not anti-business; we are giving businesses opportunities that they have never had before. They asked the Liberals for those opportunities but they never got them.

This tax package is all encompassing. From the tax point of view it will cover those areas which have been used for evasion and avoidance. Take, for example, the private use of company motor cars. I doubt whether there is one person listening to this debate who does not know someone who has had a company car and has used it privately over and over again. We want to put an end to that. We do not want to be unfair; so we are allowing the use of the car to be measured and checked on to ensure that those who use their cars for business purposes or for income earning purposes have that claimable deduction. But those who are not--

TALK.START.PARA: —The farmer with his utility has to make seven entries every time he uses his vehicle.

—That is not so. If the honourable member looks at the legislation he will see that there is a measure that will be used in such cases. I will explain it if he wishes me to do so. It has been introduced in such a way that a person has an option to adopt the statutory formula. I think that is fair because not everyone will have the time to sit down and fill in the records. There will be those who will opt for that preference. The Government will overcome so many problems here. Take as another example of fringe benefits the interest free loans for those who deserve them as an incentive for employment. In the banking area negotiations are going on with bank employees. Other matters covered by this legislation include the release of debts and the payment of private expenses. Is it right that someone should get, as part of his income, part C or part D, the costs incurred in sending his kids to school? Every other Australian must pay his own way. But the Liberals and the Nationals say no, there are those Hottentots, those who sit on top of the pine tree, who should have special advantages. Instead of being paid an extra $10,000 a year in wages which are taxable, those people have had their children's fees to some of the posh private schools paid for them. That was a way of getting around the tax laws. Those fees were income but they were not being taxed. This Government says no and the people of Australia say no. They say that everyone must pay his way.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill also covers free and subsidised residential accommodation. The Government is not being stupid over this; it has recognised the difficulties of isolation and distance. It has accepted these problems. It is quite hard to get people to go to regions such as mine, in the mining area, and it is necessary to subsidise their accommodation as an incentive. So the Government said it would give such people special consideration. The Bill also covers free and subsidised board and concessional fares for airline transport. While we accept that these should not be used as some sort of means of tax evasion, the Government has said that it will come up with an arrangement which is being negotiated now with the airline industry unions so that those who get a special benefit because of their employment will not lose out. The list goes on. (Quorum formed) The quorum was called by members of the Liberal and National parties because they do not really want this issue to be debated. They do not want the people of Australia to hear what they have been doing and what we are trying to stop. As I said before, those at the top of the tree-the Tories who want to keep their special advantages-want to rort the tax system and not pay their way. But this Government is determined to overcome those problems.

The fringe benefits tax is typical of what we are about, just as is the entertainment tax which I mentioned a moment ago. The revenue gained from the imposition of the fringe benefits tax on or after 1 July is estimated to be worth $330m for 1986-87, $540m for 1987-88 and $625m for 1988-89. Millions upon millions of dollars will be used for the people of Australia. This money will not be used in the board rooms of some of the big corporations of this nation; it will not be used to back the toffs and the Hottentots. The money will be used for hospitals, roads and local authorities. As I say, the money will be used for the people of Australia. It is no wonder the Tories do not want to see this happen. We know their record of supporting the evaders and avoiders.

This Government is introducing a fringe benefits tax because the tax system has been increasingly subjected to evasion in the fringe benefits area. What did we find when the blatant paper schemes were closed off in the early 1980s? We found that the high income taxpayers-again the Tories, the Liberal supporters, the National Party supporters-increasingly turned to fringe benefits as a means of minimising the tax paid on their total remuneration. They were not prepared to pay their way and they used any scheme available to them legally, and in some cases illegally, to avoid paying tax. As I said, the Liberal Party's record on taxation is abysmal. It has always sought to defend the tax avoiders and the tax evaders. It has always sided with its high income friends who make party jokes about how much tax they do not pay.

We in the Labor Party represent people. We realise that governments must have revenue. However, we realise that everybody ought to pay tax on an equal basis. The Labor Party has always taken a firm stand against tax avoidance and evasion since its election to office. The Labor Party has introduced dozens of measures aimed at making the tax system fairer and less open to abuse. The measures before the House tonight also have that objective. However, as usual, the Liberal Party is going to oppose us. The Liberal Party will continue to fight and say: `This is not in the interests of the people.' What baloney, what bunkum. It is time the people of Australia realise what is going on and the real motives of the Liberal Party. The Opposition dishonestly supports the tax cuts provided by the Government to honest taxpayers. Members of the Opposition certainly want tax cuts to be given. They say that that is wonderful. But when it comes to finding the revenue to meet those tax cuts-this is revenue neutral; in other words, we will give the moneys we raise back to the people-the Liberals and the Nationals say: `Well, we do not want those taxes but we want the tax cuts'. They have no credibility whatsoever. They certainly cannot have it both ways. It is time they got on side with the people of Australia and realised that the people of Australia want each and every one of us to do what is right, to be fair dinkum when it comes to the tax system. We need to act against those who are blatantly avoiding their burden of tax. We accept that taxation is a burden. But we all have a responsibility to bear.

The motor vehicle fringe benefits are typical examples of rorts. As I said before the quorum was called, many of us know of people who use business vehicles for private purposes. The same sort of thing can be said about entertainment. I recall talking last year to some lawyers in Brisbane who told me that their daytime eating arrangements were finished. Five of them used to take turns to pay for a meal. On Monday one of the lawyers would pick up the tab for everybody. The next day another lawyer would pick up the tab and so it went on and on. It was also a common practice around the Inns of Court. Regrettably, lawyers in particular were in it up to their necks. This was the normal thing. The restaurateur did not even have to take any money from them. He even knew whose turn it was to pay. He just noted which lawyer owed what on a particular day. I am sure that many people in the business sector did exactly the same thing. I should not cast too many aspersions on lawyers because we have some mighty young and successful lawyers on this side of the House. I notice that my colleague from South Australia, the honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan), the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths) from Victoria and a few others are in the chamber listening to this important debate. I would not want to cast aspersions on my colleagues because I might need the numbers in Caucus. However, people have been rorting the entertainment system. I do not want to introduce too much frivolity into the debate because this is an important subject. It is important that we have a proper tax system. It is important that people pay their way. It is important that governments bite the bullet and close the tax loopholes. That is exactly what this Government is doing. The people shall be the beneficiaries. The losers will be the rorters, the tax evaders and the tax avoiders. I am pleased to say that most of them are members or supporters of the Liberal Party and the National Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we have heard a load of tripe from the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright). He portrays himself and his Party as not being anti-business and not being opposed to the professionals in this society. He got into trouble when he started to cast aspersions on lawyers in the Australian Labor Party. It was interesting to see how quickly he retreated when in fact they looked at him in a way which meant that his future prospects could be threatened.

SPEECH.PARA: It was 225 days ago-19 September 1985-when the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the bowser bandit as I think he is called by some people on this side of the House, came in here and told us about his reform of the Australian taxation system. The Government claimed that the new system would be fair. It claimed that the new system would be equitable. But the reverse happened. Since 19 September 1985, employers, employees, business people-the ordinary men and women of Australia-have been concerned, worried and overcome by a state of uncertainty because of the way this Government has prevaricated and threatened so many industries through its broad brush approach and its failure to take into account both the needs of the people of Australia as well as the desire and the need to keep industry viable.

We find that the taxation Bill debated in the House yesterday and the fringe benefits taxation package discussed today total 199 pages of legislation. There are 151 pages in the four Bills relating to fringe benefits alone. We find that there are 274 pages in the explanatory memoranda, and on it goes. Yet, we find that the second reading speeches of the Treasurer and the Minister of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford) total only 22 pages. We wonder whether the Government is trying to avoid its responsibility to outline to the Parliament the way that it intends to change the laws of this nation. We should consider some of the things which are being adversely affected and some of the areas which will be hurt, and hurt drastically, by the Labor Government's policy.

The car industry is now in great trouble because of the tax on motor vehicle fringe benefits. Mr Bannon, the Premier of South Australia, came to Canberra just a couple of days ago and spoke at a dinner. He said that he had hoped to bring good news-good news for the industry which plays such a vital role in South Australia. However, he had to stand up and say in effect, though not in these words: `The ALP Federal Government has let down the State of South Australia'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has.

—As the honourable member for Mayo points out, it has. The South Australian Labor Government will be swept from office and replaced by a National-Liberal Party government in South Australia after the next State election. We find that people in remote areas and those who are in receipt of housing benefits will be threatened, admittedly not to the extent that the Government first outlined. But people who are in mining areas and remote areas are adversely affected by the Government's policies and by the legislation that is being debated today. The Government is threatening the jobs of 10,000 restaurant employees. Ten thousand people will be cast out of employment in the restaurant industry.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a sad and sorry day for Australia when the Income Tax Assessment Act is being turned upside down and cast out the window. Assessable income has traditionally been calculated in this country by subtracting reasonable and allowable deductions from gross income. I think it would be illuminating for members of this House if I read section 51 (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. It states:

All losses and outgoings to the extent to which they are incurred in gaining or producing the assessable income, or are necessarily incurred in carrying on a business for the purpose of gaining or producing such income, shall be allowable deductions . . .

What has happened is that deductions, which traditionally have been allowable deductions-which the Treasurer himself admits are allowable deductions-are no longer to be deducted. The result, at least in the restaurant industry, is that 10,000 Australian men and women-employees whom the Australian Labor Party purports to represent-will be cast out of employment and will be cast on to Labor's dole queues. We know how unemployment is rising under this Government. We know how more and more people are being cast out of work by the disastrous policies of the Hawke Government. We find that the fringe benefits tax is only one aspect of the Government's overall budgetary tax strategy.

We find that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in his election policy speech at the Sydney Opera House prior to the election in March 1983 that there would be no new capital gains tax. What do we find now? We find a new capital gains tax. We find that the quarantining of farm losses has now been brought in. We find also that negative gearing is to be abolished. What this Government is doing is mounting a concerted attack and undermining the traditional Australian idea of a fair day's reward for a fair day's work.
