We find that there will no longer be, after this legislation is passed, any reward for initiative, enterprise and hard work. We in the Opposition believe that the Government will stand condemned for this. We believe that the measures that the Government has brought before the House will in no way carry into effect the idle rhetoric that the Prime Minister and Treasurer of this nation saw fit to utter before the people of Australia prior to the National Taxation Summit.
It is interesting to note that prior to that Summit the Prime Minister announced nine principles to be followed in any tax reform measures. The fourth of these principles stated:
. . . any reform must lead to a simpler system, which therefore all Australians can understand more easily--
The eighth principle stated:
. . . any reform must provide the best possible climate for investment, growth and employment in Australia.
The ninth principle stated:
. . . any reform package must have widespread community support-

In fact, these three points have no public support. Indeed, the other six principles have been rejected by the people of Australia also. I really wonder why this Government insists on inflicting on the people of Australia-the people who make up our country-such adverse and terrible policies; policies which will undermine so many industries. We know what Mr Bannon said. We know what the restaurant situation is. I think it is now time for the Government to re-evaluate what it is doing.

I would like now to look at a couple of other aspects of the legislation. In my electorate I have been approached by very many airline employees and former airline employees who are concerned by the way that the fringe benefits tax will affect their entitlements. We should remember that airline employees and former airline employees travel on a sub-load basis. They do not get a confirmed ticket; they do not get the sort of ticket that anyone who pays the full fare gets. However, we find that this Government will penalise those people. As a result, there is a very real possibility that the airlines will withdraw these benefits and that there could be very considerable disruption in the airline industry as a result.

I have heard it suggested that there could be a blockade of Canberra by the airlines. I suggest that there should not be a blockade of Canberra because members on this side of the House support the airline employees one hundred per cent. What would be more appropriate perhaps would be a black ban on Labor Party politicians because they are the gentlemen, and I suppose I should say gentlewomen, who are bringing in this legislation-a law that will act against airline employees and retired employees with such adverse effect.

It is about time that the Government took note of the prevailing political climate in Australia. We should look at the opinion poll published yesterday in the Bulletin magazine which shows that the ALP has now fallen behind the National and Liberal parties. That is a trend which will continue. It will grow. There is no doubt in my that the ALP will be swept from office at the next election. We heard the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) this morning state that the election would take place at the end of 1987. I hope that this Government goes its full term, but we have heard promises before. ALP promises seem to be torn to shreds and thrown out the window over and over again. We believe that governments should run their full course. We know how the Prime Minister broke his promise in 1984 when he called an election for December in that year. We know what his promises are worth. The fringe benefits tax proposals which are before the House are yet another indication of the way that the Labor Party is continuing to ignore its promises and continuing to ignore the interests of the people of Australia.

The National Party has been completely and utterly opposed-I make this clear for those people who are listening-to the fringe benefits tax since that proposal was unveiled by Labor in 1985, 225 days ago. It has taken Labor that length of time to get this legislation before the Parliament. We have all read the newspapers. We all know that there has been a great factional battle in the ALP. We have had left against right; we have had centre left, presumably, against the rest; we have had the socialist left against everyone else; we have had the left guard against the right guard; and I do not think any honourable member would be surprised, if we had the mud guard as well.

We remain opposed to the fringe benefits tax. We wish to assure the people of Australia of our opposition to this tremendously negative impost on business and, indeed, on all Australian people. We remain opposed to Labor's assets test, especially when it is going out of its way to hurt those people who for so many years have contributed to make Australia the country that it is today. We are opposed to that miserable, underhanded deal of the ALP with the unions for a 3 per cent superannuation payment. Without doubt Labor is trying to drive all incentive and initiative out of Australia's most efficient and industrious innovators, namely the small business and export industries. Why is Labor opposed to these industries, I wonder? Indeed, the people of Australia no doubt also are wondering. If we cannot stop Labor's fringe benefits tax-we will certainly be doing our best to do so in the Senate-it is important for us to get rid of the fringe benefits tax on our return to government at the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I thank the honourable member for Farrer for his whole-hearted support. I guarantee that I will be working along with my colleagues to make sure that Labor's fringe benefits tax and the adverse effects which it will have on Australian business, Australian farmers and the Australian people as a whole, will be repealed after the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join this debate and support the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill and cognate bills, which have been the subject of much public debate recently. I am surprised that the previous speaker, the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), did not put forward any arguments, on behalf of the Opposition, against the fringe benefits tax to the degree where he was able to point out to this House how those taxes would affect the ordinary people of Australia. We heard a lot of rhetoric from the previous speaker. In fact, when one talks about left guards and right guards one must say that perhaps he is appearing as the rear-guard of the National Party of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill introduces another major element of the tax reform package. It represents a system for effectively taxing remuneration obtained as fringe benefits which, up until now, largely have escaped tax. The legislation redresses the position whereby over the years there has been a very strong movement towards the remuneration of employees, especially higher income earners, by fringe benefits packages which allowed income tax to be avoided on substantial parts of the overall remuneration.

So-called tax-free perks came to dominate salary package negotiations, and such packages were openly advertised in the business market-place. Increasingly innovative deals were emerging, particularly following the demise of the `paper' tax avoidance schemes in the early 1980's. This situation was exacerbated because of deficiencies in the income tax law which was unable to cope with the necessity for subjective judgments on a case-by-case basis to be made for taxation purposes of the value of fringe benefits in the hands of individual employees.

From the outset let us examine some of these fringe benefits in greater detail. Fringe benefits, in the form of company cars, low interest or no interest company loans, subsidised accommodation and the like, are goods and services. They are goods and services just like the ones that any average income earner may acquire, with one important exception-the taxpayer does not pay for the benefit. It is pointless arguing that a mere taxpayer on $25,000 without any fringe benefits is in the same position as a salaried staff member on $25,000 per annum who has his own company car, the ability to borrow money from his employer at a favourable rate or make use of other company-provided fringe benefits. Clearly, fringe benefits put employees in a far better position, a position which cannot be analysed purely in terms of actual money paid out to them as salary. If fringe benefits were quantified and added to income we would see our hypothetical employee's income take a quantum leap of many thousands of dollars.

It was during the reign of our predecessors that fringe benefits packages became so popular. As a result of these extra benefits going untaxed, usually to the benefit of upper income earners, the Government lost more and more revenue. To make this up, more pressure was exerted on those on marginal income levels to come good with the tax money. Again, the rich got richer, and the poor made up the difference. Again, it is in the interests of equity amongst taxpayers that the Government should intervene to ensure that the burden is evenly shared. For administrative reasons, the tax will be assessed and paid by the employer, not the employee. To avoid unnecessary administrative burden, the tax will be payable for benefits in a year ending on 31 March, rather than on 30 June. The tax will be payable in quarterly instalments by 28 July, 28 October and 28 January only. That transition period will be from 1 July this year to 31 March 1987. The tax rate for the transitional year will be 46 per cent, while the rate will go up to 49 per cent in subsequent years.

One need only look at the specific provisions of the legislation to see how just is the Government's approach. It is only right, for example, that an employee, when engaged in his work away from home, should be given an allowance to cover his expenses. As such, a reasonable living away from home allowance is not taxable. However, the practice has arisen of virtually awarding employees a tax-free bonus by bestowing allowances out of all proportion to the needs of an employee when engaged in work out of town. Such excess amount will come within the ambit of the legislation. Other areas of necessary exemption are staff canteens, employee commuter transport benefits and the provision of child care facilities. It would be hypocritical for a government committed to equal opportunity for women to have taxed child minding facilities, the very facilities which are necessary to allow some women to enter the work force. Other, strictly drawn provisions, will exempt clergy members of religious orders from taxes. Clearly, the legislation is designed to affect only those who have escaped tax for some time through fringe benefits, and not to hurt the average income earner.

Several speakers have already dealt with the question of the effect the taxation will have on the motor vehicle industry. The only contribution I wish to make is this: The Opposition is already prophesying doom, as is usual, following the introduction of this tax. It claims that vehicle sales will be down this year on last year's figures. Of course they will be down. Last year was an extraordinary year of growth for the whole economy, and the best that the motor industry has ever had. We know that growth will be lower this year, and therefore so will sales in the industry. As for the effect of fringe benefits taxes, I can again only reiterate the facts. The promised lull in the entertainment industry following the abolition of tax deductible business lunches did not occur. Another example is the attitude towards the tax as it affects airline employees. The previous speaker said that airline employees would be affected. That, of course, is not the case. When first announced, airline employees justifiably feared the effects on their very generous travel concessions. I received many representations from airline employees within my electorate. Following talks with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and the airline industry unions, the airlines have agreed to pay the full cost of the tax without threatening the existing travel concessions. This is yet another example of consensus in action.

I think it must be clear, even to the Opposition, that ethics of justifiable evasion of tax by well-heeled taxpayers is a thing of the past as far as this Government is concerned. Bottom of the harbour schemes are out, and now we are pursuing some of the residual benefits which the rich still have to the detriment of the average earner. Until now there has been a perception in the community that everyone has to pay tax except for those rich enough to get out of it. Frankly, the people have had a gutful of it. The Bills before us today are a giant step forward towards restoring equity to the taxation system. They are measures which are necessary to give the public confidence in the ability of the Government-any future government-to tax fairly.

One must also bear in mind that the revenue gained from the tax measures before the House today will be passed back to the taxpayers by way of tax cuts. As I and other speakers pointed out yesterday, the amount of tax cuts which will go back to taxpayers from the beginning of the next financial year will be more than generous. Indeed, it will more than offset any of the revenue gained. People will receive in their pockets during the next financial year just over $9 per week. In the following financial year it will amount to an average of $15 per week for the average wage earner.

In conclusion, I support these Bills because they form part of the tax package, the first part of which was passed by the House yesterday, to try to bring about tax equity for the Australian community. Until now, that has only been a myth because those who have been able to get out of paying tax have had very little remedy applied to them. These tax Bills, along with those passed yesterday, will correct that situation. I believe they should be supported by the Opposition. Surely, the Opposition is not in the business of backing those people who are trying to get out of paying their fair share of tax. I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to this debate almost from its beginning this morning. I have heard a large number of very good speeches from members on both sides of the House, expressing quite different, and quite legitimate, points of view. I draw the attention of the House to the quality of only one speech-that is, the speech by the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright)-who, as usual, directed a voluble flow of defamatory abuse against members of this House and members of the Australian community. He does it every time he speaks. If any of his constituents are listening, I hope that they will take note of that point.

SPEECH.PARA: This debate, of course, concerns measures which form part of the Government's taxation package. We have already had some debate on that package yesterday. One would have hoped that, in introducing some tax initiatives, the Government would have taken account of the three bases of an effective taxation system: A system which is efficient, a system which is simple, and a system which is equitable. This measure and, indeed, other measures in the Government's tax package, do not meet those three basic requirements which all economists would agree are important requirements for an effective taxation system. This measure is clearly not efficient in economic terms because it reduces economic growth, takes jobs away from Australians and adds costs to the extent of between $600m and $800m to Australian industry. It is not simple, as other speakers have pointed out, because the paperwork in relation to this legislation alone comprises 151 pages of legislation, 176 pages of explanatory memorandum and a 56-page booklet which is to be sent to all businesses in Australia to explain how this tax is supposed to work. It obviously is going to impose an enormous burden of paperwork on the 700,000 or 800,000 businesses which will have to cope with the legislation. That could not by any definition be described as simple.

It is not equitable legislation either, particularly when one looks at the effect it is going to have on the jobs of those people in the car industry in South Australia and other parts of the nation. The 4,500 people in South Australia who will lose jobs because of this legislation will not regard it as equitable; nor will the disadvantaged in our community regard other tax measures, such as the negative gearing proposal as equitable when we consider the effect that has had on rental prices in Australia. It is not equitable either under the Australian taxation law or under the principles we have applied to taxation in this country to make the employers pay the tax rather than employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—This a point that the honourable member for Curtin very much wanted to make had the Government, by way of the guillotine, not taken away the right of that honourable member to represent the views of his electorate. It is not equitable to tax a non-beneficiary for a benefit. The Government has done that because it is too cowardly to face the wrath of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, which apparently will not implement equity on this occasion. This fringe benefits tax proposal is having a very severe effect on Australian industries. It is having a severe effect on manufacturing industry, as I shall explain. It is having a severe effect on the mining industry, as others have pointed out. It is even hitting hard Australia's primary industries, those industries which in any case are the hardest hit by both the Government's policies and international circumstances.
—Hear, hear!

—Fancy imposing another cost on that industry when it is in the disastrous circumstances so often articulated by the honourable member for Wakefield. The industry I want to talk about briefly is the industry which is so important to the State of South Australia, the automotive industry, and the effect this fringe benefits tax will have on that industry. Honourable members will be aware that between 40 and 50 per cent of car sales in Australia are fleet sales, that is, cars sold in the interests of business. The fringe benefits tax will increase the cost of those cars to employers by some $1,600. It is not surprising then that already this year sales in the car industry have dropped by a staggering 25 per cent. The effect of that on the State of South Australia, which depends so much on the automotive industry, has clearly been quite disastrous. The South Australian Government, a Labor government, pleaded with the Federal Labor Party to abandon this measure. The Premier of South Australia, as the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) mentioned earlier, was speaking in Canberra only last Tuesday. In his speech he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am addressing you-
these were car people-
in the knowledge that a decision has been taken which will prove detrimental to the car industry and one which will have severe ramifications for my State in particular . . .
I am particularly disappointed that the Federal Government was unable to show the flexibility to change its plans as this was an issue which was not being opposed on purely sectional grounds.

They are the words of the South Australian Labor Premier, Mr John Bannon. He was right to say those things because he knows-and these are his own figures-that 4,500 jobs will be lost in the State of South Australia because of this measure. Indeed, the estimate is that nationally some 10,000 jobs will be lost. The Government apparently is not concerned about the consequences of this legislation on employment in my State or in other parts of Australia. I think that shows an extraordinary lack of compassion and common sense on its part.

Car sales in general terms are going to fall very substantially specifically because of this legislation. The National Institute for Economic and Industrial Research, which is by no means a political organisation and which has no political sympathies, estimates that in 1986 some 35,000 cars will not be sold because of the fringe benefits tax and that in subsequent years 25,000 cars a year will not be sold. The total effect of this tax on the automotive industry is simply a disaster. It is also a disaster in terms of the Government's own car industry plan. When I personally raised this question in the House with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) late last year the Treasurer's response was that when the Government introduces tax legislation it does not necessarily do a study of the effects of those taxes on an industry and he conceded that no such study was done in the case of the car industry. The consequence will be that employers who are purchasing cars for their employees will purchase smaller and cheaper cars rather than the Commodores and Falcons they have been purchasing until now, and those smaller and cheaper cars have a lower local content. That will create chaos in the context of the car plan. No wonder Senator Button went to Cabinet pleading for this measure to be changed. No wonder so many members of the Labor Party expressed concern about it. It really is an extraordinary indictment of the Treasurer's arrogance that he should have cast aside all those jobs that will be lost in my State and other States and indeed the effects of this tax package on the Government's car plan.

In recent days, with the co-operation of the Liberal candidate for the Federal seat of Hawker, Mr Kym Jacobs, a man who will be a member of this House after the next election, I have conducted a survey of metropolitan Adelaide and country areas of South Australia to establish what effects this legislation and other recent initiatives of the Government have had already on the car dealers. Those car dealers who have responded to the survey have pointed out that their sales are down on average by between 30 and 50 per cent this month. The simple consequence of that is that they are now beginning to lay off staff. In the town of Murray Bridge in my electorate, for example, Murray Mitsubishi has said that it has not sold one single fleet car this year and as a consequence is beginning to lay off staff. Martin Motors Pty Ltd in the country town of Yankalilla which is already struggling because of the consequences of the rural decline has pointed out that from its point of view things could not get any worse because it cannot sell any cars anyway. It cannot sell any cars partly because of the rural crisis and partly because of interest rates, so from its point of view the fringe benefits tax will not be so devastating because it is going under any way. Two dealers in the town of Victor Harbor have said that sales will be down by between 40 and 50 per cent. One of those dealers, Southern Holden, has cut back its staff by two. The impact of this legislation on a small town like Victor Harbor in rural South Australia is the loss of jobs. It obviously has a very negative impact on that society. I would have thought that members of the Labor Party would have shown more compassion for those who are going to lose their jobs through this legislation and would have shown more common sense about the total impact of this legislation on the car industry and other industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —And some courage.

—I would have thought that, as the honourable member for Curtin says, South Australian Labor members and senators would have had some courage in this matter and stood up for their State and their electorates instead of scurrying behind the cloak of the Labor Party and would have voted in the House of Representatives and the Senate against this pernicious anti-South Australian measure. If they took their electorates seriously and if they respected the people who put them in the Parliament rather than just the internal processes of the Labor Party, they would have voted against this legislation. The Labor Party would not have expelled them all from the great Labor Party of South Australia. They would not have been expelled. The Labor Party would not have dared expel every single Federal member from South Australia. Of course it would not. Those members, including the Leader of the House and honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young), who has just walked in, have not had the courage to stand up and vote against this legislation-legislation which is anti-South Australian, legislation which is anti-business, legislation which makes our industries less competitive and legislation ultimately which will savage the weak and savage the disadvantaged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak on the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill and cognate Bills before the House. I have some reservations on only one aspect of these Bills which disadvantage farmers and, more particularly, their employees. The bulk of the Bills are reasonable and do face up to some massive tax rorts. After careful consideration, I have decided to vote for them. They counter the increasing tax burden borne by pay as you earn taxpayers where others are able to use tax provisions to avoid paying tax on benefits received. PAYE taxpayers are forced into paying their tax each week without the types of strategies that can be developed by non-pay as you earn taxpayers. Why should wage and salary earners pay more and more tax while others can claim meals at posh restaurants, call-girls, and flash hotels as tax deductions?

SPEECH.PARA: My concern, which will take only a few minutes to express, is that farm employer-employee relationships need to be properly considered when we look at fringe benefit tax. I note that in the paper put out entitled `Fringe Benefits Tax-a guide for employers', where residential accommodation is within Australia but not located in a designated remote area the taxable value of the housing benefit in the transitional year of the tax is also the market value of the right to occupy or use the accommodation for the period of the year during which the employee had that right, less the amount of any rent paid by the employee. In future years of tax the taxable value of accommodation within this category will be subject to indexation arrangements. These will be explained in the further booklet to be published in relation to subsequent years of tax.

The booklet then goes on to talk about residential accommodation in a remote area and notes that if an area is near a population of 14,000 or more, for farms less than 40 kilometres by the shortest practical surface route from the centre point of such a centre or less than 100 kilometres from the centre of an area with a population of 130,000 or more, then it has remote area consideration. There are different strategies for those remote areas.

I would like to point out a problem in areas which are within those limits; for instance, this sub-region of Canberra to which my electorate adjoins. Farmers in these close areas near the Australian Capital Territory and similarly farmers near the close areas of cities such as Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide, Brisbane and Perth are often paying wages to employees. They could lease out their cottage for $80 or $100 a week simply by making it available to a person in a nearby town. These people are confronted with a difficult choice. First of all, they can charge the employee full rent and face the possibility of losing the employee and not getting another one, or they can allow the full rent and pay perhaps up to $35 a week more tax. This might lead to a decision to reduce the number of employees on a farm. The employer and employee could, alternatively, share the drop in which case neither would be particularly happy and again the relationship between the employee and the employer would be soured, or there could be other strategies to minimise tax. Of course, these are always looked at and quite often found.

I make the point that it is up to the Australian Taxation Office to dispute any assessment that is made by a farmer. It is interesting that an estimated 42,000 people receive accommodation benefits on farms in Australia. Of those people quite a lot of shearers, pickers and others are exempt from this fringe benefits tax. In all, not more than 30,000 people will be affected. This is approximately one sixth of the total farms. A fairly significant number of people will still be affected and a number will be classified as living in remote areas.

Many measures are alleged to threaten employment in the list of fringe benefits taxes but very few of them affect employment so directly as this one and virtually none of them on an industry sector which has such an important role in our balance of payments, as has the primary industry sector. One of the previous speakers, the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), spoke about the employee concessional travel, such as that by the airline employees. He neglected to reveal the fact that there has been a joint agreement by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the airline industry unions, Ansett Airlines of Australia, Trans Australia Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd on the taxation of staff travel concessions. In fact, airline employees have been advised that there has been a co-operative approach by unions and companies on this very issue. Successful discussions have been held and an agreement has been reached which results in a reasonable level of tax to be paid by the companies. So for employees the existing entitlements to staff travel concessions will remain unchanged. That has been agreed to by the airlines and the ACTU.

Since the announcement of the package the ACTU and the airline companies have met with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and his advisers and have discussed the airline industries, concerns regarding implementation. These discussions have been mutually beneficial. First of all the point needs to be made that the companies will pay the tax, not the employees. Secondly, in answering the question how is the tax calculated, it needs to be said that the fringe benefit tax applies to the arms length price of an airline ticket. The arms length price is 50 per cent of the lowest published fare for international travel. The Government concession accepts that staff travel is not equivalent to commercial travel.

There has been a joint statement on the fringe benefits tax which establishes the tax value of fringe benefits. This indicates a 75 per cent of arms length fare, minus employee contributions and minus $200 per employee per annum. The final money amount resultant is then taxed at 46c in 1986-87 and 49c in the dollar thereafter. The tax is to be paid by the company. To establish the amount of tax payable by each airline it may be necessary to change procedures in order to minimise administrative costs. While the tax will mean an additional cost impost for each company, the result is reasonable in all the circumstances. It has also been asked: What will happen to existing travel concessions? Nothing will happen to existing travel concessions. The parties have agreed to maintain the status quo. The airlines will not diminish staff concessional travel arrangements, nor will benefits be improved. Existing concessional travel or entitlements for current and future employees, eligible relatives and retired employees will be maintained. Employees staff travel concessions in the airline industry have been protected. The ACTU and airlines have agreed to enter discussions on a formal, signed document which reflects that agreement.

I feel that 13 measures other than the particular one I mentioned affecting farm accommodation contained in this Bill are not only acceptable but also are important in turning the tax burden away from pay as you earn tax payers. I therefore support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend, Madam Speaker, to say a little more when the next motion comes before the House. However, the people of Australia need to know that this small extension of allotted time for this particular package of Bills-the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill, the Fringe Benefits Tax Bill, the Fringe Benefits Tax (Application to the Commonwealth) Bill, and the Fringe Benefits Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill-relates, as I explained earlier today, to the Government's failure to get its act together on the whole question of taxation. We are dealing, under a guillotine, with measures that were first foreshadowed last September. On 19 September we were told that these Bills would be introduced. We have waited from then until now for them to come into this Parliament.
—We were waiting for you to do it for seven years.

—The Government is unable to control its members-including the honourable gentleman who is endeavouring to interject, the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent). The left wing of the Labor Party is increasingly dictating to the members of the Government where they are going and how they are going, and what they are doing in foreign policy and what they are doing to Indonesia-and the honourable member has done more harm to our relations with Indonesia than many others. It is appropriate that the people realise that the Government has extended this guillotine only because of its inability to introduce legislation at the time that it should introduce it.

SPEECH.PARA: This measure provides an extension of the hours on the guillotine measure introduced by the Government yesterday morning. It is of no credit to the Government that significant pieces of tax legislation adversely affecting every Australian are not being given adequate consideration in this place but are being now given a guillotine extension not because the Government wishes to give greater opportunity for parliamentary debate but because it has another piece of legislation and, were it not to extend the hours, it is probable that the tax Bills would not come up in time.

In that climate, we object to the whole of the character of these proceedings. We believe it inappropriate for the Government to try to confuse the electorate by bringing in yet another important and sensitive piece of legislation through a device which is facilitated only by the motion that the Leader of the House (Mr Young) has just moved. We understand why the Government is introducing the measure. We oppose it. Whilst we may not vote against it in this instance, that is only because the clock is ticking away and there are so many matters about which we wish to talk that are of extreme importance. In that climate, we oppose the measure but will not vote against it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill-by leave-presented by Mr Lionel Bowen and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Madam Speaker, I refer to my statement that the Government intended to place before the House a Bill to establish a Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry into various matters relating to the alleged conduct of Mr Justice Murphy, and this Bill is to establish such a Commission of Inquiry. Madam Speaker, it is a matter of record that on 28 April Mr Justice Murphy was acquitted by a jury in a trial which had obliged him to stand down from the High Court of Australia pending its hearing. It is also a matter of record that on 29 April the Opposition issued a statement in the following terms:

In view of the finding in the trial of Mr Justice Murphy, the Opposition does not propose to take parliamentary action in terms of section 72 of the Constitution based on the specific issues dealt with in the criminal trial.

The High Court was to resume sittings on Tuesday, 6 May. At 3 p.m. on Friday, 2 May, at a meeting with the Chief Justice, I was informed that Mr Justice Murphy had agreed to meet with his fellow judges at 2 p.m. on Monday, 5 May, to discuss matters known only to them. Following that meeting it was announced that Mr Justice Murphy would voluntarily refrain from sitting on the High Court until such time as he had had an opportunity to answer matters allegedly involving him as published in the National Times newspaper of Thursday, 1 May, and also matters relevant to him in the confidential volume 2 of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions tabled in this House on 1 May.

It was also announced that Mr Justice Murphy's statement by way of an answer is to be made available for consideration to the Court, the Attorney-General, the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the Australian Democrats. This meant that there would be a further meeting by Mr Justice Murphy with his fellow justices of the Court at a time dependent upon when he had had an opportunity to furnish his statement. This announcement caused a great deal of misunderstanding of the intentions of the justices of the Court and on 6 May the Chief Justice was obliged to make a statement that the justices did not intend to make any inquiry or make any finding in order to resolve any controversy as to Mr Justice Murphy's judicial status, rights or duties. The statement further mentioned that the members of the Court agreed to postpone further discussion until Mr Justice Murphy has made such response as he wished.

It is clear that further discussion between the justices will not resolve the matter and there is the likelihood of further allegations being made in the National Times newspaper. This makes it imperative that all such matters are resolved as expeditiously as possible. Accordingly, as the Government has always been mindful to have full regard to the necessity of protecting the standing and integrity of the High Court and the preservation of public confidence in it, it decided that this Commission should be established without delay. Madam Speaker, this Bill is to establish a Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry into the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy.

The Commission is to consist of three persons who are or have been judges of a superior court. The terms of reference are set out in clause 5 and are to inquire and advise the Parliament whether any conduct of Mr Justice Murphy has been such as to amount to proved misbehaviour within the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution. It will be noted that the terms of reference provide for a potentially wide-ranging inquiry. This has been necessary because, notwithstanding his acquittals of criminal charges, allegations continue to be made against His Honour. It is necessary for the standing of the Judge and of the High Court that all allegations be dealt with one way or the other.

The width of the terms of reference is to be read in the light of clause 5 (2), under which in carrying out its inquiry the Commission is to consider only specific allegations made in precise terms. Mr Justice Murphy is not to be required to give evidence before the Commission on a matter unless it is of the opinion that there is before the Commission evidence of misbehaviour sufficient to require an answer and the Commission has given the Judge particulars in writing of that evidence. These important requirements are intended to limit the inquiry to specific allegations, and also allow vexatious or irrelevant complaints to be summarily rejected by the Commission. In addition, clause 5 (4) requires the Commission not to reopen issues dealt with in the trials leading to the acquittal of Mr Justice Murphy except to the extent it is necessary to do so in order to examine other issues in the performance of its inquiry. This includes in particular the issue of guilt or innocence of the charges laid, and whether the conduct the subject of the charges was such as to constitute proved misbehaviour in any other way.

The Commission is required by clause 6 (2) to base its findings on evidence admissible in a court of law. It is to have all the normal powers of a royal commission, including the power to subpoena witnesses and call for documents and other material. This will include Mr Justice Murphy, where the Commission decides that there is a case to answer on the matter in question. As is normal for royal commissions, self-incrimination is no excuse for failing to answer, but the evidence cannot be used in any court proceedings other than for perjury. I refer the House to clauses 16 and 27.

In order to enable the fullest possible consideration of the matters in issue, but in such a way as not to unduly prejudice the rights and reputations of individuals, the presumption is to be-subject to any decision to the contrary by the Commission-that the proceedings of the Commission will be conducted in private. I refer to clause 7 (1). The Commission is to have access to documents and other materials of the Stewart Royal Commission, including tapes and tape transcripts and summaries, now held by the National Crime Authority. I refer to clause 13 (1). In considering any allegation it is to have regard to the outcome of any previous official inquiry into the allegation, and consider it only to the extent that the Commission considers it necessary or desirable to do so. I refer to clause 5 (3).

Under clause 8, the report of the Commission is to be furnished on or by 30 September 1986 unless both Houses extend that date. The Commission is to report to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives-
(a) its findings of fact; and
(b) its conclusions whether any conduct of Mr Justice Murphy has been such as to amount, in its opinion, to proved misbehaviour within the meaning of section 72 of the constitution.

As honourable members appreciate, if it so reports it will still be for each House of Parliament to decide whether a case of proved misbehaviour within the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution has been established. If the report is that there is no conduct that amounts to proved misbehaviour it will, I trust, be accepted by all members as putting the matters dealt with finally to rest. I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Leave granted for second reading debate to continue.

We have been given five minutes in which to analyse one of the most significant measures ever brought before the Australian Parliament-five minutes in Committee. This Government has done more to undermine the institutions of this nation than has any other. SPEECH.PARA: Those on the Left, the sycophants of those who in this place so often try to destroy what is right and proper, are those who are really calling the shots. We all know of the revolt in Caucus this morning. We know the reason why there is no opportunity for us in this place to consider this Bill. It is only because the members of the Left of the Australian Labor Party were not prepared to accept the Bill as it was originally submitted to Caucus. Having had a reprint later this afternoon, now, at a quarter past eight, we are told that the Bill has to be passed through this Parliament within approximately an hour and a half so that it can get to the Senate.

I believe that there is no greater condemnation of the Leader of the House (Mr Young) and the Government than the fact that they are not able to control members of their own Caucus in introducing a measure which is designed to sustain the integrity of the High Court of Australia any more than they are able to determine the proper and correct procedures of the House of Representatives. This place more and more is becoming very secondary to the Senate in the consideration of significant legislation. The reason is measures such as that which the Leader of the House has just introduced.

This measure is designed to reduce debate on this Bill. It is designed to give the members of the House of Representatives one and a half hours, including five minutes in committee, to consider matters that deal necessarily with the secrecy of the inquiry; the wording and the adequacy of the terms of inquiry; and the degree to which others outside this Parliament, and certainly in the Labor Party and holding high office in the Government of New South Wales, may or may not be involved. For this measure to be accepted by this House is an indictment of democracy itself. Regrettably, we have no time to debate the measure. It is in that climate that, while we are opposed totally to the motion moved by the Leader of the House, I do not intend to delay the House by calling for a division. But people outside the Parliament need to understand that it is not because we do not object; it is only because the Government gives us no alternative.
