SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an historic and sad occasion. It is the only time in our history when we have had to consider action under section 72 of the Constitution. It is sad because it has to be done and because it involves the highest court in the land-the court on whose standing, repute and perceived integrity public confidence in our legal system depends. The Opposition's proposal has been adopted by this Government. To that extent, we most certainly welcome the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Bill which is before the House. But we leave it to this House and to the public to judge how far the principles underlying that proposal have been adopted by this Bill. We have heard almost nothing from the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in explanation of what has taken place, but I gathered two things from him. He thought that the High Court had caused a great deal of misunderstanding-we all know where the misunderstanding came from-and he said it was now imperative that all issues be resolved as soon as possible. It has been imperative for months that all issues be resolved as soon as possible and Blind Freddy would have known that.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not debating this legislation tonight because of some principled decision by this Government. The Government has been driven here by the Opposition, by the inexorable pressure of events, and by the mounting tide of public opinion. It has abjectly surrendered the position it has taken in the past. It has half-heartedly brought this Bill into the Parliament because it has been forced to do so and not for any other reason. It did not lack warnings. In September 1984 Senator Durack said to the Senate:
If the Government really were willing to resolve the substance of this matter . . . it would co-operate in establishing a form of Parliamentary commission.

That is exactly what is being done now. Twenty months later, after two Senate hearings, two trials, one application to the High Court of Australia, an appeal to the Court of Appeal of New South Wales and immeasurable controversy, we are here debating a Bill to set up a commission to investigate matters relating to His Honour Mr Justice Murphy. Just a scant 48 hours ago we heard the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) speak on this matter in this chamber. Let me quote two passages of what he said:
It is impossible for this Government to discharge its primary duty, which arises under section 72 of the Constitution, without allowing the members of the High Court to go through that process . . .
He said that it was impossible 48 hours ago. Again, what did that pathetic man say? He said:
The miserable people on the other side of the House . . . now seek to usurp the function of the High Court itself.

We said at all times that a commission should be established. The Government sought refuge by any means available to it. Was that a call of principle? The Government was looking for the political fix by the High Court regardless of the odium that the High Court might reap as a consequence. The impossibility has disappeared and the Australian Labor Party, condemned by its own Leader, has been dragged here on a pretence of integrity which demonstrates not only a grievous and cowardly failure of duty over months but also an unprincipled abdication of constitutional responsibility. So bereft in understanding of questions of high principle has this Government been that it would devolve responsibility to anyone, regardless of the potential cost to our institutions, as long as it could get itself off the political meat-hook on which it had impaled itself.

The Bill before the House should offer an inquiry so wide as to encompass any charge and any allegation so that no possible basis of controversy would remain. Yet it appears that pressures have been at work. Perhaps there was pressure from supporters of His Honour Mr Justice Murphy, and with supporters such as those honourable members who take his cause in the Caucus he needs no enemies. Added to that is the Government's incompetence and incomprehension of the gravity of the issues and the demands of factionalism. The result is that we may have before us an inquiry whose limitations-limitations which are enshrined in the Bill-may doom it to failure. In short, the Government, having shot itself in one political foot, has taken dead aim at the other and, quite by accident, at the judge himself.

Let us therefore examine the Bill and some of the issues. We do not have time to examine all the issues, and we are not talking about any single matter. Single events, single instances, single matters by themselves may be excusable and we are not here to pass judgment, but together they must be assessed and weighed. It is the cumulative effect of events, when examined and when the question at issue is one of conduct, that can present a devastating indictment. I do not for a moment say that is the case here, but let us look at some of the issues that the Commission of Inquiry must look at.

It must look at the material presented to the Senate Select Committee on the Conduct of a Judge, appointed by the Senate in March 1984. It must look at the material presented to the Senate Select Committee on Allegations Concerning a Judge, appointed in September 1984. It must look at the relevant material presented to the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions and the issues arising out of and related to that material.

It must look at the material relating to the alleged communications and the relationships between the judge and Inspector Don Thomas, as he then was, of the Australian Federal Police, and other persons. All members of this House know that there was a joint opinion and we all know that there was a recommendation that a prosecution be launched against the judge in respect of those matters, and that must be regarded. I should not have thought that any honourable member in the chamber would deny that proposition.

The inquiry must look to the nature of the relationship between Mr Justice Murphy and Mr Morgan Ryan and others and between Mr Justice Murphy and other persons referred to in volumes 1 and 2 of the Stewart Royal Commission. It must look at any conflicts of evidence between evidence given by Mr Justice Murphy in the first trial and the unsworn statement made by Mr Justice Murphy in the second trial. It must look to the failure of Mr Justice Murphy to give evidence in the second trial.

It seems to be thought in some circles in the Labor Party that it is a matter of no consequence that a justice of the High Court should not give sworn evidence. It was perfectly open to His Honour Mr Justice Murphy as a citizen of this country not to go into the witness box. It was perfectly open to him to adopt the procedure which grew up in the nineteenth century when, so the rules were, one was not entitled to give evidence on one's own behalf, and in many cases for many charges one was denied counsel. That rule still exists in New South Wales. It has been abolished elsewhere. It exists in some other jurisdictions. As a citizen, Mr Justice Murphy is entitled to the benefit of that rule. But the question that the Commission must address itself to is this: Since the evidence for the prosecution was given in the witness box, since the justice's case was put to the prosecution witnesses, was it correct behaviour for the justice then to adopt the process of making an unsworn statement, a statement which is colloquially known in Phillip Street as a statement from the dock? What is the purpose of such a statement? The purpose these days is usually to assist those who may find the strain of giving evidence, coupled with their lack of sophistication and education, too much. So that right still exists. That question must be looked at by the Commission and answered.

It must look to the allegations by Mr Justice Murphy at the conclusion of the second case that the trial was politically motivated and at the reasons for that allegation and whether there were any grounds to sustain it. This is not just a case of an ordinary citizen coming out and saying that a trial was politically motivated. Here we have a justice of the High Court, a man who has had an extensive career in politics, who understands the nuances of public life, who after a grievously difficult case-there is no doubt about that-and who was certainly under a great strain, saying that the trial was politically motivated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it was.

—`Of course it was'-there is the interjection. Now let us examine that allegation. The charges were brought by the Director of Public Prosecutions. The Director of Public Prosecutions is an institution set up by a statute passed by this Parliament under a Bill presented by this Government. The Director himself, Mr Temby, was appointed by this Government. Does anyone really suggest that he was politically motivated when he commenced his prosecutions against Mr Justice Murphy? The case in question on which he based his complaint-the Briese case-went to the Court of Appeal of New South Wales. The Court of Appeal of New South Wales sat a bench of five justices, which is almost unprecedented. I can recall only one other instance of that happening in about 20 years or more. There may be other cases, but that was a very unusual course. That court unanimously determined that there was a case to answer on the Briese allegations. Is it suggested that that decision was politically motivated? If neither the Director of Public Prosecutions nor the Court of Appeal of New South Wales can be considered to be politically motivated, what are the reasons for that statement? Let me put this to honourable members opposite-this should be examined by the Commission-what kind of damage might that statement do to the institutions of justice in our country, coming from a justice of the High Court who says: `This prosecution was politically motivated'. That is as serious a charge as one can make against the administration of justice in this country. That matter must be investigated.

SPEECH.PARA: We have the seven questions put to Mr Justice Murphy by Mr Justice Stewart in the course of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions. Whatever those matters may be, it is a matter of public knowledge that those questions were put and that they should have been responded to. We must consider the failure of Mr Justice Murphy to respond to those allegations during the course of the inquiry. I do not contest that he was perfectly entitled, in the circumstances, to take the course that he took. As a citizen of this country that course was open to him; but as a justice of the High Court, was it? Is that the kind of behaviour that we should expect from a justice of the High Court? Was it really open to a justice of the High Court to say: `No, I do not believe I should go before your Commission. There is a case pending.' The correct procedure would have been for him to say: `Yes, I will come before your Commission; yes I will answer these questions, I have nothing to fear and I have an obligation higher than that of other citizens because I am a justice of the High Court and I must at all time co-operate with the institutions of justice, regardless of my own personal position'. Those matters, amongst others, must be investigated.

I turn now to the Bill. I wish to say something about the problems that emerge when one examines it. Let us look first of all at the terms of reference which are to be found in clause 5 (1) That clause says:

The Commission shall, in accordance with this section, inquire, and advise the Parliament, whether any conduct of the Honourable Lionel Keith Murphy has been such as to amount to proved misbehaviour--
That is a wide statement of the terms of reference. But the question is whether that wide statement is cut down by what appears later. In clause 5 (1) it says:
In carrying out its inquiry the Commission shall consider only specific allegations made in precise terms.

I am somewhat puzzled by that. Is it not a matter for the Commission itself to formulate whatever allegations it believes arise out of the material considered by it. Then we come to clause 5 (4). Originally, when I received the draft of the Bill shortly before 8 o'clock this morning, 5 (4) read in these terms:

The Commission shall not consider the issues dealt with in the trials leading to the acquittal of the Honourable Lionel Keith Murphy of certain criminal charges on 5 July 1985 and 28 April 1986, except to the extent that the Commission considers necessary for the proper examination of other issues arising in the course of the Commission's inquiry.

Honourable members will note that that provision is directed to the issues that were dealt with in the trials. The clause, which I understand is now before the House, since it is the clause that I have been provided with as an amendment, reads:
The Commission shall not consider-

(a) the issues dealt with in the trials leading to the acquittal of the Honourable Lionel Keith Murphy of certain criminal charges on 5 July 1985 and 28 April 1986 and, in particular, the issue of the Honourable Lionel Keith Murphy's guilt or innocence of those charges;
I do not for a moment say that the question of his guilt or innocence should be re-examined. The clause goes on:

(a) whether the conduct to which those charges related was such as to constitute proved misbehaviour within the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution, except to the extent that the Commission considers necessary for the proper examination of other issues arising in the course of the Commission's inquiry.

The focus there is on conduct to which those charges related. Apparently that means conduct revealed to the court, conduct which may be revealed elsewhere and conduct as revealed before the Senate Committee on Allegations Concerning a Judge. That greatly broadens, it seems to me, the exclusion of the matters that the Commission can examine. The Commission must find some other issue arising in its inquiry before it can look at that conduct.

I turn to clause 6 which deals with evidence. This is a crucial clause because it provides first of all that Mr Justice Murphy shall not be required to give evidence on a matter before the Commission unless the Commission is of the opinion that there is before it evidence of misbehaviour-I emphasise the words `evidence of misbehaviour'-within the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution, sufficient to require an answer and the Commission has given Mr Justice Murphy the particulars of that evidence. Therefore there must be evidence of misbehaviour before the Commission and the particulars must be given to Mr Justice Murphy. So far as we are talking about a prima facie case, we have no quarrel with that. There should be a prima facie case set up which Mr Justice Murphy has to meet before he is compelled to give an answer. That seems fair enough. However, we know that one of the matters at issue before the Commission will be the Age tapes. We have two reports on the Age tapes and transcripts. We have the findings of Mr Justice Stewart in the published volume and we know the extent to which those findings go. Let me read to the House what he said on page 292 of volume 1. The report states:

The police witnesses' inability for the most part to identify with any precision elements of the tapes and transcripts, or to give first hand evidence about them, renders it highly unlikely that any such material would be admitted as evidence in criminal proceedings.

Let me stop there and tell the House that in general terms there is little difference between the rules of evidence that apply to criminal proceedings as opposed to civil proceedings. The judge goes on to say:

The Commission has certainly not succeeded in drawing up an accurate picture of the identity of each person responsible for each part of the process leading to the creation of the material in its possession and has concluded that this would be an impossible task-
note the words `impossible task'-
In the vast majority of cases the Commission cannot be satisfied as to who typed any particular page--
Once again note the words `vast majority of cases'. He continues:

However the Commission has received sufficient evidence to lead it to the inescapable conclusion that the material is the product of illegal telephone interceptions carried out by officers of the NSW police in NSW.

So he concludes that the material is the product of interception. Let me return now to clause 6 because this is the linchpin when one looks at the Age tapes and transcripts. Remember that there must be evidence of misbehaviour before an answer can be called for from Mr Justice Murphy.
Clause 6 (2) states:
In the conduct of its inquiry, the Commission shall not make a finding except upon evidence that would be admissible in proceedings in a court.

There is the key and this is how it, in all probability, will work. Certainly, this is what is going to be submitted, I should have thought, on behalf of His Honour. First he will say: `Under clause 6 it is necessary for there to be evidence of misbehaviour'. Next he will say: `In order for there to be evidence of misbehaviour you must be in a position to make findings because, unless you have made findings or are in a position to make findings, you cannot have evidence. Recall that evidence must be evidence admissible in proceedings in court'. He will say, or one can imagine it being submitted: `Since it is impossible to identify who made the tapes, since it is impossible to identify the authors of the transcript, it is not possible for anyone to make a finding against me. There is no legal evidence and therefore I cannot be called on to make an answer to any matter arising out of the Age tapes or the Age transcripts'.

It may be that the Commission will have greater luck than Mr Justice Stewart did. One would think that that was unlikely. One would think that with Mr Justice Stewart's analysis of the evidence, with his wide-ranging powers to recommend indemnities, which cover incidentally quite a few pages, he would have found, if anyone could, who it was who had made the relevant transcripts. But he says-and again I repeat:

The police witnesses' inability for the most part to identify with any precision elements of the tapes and transcripts, or to give first hand evidence about them, renders it highly unlikely that any such material would be admitted as evidence in criminal proceedings.

Does this mean: Exit the Age tapes, exit the Age transcripts? Were these matters in the mind of the Government? Did it not understand that that was one consequence of applying at all stages the strict rules of evidence?

We have sought to overcome this in an amendment which has been circulated and which we have, along with other amendments, no more than five minutes to explain. Our amendment seeks to make sure that this matter is dealt with in a way which would leave matters within the power of the Commission and would safeguard the interests of Mr Justice Murphy. What this Government has done, deliberately or unwittingly, is, in all likelihood, to exclude the Age tapes material and the transcript as any basis on which findings can be made.

Next, I refer to the conduct of the hearings in private. Is it not astonishing that a creature of this Parliament-and that is what we are talking about-is going to hold its hearings in private? Clause 7 (1) reads:
The Commission shall, unless it thinks the circumstances require otherwise, conduct the whole of its inquiry in private.

We have had enough of private inquiries. If we are to be in a position to dispel once and for all the controversies which have arisen, let us have the hearings in public. How are we going to keep it private when it comes back here? Let me show honourable members what I mean. Clause 8 (3) provides that when the Commission comes back here `the Commission shall submit with its report a record of so much of the evidence before the Commission as the Commission thinks necessary to substantiate its findings of fact and its conclusions'. What appalling nonsense. It is not for us to consider simply the material that the Commission relies upon. It is for us to consider the whole of the material before the Commission and nothing less. Let me point out to the House that so long as any part of the inquiry is closed, so long as the public or members of parliament cannot be confident of what is taking place, so long as inquiries are not going to be subject to public scrutiny, we will have rumour and innuendo-we will have a repetition of the kinds of problems that plague us presently.

Let me go to the climax of incompetence which this Bill presents to us, and that is to be found in clause 8 which, very briefly, provides for certain matters. It provides for the Commission forming an opinion. Of what? It forms an opinion that `a person who has been or may be charged with an offence may not receive a fair trial', that the conduct of an investigation or a breach of a law may be impaired or that there may be prejudice to the reputation of a person or prejudice to his safety. In those events, and in some other events as well, the Commission has these powers: It can `include those findings or conclusions, or that evidence, in a separate report and deliver the report to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives, together with a statement of its opinion'. One would think: `Well, that is interesting; what is meant by a separate report?'. We know what a separate report is. We had one a few days ago. There is one for the public and there is one which is not to be for the public. Clause 8 (6) provides:

Where a separate report is prepared in accordance with sub-section (5), the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives shall not cause that separate report to be laid before the Houses of the Parliament.

Will anybody here explain to me the answer to this question: If a separate report is delivered, if it goes to the Speaker of this House and the President of the Senate and is not laid before the Houses of Parliament, how are we to make a judgment? Is that possible? It is not. Are we to make a judgment upon a report that we have not seen? Are we to make a judgment on a report that we cannot debate? Are we to make a judgment on the basis of material that we are not allowed to see? That puts this absurd series of provisions out of court. We can only hope that it will not be necessary and that the Commission will have the sense to bring all of its material back before this Parliament.

Let me lastly say something about the constitutional duties of this Government. Its duty was to set up an inquiry that will put to an end forever the controversies that have festered for more than two years. Its duty was to place Parliament in a position to make an informed and definitive judgment on all issues, with members voting according to their individual judgment on the matters before them and not in the pursuit of any part political aims. If we find ourselves in a position where there is a separate confidential report, we will simply be unable to make a judgment. If, as it turns out, the Commission takes a restricted view of what it should or should not do, we will be in the same position. I ask honourable members this: If the Age tapes material is excluded, will it be an entirely full inquiry?

We wish the Commission well. We hope that, despite what I believe to be very major deficiencies in this legislation, it operates fully, openly and quickly and comes back with the result which all members of both Houses can accept.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is critical on an issue as significant as the one before us that the House direct its mind to the important issues that not only go to the integrity of our judicial system, the reputation of the High Court of Australia and, indeed, the reputation of Mr Justice Murphy, but also go to the very complex relationship that exists between this Parliament, in the exercise of its responsibilities under the Constitution, and the High Court. All honourable members will be fully aware of the issues which led to the trial of Mr Justice Murphy. I do not propose to canvass them again. However, I want to address the minds of honourable members to the decision made by the Opposition following the decision on the trial of Mr Justice Murphy. I will quote that position as it was stated on 29 April by the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender). The Opposition's conclusion was:

SPEECH.PARA: In view of the finding in the trial of Mr Justice Murphy the Opposition does not propose to take parliamentary action in terms of section 72 of the Constitution based on the specific issues dealt with in the criminal trial.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read that again.
—The shadow Attorney-General stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In view of the finding in the trial of Mr Justice Murphy the Opposition does not propose to take parliamentary action in terms of section 72 of the Constitution based on the specific issues dealt with in the criminal trial.

That is a thoroughly impeccable position. What the Opposition recognised is what every member of this Parliament recognises-we do not have a system of double jeopardy in this country. We do not have a system whereby the institution of parliament seeks to bypass the findings of the jury. It is as simple as that. If that were the case for the Opposition-it was certainly the case for the Government-what then has changed? What then has brought about this legislation? The facts are that fresh allegations-at this stage they have the status only of allegations-have been directed at Mr Justice Murphy. Those allegations-I repeat that they are no more than allegations-were specifically rejected by Mr Temby, the Director of Public Prosecutions, as founding any cause of criminal action against Mr Justice Murphy. I ask honourable members to consider that. We are considering the situation of a man who has stood trial, who has been acquitted by a jury and who is ready to take his place back in the community and in the execution of the high judicial office that he holds. However there are some fresh allegations. The person in our legal system who is responsible for deciding whether these allegations lay any foundation or any basis for any further criminal charge against Mr Justice Murphy-this is the issue-has answered `no'. What problem does that present to this Parliament, this House and this Government?

The reality is that in regard to other events and other trials some of these allegations will emerge in various ways. Mr Justice Murphy will not be involved in those trials. Some of those allegations may amount to scuttlebutt which will be rejected by the court. The tribunal which is dealing with other issues may decide that they are completely irrelevant. However, the High Court of Australia has said-the Government has accepted the view and indeed, I think Mr Justice Murphy has accepted the view-that until these issues are finally dealt with and resolved, in fact, it is untenable for Mr Justice Murphy to be sitting on the court and discharging his responsibilities while this sort of material continues to appear in the media and when questions are being continuously raised. The proposal before the House is a very simple proposal. It says that we will get judges, exercising judicial power, to look at those allegations which the Director of Public Prosecutions says cannot found any criminal charges against Mr Justice Murphy.

The reason these proposals are being examined is so that the House finally can be informed of the facts. That is the reason. I am disturbed to hear the honourable member for North Sydney take the view that there is something intrinsically wrong in any citizen, be he a judge, member of parliament or Minister of the Crown, exercising his rights to make an unsworn statement, which is part of our judicial process. We are in an extraordinary situation. I must say, if the Press comment I have read which is attributed to some justices of the High Court is correct, it is a matter of regret and concern to me that there can be a view in any judicial body in this land that a right available to a defendant who is accused of a breach of law should not be used, when that very process, which is an inherent part of our judicial system, is intrinsically as much a right of the accused as is the duty upon the Crown to discharge the onus of proof. It is a matter of regret that if an accused person exercises his right someone should then say: `Hang on, he is not like an ordinary citizen, he has a law degree'. That person might be a politician or a Minister of the Crown. The proposition that such a person has some reduced right is untenable and unconscionable. The honourable member for North Sydney knows that that is so. On how many occasions has he, as has any lawyer who has had the conduct of a case, said to his client: `I think we are so far ahead I am not even going to waste the time of the court by putting you in the box'?

TALK.START.PARA: —The last time I did it I didn't want to put him in it.

—That might be so, but the point I am making to the honourable gentleman is that the integrity of our judicial system and the integrity of our High Court does not just rest on the reputation and the integrity of the individual justices who compose it; it rests upon their capacity to maintain the rule of law, to see that the fabric of our judicial system is maintained. The right of any accused, be he the most ordinary and most humble citizen or the one holding the most exalted office, to exercise his rights, rights that are given to him by the judicial system, is not something that can just be put aside. It is the duty of the court, it is the duty of any judge, to maintain the integrity of that proposition as part of the whole process of trials proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: It cannot be said-it should not be said; it is mischievous to say-in regard to this aspect of the law that a person who happens to be a professional man, a lawyer, a judge or, God help us, a politician, has fewer rights than the other citizen. That is a nonsense proposition. It is a mischievous proposition. It is a proposition which ultimately would undermine the whole fabric of our judicial system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why the register of pecuniary interests if we are not different?

—I do not want to take up too much time in this debate because I think time ought to be made available to the Opposition. However, I am concerned to join issue on what I believe are some of the basic and essential factors that we have to consider. In all this it is perfectly true that Lionel Murphy was a controversial political figure. In my view it is equally true that he is a great judge. In my view, neither of those facts in any way should be allowed to demean his rights as an ordinary citizen. This Government-I hope this Opposition too, regardless of whatever political advantage it may see in it-should not allow itself to go into a situation in which a citizen finds himself having to answer not criminal charges, because Mr Temby has said that there is no foundation for criminal charges, but slanders, smears and innuendo. This is particularly so if that smear or innuendo is based on evidence which has been illegally obtained.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an important issue. Do we, as a parliament, say to our courts and to our judges that if a person happens to be a parliamentarian, a Minister of the Crown or a judge and there is an illegal phone tap-we do not know whether the recording is true of false, but it might be true-that that person should have his rights and liberties as a citizen reduced because there might be a political advantage at the end of the day. That is the issue that I think this Parliament must face, and face squarely. We have here a man who has stood trial and been acquitted. So those matters are no longer in issue. What we are dealing with at this stage are allegations, many of them unsubstantiated, many of them to be tested, many of them illegally obtained.

What we as a Parliament are saying is that in order to ascertain the credibility of those propositions, because we are not entitled to presume the truth or the accuracy of those propositions, we will adopt a process which will ensure the rights and liberties of Lionel Murphy, citizen of Australia. Because he is a judge of the High Court, he has not lost those liberties. Because he is a judge of the High Court, he has not lost those rights. The honourable member for North Sydney found it a little difficult to comprehend the process that will take place. This Commission will determine the veracity of this evidence-I do not know whether I should use the word `evidence'-or this scuttlebutt. If it believes that there are some issues which need answering, it will call upon Mr Justice Murphy to answer them.

The concept of privacy is a concept which has been produced in order to protect the reputation of the Court and the individual. There is not a politician in this place who, from time to time, has not said in this place that he has been misrepresented. Are we, the people who are continually involved in that process, now saying that if somebody says something that is untrue, on the basis of information illegally obtained, we will say that that is all right as it has to be dealt with in a public way, no matter what damage it does, no matter how false it might be?

Those are the issues. They are complex and difficult issues. Ultimately, the responsibility will rest upon this Parliament. The obligations upon the Parliament are clear and they are set out in the Constitution. They cannot be abrogated. They cannot be handed over to a set of judges in the High Court. We have asked judges to look at allegations which at this stage do not have the status of evidence which could be accepted in a court, allegations which the Director of Public Prosecutions has said that he has found no basis upon which anybody can be charged, and then to advise this Parliament in respect of those matters.

We believe that there are two elements involved: To resolve these issues once and for all and to resolve them within the framework of accepted judicial standards and accepted judicial processes, but, ultimately, also to decide them in terms of the rights and liberties of a very distinguished Australian. Because Mr Justice Murphy has that distinction, because some people here may dislike him and some people may love him, he does not lose those basic rights. If we go down a track that suggests an abnegation of those principles, we will have done a grievous wrong not only to Mr Justice Murphy, but also to our judicial system. More importantly, we will have done an awful wrong to every citizen of this nation. Because the rights of Lionel Murphy are no more, and no less than the rights of every Australian.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly in the Committee stage tonight in relation to some of the amendments that have been moved by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender). I will refer briefly to two of those amendments in particular. Amendment (2) seeks to omit the words `made in precise terms', which relate, of course, to the charges-if not charges, the allegations, at least, or whatever else they might be-that must be made under clause 5. The proposed sub-clause (6a) in clause 14 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purpose of removing doubt, it is hereby declared that any Member of the House of Representatives and any Senator has standing to appear before the Commission and to put such submissions in writing to the Commission as of right either personally or by his or her representative.

I think I can amply claim that that sub-clause specifically is intended to be a muck-raker's charter. That, of course, is what this Opposition has done for the last 2 1/2 years. It wants to set up tonight a commission which will give it the opportunity to continue to pillory Mr Justice Lionel Murphy to its heart's content until it hounds him from the Bench. That is what these amendments are designed to do.

Members of the Opposition want to have the opportunity, as members of the House of Representatives or the Senate, to appear before the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry and trot out any allegations that they can find. They do not want them to be in precise terms. They specifically want to be able to make them generalisations. They are not interested in putting up specific allegations. They want to make generalisations which are much harder to answer. More importantly, they want to have a muck-raker's charter. They want any member of this House to be able to go before the Commission, with his or her barrister, and be able to wheel out any nonsense muck or rubbish as he sees fit.

That is in keeping with the great tradition of conservatives in this country since federation. One has only to look at the history of the High Court to see the way in which the conservatives in this country have always hectored and hounded Labor appointees to the High Court. I need only mention what occurred in the 1930s when Evatt and McTiernan were appointed to the High Court. For years and years afterwards members of this place refused to recognise them as legitimate appointments. They attacked them in this Parliament. If one cares to look at standing order 75, one will see the results of that. It was found necessary in this Parliament to pass specific standing orders to stop people attacking Labor appointees to the High Court. That is the sort of thing that went on. One can look at instances which occurred even earlier than that. In the early years of the federation the Fisher Labor Government appointed a person named Piddington to the High Court. He was then known as a liberal conservative, which in itself is a contradiction in terms. His appointment was so greeted with outrage by the conservatives in the nation that before he took his seat on the Bench he chose not to sit. Because that outrage which greeted his appointment was so great he decided not to do any harm to the institution.

I want finally to refer to the first days of Mr Justice Lionel Murphy's sitting on that bench. Various conservative elements in the legal profession refused to recognise him; said that they would not appear before him, and the like. He overcame that. He has overcome two and a half years of hectoring and hounding by those opposite and many others of their ilk in the community. He will overcome the allegation and the smears that are now at foot and at large in the community, and I have no doubt that when the Commission brings down its findings he will have been cleared, as he has been cleared of the criminal charges brought against him. I want to conclude by saying just one or two more things.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on.

—I said I will make one or two comments, and I will. These amendments attempt to water down the provisions for hearings in private that are contained in the Bill. Every fruit cake, every nut case in this nation at the moment knows full well that the way to get his face and name on the front pages of the nation's newspapers is to become linked with Mr Justice Lionel Murphy. I have no doubt that before this Commission is through there will be plenty of examples of the crazies of this nation, the sad cases-we have seen a couple of them already making allegations-wanting to make allegations before the Commission. If the privacy arrangements hold, those people will achieve little or nothing by their baseless allegations. If this Bill is changed so that it is possible for these fruit cakes, as I describe them, to wheel out their baseless and crazy allegations, the inevitable fact is that newspapers in this nation-particularly the more disreputable ones such as the National Times-will run such allegations, baseless as they may be, to the fullest extent. Is that fair? Is that just? Is that the way to run a nation? I suggest that it is not.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that these amendments, in total, ought to be rejected, and rejected soundly by this Committee and by the Parliament. The Commission ought to get on with its job and at the earliest possible time bring back its findings so that Mr Justice Murphy will be able to retake his place on the High Court bench and continue to give this nation the outstanding judicial service for which he has become renowned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter of profound regret that we are debating in minutes a measure which will impact upon the legal and constitutional framework of our Commonwealth for decades. As the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) has pointed out so eloquently, members of the Opposition feel that we would be failing in our duty were we not to express our gravest concern as to some aspects of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Bill and our determination to move, to argue for and to vote for amendments which in our judgment are absolutely crucial if this Commission if to properly perform the function for which it has been established. The Opposition will not be a party to flawed legislation which makes or tends to make this Commission a hobbled commission from its inception. This Commission is to carry out a very important preliminary stage in the most significant legal/constitutional process ever to be debated during the lifetime of the Commonwealth of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst it is clear beyond doubt that responsibility for the ultimate decision under section 72 of the Constitution rests on the shoulders of both Houses of this Parliament, it is axiomatic that the findings of this Commission are being sought by this Parliament for the ultimate use of the Parliament itself. I must emphatically reject the contention by the honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan) that a member of this Parliament should be denied access to and audience before the Parliament's Commission. I further adopt the comments of the honourable member for North Sydney, in that as the Commission is carrying out a function on behalf of the Parliament it is untenable that any part of the Commission's findings or determinations be kept from the Parliament-which is what this legislation proposes.

I have to be brief because others wish to speak, but I want to make these points if I may: That great founding father, Isaac Isaacs-later Sir Isaac Isaacs, Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, and a very great Chief Justice, and Governor-General of the Commonwealth-was emphatic that the ultimate decision of the Parliament would be final and unchallengeable. He even referred to the address from both Houses, referred to in section 72 of the Constitution, as being a verdict. I think it would be of benefit to honourable members if I read the precise words from the debates of the 1898 convention in Melbourne. The reference is the official record of the debates on 31 January 1898 on the Commonwealth of Australia Bill, at page 313. Isaac Isaacs said:

I want to lay it down distinctly that a judge shall not be removed under any circumstances, except for misbehaviour or incapacity; but I want the verdict of Parliament-the verdict of the States House by itself-
I interpolate to say that that is the Senate; as well as the verdict of the people's House, the House of Representatives-
the conjoint, independent, and separate verdicts of these two Houses to be final and unchallengeable.

This Parliament will be denied the opportunity of properly performing its functions, whichever way it goes, if this flawed legislation passes in its present form. I believe that the honourable member for North Sydney has impeccably pointed to the flaws. I do not wish to see, nor does anyone in this Parliament wish to see, a situation in which this Commission's functions do not conclude this matter one way or the other. I urge the Government, even at this late hour, to accept the propriety, the integrity and the absolutely overwhelming veracity of the amendments moved and the arguments advanced in this chamber by my colleague the shadow Attorney-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to deal briefly with amendment (7), which is the proposal to omit `private' and substitute `public'. I think that very much the questions raised by the honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan) are relevant to the amendment moved by the Opposition. Clearly the points that he made about the continuing attempts to smear Mr Justice Lionel Murphy really are at the heart of this quite ridiculous amendment. When we bear in mind the subject matter of this Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry and the need to preserve the public stature of the High Court of Australia, it is the view of this Government that the public interest will not be well served by the publication of evidence before the Commission has determined the relevance of that evidence to its terms of reference, as well as its credibility. As the honourable member for Makin stated earlier when he was referring to nut cases-there are a few of them over there-the fact is that there would be all sorts of attempts to get evidence in. The situation is that there will be a continuing flow of allegations which are ventilated in a way which maximises the prejudice not only to Mr Justice Lionel Murphy but also to judicial institutions. To have all of these allegations publicly ventilated-seriously, I do not know how the honourable member for North Sydney can put forward that sort of an amendment-would totally defeat the aim of the exercise, which is to permit Parliament to finally settle the question and the issues involving Mr Justice Murphy.
—How can we settle the question unless we know what they are talking about?

—The honourable member does not understand that we are not talking about the report back to this Parliament; we are talking about the fact that at this stage the Commission has not even determined the relevance of the evidence. I am not talking about the report back to the Parliament. If you would sit there and listen, you silly idiot, you might understand it. Additionally, pursuant to clause 6 (2), the Commission--

—Mr Deputy Chairman, I raise a point of order. The point of order is that shouting across the table `that silly idiot over there' will not assist debate. It is not parliamentary and it should be withdrawn.
—I am sure the Minister will withdraw the offensive word.

—I did not notice that the honourable member for North Sydney indicated it was offensive. If he does, I will withdraw it. If he stops interjecting there will be less shouting across the table. Additionally, pursuant to clause 6 (2), the Commission will make its findings upon evidence that would be admissible in a court of law. That makes this Commission considerably different from the normal royal commission. It is likely that material will be supplied to the Commission which would not meet this criterion and it would be inappropriate for such material to be published. SPEECH.PARA: It is likely that the unique body has the structure and powers of a royal commission, including the powers to require incriminating answers to questions put to witnesses. Like royal commissions, this body is likely to deal with very sensitive matters requiring confidentiality. I would have hoped that honourable members would be aware that for these reasons royal commissions frequently take evidence in camera. But this Commission is also unique in that the conduct of the particular named person is under scrutiny and on trial. There is no analogy with ordinary judicial proceedings-the honourable member for North Sydney fully understands that, and that is why I repeat that it is just staggering that he put forward these amendments-where the general rule is that evidence is taken in public and in which the tribunal finally determines the issues between the parties. This Commission can report only to the two Houses of Parliament which, under the Constitution, must make that determination.

The evidence, conclusions and findings of the Commission will, generally speaking, be made public subject only to the specific limited exceptions authorised by sub-clause 8 (5) and then only when the Commission, in its discretion, decides that the material should be included in a separate report to be furnished only to the Presiding Officers of both Houses.
