PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill and orders of the day Nos 2 to 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, against all principle the fringe benefits tax is to be levied on the employer and not on the beneficiary. Surely equity demands that any tax on non-cash benefits be levied on the recipient of the benefits. To support that point of view, I need go only to the Government's draft White Paper published in June 1985, which states, at paragraph 8.9:

SPEECH.PARA: The best approach in principle, would be to include the defined value of fringe benefits in the employee's assessable income so that tax would be paid on total remuneration, whether received as salaries or wages or by way of fringe benefits at the employee's personal tax rate.
As if that were not enough, the same draft White Paper had this to say, at paragraph 8.11:
With clear provisions in the law for valuing benefits, it would generally be practicable to collect tax on a PAYE basis in respect of most such benefits.

So there you have it, Mr Deputy Speaker. The Government knew the principle and knew how the tax should be levied and collected. All that it lacks is the political courage to do what it knows to be absolutely right. The problem of non-disclosure of benefits by employees would be overcome by requiring employers to do what is set out in paragraph 8.12 of the draft White Paper, which states:

. . . report all elements of each employee's `remuneration package' that are not now disclosed on a group certificate, in the form of `An annual statement of non cash benefits granted to each employee'.

That provision already exists in the Income Tax Assessment Act. If the Government had the courage to require the Commissioner of Taxation to enforce the Act as it now stands, that is all that would be needed. Whilst there may have been some abuse of non-cash fringe benefits laws which already exist, and which allow for those abuses to be tackled by the Australian Taxation Office, the tackling of such abuse is, undeniably, a difficult task. I do not believe that there is sufficient justification for overturning the basic tax principle that benefits of this kind should never be a tax on employment, as is the payroll tax. That is what this fringe benefits tax is, essentially: It is a tax on employment. The assertion by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his second reading speech that `there is no practical alternative' to imposing the fringe benefits tax on employers, contrasts sharply with the comments in the draft White Paper of June 1985, parts of which I have just quoted. On the very first page of his second reading speech, the Treasurer makes much of the Government's goal to:
. . . improve the fairness of the system for the majority of Australians by pursuing with resolve our policy of rooting out tax avoidance and evasion practices . . .

Yet when we examine two important fringe benefits-namely, low interest loans and employer-provided cars-we find that the majority of people receiving low interest loans, in the first instance, are on or below average weekly earnings. For instance, the figures for 1985 show that bank officers in the sixth year of service received-they do not receive much more now-$16,856 per annum, or 81 per cent of average weekly earnings and, in the thirteenth year of their service, were entitled to receive $19,457, or 94 per cent of average weekly earnings. Low interest loans raise the average bank employee's effective income by around 14 per cent. Now, with over 200,000 people in the finance and investment industry and about half of these likely to be in receipt of subsidised loans of one sort or another, we are not dealing here with the highly remunerated employees the Treasurer was so concerned to identify and of the type whom we heard so crudely referred to by members of the Government back bench in the course of this debate earlier today.

I move to the area of employer-provided cars. One estimate has around 70 per cent of fleet vehicles as being in the Commodore-Falcon class. These are largely provided to employees earning around average weekly earnings. Only about 7 per cent of the fleet market could be said to be in the luxury car class. The truth is that the majority of people provided with access to a company car are not high income earners. A practical example of the effect of the Government's tax policies can be seen in the current state of the car industry. My respected colleague the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), who made an excellent speech before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, has also mentioned this point. The Treasurer has argued that it was the Government's considered view that the:
. . . tax rules are quite fair . . . and will not produce distortions in the car market.
While acknowledging an impact on car sales, the Treasurer said also:
. . . the loss of unit sales due to the tax will fall within tolerable limits for the industry.
Well, good luck to the Treasurer! He did not ask the car industry for its opinion. He will wish he did before his days are out.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bet he will.

—I am glad the support from the honourable member for Denison. The Treasurer went on to say that we `cannot let short term adjustment considerations' stand in the way of his proposed changes. He then added:

SPEECH.PARA: The industry need not rely on unfair tax advantages in the context of the stronger economy, improved competitiveness and the further advantages provided by the car plan . . . .

Yet this has not been the judgment of the car industry or those he intends to tax. While it is quite true that the Governments's fringe benefits tax on company cars cannot be held totally accountable for the downturn that is being experienced in the car industry at all levels, it is a major contributor, if not the major contributor, to that set of circumstances. Obviously, the rural crisis has had an effect, and I acknowledge it. So have higher interest rates and higher car prices caused by the devaluation-both to some extent attributable to the economic policies of this Government.

The Treasurer cannot have it both ways. If he wants to claim what he sees as the strengths in general economic conditions as credits to offset problems now being foisted on the car industry, he is also liable to severe criticism from us and others over the conduct of economic policy resulting in high interest rates and the 20 per cent or more devaluation of the Australian dollar now affecting consumers and as seen clearly in evidence in the prices of cars. Mr Max Gransden, the Marketing Director of the Ford Motor Co. Australia Ltd, recently noted:
The average young couple has things like a mortgage and school fees to pay. The sort of car they'd be looking at buying-the Mazda 626-
which was very ecumenical of him-
the Telstar, the Magna, the Corona and the Camira have gone up in price by about 20 per cent since the start of the year.

The year being 1986. At the very least, the Government has picked a most inappropriate time to introduce a tax that has already seriously hit fleet sales. Mr Lim Say Boon pointed out in the Australian Financial Review on Monday of this week that there has been a sharp downturn. He wrote:

There are serious fears of a slump in market volume leading to widespread retrenchment, dealership failures and massive financial losses following the 2.5 per cent market decline in the first quarter of the year.

With private, urban and rural markets in severe decline, the fringe benefits tax could not possibly have come at a worse time for the car industry. If the current trend continues, the market will find itself in the appalling position of turning over only something like 520,000 units this year. This would be 48,000 units below those recorded sales during the 1983 slump. No wonder we find Mr Max Gransden of Ford, to whom I referred earlier, saying:
I think you can say the downturn was greater than expected . . . the industry is in a pretty serious state.
It is no wonder that Mr Steve Markwell, Sales and Marketing Director of Nissan Motor Co. (Australia) Pty Ltd, recently said:
We desperately need numbers . . . I'm pretty depressed about this . . .
He is not the only one. Mr Graeme Longbottom, Deputy Managing Director of Mitsubishi Motors Australia Ltd, said that his organisation:
. . . will be struggling to turn in a profit this year.
The Executive Director of the Australian Automobile Dealers' Association, Mr Alex Brown, told the Australian Financial Review:
Since the start of the year around 20 dealers have fallen into serious financial trouble.

The story goes on and on. My colleagues and I could have spent the full 20 minutes we are normally allocated in this place to speak on important measures with great effect. We will not be able to debate the Bills clause by clause simply because this Government and the Leader of the House (Mr Young) cannot organise the order of business and speaking time for this vastly expanded Parliament. It is preposterous and a disgrace. We have, by acceding to this method of handling the business of the House, given away all our rights to the Senate, which has become the true legislative chamber in this country. That is not to our credit and I think it is something we will live to regret.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government was elected in 1983 with a mandate to provide economic management for this country and, perhaps, to lead it out of the industrial chaos which had characterised the previous Government. If there is any way by which one can measure the success of this Government, I think it is the figure that was mentioned by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) today in Question Time. It is the figure that gives outstanding testimony to the success of this Government. The achievement of 670,000 new jobs in three years is indeed an outstanding record of performance in economic management for the Government. But there is one other thing which was demanded by the people of Australia and, indeed, which this Government intends to fulfil, and that is a significant and wide-ranging reform of the taxation system in this country. There is no question that the progressivity of our taxation system had been severely eroded over the last couple of decades and that the fairness and equity of the system had suffered as a result of oppressive marginal tax rates. Indeed, it is this principle of providing incentive for those who wish to work hard and produce which underlies the principles behind the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986. It is the measures contained within these four Fringe Benefits Taxation Bills which will provide the wherewithal for the Government to lower the marginal tax rates and thereby provide an incentive for all Australians to work hard and provide for a fair and equitable taxation system.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday in this place we discussed the negative gearing provisions and other measures in the other tax Bills and we heard from the Opposition bleatings about how unfair this was and how industry would suffer. Today, in these four Bills we get a thorough reassessment of the benefits provided by employers to employees. They contain specific rules for valuing the kinds of fringe benefits that are provided by employers, and the following cases are included: The private use of motor cars, interest free or low interest loans that are provided to employees, the release of debts, payment of private expenses, free or subsidised residential accommodation, excessive living away from home allowances, free or subsidised board, concessional fares for airline transport, entertainment for tax exempt bodies only, and free or discounted goods or other property. A number of other measures are included within the ambit of these Bills.

I will just take one or two examples. It is clear for all to see that there are significant benefits for employees in circumstances where, for instance, the school fees of children at a private school are paid by the employer. When those fees come up to the level of perhaps $3,000, $4,000 or $5,000 a year, it is clear that an employee in those circumstances is receiving a significant tax benefit from that sort of fringe benefit that is provided by an employer. The provision of cheap accommodation may be another way in which it is possible for a tangible benefit to be received by an employee from an employer, and there is no way under the present provisions in which the Government is able to obtain taxation revenue from that arrangement. Certainly, the provision of a motor car for use privately provides the employee with a significant tax free benefit. I could go on. The simple way around this problem would be for the employee to be paid money that is equal to the benefit. Then the Australian Taxation Office would be able to retain a significant proportion of tax from that amount.

What sorts of responses did we get from members of the Opposition? The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) came into the chamber yesterday and said that his response to these proposals was that he could provide an army of accountants and lawyers who would allow him to slide around the new provisions. If that is the sort of approach we have from the Opposition, it is not surprising that it is opposing some of these measures. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) went into nervous paroxysms about how the car industry will suffer and how the housing industry is suffering. The honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) was even more explicit. He came into the chamber and talked about crematoriums in Brisbane and how the National Party had been involved in mismanagement on certain occasions.

It seems that the only debating point that the Opposition has with regard to these Bills is that of jobs. The Opposition says that jobs will be lost and it is concerned about jobs. This Opposition provided us in its last year in government with a net job loss of a quarter of a million in this country. It is trying to tell us-people who in three years have provided 670,000 new jobs-how we should go about providing jobs in our community. That is sheer humbug. It is very depressing for all honourable members on this side of the House to think that after three years honourable members opposite have learnt absolutely nothing in opposition.

The pet concern of the honourable member for Mayo is the car industry. He comes into the House and speculates widely and talks down the car manufacturing industry. There has been a downturn in car sales in this country in the early part of this year. There are a number of reasons for this. No doubt the state of interest rates in this country forms part of the story. Clearly, 1985 was a record year for the car industry. Perhaps one would expect that there would be some downturn. The introduction of unleaded petrol caused a pull forward of orders, and that has distorted the figures somewhat. It is the employment story in the industry that we hear about consistently from members of the Opposition. The honourable member for Mayo should know the story because there is a significant car manufacturing industry in South Australia. I draw his attention to an article in the Adelaide Advertiser of 2 May which provides a survey of employment effects in the car industry in the early months of this year. I will quote from that report.

The Australian car manufacturing industry overall is recruiting and not sacking workers despite a downturn in sales and worries over the looming car tax. Mitsubishi has taken on 400 workers this year.

The Mitsubishi company is one of the principal manufacturers in South Australia, and the reference is to this calendar year. In fact, Mitsubishi is expanding its operations. I heard recently that it was talking about introducing a new facility in South Australia for exporting cars. This will be possible because of the Government's policy on deregulation, together with the devaluation of the dollar, which has made our industry more efficient and more able to export. The article continues:

Nissan is employing 300 extra; Toyota is advertising jobs to overcome a `shortage'; Ford says it has not had to shed any staff and GMH says the 500 employees it has lost over the past six months are the result of a wind-down of the Woodville plant announced three years ago.
Clearly, the evidence is not that there has been a significant downturn in the car industry in South Australia. The article continues:
In addition, major Adelaide automotive component supplier W. H. Wylie and Co. is advertising for process workers to cover normal attrition and keep up its workforce numbers . . .

In South Australia, Mitsubishi's workforce has increased from about 4,000 at the start of the year to 4,400, while production is running at full capacity of about 300 vehicles a day, despite the general market slump.

Within the industry there is variation from car dealer to car dealer, but I do not think, on that evidence and on other evidence that is available, that it is fair to talk down the industry; nor is it fair to say that this tax is the reason for the present circumstances. As I said yesterday, it is not appropriate that industries in this country should be underpinned by tax shelters. That applies to negative gearing provisions just as it applies to the fringe benefits taxes that are proposed in the Bills.

But the complaints from the members of the Opposition continue. Jobs will be lost, they say. What validity is there to this sort of argument? I take another example. Let us look at the impact on employment in the entertainment industry of the fringe benefits tax on entertainment-the so-called free lunch proposal-which was introduced by this Government in September last year. The industry protagonists, the tax avoiders and, of course, the Opposition have been saying that this proposal would bring about disaster in the restaurant industry. I note that the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), who is sitting opposite, has revised his figures with regard to that industry. His latest estimate is that 10,000 jobs will be lost in that industry as a result of this legislation. I see him nodding his head. At least I am glad that he is sticking by his latest estimate.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to the 80,000?

—Eighty thousand was the figure, but that has come down. I accept the personal explanation that the honourable member made today and I have seen his Press release. Perhaps there was a misquote. Ten thousand is now his figure. The National Restaurant and Catering Association said that 10,500 jobs would be lost, but in the other place Senator Messner gave a figure that was a little more expansive. He said 18,500 would be lost. Looking at the Australian Bureau of Statistics category of figures for restaurants, hotels and personal services, the latest figure available before this measure was introduced showed employment of 284,000 in the industry. In December 1985-the latest figure available to us-303,000 were employed in the industry. Since the fringe benefits provisions were changed-since the end of the free lunch-there has been an increase of 6.9 per cent. The total industry increase in employment over those four months was 2.3 per cent. Not only was that a very good result over four months-a 2.3 per cent increase in total industry employment-but also employment in the restaurant industry increased by 6.9 per cent, three times the figure for the total industry. That just gives the lie to the mindless exaggeration and the talking down of the economy that we get from those on the other side of the House.
—There are more jobs.

—It seems that those changes have made more jobs or perhaps it is just a result of this Government's progressive policy with respect to tourism and in other areas. The honourable member for Denison is wrong by 30,000 after four months. God knows how far he will be out after a year.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation will have an effect on ordinary people. It will allow them to share the burden fairly and evenly. It will allow this Government to reduce significantly the marginal rates of taxation. That will provide incentives for those who want to work hard. It will provide for those who want to produce and employ people in this country. Tax will be paid where it is due and where it should be paid. This legislation will stamp out many of the distortions which presently exist within our system. I have no hesitation in supporting the legislation and I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that some of the revenues that will be raised from the fringe benefits tax which is being introduced under the Hawke-Keating tax package will go to the running of this Parliament and I suppose that some will probably go towards paying the costs of the Commission, the appointment of which will follow the passing of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Bill 1986 which we dealt with so badly just a short time ago. We made history and we made it very badly indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: On Friday 1 November last year the Australian Financial Review was kind enough to publish, as the main letter in the letters to the editor column, a letter that I wrote on this very subject of the fringe benefits tax. Because I believe in consistency in argument I went back to the files and obtained the letter. I preface my remarks by reading that letter. It is not very long but some of the points it makes will be picked up and accepted as reasonable and valid by the men and women of Australia who are listening to this debate tonight. The letter amounts to a condemnation of the Government which has brought in what I believe to be a tax package which is quite contrary to the interests of Australia. Under the heading `Government tax package a fraud' it said:
Sir, The Hawke-Keating tax package is a fraud and should be opposed-lock stock and barrel.

The package must be viewed as a whole. It is not divisible. Although it will be presented in separate Bills, the poison in it far outweighs the few sugar-coated pills. They are the `sweeteners' and only suckers would fall for a few `sweeteners' in such a poisonous tax package.
I wrote this letter on 1 November last year and it was published on that day.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were right.
—I am grateful. The honourable member for Kooyong, as ever, is on the ball, completely and absolutely. My letter continued:

SPEECH.PARA: Two fundamental principles of income tax law are at stake. Firstly, the inviolate principle that expenditure incurred in earning income is tax deductible will go out the door with the elimination of entertainment allowances. Quite bluntly, Section 51 of the Act is being raped.

Secondly, the fringe benefits tax proposals transfer the obligation from the employees to the employer and, as John Spalvins has pointed out, thousands and thousands of Australians will lose their jobs as a direct result of this proposal alone.
It is bad enough that the Hawke-Keating package will wipe out one-quarter of the motor industry,-
and that is correct-
one-third of the tourism industry-
and that is correct-
and one-half of the restaurants in Australia,-
that also is correct-

but it is even worse, the Hawke socialist Government will `get its foot in the door' to further ravage the fundamental principle of section 51-which is sacrosanct in every free enterprise democracy in the world.
I concluded by saying this:

The package is, at worst, a prescription for economic disaster to private enterprise in Australia-and at best a fiscal presentation of The Mad Hatter's Tea Party. Between them The Bandicoot and The Ferret are about to stuff-up Australia's economic development for at least a decade to come.
I believe every single word that I wrote is correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is the `bandicoot' and who is the `ferret'?

—We all know who the bandicoot and the ferret are. The Opposition opposes lock, stock and barrel this disgraceful Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill. It is one of a package of six Bills which have been rammed through this House with gagged debates. The guillotine has been used so much that the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) will be known from this day forward as Monsieur Defarge. He guillotined the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill, he guillotined the tax legislation, he guillotined the infamous Bill that we have just passed and now he is guillotining this Bill. The people of Australia should know that this Government is so scared of free, frank and full debate on this issue that it has limited the members of this Parliament to a miserable 10 minutes each in the middle of the night to talk about legislation which will put thousands and thousands of Australians out of their jobs. With the greatest respect to the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth), who spoke before me, he has proved two things: First, he is a magnificent hockey player and a superb captain of Australia; and secondly, he is a lousy politician. He just does not understand that the legislation he has been caucused to vote for and which he blindly supports is legislation that will put decent Australians out of their jobs. I thank the honourable member for Perth for accepting my personal explanation in the House today. I issued a Press statement on the very subject of the fringe benefits tax on 7 October last year. Ah! I see that the grave robber has entered the chamber--

—Order! The honourable member for Denison knows only too well that that is an infringement of Standing Orders. He must refer to honourable members by their electorate names and to Ministers by the portfolio they hold. I assume that the honourable member for Denison was referring to a Minister.
—Yes, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and he has now left the chamber. Back on 7 October last year I said in my Press release:

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Socialist Government's proposed abolition of entertainment expenses will cost the Australian restaurant industry at least 10,000 jobs in 1985-86.

I went on to say that a further 10,000 jobs in industries servicing the hospitality industry were now on the line. That was twisted by a Minister in another place. That Minister is fast earning the reputation of a person of very doubtful veracity. He stood up in the Senate this week and claimed that I had said that 80,000 jobs would be lost in the restaurant industry arising from the fringe benefits legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which Minister was that?
—Do I have to refer to Ministers in another place by name? This Minister has many nicknames.
—The honourable member for Denison has been here long enough to know the correct procedure.

—The Minister who made that statement was Senator Walsh. He claimed that I said that 80,000 jobs would be lost in the restaurant industry. That claim was false, as I have proved by producing my Press statement which the Special Minister of State permitted me to table in the Parliament today. That Press statement said `10,000 jobs'. If honourable members opposite make a thing about me being out by something like 20 per cent, what do they think about a Minister for Finance who is out by about 800 per cent? What about that? No wonder people say that certain people are `barmy as bandicoots' and `mad as a gumtree full of galahs'. The plain fact is that it would be funny if it were not so serious.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the situation. The Government is turning a deaf ear to the motor industry which is crippled and on its knees. Government members are skiting and laughing to themselves and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is saying that they must be able to accept and tolerate these things. The Government is turning a deaf ear to the restaurant and tourist industries which it claims to support--

TALK.START.PARA: —The restaurant industry is booming.

—The honourable member for Perth says that it is booming. Obviously he is so ignorant of the facts that he does not realise that restaurant employment goes up in the summer months. That is how thick the Hawke socialist Government is. There is no doubt that these figures go up in summer. You, Mr Deputy Speaker, know that in Queensland employment goes up in the summer. My daughter is working in the tourist industry and she knows that employment goes up in the summer months.
—You have destroyed tourism.
—Order! The honourable member for Perth has made a contribution to the debate. He should remember that these interjections are out of order.
—Thank you for your protection, Mr Deputy Speaker. This rabble that occupies Moscow corner does not understand.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: Earlier you allowed the honourable member for Denison to refer to me as a disastrous politician--
—I did not; I said that you were a lousy politician.
—Well, whatever, I really believe that that comment should be withdrawn.

—I did not hear the remark made by the honourable member for Denison about the honourable member for Perth. I am sure, knowing full well the tolerance and understanding of the honourable member for Denison, that he will withdraw any remarks that the honourable member for Perth regards as offensive.

—Of course I will. This Government does not understand private enterprise, it does not believe in it and by this legislation it is proving that it will get the last drop of blood out of every crippled small business in this country in order to pay for the enormous socialist programs which are part and parcel of its philosophy. The Minister for Social Security, who is now at the table, is the most committed and dangerous socialist this country has seen. He makes Dr Jim Cairns look like a choir boy. The honourable member for Kooyong knows of restaurateurs in his city of Melbourne, as I know of them in my city of Hobart, who will go to the wall. I am not talking about big, rich silvertail restaurants. I am talking about people who have worked their guts out to make a living in this industry and to support the tourist industry, which the Government claims to support but which, by its actions, it has stabbed in the back. The time that has been allotted to me has almost expired.
—It has gone.

—I have a couple of minutes in time on, in hockey terms. If it is good enough for the honourable member to get time on-the honourable member is a darn good hockey player but we know what sort of politician he is-it is good enough for me to get a couple of minutes time on so that I can finish my remarks. As I said, we have the most extraordinary situation. In the other place we have a Minister described as being as mad as a gum tree full of galahs and as barmy as a bandicoot. He happens to be the Minister for Finance. In this House we have a person who on any basis has been involved in tax evasion which would make any of us cringe, as we do.
—Who was that?
—Well, he is the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins). So we have a situation--
—Order! I think the honourable member should withdraw that.
—I asked him.
—Well, it is fact.
—I take a point of order. I think the remark that was made by the honourable member was offensive to a Minister and ought to be withdrawn.
—I am asking the honourable member to withdraw it.

—Well, it is true, but I withdraw it. I withdraw. I would like this to be the subject of a substantive motion to deal with this properly. In conclusion-I have gone one minute over my allotted time-I say that the chickens are going to come home to roost for this Government. Its fringe benefits tax legislation is going to cost it a heck of a lot of votes. Its capital gains tax legislation is going to cost it ten to 20 time more. Its negative gearing legislation will get not the tall poppies but middle Australians. Last but not least, I say to everybody: Do not hold your breath waiting for the Hawke-Keating promised tax cuts because I guarantee that this time next year we will be wondering what on earth happened to them. They will not be delivered; they cannot be delivered. This Government is derelict, bankrupt and thoroughly disgraced. It is a minority government in Australia today. Honourable members opposite are on the way out. I ask them to enjoy the remainder of their time in government because the Lodge will be back in the right hands with the right person in it before any of us are very much older.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I laughed a lot at a dinner the other day attended by Fred Daly. I thought that Fred would have been a good comedian. Now I know that the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) would probably make a better one, because I have never heard so many funny lines in one speech. The honourable member stood up and said that the Government was supporting tax evasion despite the fact that for seven years the Government of which he was a member allowed the greatest tax rorts to develop. The tax evaders that prospered under his Government were supported by his Government. In fact, they probably voted for that Government. The former Government allowed those tax evaders to rob the Treasury and thereby deprive honest taxpayers of millions and millions of dollars. It is an absolute joke for the honourable member to come in here and say that this Government supports tax evasion. In fact, we are now debating Bills which are designed to close down the tax shelters and the rorts that were allowed to grow and prosper under the previous Government.

SPEECH.PARA: A great deal of time has been spent today in discussing the implications of this legislation for restaurants and the car industry. However, we have homed in on other types of fringe benefits, particularly the benefits which allow people to receive payment in kind and the payment of private school fees which is not declared as part of income and which therefore is not subject to tax. We are now eliminating those sorts of rorts. The honourable member for Denison embarked on an exercise of saying that jobs will be lost because of the Government's desire to clamp down on and eliminate the free lunch. People have been able to claim the cost of the most expensive lunch as a business expense. In effect, the honest taxpayer had to pay for this. The honourable member claimed that 10,000 jobs would be lost in the restaurant industry. He also claimed that a third of the car industry would go. Not even the car industry claims that. That is how much nonsense he speaks. The car industry is not even predicting that sort of doom. He also said that a third of the tourist industry would be lost. Australia is experiencing the greatest boom in tourism that we have ever seen. The planes are coming in absolutely jam packed with tourists. Yet we hear this nonsense from the honourable member for Denison who talks about a third of the tourist industry going bankrupt because of all the jobs that are going to be lost. We are told that half the restaurants in Australia are going to close. What absolutely arrant nonsense!

The honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) gave a very clear indication of what is happening. The restaurant industry is growing because of the growth in the tourist industry. The honourable member cited figures which reflect that growth. There are more jobs in the restaurant industry since we moved to eliminate free lunches in restaurants. There are more jobs, not fewer. There are not 10,000 fewer jobs, as the honourable member for Denison claimed. The honourable member is about 37,000 out on his figures and his predictions are getting worse all the time. Honourable members opposite talk about a disaster, and that is what the Opposition really is. All that members of the Opposition can do in regard to every positive step we have taken to eliminate tax evasion is the same as the tax evaders-stand up and cast misery and doom.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I take offence at that reference to any member on this side of the House being the same as a tax evader. I ask the honourable member to withdraw it.
—Could the honourable member for Aston tell the Chair again what he said?

—I said that members of the Opposition used the same sorts of words that the tax evaders do. They stand up and cast misery and doom in regard to every one of the Bills we have introduced. I did not say that members of the Opposition are tax evaders. I did not say they were associated with them. I said that they used the same arguments.
—I do not think it is unparliamentary to say that people cast misery and doom.

—I take exception to the honourable member using the words `the same as a tax evader'. Mr Deputy Speaker, you properly directed me to withdraw the remarks I made about the Minister. I object to being compared with tax evaders and I ask for that remark to be withdrawn.
—It would suit the House if the honourable member for Aston withdrew the remark.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, in deference to your position and rather than get into a long debate, I will withdraw.
—I think the honourable member might just say that he withdraws.

—I withdraw. All we get from the Opposition is misery and doom. We introduced these Bills to eliminate tax shelters and rorts. All we get from the Opposition is claims that there will be disaster. What is the Opposition's solution? Its solution is to leave in the provisions which allow the tax shelters. The Opposition has no alternative.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is taking a logical step. I wish to refer again to something that the honourable member for Perth said. In talking about the car industry the honourable member pointed out that no industry in Australia can expect to survive on the basis of a tax rort or a tax shelter. The honourable member for Denison, who has just left the chamber, said that disaster would befall one-third of the car industry and that one-third of the car industry would close down and be finished. It is interesting to note the comments that were made in the other place yesterday by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) about what has been happening in the car industry since we have announced the changes, in view of the forecasts of misery and doom that have been made in respect of the car industry. I might just run through the salient points in a report in the Adelaide Advertiser to which the Minister referred. The report stated:

The Australian car manufacturing industry overall is recruiting and not sacking workers despite a downturn in sales and worries over the looming car tax. Mitsubishi has taken on 400 workers this year.
The Minister then said:
Mitsubishi is a principal manufacturer in South Australia and the reference is to this calendar year.
The article continued:

Nissan is employing 300 extra; Toyota is advertising jobs to overcome a `shortage'; Ford says it has not had to shed any staff and GMH says that 500 employees it has lost over the past six months are the result of a wind-down of the Woodville plant announced three years ago.
In addition, major Adelaide automotive component supplier W. H. Wylie and Co. is advertising for process workers to cover normal attrition and to kept up its work-force numbers.

In SA, Mitsubishi's workforce has increased from about 4,000 at the start of the year to 4,400, while production is running at full capacity of about 300 vehicles a day, despite the general market slump.

Where is the argument of the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) in regard to this? He has said that a third of the car industry will be destroyed and that a third of car industry jobs will be lost. The facts show up his statements for what they are-arrant nonsense. The reality is that the car tax will not have that impact. I support the tax provisions that we are introducing because for the first time we really are attacking those in the wealthy class in Australia who have been in a position to evade tax and to manipulate the tax system to suit themselves so that they have virtually been in a position of not having to pay tax at all. The pay as you earn taxpayer is the person who has borne the weight of that tax evasion. These Bills represent the first part of the taxation package which will turn around that assault on the ordinary PAYE taxpayer.

In coming to the end of my speech, I would like also to take up a point raised by the honourable member for Denison in regard to the gag which has been moved on these Bills. He came in here and said that we have gagged the debate on these issues because we are not prepared to debate them. He knows that is not true. It is simply the fact that Opposition senators have decided not to deal with any business after 30 May.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have waited for nine months to see the legislation. The Government would not take that decision.

—The honourable member knows that we have used the gag because Opposition senators have said that they will refuse to consider any Bills introduced after 30 May. They have said virtually: `We have worked long enough, we will take a holiday after 30 May. We will not consider new business'. In fact they know their responsibility is to consider business as we introduce it. That is why we are sitting an extra week; that is why we have to introduce the gag on these Bills. It has nothing to do with our not being prepared to debate the issue. We would like to debate it more than we have been able to do. We would like a lot more time to talk about many of the other benefits contained in the tax package. We do not have the time because we are forced to this schedule by Opposition senators deciding to go on strike after 30 May. The reality is that they will not consider any business after that date.

SPEECH.PARA: I will summarise the two main points I have mentioned. I talked about the free lunch and the car industry. I think the figures that I have given and the figures given by my colleagues who spoke before me have shown quite clearly that the tax reforms we are introducing are not affecting the restaurant and car industries. In fact, there is evidence to show that those industries are benefiting not just from the tax package but also from other economic decisions we have taken. These industries are in a better position because of our being in government. Taxpayers are in a better position because in government we have attacked the tax evasion industry and we are introducing the greatest tax reform we have seen in this Parliament for many years. The benefit of this will flow directly to those honest taxpayers who will receive reduced personal income tax payments as a direct result of the package we are debating today. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) and other honourable members opposite have been at pains to tell us just how well things are going in the business community and, in particular, the small business community. I think it is worth drawing their attention to the report in the Australian of 2 May 1986 which is headed `Bankruptcies blamed for 9.6 per cent fall in AGC profit'. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Directors blamed the result on the growing number of bankruptcies in the small business sector, caused by-
I hope honourable members are listening to this-
high interest rate, high levels of unemployment, the impact of tax changes-

This is an independent view. This is the view of a group of directors who are turning around to look at the reasons for their fall in profits. They are identifying the reasons for the fall and the low level of economic activity. The directors of Australian Guarantee Corporation put that in black and white in their report. Unlike the Treasurer (Mr Keating) who wanders around convincing people that two and two equals any number up to 10, these gentlemen have the figures in front of them. These are the figures for the last six months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the initiative that you put into small business.
—Oh, I see. I ask the honour- able member not to worry about that. He is in the Government. His Government is running this. This is the situation his Government has caused. The article continued:

SPEECH.PARA: AGC's directors said yesterday that the results were attributable to difficult economic conditions in the past six months.

We had the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) in here the other day reading out to us all the beautiful figures, but he never read out one figure that applied after November 1985. There is not one figure after that. People are living today. Honourable members opposite form the Government. It is about time that they stopped telling themselves fibs.

TALK.START.PARA: —And we are a good Government, too.
—Yes, the honourable member keeps telling himself that but the pity is that people have to suffer while he deludes himself. The article continued:

SPEECH.PARA: The net charge against profits for bad and doubtful debts amounted to $39.3m, up 300 per cent on last year's charge of $13.3m.

Those are the figures for six months as compared to 12 months. That is the economic indicator which it is time honourable members opposite took notice of. I remind honourable members opposite that one of the causes listed for bankruptcies which they have been denying was, of course, the impact of the tax changes. That is what we are here to talk about. The words I quoted are not my words; they are the words of the directors of the Australian Guarantee Corporation, one of the biggest finance companies in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What else have they got.
—Get Paul to ring them up and abuse them for having the temerity to put out a report like that. He does it to everyone else.
—Order! The honourable member for Aston will cease interjecting.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order--
—The Minister does not know who Paul is; sit down.
—Order! If the honourable member for O'Connor is referring to a Minister he will refer to him by his correct designation.
—We will get the Treasurer to ring up and use some of his filthy language, just as he did to our Leader.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor shall not reflect upon another member. He would assist the House by withdrawing.
—I withdraw because I cannot afford the time to argue.
—I think you should just withdraw.
—I withdraw. That is the point that we get to. Where are we now? Let us look at some of the myths.
—The scum.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order--
—I ask the Minister to withdraw.
—Withdraw what?
—Withdraw what you said. You have been asked to withdraw. Come on, hurry up!
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I referred to no particular member.
—I referred to `Paul'. He could have been the bloke who worked at Galilee.
—Order! There is a provision that if a member makes an allegation against a class of members he can be called upon to withdraw. I ask the Minister to withdraw.
—I withdraw.

—We have so many myths in relation to this Government today that it is becoming a problem to which we should refer. Originally, there was the myth that this Government had the best group of Ministers in history. They are now the Ministers best equated as being wax dolls. They go very soft at the first heat. We have seen one after the other fall down. They cannot cop it. They were pretty good at giving it while the road is smooth and while the going is easy. However, they all start tripping up when they run into a few pot holes and someone gives them a bit of it back. They are wax doll Ministers supported, of course, by a lame duck back bench that lets the Ministers roll it every day of the week.
—How many Ministers did you lose-13 or 15?
—How many Ministers resigned in your Government-all 27 of them.

—It is the honourable member's seat that is at risk. We also have the myth of tax cuts. Let us look at the National Australia Bank Monthly Summary for November last year, shortly after the Treasurer made his statement of 19 September. The National Bank talked about what honourable members opposite have been telling us today, that all the pain that the Government is going to inflict on people, all the administrative burden, all the cost, is to save someone some money. No doubt, honourable members opposite expect that there will be some saving for average weekly earnings. Let us see what this reputable document has to say about that. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: No attempt has been made to compensate for the effects of inflation on income between now and June 1987 when the new rates come into effect. This means that a taxpayer on average weekly earnings in June 1985 and paying 22.4 per cent of salary in tax, will actually pay 23.4 per cent tax when the new tax scales come into effect two years later, should average earnings increase by eight per cent per annum in the interim!
The suggestion is that the CPI increase will be only 8 per cent. It is running at 9.2 per cent, and that will make it worse. The document continues:

More alarming however, no commitment has been made to index the tax scales for inflation beyond 1987-88. In other words, there is nothing in place to prevent 50 per cent becoming the marginal rate for the majority of full-time salary earners in the near future, or looking further ahead, to prevent 50 per cent scale from gradually assuming dominance, even to the point of eventually creating a virtual flat tax system at this still substantial income tax rate. Is this tax reform?

It is a fraud to suggest that people must carry burdens that are delivered in this fashion on the understanding that in the future they will get some tax cuts. That document shows how fraudulent that statement is. People will pay one per cent more of their income after all of these burdens are placed upon them.

How did it all happen? We all think that this was something that materialised on about 19 September. We had the Tax Summit in July-that wonderful occasion on which the Treasurer strutted before Australians, telling us he had it dead right, it was all going to be fixed, and he would give us a consumer tax. He did all the things that history has recorded. A little research tells us that on 3 February, about six months before the Tax Summit took place, Mr Kelty of the Australian Council of Trade Unions gave a speech to the Socialist Forum in Melbourne. Maybe the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), who is at the table, was present. Mr Kelty laid down the tax package in February, according to an article which states:
The ACTU has predicted a bumper year for wage and salary earners, including two national wage rises, additional money for low income earners, no tax increases and superannuation for every worker.
A little later the article states:

He also foreshadowed a push by the ACTU for a Government crackdown on perks-such as company cars, expense accounts and education fees enjoyed by executives-and an expansion of the tax `pot' into currently non-taxable areas.

Quite clearly, he was talking about the capital gains tax, the tax we have heard about since 19 September, but we still do not have any legislation to tell the Australian people how it will work. That is when the Government received its instructions to introduce this stuff. It is further evidence as to who is running the country. It is certainly not the Treasurer or these wax doll Ministers that we have experienced in recent times.

Let us look at the fringe benefits tax proposal. I know all about equity in the tax system. I am prepared to concede equity in the tax system. I am prepared to concede that there have been abuses of the fringe benefits arrangements. That has happened because the Commissioner of Taxation has not used the laws available to him to address those problems. One has only to look at the tax return form that most people fill in. There is provision on that form to tell the Commissioner of non-cash fringe benefits. Those provisions exist today. The Opposition is objecting to what we see in this legislation because the Government is throwing the baby out with the bath water. That is what it is doing. It is hitting little people in farm houses. It is hitting the small country shire clerk. He needs some of the things he gets because he is not living in an environment where he can buy and sell a house on arrival, as he would in a big city. There is no bus stop at the front of the house where he can jump on a bus to go into work. He drives a vehicle all day. Like so many other employees, if he did not take it home and put it in the garage, it would stay out in the open. Those people can be treated differently. But the Government does not choose to do that. They will be the ones who will be hardest hit.

Small businesses will suddenly find themselves with a substantial administrative burden. Many of them will be obliged to pay a tax when, due to the economic circumstances that this Government has created, they will have tax losses. They cannot offset that tax against losses; they will have to pay in this way. Let us look at who will pay the cost burden in the end. I am told that Elders IXL Ltd has a fleet of 5,000 cars. When it pays the tax on those 5,000 cars, as it must because its business is such that its employees cannot be without vehicles, Mr Elliott must maintain his shareholders' dividends. He cannot absorb that loss. It will be passed on to our rural sector, which cannot afford it. That will go on and on. In regard to the stupid taxes on State and local government, those officers will continue to vote themselves the fringe benefits they receive today. The taxpayer, that ordinary Australian for whom the Government has all of this sympathy, will pay for that also.

But the greatest fraud of all-and I close on this point-is that we have a separate Bill particularly to allow the Government to tax itself. Have honourable members ever heard of anything more silly? Take it out of one pocket, put it in the other, and slap oneself on the wrist in the process. It is a Bill for an Act to provide for-and here are the operative words-`notional application of fringe benefits tax in relation to the benefits provided in respect of the employment of Commonwealth employees'. I say to the Minister that if he and the Treasurer are fair dinkum about the abuse of fringe benefits, they should stop giving them to their employees at the Commonwealth level. They will be the privileged group. They will continue to get their benefits. The Commonwealth will suffer no cost because the money just rolls back in and the Commonwealth cannot tax itself. So they will have the benefit. Those packages can still be offered. Yet in every other sector of employment this disincentive contained in this proposal will remain. It is a ridiculous proposal. The Government has thrown the baby out with the bath water. It is contributing to all those bankruptcies to which AGC has called its attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted tonight to be able to follow the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) in this debate, which has been raging in this chamber for almost 12 hours. In many respects it has been the most amazing debate that I have seen during my time-almost a decade-in this House. It is an amazing debate because it involves probably the biggest single change to the tax structure of Australia that we have seen for decades. Yet we are all restricted in terms of time limits for the debate. The Government has introduced an amendment at the last minute. Under the Standing Orders of the House we have no opportunity to debate that amendment. When the guillotine finally strikes, the whole thing must go through. When we are considering such fundamental changes to the system of taxation in Australia, I think that is a very poor reflection on the calibre of the type of government that we have in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Even at this late hour, when not one member of the Government is present on the back bench and the Government has run out of speakers, we are still being subjected to the same old line that we have copped all day. That line is definitely the Government line. There has been no original thinking on the part of honourable members on the other side of the House. Indeed, there has been very little contribution by Government members to the debate. I have been present for an hour or so. I have had to put up with the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) and the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) giving the Government line. I suggest that many of the figures that have been given to us tonight are nebulous, to say the least. Indeed, many of the aspersions that have been cast on so many sections of Australian society and Australian industry have been unwarranted. I think it is about time that we brought a few of the facts to the fore.

I was amazed that the honourable member for Perth should talk about the restaurant industry and the tremendous creation of jobs in that industry. This has been the sort of misrepresentation that we have had in this House since 9 o'clock this morning. It is really quite amazing. There is no argument from this side of the House that we should have any sympathy whatsoever for tax dodgers or tax cheats or for those who rort the perks system in Australia. Nobody on this side is arguing with that. The point has just been made by the honourable member for O'Connor that within the taxation system and within the powers of the Commissioner of Taxation we have had the facility to be able to deal with any rorts that have taken place. In fact, this Government and the bureaucracy of this country have not acted in regard to those rorts. I think it is a shame that industries such as the motor vehicle industry and the restaurant industry have been literally smashed to pieces because the Government has not been prepared to use the legislation that is already in place. I am amazed to hear of the growth of employment in the restaurant industry. I have been checking my figures tonight and there is no doubt that there has been an increase in the number of people employed in the hospitality industry so far this year, but I can name the places where that increase in employment has occurred. It has occurred in Jupiter's Casino, in the Adelaide casino and in the casino in Perth, and it has occurred in a number of new hotels that have opened. In the meantime, the restaurant industry in Australia is in decline. In my city of Brisbane alone in the last few weeks no fewer than three restaurants have gone to the wall, and they were top-class restaurants. I refer to Dods House, Dooley's and the old Camelia restaurant which was one of the long-established silver service restaurants in Australia. It had been in business for some 26 years. For the honourable member for Perth to come in here tonight and talk about the rorts and the frauds that have been going on in the restaurant industry when a couple of days ago he talked in this place about the tremendous job that the Government has done in terms of infrastructure for the America's Cup in Perth, is absolutely amazing.

While this Government has been pouring tens of millions of dollars into Perth to look after what some of its members would call a silver-tailed sport, it amazes me that it has let this sector of the hospitality industry decline. That is a very poor reflection indeed on the honourable member for Perth. Yes, 2,800 jobs have been created in the hospitality industry in recent months, but the restaurant industry in Australia has experienced a major decline in employment. Admittedly many people have gone out of the restaurant industry into the casino and hotel businesses. That is fair enough, but what will happen in the coming months and what effect that will have especially on the tourist industry never ceases to amaze me. It is surprising indeed that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) comes in here and trumpets his so-called achievements in terms of his capacity to be able to bring people into Australia when in fact he is destroying the basic infrastructure that he is trying to support. It is no good putting on America's Cups; it is no good putting on Expo 88s if we do not have the capacity, the infrastructure, to service those people who come to Australia.

The restaurant industry is an area on which we should concentrate because it has been one of the few growth industries in terms of employment that Australia has had. It is one of the few industries that has the capacity to continue to increase employment opportunities for the young people of today. I am amazed to hear the Government and the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) trumpeting also about the tremendous funds the Government has invested in Australia's education system. I give due credit to the Government; it has poured literally hundreds of thousands of dollars into providing secondary and tertiary education for the hospitality industry. I wonder what the young people involved at the moment in hospitality industry courses, who have their minds set on a career-a long-term career at that-in the hospitality industry think about these moves being made in the legislation we are debating tonight when they know that their very future is in jeopardy because of the Government's attitude.

As I say, there is nobody on this side of the House who is not prepared to go after those rorts in an industry such as this. But the mechanism exists. We should have gone after those rorts and not become virtually the only country in the world that does not allow legitimate entertainment expenses. That is a fact. Why did the Government not have a look at the voucher system that exists in the United States, or the means of claiming legitimate entertainment expenses that exists in Britain at the moment? These things just were not considered. This action is really the fraud of the whole operation. It is income generation for the Government to get itself out of a tight spot. It had the legitimate argument, it said, to go ahead and knock these so-called rorts on the head. It did more than knock the rorts on the head-it knocked a whole industry on the head and it destroyed the potential employment opportunities of many of the young people of Australia.

Tonight I will not go ahead and talk about the motor vehicle industry because I think that that has been well covered. We heard this morning of the Peugeot motor people who are trying to get back some of the import market. It is amazing that one of the biggest distributors of imported motor vehicles in Australia is on the verge of giving away its franchise on one of the most popular makes of imported cars. That, in its own right, is a surprising move. That distributor estimates that 9,000 jobs will be in jeopardy because of that move. We hear about employment in the local motor vehicle industry, but the imported motor vehicle industry in its own way also provides a tremendous number of jobs for Australians. There has been no mention of that from the Government benches; there has been no mention that we may not be able to by Mazda motor vehicles in Australia in the near future because the distributor is going out of business. Of course there are two reasons why the importation of those vehicles may be stopped. Admittedly the devaluation has something to do with it, but most importantly it is to do with the drop in business from the fleet market. So once again people will lose their jobs because of this measure. The imported motor vehicle industry caters to a very specialised market, as well.

The hour is late and I know another member wants to speak, but we heard today about airline employees who get tremendous perks in the way of travel arrangements. It is interesting to hear quotes from companies such as East-West Airlines Ltd, in regard to this tax. I agree there has been an agreement between the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the airlines that the airlines will pay this tax, but East-West Airlines is talking about having to pay half a million dollars to cover the tax. What will that do to services? I ask the honourable member for Perth: What happens if Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd gets in trouble with its network in Western Australia? That is very much on the cards. Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans Australia Airlines will be up for a bill of between $4m and $6m to cover their costs, and Qantas Airways Limited will be up for between $6m and $8m to cover its costs. Who will pay for that? You can bet your bottom dollar that the airlines will not pay for it; they will pass it on to the consumers of Australia. Once again we see the fraud of the Government's alleged cheap airline regime, because that sort of money will have to go into the cost of fares in Australia. That will not only affect business in Australia; it will also, in itself, affect the domestic tourism industry and, even more importantly, it will affect Australia's international tourism market once again.

The only people who I believe will benefit from this legislation and its 150-odd pages of explanatory memorandum are the accountants. That industry will do very well, but we have to make sure that we try to get rid of this legislation if we possibly can because literally hundreds of thousands of people, ordinary people in Australia, will be most adversely affected indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never heard so much prejudice and pure exaggeration from the Australian Labor Party as I have heard today in this debate on the fringe benefits legislation. This is a list of some of the organisations that will be affected by the Government's so-called positive steps to eliminate tax evasion and, to use another term that has been used frequently today, the rorting of the tax system: The Smith Family, the Salvation Army, the Sydney City Mission, the St Vincent De Paul Society, the Wesley Central Mission, the Autistic Association, the Spastic Centre, the St John of God Hospital and the New South Wales deaf and blind societies. These are the organisations the Government is getting at in relation to the rip-offs it has described in the House today-the charitable and hospitable organisations; those that depend on the donations of well-intentioned Australians to keep on providing their services. Their dedicated employees are often under-paid, or lowly paid, and work long hours because they believe in what they are doing. What about the Government's definition of the clergy? That brilliant and capable man, Brother Anthony Duncan, who runs the St John of God Hospital, is a member of the clergy, yes, but he is not doing religious duties as defined by the legislation passing through this House today.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the Government up to, hitting these people who look after the poor and the needy? No doubt they will be taxed on their tea and biscuits and on the low-priced lunches they have at the institutions. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) ought to be called the charity bandit rather than the bedroom bandit, as I think he was called by one of our members. It will cost the Central Wesley Mission $35,000 for the fringe benefits tax. It thought it had solved this problem at the Tax Summit, but the Government is going to go ahead and tax it anyway. All these charitable organisations are looking after the poor, the needy and the helpless. That is how good the Government's tax is. It ought to be thrown out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I would just like to take one minute to point out to the House that from figures provided to me by an expert who works with the shadow Treasurer it is interesting to note that in the three years that the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) has been Treasurer of Australia, personal and company tax receipts have risen by 43.1 per cent. He, therefore, is the highest taxing Treasurer in the history of Australia. He has beaten the record of the Whitlam Government, under which tax receipts rose by 38 per cent in three years. As of 30 June this year, this fiscal ferret will have on his record, which will go into the Guinness Book of Records, along with his record of being one of the greatest breachers of promise ever, a 43.1 per cent increase in personal and company tax receipts over the three years from 1 July 1983 to 30 June 1986. The honourable member might as well enjoy his time while he is in that office. He is Treasurer in a minority government. The majority of Australians do not want that government to remain in office, according to the latest public opinion poll. It is on borrowed time. The honourable member for Blaxland should not get up in this House and beam with the pride of a man who has ripped off the workers of Australia with tax increases of 43.1 per cent in the last 36 months. If he were an accountant, he would be in gaol behind bars.
