DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON AN AUSTRALIA CARD

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, I present the report of the Committee, which incorporates a dissenting report, together with the transcript of evidence and written replies received to questions asked by the Committee. Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask leave of this House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. By resolution of the House of Representatives and the Senate, a Joint Select Committee of eight members, representing each of the four main political parties, was established on 29 November 1985 to examine the Government's proposal for an Australia Card to combat tax evasion, social security fraud and illegal immigration. The Committee fulfilled this task within what has been a very tight time schedule. We have held public hearings in every State; we have taken 5,000 pages of oral and written evidence; and we have heard 168 witnesses and held 18 public hearings.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee believes that it has served an important function in encouraging a systematic and widespread debate about the related issues of privacy, civil liberties, prevention of tax and social welfare fraud, and the question of illegal immigration. In addressing those issues, the Committee was able to come to a series of unanimous recommendations which we believe will be of value to the Government, the Parliament and the Australian community at large. These recommendations are contained in chapter 2 of the report.

For the interest of honourable members and honourable senators, it is worth briefly listing those areas of agreed concern: The computerisation of births, deaths and marriages registers; the introduction of a data protection agency; the introduction of privacy legislation; the implementation of banking controls, recommended by the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union; the implementation of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure recommendations on illegal immigrants; the transfer of the responsibility for payments under education assistance schemes from the Department of Education to the Department of Social Security; and administrative reforms within the Department of Social Security relating to proof of identity procedures.

However, when the major issue of whether or not there should be an Australia Card was addressed, the Committee split in a 5:3 decision. A majority of the Committee-Senators Puplick and Haines, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) and I-favoured an upgraded tax file number system in preference to the Government's Australia Card proposal. The proposed high integrity tax file number would be used in a wide range of financial transactions and in the reporting of information to the Australian Taxation Office. The majority view point left open the question whether a card should be issued with the tax file number. A minority-Senator Aulich, the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) and the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby)-supported a modified version of the Australia Card proposal. The main modifications in the minority report were recommendations supporting the inclusion of a photograph on the card--

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a range of views on this side!

—There is indeed a range of responses from the Government side to that proposal-and the limitation of its use to four government agencies: The Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Social Security, the Health Insurance Commission and, on a more limited basis, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I look forward to the reports of the Caucus debates on these recommendations. Thus the report contains unanimous recommendations, a majority viewpoint, a minority dissenting viewpoint and a personal addendum by Senator Puplick.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card arose out of Opposition concern about the Government's proposal and our declared position to oppose the granting of funds until the Government proved its case. The Australian Democrats shared our concern and, in the face of this united opposition, the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) was forced to back down and accept an inquiry. The report vindicates the stand taken by the Opposition against the hurried implementation of an ill-considered identity card plan. Not one member of the Committee supports the Government's proposal. The majority of the Committee-made up of two Liberals, Senator Puplick and me; one member of the National Party, the honourable member for Richmond; one member of the Australian Labor Party, the honourable member for Aston; and one member of the Australian Democrats, Senator Haines; in other words, representatives of all parties-does not believe that the Government's proposal will achieve its stated objectives. That is, the Government's ID card proposal fails properly to address the major problems of tax evasion, welfare fraud and the identification of illegal immigrants. While the majority of the Committee disagrees with the Government, indeed, so does the minority. It believes that the card must have a photograph-a proposal clearly rejected by the Government last year--

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—Rubbish? We are talking about the Government's proposal, which rejected a photograph. In other words, no member of the Committee supports the Government's proposal.
—Hear, hear!

—I thank the honourable member for Hindmarsh for the support from the Government benches. Let me go to the heart of the decision of the majority of the Committee. We believe that there are much cheaper and more effective ways of overcoming tax evasion than the proposed ID card, and such alternatives do not have all the civil liberties problems associated with an ID card.

SPEECH.PARA: The primary function of the ID card is to allow a better matching of information regarding financial transactions, interest earned, et cetera with the Australian Taxation Office files. The Government's proposal was never intended to monitor the black or cash economy, where the big tax evasion occurs. However, a better matching system, as proposed by the majority, may assist in identifying some of the so-called hidden money in bank accounts and elsewhere. The majority believes that its proposal to upgrade the integrity of the tax file number to that of the proposed Australia Card will enable the better matching of the information held by the Australian Taxation Office and the raw data within the financial sector. I put the proposal to officers of the Australian Taxation Office when they came before us. Their response was in the following terms:

If we followed the Australia Card identification requirements before allocating tax file numbers and purified existing records on that basis, we would expect to achieve similar revenue gains to those under the Australia Card option, without a photograph, with a similar staff and equipment costs.

Let me give one example of the advantages of increasing the ability of the Taxation Office to match information it has on file with that which is provided to it under current laws by banks and others. In the Taxation Office's view, one of the largest areas of revenue evaded arises because of the Taxation Office's inability to match income returns with information provided by banks. According to the Australian Taxation Office, at the moment only 18 to 20 per cent of the total interest paid in Australia is reported to it by banks and the Taxation Office is able to match only about half of those transactions. The Taxation Office believes that an improved capacity to match information, such as the majority has proposed, would enable it to match up to 75 per cent of dividends and interest, resulting in an increase in revenue collection of around $255m a year.

A point I make in passing is that the whole of the Committee believes that the Australian Taxation Office has available to it powers and information which are not fully utilised, and that there are alternative measures which can also make substantial inroads into tax evasion. The Government has a heavy responsibility to ensure that immediate action is taken to upgrade the administration of the Australian Taxation Office and, according to the majority of the Committee, it should do so when it implements the action proposed by the majority to upgrade the use of and the integrity of tax file numbers.

One of the other aims of the Government was to act against social security fraud, yet we discover that the Government's proposal would result in no net gain from the introduction of the Australia Card. I repeat: The Australia Card would not result in any savings in the area of social security. The Government's submission also claims that one of the largest gains to revenue through the introduction of the Australia Card is in the area of the identification of illegal immigrants. Yet the whole Committee stated, as to the revenue of some $1,000m expected by the Government in this area-I quote from paragraph 1.56 of the report:

. . . it became clear that the estimates for illegal immigrants were based on guesswork, the percentage of illegal immigrants who worked was based on guesswork, the percentage of visitors who worked illegally came from a departmental study based on guesswork. The discount factor could not be defended and the overall benefits from 1987-88 to 1991-92 was the result of `crystal ball gazing'. In the light of these statements the Committee-
I repeat, this is the whole of the Committee-
is unable to place any confidence in the proposed revenue gains under this use.

Those are the words from the report. The whole of the Committee stated that it was unable to place any confidence in the proposed revenue gains-some $1,000m relied on by the Government-under this use; namely, to assist in overcoming problems relating to illegal immigrants. In the area of social security the Committee has established that the Government's identity card proposal will result in no net gain to government. In the area of illegal immigrants, the Committee has no confidence in the Government's revenue estimates. Finally, in the area of tax evasion, the Taxation Office agrees that the majority proposal for the extended use of a high integrity tax file number would raise the same revenue as the Australia Card proposal put forward by the Government.

The minority report was made available to the rest of the Committee only at 5 p.m. tonight. In it, we read that the minority has attacked the majority proposal without, of course, giving the majority an opportunity to review the minority's proposal. This sort of underhand behaviour does not give one much confidence in the contents of the minority report. I shall therefore deal briefly with the minority's criticism of the majority report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hey, what about the agreement?
—We had an agreement; you have been going for 15 minutes.

—I know that those honourable members opposite do not want us to deal with this, and it was kept from us so that we could not deal with it. If honourable members in the Government ranks were to stop arguing amongst themselves, we would be able to get through this debate much faster. What is more, if the Government had been a little more organised we could have been debating this report at 6 p.m., instead of its rushing into this House legislation that it should have rushed in three days ago.
—Get on with your speech, you moron.
—Order!
—He cannot help himself. The first of the objections of the minority to the majority proposal that I want to refer to is the point made in paragraph 4 of the minority report, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The integrity of the tax file number system is not capable of being upgraded to the standard of the Australia Card, with or without a photograph. There will be less rigorous checks on the issue of a tax file number and, accordingly, it will be easier to use such a number to defraud the revenue.
The majority in its report states quite clearly:
That the integrity of the tax file number be upgraded to that of the proposed Australia Card number based on the following premises . . .
Included in those premises is the following requirement:
. . . persons who do not currently possess a tax file number verify their identity to the same level of integrity as proposed under the Australia Card . . .

In other words, the same rules would apply. Those who have a continuous record tax exceeding five years initially would not have to make an application for a number under this scheme, because they have been recognised by the Taxation Office for over five years. So in our proposal we are trying to assist in the early implementation of this program. Initially, those taxpayers would not have to go through that process. Of course, over time they will be subject to audit and verification of the same standard as that required by the Government for the issue of the Australia Card. There is no difference. Secondly, the minority report states:

The fact that no card will be issued (and hence the tax file notice issued will have no security features) means it will be relatively simple to fake the document, or use stolen or lost tax file numbers.
The recommendation of the majority of the Committee is as follows:

We accept that the ATO will need to provide formal notification to each individual of their registered tax file number. This can be done in a variety of ways, however, it may be most convenient for this notice to be provided annually when the ATO issues taxpayers with their notice of assessment.

The form of notification requires further investigation. We accept that that is what we say. We expect work to be done on the most appropriate form of identification of the number. Again, the criticism of the minority is totally unfounded. The minority report says further:

The proposed administrative arrangements whereby the Department of Social Security . . . or its nominated agents interview applicants, yet Australian Taxation Office . . . issues the numbers, is cumbersome and inefficient.

The minority report says the public will be considerably inconvenienced and expected to travel large distances for interviews with the Department of Social Security with regard to the issue of numbers because, as the minority report says, the DSS has only 204 branch offices whereas Medicare has 356. Again, I refer to the recommendation of the majority, which states quite clearly:
. . . the interview process for verifying identity be conducted by the Department of Social Security or nominated agents . . .

We specifically put that point in because we were aware that in a number of areas, specifically in country areas, there are not that many offices of the Department of Social Security. So we are suggesting that other offices do the work for the Department of Social Security.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Medicare?
—There is no reason why Medicare could not do it in those cases.
—You don't like Medicare, do you?
—You are quite right.
—It is an obsession.

—The Minister is quite right; we do not like his Medicare proposal. We believe that he has provided incentives for enormous fraud and overservicing, and we believe that he has cost the taxpayer an enormous amount of money through his maladministration of the Medicare program.
—Order! I suggest that the Minister cease interjecting and that the honourable member for Barker return to the subject.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am sorry that I responded to the interjections of the Minister for Health.
—Don't be provoked.
—I will try not to be provoked. The next point of criticism by the minority of the majority is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The establishment and operating costs of the tax file number registry will actually be far higher than estimated in the majority report.

No explanation is given for that statement. The Australian Taxation Office says that it can implement the proposal for the same cost; yet the minority report says: `Oh, no, the Taxation Office is wrong'. The minority report goes on to say:
The proposal for one tax file number registry and another independent registry for Medicare, represents a costly duplication of time, effort and money.

Do we not have two registries now? The criticism is just farcical. Let me finish up with the best criticism of all from the minority. Let me read it to honourable members. This is supposed to be a criticism. The last point of criticism in the minority report is as follows:

The ATO revenue gains from the tax file proposal over ten years will compare most favourably with Government estimates of $3.115b for the Australia Card proposal (without photo), or at a very conservative minimum, $4.074b with photo . . .
In other words, the minority report ends up by saying that our proposal is as good as the Australia Card proposal. That is some criticism! I just cannot believe it.

I return to the majority report. It highlights the fact that the Government's proposal is full of holes, ill-conceived and ill-considered. It is yet another example of the maladministration by the Minister for Health of his portfolio. It is really quite extraordinary that the Government should propose that the Minister for Health be put in charge of holding secure personal information which is garnered for the purposes of an ID card. How on earth could it make such a suggestion? How could we believe that he could keep such information confidential when the records that he has kept of Medicare information, which he supposedly promised to keep confidential, appears on the front page of newspapers? It is unbelievable. We have no confidence in the Minister and the majority of the Committee has no confidence in the Government's ID card proposal, put forward by the Minister for Health.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-At the outset I wish to draw the attention of members, senators and the community to the fact that the total report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card is in excess of 400 pages. However, one does not have to read 400 pages, one only has to read the content of the dissenting report by Senator Terry Aulich, my colleague Mr John Brumby and myself because that report provides a proposal of compelling logic. Not only does it provide a proposal of compelling logic, but also it provides absolutely devastating arguments against the majority report. It not only demolishes the content of the majority report, but also it unquestionably demolishes its credibility. I do not wish to go into the details of the content; that will be apparent to all those people who will and should take advantage of the opportunity to read it. I want to make a few general observations about some background issues to the dissenting report and the majority report itself.

SPEECH.PARA: The minority report, or the dissenting report, has been motivated by a serious concern on the part of its signatories that the opportunity provided by the Australia Card proposal to make major inroads into tax evasion and social security fraud may be lost if the Government fails to adopt the system which will maximise the potential revenue advantages and, at the same time be characterised by the highest possible level of integrity. I take issue with the majority conclusions and recommendations on the following grounds: First, the majority has failed to appreciate the dimensions and the significance of tax evasion and social security fraud in the community and the contribution made to those abuses of the system by inadequate identification procedures. Secondly, the majority proposals are an inadequate response to the measures and approaches which are both necessary and desirable to confront these abuses most effectively. Third, the adoption of the majority proposals in the form in which they have been presented would represent a serious failure to take full advantage of the positive and significant benefits which can flow from this major initiative.

The Australian Taxation Office was of the view that there was no other single action that would produce the revenue gains of the magnitude estimated as a result of the proposed Australia Card program. I accept that the complex and integrated nature of modern society necessarily requires some diminution in the citizen's right to privacy in order to ensure that all citizens make their rightful contribution to public finances and that no citizen draws more than his just entitlement. This clearly involves a trade-off and the making of subjective judgments. However, I am concerned about an apparent double standard which seems to accept the legitimacy of the gross and serious invasion of the privacy of disadvantaged individuals to prove their eligibility for benefits, but is reluctant to apply similar standards or requirements to the more affluent members of the community in order to ensure that they meet their obligations.

I fail to see the sense in maintaining a separate Medicare number, as proposed in the majority recommendations, but I appreciate that the deficiencies of the majority proposal make it difficult or impossible to utilise the tax file numbers for Medicare purposes. I believe that maintaining separate and distinct numbers in this way-one for Medicare purposes and the other for other defined purposes-is unnecessarily confusing and expensive and involves avoidable duplication.

The evidence from the polls and the surveys indicates a strong community support for the Australia Card proposal and the inclusion of a photograph on the card. I believe that because the Australia Card proposal is a significant new national initiative, the public is entitled to have its wishes recognised and responded to. Significant additional net revenue benefits would also result from the inclusion of a photograph on the card. I am concerned that this opportunity to strengthen the revenue base of the Commonwealth may be squandered if a `Mickey Mouse' system of the kind proposed in the majority report is adopted because it will fail to achieve two fundamental objectives: First, the establishment of a system of the highest possible integrity; and secondly, the maximisation of the potential revenue benefits.

I emphasise that the Australia Card proposal will achieve its identified major revenue benefits without increasing either the range or rates of taxation. It will simply help to ensure that all taxpayers meet their legal obligations to public revenue. Also, it will achieve its goals without reducing either the range or the rates of welfare benefits. Again, it will simply help to ensure that noone draws from the system more than his just entitlements. I certainly do not claim that the total package proposed in the dissenting report will eliminate all tax evasion, social security fraud, illegal immigration or organised crime. To do so would be quite absurd. However, I do assert that the adoption of the dissenting recommendations would represent the most important and effective single assault on these abuses which have ever been undertaken in Australia. I believe that rather than threaten or diminish civil liberties and offend privacy considerations, adoption of the total package will positively enhance them. I also emphasise that in the sum total of human welfare, civil liberties are but one component. If it were asserted, incorrectly I believe, that the right to privacy might be at risk with the Australia Card proposal, I would confidently state in answer that on balance human welfare would be enhanced by it. I commend the dissenting report to honourable members, senators and the community at large. I hope that it encourages the Government in the initiatives that it and the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) have already taken in connection with this matter. I hope the Government will proceed and introduce a system which will be of lasting benefit to all Australians and which will introduce a greater degree of equity than has existed hitherto.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Let me say at the outset that I regret that the opportunity for members to speak to the report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card has been restricted because of the incompetence of this Government in its legislative program and its determination to bring the debate on this very important matter which is of great significance to the structure of Australia into the Parliament at this hour of night. Let me also say that I take great exception to the imputations made by the Chairman of the Committee when he was delivering his report in another place earlier tonight. He questioned the integrity of the majority of members of this Committee who brought down a recommendation which happened to be contrary to the Government's view. He suggested that there was collusion or some other form of co-operation to thwart the Government's program. All five members of this Committee, who have contributed to the majority report, are people of integrity who have considered this issue on its merits. They have considered the evidence provided objectively and they have brought down a report without collusion and with the best interests of the Australian people at heart. The three members of this Committee who have brought in a minority report, and who are all members of the Australian Labor Party, could be accused of simply towing the party line and not having the character or conviction to express their opinions for fear of party retribution. Let me congratulate the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) who had the courage of his convictions and was prepared to join with other committee members to bring down the report designed to achieve solutions to the problems that exist in the three areas we have considered.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a general acknowledgment in Australian society that there are problems within the income tax system and the social security system in terms of illegal immigrants and, of course, organised crime. It concerns me that the proposal brought into this place by the Government is really one of sophistry. It has suggested that the solution to the problems of income tax evasion, social security fraud and illegal immigrants can be addressed by a national identification system. At no time-and certainly at no time did the majority of the members of the Committee take such a view-have we been convinced by the arguments or the evidence tabled by the Government or the Health Insurance Commission. The problem is that the ID system does not address specifically the problems of social security, income tax and immigration. It would be far preferable for the Government to admit that the problems of those systems could be addressed independently rather than to suggest the establishment of a bureaucratic system.

It is appropriate to devote some time to considering the social security system. My colleague the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) addressed at considerable length-and rightly so-the minority report. As he said, the report of the majority of this Committee was made available over a week ago and the minority report was not available until about 5 p.m. this evening. Quite frankly, it is appropriate to say that the logic of that report is questionable and that its accuracy is doubtful. It is really appropriate to question some of the statements made in that minority report.

It is also appropriate to address the question of social security overpayment and fraud. Although the honourable member for Aston has had the courage of his convictions, unfortunately the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) has not been prepared to make a statement about his attitude and the attitude of the Department of Social Security to the use of the Australia Card in addressing overpayments and fraud. In evidence to this Committee, senior officers of the Department of Social Security said that they did not regard the Australia Card proposal brought forward by the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) as a sound document and would not rely upon it for identification purposes. On that basis, how could any member of the Committee agree with the proposition put forward by the minority that the Australia Card proposal will be of benefit in addressing social security fraud and overpayment?

The public support for this proposal is based on the premise that the Australia Card proposal will address and solve the problems of fraud and overpayment in social security. That cannot be demonstrated, has not been demonstrated, is not accepted by the Minister, is not accepted by the Department and is certainly not accepted by the majority of members of the Committee. The members of that Committee who are of that opinion come from all parties. They come from the Liberal Party; they come from the Australian Labor Party; they come from the Australian Democrats; and I come from the National Party. We accept that proposition. The only people who will not accept that proposition are three members of the Australian Labor Party who have brought in a minority report which I will deal with at a later time and which quite frankly does not address the facts that have been presented to the Committee at great length by people of considerable expertise.

The proposal for the Australia Card originated during the course of the Tax Summit, the ill-starred fiasco that took place in this chamber some time in 1985. From then the Government proposed a course of action. Because of the ability of the Opposition in this place and the other place to convince it of the errors of its ways, we were able to have a Committee set up to investigate that proposal. That Committee was established before Christmas 1985. The Government's submission to that Committee was not available until 28 February 1986. It was a submission of some 1,000 pages. That is unquestionably prima facie evidence that the Government did not in fact know what it proposed to do with the Australia Card proposal and set about justifying its proposal and developing its proposed uses after in fact it had been forced into a committee of inquiry by the Parliament of Australia. I believe that the Minister stands condemned for that course of action because, quite frankly, embarking on a proposal that would cost many hundreds of millions of dollars without first knowing exactly how it would be used and its effectiveness is bordering on the irresponsible.
I have mentioned that the report of the minority is of doubtful accuracy. I would like to refer to paragraph 1 of the overview of that report. I quote quite briefly from that paragraph. It states:
It is our firm belief-
the view of the minority of three members of the Labor Party-
that the Australia Card proposal is an effective, innovative approach to the problems of tax evasion, social security fraud . . .

As I said previously, the Department of Social Security does not regard the Australia Card proposal as a sound document and will not rely upon it for identification purposes. Further, in the evidence given to the Committee by the Department of Social Security the Department said that the revenue benefits would be neutral-the cost of implementing the proposal for the Department would be matched by the benefits to flow from it. How can the three Labor members who brought in a minority report possibly claim that the Australia Card proposal is going to be of significance in reducing social security fraud and overpayment?

The three Labor members have also suggested that the Australia Card will be of benefit to the Department of Social Security in checking the income status of recipients. That, quite frankly, is a direct and, I say, deliberate misrepresentation because the Department of Social Security, in giving evidence to the Committee on a number of occasions, said that the financial information available to it through the Australia Card proposal, with or without a photograph, would not be sufficiently current for it to be of any use to the Department in determining the income of beneficiaries of the Department of Social Security. Let me take one moment to explain that. Income is earned on a weekly basis. The income returns available through the Government's Australia Card proposal would be at best available on an annual basis. Payments made by the Department of Social Security are made on a fortnightly basis. How can the Australia Card proposal possibly be used to determine the income status of clients of the Department of Social Security when the information is at any one time up to a year out of date? This is a most spurious argument-an argument deliberately designed to mislead the Parliament.

I believe it would be appropriate for this matter to be brought on for a complete and full debate in this Parliament because it is a matter of great concern and great interest to the Australian people. It is not appropriate to bring this matter on at a late hour of the day after, as I have said, this Government's legislative incompetence and desire to guillotine and gag debate on important tax legislation and matters affecting the High Court of Australia. This matter has been brought on after 11 o'clock at night. It is then suggested that members of the Committee who are seeking to explain their position and to put the facts before the Australian people should wind up debate on this matter. In deference to my colleague the honourable member for Aston, who I am sure wants to speak on behalf of the majority view, I will curtail my remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I happen to be a member of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card and Chairman of the House of Representatives Committee on Publications. At this stage I will be making some comments on the Australia Card and not on the Publications Committee's report. Firstly, I would like to place on the record my appreciation and, I know, the appreciation of all members of the Committee of the enormous contribution made by the secretariat of the Committee during our deliberations and in the preparation of the report. As most Committee members would know, the deadline has been extremely tight the past few weeks and the work load has been exceedingly heavy. On many occasions the secretariat staff worked right through weekends and on at least three occasions right through the night until 6 or 7 o'clock in the morning. I place on record my appreciation to the Committee secretary Tim Dodson and to research officers, Judy Ryan and, in recent times, Brett Levy. I also thank the stenographers Rachel Colombo, Janice Paull and many others who made a tremendous contribution and put in an enormous amount of work in the last week.

SPEECH.PARA: Also I make clear for the benefit of honourable members that within this report there are two reports; there is a majority report, basically supported by Opposition members and a dissenting report, produced by Senator Aulich, myself and my colleague, the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). I want to make clear a number of points that we made in our dissenting report. We said that we are firmly convinced that the recommendations we have made for the use of an Australia Card with photograph should apply in very restricted areas to the Department of Social Security, the Australian Taxation Office and Medicare. We have recommended that it apply to those three users only. We believe that that is an excellent proposal that we have put before the Government. We believe it promises the potential of massive revenue gains-not tin pot, half baked revenue gains as would occur if the tax file proposal were implemented-in the order of $8 billion plus.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—It would mean $8 billion plus over ten years. In ordinary money terms-in the terms that people can understand-that means tax cuts of $8 a fortnight for every wage and salary earner in Australia each year for each of the next ten years. That is what we are talking about when we talk about this card. We have said in our report that we do not accept the tax file number proposal. We do not really believe that all those members of the Committee who did propose that were genuine in their opposition to the Australia Card. There has been a fair amount of political skulduggery in this matter. Some honourable members have adopted positions simply on the basis of party affiliations.

SPEECH.PARA: In coming to a conclusion in this report it has always been our view that what we ought to be recommending is a proposal which offers the greatest revenue benefits to the Australian people at minimum inconvenience and with minimum possible threat to civil liberties. Our three criteria are revenue benefits, in other words, catching the tax cheats, convenience to the public, because the public matter-I see that Senator Puplick is in the chamber and he would agree with that-and the question of civil liberties.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have to be joking.

—I want to go through our dissenting proposal. I just make that clear again for some honourable members. We have not gone the whole way with the Government. We have not said that the Australia Card could be used for every single government department. We have recommended that its use be strictly controlled and confined to the Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Social Security and Medicare. We have recommended that no other departments use that card; that no other departments have access to it. For the benefit of the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) who often has difficulty getting things into his skull, we have also recommended a data protection agency which will not just have coverage over the public sector data bases. We have said that in three years' time it ought also to be able to monitor private sector data bases. We have said that for a start. Let us be clear about it in order to understand that. We have recommended the establishment of a data protection agency able to monitor public sector data bases and eventually able to monitor private sector data bases.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us turn to the second question about civil liberties. We have recommended that the Australian Law Reform Commission recommendations on privacy information legislation be implemented. That was a unanimous recommendation of the Committee. We have gone one further step in our dissenting report. We have said in respect of the three agencies which can use the Australia Card-Tax, Social Security and Medicare-that secrecy provisions which currently apply to the Australian Taxation Office also should apply to the remaining two agencies. The only criticism-I have to say this in all fairness and honesty-that we got as members of the Committee from people concerned about this proposal was in regard to people's concern that the Australia Card could become a national identifier and that they would have to produce it in a pub to buy a bottle of beer, on a tram or, if requested, by a member of the police force. Under no circumstances can it ever be said that as a result of what we have recommended that situation could ever eventuate. We have cut any possibility of that off at the knees. It simply cannot eventuate.

We have identified three departments-Taxation, Social Security and Medicare. We have recommended the establishment of a data protection agency, privacy legislation and secrecy provisions. To suggest that there is any possible infringement of people's liberties or their personal freedom as a result of the possible implementation of recommendations for this Australia Card is absolute nonsense. We will see in the next few weeks when credible lawyers and others with concerns for civil liberties in the community analyse this report that they will come to the conclusion, as we do in our dissenting report, that if these things are implemented the cause of civil liberties and personal freedom in Australia will not be put back but in fact will be advanced many years. That is the fact of the matter in regard to this report.

We are on a tight time constraint. Therefore, I want to conclude by repeating those three issues which I believe are fundamental. There is the question of revenue, the question of convenience to the public and the question of civil liberties. The revenue gains-they are conservative in regard to this proposal-will be more than $8 billion over 10 years. That is $8 billion from people who presently are avoiding their taxation responsibility for government programs or for cutting the taxes of ordinary wage and salary earners who I know are very much at the forefront for the thoughts of the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent). That is what the revenue will do. In terms of public convenience there will be 356 Medicare and Health Insurance Commission offices around Australia for interviewing and distributing Australia Cards. No one will be disadvantaged as a result of needing an Australia Card. No one will have to travel a long distance. Just as importantly, people in the private sector will not have large compliance costs as they would under the tax file number system.

I conclude by saying that the tax file proposal, as advocated by the majority of members on the Committee, is a politically motivated proposal. It is the product of partisan people who have not put the interests of Australians at the forefront. It is a Mickey Mouse proposal and it will not work. Those honourable members know it. Let me make it quite clear about our proposal for an Australia Card with photograph. There has been no other proposal before the Government in the last decade, nor is there likely to be such a proposal in the next two decades, which offers such magnificent revenue benefits to the Commonwealth of Australia, benefits that can be distributed to ordinary wage and salary earners at such little cost to people in terms of convenience and civil liberties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This report is the result of some quite extensive work. In the last six months the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card has met in almost every capital city and has had numerous public hearings. As has been mentioned before, the report is over 400 pages long and the transcripts of evidence amount, I think, to some 5,000 pages. Therefore, I think it is not a report that anyone will take lightly. It is probably the most extensive study done on this sort of issue in Australia. Certainly, I think it will become recognised as one of some value. Obviously the extent of the report has meant that there has had to be some cramping at the end because of the pressure to finalise the report in order to present it to Parliament in time. Unfortunately that has resulted in some delay and our being here late tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: In talking to the report I would like to make a few points. Firstly, I wrote a paper some 12 months ago in which I examined the propositions in favour of identity cards. At that time in my paper I put forward the proposition that there were viable alternatives to identity cards. One of these alternatives was, in fact, the extension of the tax file system. Over the period in which I have been involved in examining this issue, I have become, on the basis of all the evidence presented to me, more and more firm in my mind that the tax file system is in fact a viable option. That has been confirmed by evidence given to us by the Australian Taxation Office in March this year. It was reaffirmed at our latest meeting last Monday.

When the Committee was in the final stages of making a decision, apart from the fact that I had resolved in my mind at that time the correct way to go, I had to weigh up the option of being part of a majority report which encompassed the views of all Opposition members or of voting with my Government colleagues. I found that I had to follow my commitment over that period. I am sure that my colleagues recognise that that has been part of my considerations. Nevertheless, the fact that I supported the tax file system-there has been a long history of my support for that matter-shows that there is an alternative that has had a lengthy period of examination. I pick up the point of the members who wrote the dissenting report and who have talked about a tin pot scheme or the Mickey Mouse scheme. It is nonsense to suggest that the extension of the tax file system has not had lengthy examination and is not a viable system. In fact, that option has been examined not just by me but in many other reports. The Australian Taxation Office has confirmed the fact that it is a system which can work and from which it can achieve the same savings as have been put forward by the Government's option. So it is nonsense for people to try to ridicule it.

I will concentrate my remarks on the minority report because there are a number of points in it that I want to raise. The points made in the section regarding the integrity of the tax file number proposal do not stand up to examination. The report states that the file number system will not have the same integrity. In reality, if one reads the recommendations in relation to the tax file number proposal, one will find that we make that very point. In fact, it will have the integrity of the Australia Card proposition. We have gone further than that. For the first time we have laid down a process by which that integrity can be obtained. That is not contained in either the Government's proposition or the minority report.

I refer to a couple of other points regarding the cost of tax file numbers. One of the major areas in which the minority report and, I believe, the Government report fail, is that they have not concentrated on the main areas-that is, the problems of tax evasion and how one will achieve the raising of that money. In my view there is also another problem. There is an assumption that Medicare has experience in this area of issuing identity cards. That is false. It does not exist. Medicare does not have that experience. It does not have the qualifications which it is claimed that it has. One of the major reasons why we went to the Department of Social Security is that at least Social Security, in its involvement with the community when people make application to it for pensions, has had tremendous experience in identifying people, getting them to make applications and dealing with people. This is not something that Medicare has ever done. So I do not accept that proposition. I think our evidence will quite clearly show that our proposition will be far more extensive than the Government's proposition.

Another aspect I want to raise in relation to the minority report is the number of points it makes in relation to the integrity of the members who supported the majority report. I certainly take some exception to the point that is made that the majority report is primarily a political decision aimed at denying the Government significant revenues and a chance to implement a system which is manifestly popular in the electorate at large.

TALK.START.PARA: —We didn't mean you, John.

—All right. I make the point, as I said earlier, that my decision is not a political decision. It is not a decision which was made to deny the Government revenue. It is one to which I have given great thought. I would not have thought that it is necessarily a position of any government to do things that are necessarily popular in the community. There are a number of things that are popular in the community which I would certainly not support on any occasion-be it the ID card or the reintro- duction of hanging, which is manifestly popular in the community. I do not see that as being any reason to support it. A paragraph of the minority report states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the majority report has been cobbled together and is demonstrably lacking in the thought and consideration needed to build a workable system to combat tax evasion . . .

I take exception to that as I was a participant in the writing of the majority report. I take some credit for writing a significant number of those recommendations. The concept behind the extension of the tax file number system has been in place for many months. A lot of thought has gone into it. I must say that the minority report was written in the last 1 1/2 days. I also say in terms of those points that, when careful consideration is given to the report, people will find that the minority report is substantially lacking in a number of areas.

I raise a number of other points to show how the minority report is lacking in depth. One Department that has been excluded from access to the proposed new Australia Card is the Department of Veterans' Affairs. It is a Department which has a very significant amount of pension payments. It has been excluded from it. We will find that there will be two different sorts of pensions. There will be those people who go through Social Security and receive a pension. They will be forced to produce ID cards. On this basis, veterans and widows of veterans will be treated differently. I am not saying that either group is dishonest. But there is no case to suggest that a group of people should be treated differently.

A point was made concerning the extension of the secrecy provision. The honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), who spoke before me, pointed out that that was an example for how they had gone beyond us-they had extended the secrecy provision to other departments. They have done so only because they had to include other departments in their proposition. We went to the Tax Office to implement and maintain the system because it has a system of secrecy. There is no need for us to extend it to anybody else. We kept it with the Department which already has those provisions.

I now refer to the reference in the minority report to $8 billion and the saving of $8 for each individual. As I said to my colleagues when I read that figure, what those members have done is to take the Tax Office figures and doubled them. They then multiplied by two and said: `That gives us $8 billion and that is $8 each'. I say that facetiously because I know where they obtained their figures. They have taken up a number of points that the Tax Office has made. The Tax Office indicated that it had underestimated its figures. Nobody disputes that. We accept that as well. It also indicated that there are at least two areas that it did not take into account. One area, of course, was the Tax Office being able to identify people who had not paid tax and therefore owed back taxes and they would recoup money in that way. We did not include that in our estimates because it is a common fact that exists. So the assumption in the minority report is that all of a sudden, because they added that figure to theirs, it makes their figures look better and they will get more money. It is simply not a true test. We have accepted that evidence. We have accepted that those facts exist. But we have not quantified it in our report. But if the $8 billion is the correct figure, it applies to every case, whether it be the majority view or the minority view. So there is no additional benefit.

As I said, when people examine the reports they will find that the majority report contains 150 pages and unanimous recommendations, while there are only 40 pages in the minority report, and I am sure that the majority of the people who assess the reports will say that the majority report was correct.
Friday, 9 May 1986

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Light Aircraft: Unauthorised Maintenance-Duties of Elected Representatives

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Dr Blewett) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Parliament has debated at length the problems of road safety. Today the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) made further references to his road transport legislation, which has a safety component. Safety in the air is a matter of great importance, and whereas equipment failure on the highway need not result in any more than an interruption to one's journey until a tow truck arrives, most equipment failures in the sky result in major damage and/or human casualties. Consequently, the Department of Aviation has strict rules which restrict the maintenance and repair of all aircraft to Government licensed engineers. It is an offence to conduct repairs upon an aeroplane without a proper licence to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: However, due often to commercial pressures, charter operators of light aircraft, particularly those operating to remote airstrips, can be tempted to undertake certain unauthorised maintenance outside the gaze of authority. Even some minor repairs can be dangerous, but major repairs put aircraft, pilot and passengers at substantial risk. I have been involved in the industry as a private pilot for many years, and support completely the tough stand taken by the Department of Aviation to maintain this policy. Operators have some rights over their own lives, but not over their innocent, fare-paying passengers.

I have recently received reports of a charter operator in Carnarvon in north-west Australia who has blatantly undertaken major repair work upon his aeroplanes, and to the best of my knowledge may still do so. The work I refer to includes the removal and replacement of constant speed propellers and removal, adjustment and replacement of the inflight altitude trim adjustment mechanism. The undertaking of this work by untrained operators could, in the case of the propellers, result in the loss of a propeller in flight, or failure or malfunction of the constant speed adjustment with resultant engine failure. Failure of the trim gear as a result of this unauthorised removal could make the aircraft almost unmanageable, particularly during take-off and landing, resulting in a crash. Some years ago the operator-pilot referred to severely damaged a fast light twin which he had hired from me because he attempted a landing on a short landing strip which was totally unsuited to the aircraft concerned. The operator concerned is Paggi Aviation of Carnarvon, and I believe the Department of Aviation has been made aware of these offences.

I also believe the Department has had difficulty gaining hard evidence from witnesses. Mr Paggi is a vindictive man, who has previously demonstrated a tendency to violence. Consequently few people would be prepared to give public evidence against him. I have spoken to a qualified witness of one of the activities to which I have referred and have asked the Department to investigate.

As I am aware of the difficulties facing the Department, I see no alternative but to publicly warn members of the Australian community as to the level of risk they take in flying in Mr Paggi's aircraft. I am aware he has received Government contracts, and no doubt government and private employees are being carried in his aircraft as the result of their employers' arrangements. Workers compensation is little compensation for the loss of a loved one when it can be avoided. I have not taken this matter lightly, and my advice has come from more than one authentic source. From the evidence I have heard, I have no doubt that the unauthorised work I mention was done by Mr Paggi. There is no excuse, and the opportunity still exists for Mr Paggi to do this work on remote station airstrips if he so desires. If the Government cannot protect the public, the public must protect itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe, as a member of this Parliament that it is my inalienable and indisputable responsibility, obligation and privilege to represent to the best of my ability, with integrity and dignity and without fear or favour the people who live within my electorate of Casey. I have been elected to serve the best interests of my constituents and I have no intention of betraying this trust. To do so would be a gross and inexcusable dereliction of my duty. I may have neglected to do other things in my 48 years, but I have never neglected to do my duty. Part of that duty includes being aware of and sensitive to any matters which may, now or in the future, jeopardise the well-being of my constituents. It also includes an obligation to inform my constituents about such matters and alert them to the possible or probable implications and repercussions that may apply to them personally or to the community as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: If I must take certain risks-including leaving myself open to verbal attacks, abuse or misrepresentations by my political opponents-to ensure the safety, security and welfare of those who may be depending on me to represent their views or safeguard their interests, or to whom I am responsible and answerable for my actions, those risks must be taken, and I am prepared to take them. I believe in the simple wisdom of the well-known proverb: `It is better to be safe than sorry'. A prudent, careful and vigilant person, having noted dark clouds gathering on the horizon, is unlikely to venture forth into the expected storm without taking an umbrella. To do so would be to reflect a lack of caution and common sense.

Similarly, I am not prepared to ignore the warning signs that this Government is possibly preparing to launch another attack against one of the most vulnerable and neglected sections of our community-our senior citizens-without endeavouring in some way to protect them. To do so would be inexcusable, unjustifiable and unforgivable. I would much rather have another member attack me for disclosing a potential threat to my constituents than leave myself open to attack from my constituents for having failed to do so. If exposing the Achilles heels and devious doings of this Government means I am to be continually subjected to baseless and biased criticism in this House, in the local Press in my electorate, and in any other forum my opponents may deem applicable, so be it. My shoulders are broad.

In fact, I believe the disparaging remarks levelled at me during the adjournment debate last night by the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb), who unfortunately is not with us tonight, do not arise because of any personal animosity, or because my actions in informing certain people within my electorate of a possible threat to their entitlements as pensioners were ill-founded or ill-advised or carried out in an improper manner. I believe he felt obliged to attack me because I am carrying out my duties in an effective manner, and this is causing him some concern. In future I intend to use his reactions as a barometer by which I may gauge my own effectiveness and performance as member for Casey. The more frequently and vehemently he and other tattered members of his Party harangue me, the more effectively I will be doing my job. Having said this, perhaps he will reconsider his position and cease his attacks. However, let me assure him I will be endeavouring to provide him with plenty of ammunition, for I intend to continue to bring to the attention of my constituents the mismanagement, neglect and appalling performance of this socialist-inspired Labor Government.
Finally, Mr Deputy Speaker, Lord Alfred Milner once said:
If we believe a thing to be bad, and if we have a right to prevent it, it is our duty to try to prevent it and to damn the consequences.
I believe that any further imposition on our senior citizens would be bad. I have tried to prevent it; I stand by my actions and am certainly prepared to take any consequences.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
House adjourned at 12.18 a.m., (Friday) until 2 p.m. on Tuesday, 20 May 1986.
